HEADLINE: Too Many Foreigners

BYLINE: By Nicholas Lemann; Nicholas Lemann is a national correspondent for The Atlantic Monthly and the author of "The Promised Land: The Great Black Migration and How It Changed America."

 BODY:

ALIEN NATION
Common Sense About
America's Immigration Disaster.
By Peter Brimelow.
327 pp. New York:
Random House. $24. 
IMMIGRATION is one of those issues that split American conservatism in two. In the libertarian wing of the conservative mansion can be found the only people anywhere in our political debate who favor completely open borders -- like Robert L. Bartley, the editor of The Wall Street Journal, and the economist Julian L. Simon. But the most intense opposition to immigration is also located in the conservative movement, over in the cultural and populist areas, whence came much of the impetus for California's Proposition 187, denying most government services to illegal immigrants. Although there is an anti-immigration tradition within liberalism too, in the main liberals seem to have settled into a sentimental, optimistic, celebratory view of immigrants.
It is this view that Peter Brimelow aims to pick mercilessly apart in "Alien Nation," which is an expanded version of a 1992 cover story in National Review and a book-length articulation of an anti-immigration position that has been bubbling up in more obscure places for several years. Mr. Brimelow, a senior editor of Forbes and National Review, treats his fellow conservatives who support immigration, especially Mr. Simon, as admirable but sadly mistaken -- while he goes after the liberals with scornful glee.
One by one he sets up the liberal arguments and knocks 'em down. The United States was not originally conceived of as a nation of immigrants, or even as multiethnic: Mr. Brimelow reminds us that the Declaration of Independence contains a rarely quoted attack on "the merciless Indian Savages." Rather than having been continuous, large-scale immigration to the United States has come in concentrated bursts, which have been followed by long, relatively immigration-free adjustment periods. Rather than being fundamentally multiethnic, the United States was, as late as 1960, just short of being 90 percent white (though how Hispanic Americans were counted at that time seems to be ambiguous).
Today, immigration is at one of its historic highs: counting illegals, well over two million people a year come to the United States, and, compared with past immigrants, far fewer of them ever leave. Immigration accounts for 37 percent of our population growth. Instead of generating economic growth and tax revenues, immigrants, Mr. Brimelow says, are a net drain on the country, crowding public schools, welfare rolls, jails and hospitals. And by their mere presence they exacerbate ethnic tension.
Mr. Brimelow describes this situation in the direst language imaginable: "There is no precedent for a sovereign country undergoing such a rapid and radical transformation of its ethnic character in the entire history of the world," he writes. Possibly the result will be "the snuffing out of the American nation -- like a candle in a gale." If that doesn't happen, at the very least, during the next century "American patriots will be fighting to salvage as much as possible from the shipwreck of their great republic."
Buried within the apocalyptic rhetoric is a much more specific complaint, namely, that the 1965 immigration law (the Immigration and Nationality Act Amendments) led to a much higher level of immigration than its authors anticipated and needs to be corrected. In an uncharacteristically calm passage, Mr. Brimelow suggests that legal immigration be cut by about two-thirds.
Passed at the height of the civil rights era, the 1965 law was meant to undo the Quota Act of 1921 and the Immigration Act of 1924, which severely restricted immigration and also gave most of the slots to people from northern and western Europe. Much of contemporary conservatism revolves around the idea that some time in the 1960's the country took a disastrous wrong turn. Mr. Brimelow believes that the wrong turn was specifically the 1965 law, which he blames for ills ranging from the long-term slowdown of the economy to the creation of the urban underclass.
One could hold the position that the nondiscriminatory spirit of the 1965 law was laudable, but that its emphasis on admitting immigrants on the principle of family reunification as well as skills was misguided, and that the sheer number of people coming in now has moved beyond our capacity for absorption. Mr. Brimelow, however, takes an extra step. He wants to keep the immigration flow not just limited, and not just higher-skilled, but also mostly white. A waiting room of the Immigration and Naturalization Service reminds him of the New York subway: he finds each to be "an underworld that is not just teeming but also is almost entirely colored."
Most industrial nations are essentially monoethnic states that allow hardly any immigration at all. Mr. Brimelow admits that the United States has been more successfully multiethnic than any other country, but at bottom he just doesn't believe in the "American idea" that people here can transcend ethnicity through allegiance to abstract national principles like democracy and opportunity. What is required for the successful functioning of a nation, he insists, is "a link by blood."
Even "model minorities" that aren't white arouse Mr. Brimelow's suspicions. Reports of the success of Asian-Americans may be "just another immigration myth." Recently arrived Cubans "in fact participate heavily in welfare." West Indians? "It must be said that nowadays part of their enterprise goes into drug 'posses' and car-theft rings." Judging from a couple of asides, Mr. Brimelow doesn't consider Jews to meet his definition of "white" either; for example, he refers to the Clinton Administration as "a black-Hispanic-Jewish-minority white (Southerners used to call them 'scalawags') coalition." Elsewhere he points out that Jews played a major role in the passage of the hated 1965 immigration law. On the other hand, he calls it "a profound tragedy" that we don't relax our immigration restrictions to let in hundreds of thousands of eastern Europeans.
Mr. Brimelow is more an energetic pamphleteer than a reporter. He has done a good job of assembling printed material but, aside from one nocturnal visit to the Border Patrol station south of San Diego, he has not gone out in search of firsthand, irrefutable evidence that immigration actually is eating away at the very core of the country in the way he says it is. At one point he brings up a few pro-immigration arguments and then concludes, disarmingly, "I'm sure I'm right." The reason he's so sure is that it seems impossible to him that any society can remain strong for very long while allowing in large numbers of immigrants from a wide variety of ethnic groups.
When Mr. Brimelow tries to provide tangible details (as opposed to statistics) about the deteriorating fabric of life here caused by immigration, they often have an exaggerated or unproved feeling. He takes it as a given that immigrants no longer want to assimilate. In the near future, he says, Atlanta, Miami and San Antonio "will be communities as different from one another as any in the civilized world." Bilingual education is to him so obviously a program to keep people from learning English that he doesn't even bother to bring up and knock down the official rationale for it, which is that it encourages non-English speakers to stay in school while they learn the language. He views the creation of a secessionist Mexican-American state called Aztlan, a favorite cause of Southwestern student radicals in the 1960's, as a live possibility. Mr. Brimelow is right when he says that there is more risk from too much immigration than from too little, but he doesn't establish that the current situation justifies his level of alarm -- and the reason is that he finds the simple fact of substantial nonwhite immigration to be sufficiently alarming.
Several times in "Alien Nation" Mr. Brimelow mentions as one of the dangers of immigration that a significant percentage of immigrants will feel alienated from America -- the implication being that we ought not to let in too many people who are going to run down the country. This from a man who is himself an immigrant, from England, and who accuses "the American political elite" of "a species of treason"!
Mr. Brimelow's definition of "alienated" is political (it applies to complaints from the left but not the right) and his definition of "America" is racial. The amazing absence of euphemism and disingenuousness in his book helps make it clear why the immigration issue is so difficult: there is often a lot more in the opposition to immigration than straightforward policy-wonk concerns about whether we are letting in the right number of people.

HEADLINE: North Atlantic Fishing Pact Could Become World Model

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH 

DATELINE: TORONTO, April 16

 BODY:
In resolving their long-simmering confrontation over fishing rights in the North Atlantic this weekend, Canada and the European Union have reached an agreement that could serve as a model for preserving endangered fish stocks throughout the world.
The key to the accord, announced Saturday night in Ottawa and endorsed today in Brussels by European Union ambassadors, is enforcement. Independent monitors will be on every vessel fishing in disputed waters off Newfoundland to insure that conservation rules are followed. 
 The deal provides for verification of gear and catch records, steps up surveillance by satellite, sets minimum sizes to keep fish from being caught before they can reproduce and imposes stiff fines and other penalties for violations.
"Our objective was not to get a bigger slice of the pie," Fisheries Minister Brian Tobin of Canada told reporters. "Our objective was to insure that there would be pie, there would be resource for the future."
At issue was the survival of a fish known as turbot or Greenland halibut, one of the last species left in the Grand Banks fishing grounds after years of overfishing.
A three-year-old moratorium on cod fishing has left some 50,000 Canadian fishermen and fish plant workers unemployed, a crucial factor in Canada's unusual aggressiveness in the dispute.
The phenomenon has affected American fishermen as well. Last December the Commerce Department, for conservation reasons, ordered the closing of more than 6,000 square miles off the Massachusetts coast. Greenpeace International says 69 percent of the world's fish stocks are overfished or depleted.
For the first time in years, Canada, known for its role as an international peacekeeper, touched off a bilateral military confrontation.
"Obviously, Canadians are very reluctant to engage in conflict," said Robert Bothwell, professor of history at the University of Toronto. "But this was seen by most of the country as a crucial issue. And the saber-rattling certainly worked."
Spanish and Portuguese fishing boats were taking turbot beyond their internationally agreed quotas just outside Canada's 200-mile territorial waters. After repeated warnings, the Canadians seized a Spanish trawler, the Estai, on March 9, and cut the net of another Spanish boat, the Pescamaro Uno, on March 26.
Both actions in international waters touched off stiff protests from Spain and the 15-member European Union. But in Canada, opinion polls showed that the Government's toughness had the backing of 9 out of every 10 people interviewed. The conservation argument gave the exercise validity to many.
Government officials said today that the dispute was settled just as Fisheries Department vessels, backed by two armed navy vessels, were on their way to board and seize more Spanish trawlers. The Spanish boats were being protected by two armed Spanish Navy vessels.
The Northwest Atlantic Fisheries Organization, which like the European Union has 15 members, though not the same ones, was established 16 years ago to regulate the fisheries. But it lacks enforcement powers.
Putting inspectors on fishing boats and other provisions of the new agreement redresses that situation. Canada now may become the fisheries organization's chief enforcer.
The roots of the dispute were over the apportioning of shares of the organization's turbot quotas for this year. The European Union was upset that it had only received 12.5 percent of the 27,000-ton allotment, compared with nearly 60 percent for Canada. The Europeans unilaterally gave themselves 69 percent.
Under the agreement, Canada will get 10,000 of the 27,000 tons, or 37 percent. The other 6,000 tons of Canada's originally assigned catch goes to the European Union, which now has 10,000 tons. The remaining 7,000 tons goes to other members of the fisheries organization, including Russia and Japan.
But one Canadian concession allows the Europeans to haul in 5,000 tons in addition to what they have already caught this year, likely pushing them over the new 10,000-ton limit. Canada will also drop charges against the Spanish trawler Estai and refund a bond and bail money and the proceeds from the Estai's seized catch.
Fisheries Minister Tobin insisted that he was not declaring victory, but he was clearly happy with the new enforcement regime, which Canada had sought for months.
"It's a landmark agreement that will protect not only the Greenland halibut," he declared.
The settlement as well should improve the atmosphere for a broader agreement at the United Nations, which is drafting rules for so-called "straddling stocks" -- fish, like turbot and cod around Newfoundland, that swim inside and outside territorial waters.
A draft agreement reflecting what most observers said was progress in advancing international fisheries law was agreed to last week at the conclusion of the fifth round of the talks. Work on a final agreement is expected to begin at the United Nations on July 24.

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 6; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1700 words

HEADLINE: STRENGTH IS SEEN IN A U.S. EXPORT: LAW ENFORCEMENT

BYLINE: By DAVID JOHNSTON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16

 BODY:
American law enforcement agencies are rapidly expanding overseas, deploying agents to dozens of countries in scores of joint investigations. Next week, the Clinton Administration is planning to open an F.B.I. international police training academy in Budapest, one of the most ambitious projects in this effort.
American law enforcement is being exported in response to the surge of international terrorism, narcotics trafficking, links between terrorists and drug dealers, illegal immigrant smuggling, financial fraud, corruption, arms smuggling, money laundering and the potential theft and sale of nuclear material and chemically or biologically hazardous substances. 
 Global crime is not new, nor are instances of international police cooperation. But international crime is increasingly being redefined as a national security issue at a time when there are threats to the stability of governments in the former Eastern bloc, of civilian populations in Japan and of national economies in the Andean nations. As a result, Government officials say the Clinton Administration is redirecting the manpower and resources of law enforcement and related agencies to confront international crime as never before.
Under statutes that provide Federal law enforcement agencies with jurisdiction in crimes against American citizens overseas, United States agents are working on terrorism cases in the Gaza Strip, Pakistan and the Philippines. In countries like Mexico, the Federal authorities are planning broader joint counter narcotics operations.
The new efforts involve not only traditional crime-fighting bureaucracies like the F.B.I. and the Drug Enforcement Administration but also the State Department and Central Intelligence Agency. For the C.I.A. in particular, crime-fighting offers a way to try to justify its overseas networks and keep its budget intact in the post-cold-war world.
For the F.B.I., the initiatives represent a more direct expansion of its traditional activities. But while the new moves have generally found bipartisan support, some lawmakers have expressed skepticism about the emphasis on international issues, viewing it as a drain on domestic law enforcement. At a recent hearing, Senator Ernest F. Hollings, a Democrat from South Carolina and a member of the appropriations subcommittee responsible for the F.B.I.'s budget, criticized the deployment of agents overseas.
"This bothers me," Mr. Hollings told Louis J. Freeh, the F.B.I. Director, at a recent hearing. "I need more agents down here on 14th Street," he said, referring to a crime-ridden neighborhood in the District of Columbia.
Mr. Freeh, who as a Federal prosecutor in the 1980's helped break up a vast Sicilian Mafia heroin ring with close cooperation from the Italian authorities, is a principal advocate of overseas law enforcement. Last year, Mr. Freeh opened an F.B.I. office in Moscow, one of an overseas network of 24 such offices, forward command posts for an increasingly global detective agency. He has also been a driving force behind the Budapest training academy, an operation to be housed in a building complex donated by the Hungarians, financed with State Department and F.B.I funds to be approved by Congress and modeled on the F.B.I. training academy in Quantico, Va.
Mr. Freeh said the 37 recent cases in which the authorities discovered illicit shipments of radioactive material transiting former East bloc countries provided a powerful rationale for the Budapest school.
"There couldn't be a better reason to have a centrally located school where we can develop a network of police partners in countries where we do not have now those relationships," he said in an interview.
The new efforts go far beyond existing international arrangements like Interpol, a worldwide police alliance that some law enforcement officials regard as little more than a communications network for alerting other countries about fugitive cases.
In recent months, the United States has begun a law enforcement project with Mexico to expand joint investigations with the Drug Enforcement Administration and the F.B.I. to stanch the torrent of Colombian cocaine shipped through Mexico.
The project is focused on four of the largest Mexican drug transportation cartels, patterned after the Colombian organizations, which haul drug shipments across the border and which are suspected of using a portion of the millions of dollars in illegal profits to pay off police and justice officials in Mexico.
In February in Pakistan, the capture of Ramzi Ahmed Yousef, the suspected ringleader of the World Trade Center bombing, opened a window on an international manhunt that took F.B.I. agents to three countries. The trail that led to Mr. Yousef in Pakistan began in Manila, where F.B.I. agents investigated what the authorities said was Mr. Yousef's involvement in a plot to bomb American jetliners. That connection sent agents to Tokyo to examine a Philippine airliner that had been bombed en route to Japan in what law enforcement officials suspect was a dry run by Mr. Yousef and his confederates.
In the Gaza Strip, F.B.I. agents are examining the suicide car bombing last Sunday that killed seven Israelis and an American student. Other agents are examining the killings of two United States Consulate workers in Karachi in March, while others have been sent to Japan study the implications for the United States of the poison-gas attack on the Tokyo subway system, also in March.
Even the suspects on the F.B.I.'s list of "Ten Most Wanted Fugitives" is taking on a international cast. When it was first introduced in 1950, the list included car thieves, kidnappers and bank robbers. Last month, the F.B.I. added three new names to its roster, all foreigners: Juan Garcia Abrego, the chieftain of Mexican drug cartel, and Abdel Basset Ali Al-Megrahi and Lamen Kahlifa Fhimah, the two Libyan intelligence operatives wanted for the bombing of Pan Am flight 103 that killed a total of 270 people in 1988 as it flew over Lockerbie, Scotland.
An unofficial State Department survey completed this year found that eight American law enforcement agencies employ 1,649 people permanently assigned overseas. The Drug Enforcement Administration employs 499 agents in 50 countries, the United States Customs Service has 323 employees abroad and the F.B.I. has 121 employees overseas.
Secretary of State Warren Christopher, a former Deputy Attorney General, announced in January that law enforcement would be a top foreign policy priority for the State Department, and assigned it to Robert S. Gelbard, the assistant secretary for narcotics and law enforcement affairs.
The Pentagon has provided aircraft and sophisticated radar gear to track drug shipments from South America and more recently has provided linguists and intelligence analysts to support antinarcotics efforts. Mr. Freeh, the F.B.I. Director, said in Congressional testimony last month that a total of 460 military personnel worked on 135 drug investigations -- often helping the authorities translate intercepted communications.
As part of the fight against illegal drugs, the Central Intelligence Agency has also expanded its role from assembling information about drug trafficking to providing law enforcement officials with intelligence on worldwide organized-crime groups and their vulnerabilities.
"With the growth of international crime, neither crime nor corruption are local matters anymore," said Jonathan M. Winer, a deputy assistant secretary of state for narcotics and law enforcement affairs.
"The weaknesses of a small haven in the Caribbean or Central Europe wind up being exploited by criminal organizations which can move money, people and goods from one end of the planet to the other regardless of how any government may feel about it. To protect ourselves, we need to help other nations develop the structural capacity to deter their exploitation by criminals."
In the former Eastern bloc, organized-crime groups that evolved from black-marketing organizations in the Soviet system had a powerful advantage over the civilian authorities in emerging democracies. The repressive tactics that controlled political dissent were also used to deter crime, and when the old regimes collapsed, so did the structures used to control lawlessness.
In some cases, the civilian authorities have had no training in specific areas like complex financial crimes.
"First you have to explain to them what a credit card is and then what a bank account is," said one law-enforcement official involved in training programs. "Then you start talking about wire transfers and Ponzi schemes and people start looking at you like an idiot."
The F.B.I. school, the outgrowth of trip that Mr. Freeh and other officials took to Eastern Europe a year ago, is in a former police academy in a residential section of Budapest. Eight-week classes will be taught by agents from American law-enforcement agencies and other European countries. The school is intended to educate middle managers of police agencies in Eastern and Central Europe and the former Soviet republics in such areas as criminal detection, managerial techniques and the democratic application of laws.
Philip B. Heymann, the former Deputy Attorney General and State Department official who has worked on criminal justice projects in countries like South Africa and Guatemala, said that the overseas initiatives of American law-enforcement agencies were worthwhile, but that they also reflect an inevitable tendency among bureaucracies to expand their turf.
"Every domestic agency likes to have its own foreign policy," Mr. Heymann said. "It's the one situation where you do not have to actually make something work. All you have to do is teach and talk and deal."
He said advocates of the training academy should calibrate their hopes for the institution to the realities of the countries that will produce its students.
"What to American eyes appears to be lack of competence that can be solved with training is often really the problem that no one wants law enforcement to work," he said, suggesting that corruption may not be overcome by professional instruction.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

U.S. Wealth Inequality Seen As Widest in Rich Nations
 New studies about the concentration of American wealth and income are showing that the United States is the most economically stratified of industrial nations.
 Federal Reserve figures show that the wealthiest 1 percent of American households -- with a net worth of at least $2.3 million each -- owned nearly 40 percent of the nation's wealth in 1989 and that the top 20 percent of Americans -- households worth $180,000 or more -- owned more than 80 percent of the country's wealth. A1. 
 Affluent Americans' taxes surged 16 percent in 1993, the first year of revisions pressed into law by President Clinton. D4.
 
Brazil's Economy Surges, Attracting U.S. Investors
 American investors and exporters are stampeding into Brazil. Trade liberalization and currency reform have produced a high-demand, low-inflation economy that is drawing imports worth billions and encouraging foreign investment. D5.
 
Fishing Agreement Is Reached
 Canada and the European Union reached agreement on fishing rights in the North Atlantic, defusing a long dispute. The pact could serve as a world model for preserving endangered fish supplies. A2.
 
The Dollar Falls Anew
 The dollar fell sharply against the Japanese yen in Tokyo early today, as traders said they were disappointed by a weekend meeting between the U.S. Treasury Secretary and Japan's Finance Minister. A2.
 
Big Rise in Global Deals
 International mergers and acquisitions, joint ventures and minority investments rose nearly 40 percent in the first quarter, but there are signs that the recent increase in such activity may be peaking. D6.
 
End in Sight for Accountants
 While the coming of tax season is as reliable as death, getting through it without getting stressed seems impossible -- especially for accountants. This year, they dubbed it "the filing season from hell." B1.
 
A Computer in Your Mouth
 Adding computer technology to the dentist's X-ray machine, new systems are emerging that can provide sharp images of a patient's mouth while exposing patients to as little as 10 percent of the radiation they receive during film X-rays. The systems use a sensor that is placed in the mouth, where it reacts to the X-ray emission. D6.
 
A Business Model on the Web
 Even innovative publishers find that profits from "going on line" are very elusive. But glimmers of hope are emerging as the Internet and its navigators grow in popularity. Denise Caruso: Digital Commerce. D7.
 
3 Networks Are Happy
 ABC, NBC and Fox can all find some positive news in the end-of-season television ratings. Not so for CBS, which has toppled from the No. 1 position it held last season and lost ground in almost all categories. D8.
 
Few Worries About House & Garden
 The re-emergence of House & Garden magazine has aroused a great deal of curiosity but remarkably little concern among competitors in the already well-served area of home-decorating and design magazines. D8.
 
A Big Gulp of Milk And Advertising
 Some of the most prominent figures in the magazine industry have agreed to look somewhat silly in print, acting out their thanks to the milk industry for spending its entire advertising budget of $35 million in magazines. In return, the magazine executives are spending $500,000 for trade ads. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. D9.
 
Tepid Times for Tax Publisher
 CCH isn't able to celebrate tax season with the usual fervor. Instead, it is still engaged in an expensive restructuring program and absorbing heavy costs from the development of new products. Market Place. D2.

HEADLINE: U.S. Investors Stampede Into Brazil

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil

 BODY:
As clear as the telephone lights flashing furiously at the United States trade center switchboard here, American investors and exporters are stampeding into Brazil.
"Calls, faxes, visitors, requests -- it's doubled in six months," said Richard R. Ades, the harried director. "We had a brief drop with the Mexico crisis. Then it went right back up. In some areas, it's tripled." 
 In the last month, the Compaq Computer Corporation opened a new factory nearby capable of producing 400,000 personal computers a year, the Anheuser-Busch Companies started spending $105 million to build a brewery to market Budweiser beer to Brazilians, Caterpillar Inc. decided to move its Latin American headquarters to Sao Paulo, and the General Electric Company signed a contract to study constructing $9 billion worth of coal-fired power electricity plants in southern Brazil.
Suddenly, it is all coming together in Brazil. The trade liberalization that began several years ago, combined with July's currency reform, has produced a high-demand, low-inflation economy that is sucking in imports by the billions of dollars and encouraging an invasion of foreign investment. Even Mexico's financial collapse has had a positive ripple effect, turning foreign corporations toward Latin America's biggest economy, 155 million people.
"Everyone is coming in and positioning themselves," said John E. Mein, executive vice president of the American Chamber of Commerce here. Noting that Chamber membership had jumped 12 percent since January, he added: "It's not a matter of whether, but when and how."
And Brazil's new president, Fernando Henrique Cardoso, wants more to come. On a visit to New York on Tuesday and Wednesday in which he will address hundreds of American executives, he is expected to announce that Brazil seeks $72 billion in public and private investment to expand highways, telephone service and hydroelectric power generation through the end of the decade. And he will be able to point to his country's recent economic successes to counter its long-standing reputation for protectionism and hyper-inflation.
It isn't all smooth sailing, to be sure. Rattled by Mexico, speculative investors have pulled the plug on Sao Paulo's stock market, depressing its value by a half in four months.
Wall Street portfolio managers are angry about Brazil because stock pickers gambled wrong last fall, heavily buying stocks of Brazil's state telephone and electricity companies. Privatization of these companies, never promised by Mr. Cardoso, now seems to be far off.
The trade balance has been running a deficit for several months and economists predict that 1994's trade surplus of $10.5 billion will shrink to $3 billion this year. Inflation is creeping back. The national Social Security system is bankrupt, and corrupt politicians in Sao Paulo have left Banespa, the state development bank, $20 billion in the red.
On top of all that, congressional gridlock is complicating efforts to change Brazil's Constitution to allow foreign investment in oil, mining and telecommunications.
But none of that heavily dents the upbeat mood in business. It is looking at the good news -- and there is plenty of that, too. Investment by foreign companies is surging to a projected $3.5 billion this year from $1.5 billion last year. Brazil's overall investment rate is expected to jump to 17 percent of gross national product this year from 15 percent last year. With tax receipts running at double their levels of last year, Government officials argue that Brazil's budget is in balance.
In 1995, for the third year in a row, Brazil is expected to record an economic growth rate of 5 percent.
Most important, consumer demand remains high, while inflation remains low. While some analysts predict that the inflation rate will increase to 3 percent a month from the current 1.5 percent, that still remains a far cry from the 50 percent level reached in the month before July's currency reform.
American economists calculate that the tariff hikes will affect only 4 percent of American exports. This year the United States is expected to record a trade surplus with Brazil, the first since the late 1960's.
"I'm betting on a surplus in 1995," said Mr. Ades, director of the United States Commercial Center here. Reflecting confidence in Brazil's trade opening, the United States Commerce department is to double its Brazil presence by August, opening trade offices in Belo Horizonte, Porto Alegre and Recife.
Despite the recent tariff hikes, the Government is clearly bent on accelerating Brazil's economic liberalization. To spur private investment in hydro power, it recently canceled 34 dam concessions that had languished unused. And even though the Constitution has yet to be amended, the Government is opening telecommunications to joint venture partnerships with the AT&T Corporation and others.
Hoping to earn $4 billion this year by revitalizing a lagging privatization program, the Government plans to sell two power companies, a bank, the national railroad and minority holdings in 13 chemical and petrochemical companies.
The threat of inflation remains. Demand is running so high that 50 percent of Sao Paulo industries in a recent survey said their factories were running at 81 to 100 percent capacity, 21 percent said they planned to expand their factories or build new ones, and 70 percent said they planned to invest in new machinery.
By another measure -- thirst for soda and beer -- the economy is really humming. In the first three months of this year, Coca-Cola's sales in Brazil ran 70 percent higher than during the same period in 1994. To meet the demand, Coca-Cola has imported this year from the United States 144 million cans of Coca-Cola, all printed in Portuguese.
Judging by the swelling flood of American investors here, companies have decided that now is the time to enter Latin America's largest economy.
Wal-Mart Stores Inc. is planning to open its first Brazilian store in May, and J. C. Penney has announced plans to open stores, too. Dairy Queen is looking for a master franchiser and TGI Friday's, a unit of the Carlson Companies, plans to open its first restaurant in Brazil in September. This year in Sao Paulo alone, Arby's is opening six restaurants, KFC, a unit of Pepsico, 20 restaurants and McDonald's 45 restaurants.
And, as the AMR Corporation's American Airlines increases its destinations in Brazil, Ramada, Marriott and ITT Sheraton are scouting for tourist hotel locations along Brazil's northeast coast.

HEADLINE: The Talk Of Detroit;
Detroit's Anxiety Over Chrysler Appears on the Rise

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 16

 BODY:
The company's rules were very clear when Chrysler's chairman and Detroit's mayor met with reporters last week to discuss plans for a new engine factory here: not a peep about the stunning bid by Kirk Kerkorian and Lee A. Iacocca to buy the auto maker.
But the mayor, Dennis W. Archer, would have none of it. 
 "I'm not going to be constrained by the same ground rules," he growled, taking the microphone. "I support Chrysler Corporation as it is, and I think they're doing a slam-bang job!"
Workers and government officials who gathered for the announcement whistled, clapped and whooped at the Mayor's challenge to Mr. Kerkorian, which crystalized anxieties that Chrysler employees and others in Detroit feel about the proposed takeover. After Chrysler's two brushes with bankruptcy during the 1980's, many here and throughout the industry view the auto maker with a certain worried, tender and proprietary pride: as the little company that could, then couldn't, could, couldn't, and now, after reporting record profits last year, most emphatically does.
But with auto sales slowing in the United States, Mr. Kerkorian's move could put Chrysler at risk again, a danger well understood in the factory town that is southeast Michigan.
Ralph Wehby, who works in construction, turned to the stranger beside him at a breakfast counter here on Saturday morning and asked the question that he and his wife, Barbara, were debating: "So, do you think Kerkorian really wants to buy Chrysler?"
The Wehbys and their friends, they said, were against a takeover, partly because Mr. Kerkorian has no track record in manufacturing. "Most people resent what he's doing," Mr. Wehby said. "They think it's manipulative."
Within Detroit's city limits, the auto companies no longer provide the jobs they once did, and some people are indifferent if not hostile to Chrysler's fate. But the auto makers still undergird the region's economy and are entwined with its history, which explains why auto parts gleam in glass cases at Detroit Metropolitan Airport and why, Mr. Wehby said, residents follow the companies' doings with the intensity, and sometimes the anguish, of sports fans.
"Our car companies are our Yankees," he said.
Within Chrysler, Mr. Kerkorian's proposal has sent a tremor of uneasiness through blue- and white-collar ranks.
"I don't know what the man's thinking," said Jim Dichiera, as he arrived for the graveyard shift at Chrysler's Jeep Grand Cherokee plant here Thursday night. "Does he want to break the company up?"
Mr. Dichiera, who has worked for Chrysler for 30 years, said Mr. Iacocca's contributions while he was chairman were overrated. "Iacocca didn't do as much as people give him credit for," he said.
Mr. Iacocca's sterling image here already seems tarnished by his partnership with Mr. Kerkorian. Local television reports and newspapers stories have suggested that he is a hypocrite, recalling his contempt for corporate raiders during the 1980's. In an editorial cartoon, the Detroit Free Press portrayed Mr. Iacocca making peace signs with arms spread in a Nixonian pose as he declares, "I am not a raider."
But to others arriving for the late shift at the plant, on Detroit's east side, Mr. Iacocca's involvement was reassuring. "Iacocca's the one who put us back on the map, so you'd have to be satisfied with Iacocca involved in any transaction," said Charles Gaston, who helps to build Jeep Grand Cherokees. "I think it's a step in the right direction."
Many in the industry are speculating whether Mr. Iacocca, ever the restless visionary, has lent his name and committed his money to his old friend, Mr. Kerkorian, in hopes of pursuing a 20-year-old dream: topping General Motors by fusing Chrysler with foreign auto makers to create what he has often referred to as "Global Motors."
Within Chrysler's new glass-and-steel headquarters in Auburn Hills, north of here, executives hope Chrysler's board will fight the two men off. "It's such a bizarre thing that people aren't sure what to say, or even gossip about," said one executive, who asked not to be identified.
The company's top officers have appealed to underlings to put the battle out of their minds and focus on their jobs. Chrysler has said that the company is not for sale but that the board will evaluate any proposals.
So far, Mr. Kerkorian's associates have professed none of the traditional rationales for a takeover. The company is efficient, they say. They say Mr. Kerkorian is simply frustrated with Chrysler's low stock price. Auto stocks have fallen on fears that the economy is slowing.
That concern did not seem terribly noble to some observers. "Would an immediate enrichment of shareholders necessarily be in the company's best long-term interest?" The Free Press asked in an editorial.
On the television talk show "Back to Back," a local pundit, Chuck Moss, ridiculed the offer. "The question is whether or not the deal helps the management and the workers," he said. "I think it doesn't. I think it's terrible." He added that Chrysler "can become an economic cripple."
While the United Automobile Workers union has remained silent about the offer, the Canadian Auto Workers, whose members build many of Chrysler's most popular cars and mini-vans, reacted furiously.
"This move by speculators will not create jobs, it will not produce useful products, but it will risk diverting money out of Chrysler," Buzz Hargrove, the Canadian union's spirited president, said in a statement, adding that he was "mad as hell."
Executives at competing auto makers, flabbergasted by the possibile takeover, said one aspect of it clearly was not credible: Mr. Iacocca's repeated claim that he would serve only as a "consultant."
"The only thing that makes me laugh is Iacocca saying he would come in in an advisory role," said a top official at another Detroit auto maker, who would know.
"He never wanted to leave anyway," a Chrysler insider said testily, expressing a widely held opinion.
Mr. Iacocca did not return repeated telephone messages. But in an interview with USA Today that appeared on Friday, he denied being a corporate raider, repeated his desire to be only a consultant -- and took a swipe at Chrysler's current chairman and chief executive, Robert J. Eaton, for not improving the quality of Chrysler vehicles fast enough.
While repeatedly praising Chrysler's management, Alex Yemenidjian, an executive with Mr. Kerkorian's company, the Tracinda Corporation, suggested that Mr. Kerkorian and Mr. Iacocca would do things differently. "I think they're excellent," he said of the company, "and I think there's a level above that called fabulous." He said the new owners would explore "foreign strategic alliances," igniting speculation about Global Motors.
As Mr. Iacocca wrote in his best-selling, eponymous autobiography: "My dream was to put together a consortium of car companies in Europe, Japan, and the United States. Together, we'd create a major force that could challenge the dominance of General Motors." Of G. M., he wrote: "I envy their tremendous brute power."
And of being an adviser, he wrote: "I'm not the consultant type. I flourish where the action is."
While he was chairman, Mr. Iacacca sought to join Chrysler with Volkswagen, Fiat or Ford, and he bought the American Motors Corporation as well as a large stake in Mitsubishi Motors of Japan. Mr. Iacocca has denied wanting to resurrect Global Motors, but he has also declared Chrysler cannot compete without going global.
To buy the company, Mr. Kerkorian and Mr. Iacocca plan to keep their shares, and offer to buy all other stock for $55 a share. They are seeking $3 billion from other investors and $10 billion in borrowed money. And they intend to use $5.5 billion of Chrysler's own cash, which the chairman, Robert J. Eaton, has set aside to see the company through the next industry downturn.
Four credit rating agencies have said they may reduce Chrysler's debt rating, perhaps to junk bond level, if the deal goes through.
That possibility -- that excessive new debt could hobble the company -- clearly annoyed some Detroit residents. "You look at $10 billion in debt -- how long is it going to take to recoup that, even in good times?" said Eric Henley, an engineer who once worked for an auto parts supplier, as he paused on his bicycle near Chrysler's old headquarters in Highland Park, a tiny town surrounded by Detroit. Chrysler is leaving that cluster of buildings for its new offices in Auburn Hills.
"I just think it was an opportunity to push up the stock and make money for the principals," Mr. Henley said, adding that Chrysler is "a main constituent of the U.S. economy."
But the auto makers do not drive the Detroit economy as they once did; the health care industry is the city's largest private employer now. Even in announcing the new engine plant on Thursday, Mr. Eaton emphasized that it might not create jobs, since the company would shift workers there from other factories. "We're not making any promises whatsoever in that regard," he said.
As a result, some here are not too sentimental about Chrysler. "How many over here in Highland Park work for that company across the street?" asked Robert Jackson, gesturing at the headquarters. "Nobody. Maybe a janitor, but I doubt it."
Mr. Jackson, who said he was searching for work, added that he didn't care about the takeover attempt. "We're not going to get any money out of it," he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Mayor of Detroit, Dennis Archer, left, who said he supported the Chrysler Corporation "as it is," listened to Chrysler's chairman, Robert J. Eaton, who said on Thursday that the company was not for sale. (Agence France-Presse) (pg. D5)

HEADLINE: Patents;
Tokyo Court Ruling Could Set Off New Trade Rift with the United States Over Protection of Patents

BYLINE: By Teresa Riordan 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
UNITED STATES patent experts are lamenting a little-publicized ruling made last month by an appeals court in Tokyo, warning that it may spark a new trade tiff between the United States and Japan. If approved by Japan's highest court, the decision could have detrimental consequences for industries like pharmaceuticals, where patent protection makes a big difference in how much a company can charge for its products.
The Tokyo High Court, in its Jap-Auto Products Inc. v. BBS Inc. decision on March 23 departed drastically from long-standing patent customs in most countries, including the United States and Japan. Patent protection traditionally is limited by something known as a "first-sale doctrine." In simplified terms, the inventor of a widget has the right to a royalty the first time the widget is sold. But the patent-holder relinquishes rights to a given widget once the object has been sold to another party. If the new widget owner decides to re-sell the widget to yet a third party, for example, the inventor is not entitled to a second royalty. 
 But the first-sale doctrine has historically applied only to commerce within the borders of the country that granted the patent. This prevents competitors from buying patented products in a country where they are sold cheaply because of lower economic standards or because of price regulation and then reselling them in a country where a similar patent was issued but where the product fetches a higher price.
The Tokyo court's decision concerns BBS, a German company that holds patents on aluminum hubcaps in both Germany and Japan. The court ruled that two companies, the Jap-Auto Products Company and the Lacimex Japan Company, could legitimately import the patented aluminum hubcaps made in Germany, which were cheaper, and then sell them at a higher price in Japan without violating BBS's Japanese patent.
The ruling, if it is upheld, would be good news for Japanese consumers, who would likely pay less money for brand-name goods. The strong yen would give added incentive for competitors to circumvent Japanese patents by importing cheaply transported products that have been inexpensively produced under the aegis of a patent in another country. But the ruling would likely play havoc with marketing strategies of companies whose pricing schedules are highly dependent on patents.
United States Patents Commissioner Bruce A. Lehman, who this week will be in Japan as part of a Congressional delegation, declined to comment on the case, which he is still reviewing. But Richard Maulsby, director of public affairs at the Patent Office, said that "we feel at this point that it's a very bad decision and it's certainly going to be appealed."
Hirotsuna Yamashita, director of the Washington office the Institute of Intellectual Property, a quasi-governmental Japanese agency, met with United States officials last week to discuss the case. However, Mr. Yamashita did not respond to a request for a comment.
 
Cough Stimulator Aids Quadraplegics
 Quadraplegics, whose nerve connections between the spinal cord and the rest of their bodies are severed, lose the ability to use many of their muscles -- not just those in their limbs. Often, for example, they lose the ability to use their stomach muscles and, consequently, are unable to cough on their own.
"Traditionally, someone with quadriplegia has to summon a caretaker who presses on the stomach to force a cough," said Robert J. Jaeger, a professor of medical engineering at the Illinois Institute of Technology in Chicago. "Because they are unable to cough on their own, they are predisposed to respiratory complications, which are now the No. 1 cause of death among this population."
Mr. Jaeger and Dr. Elliot Roth, the medical director of the Rehabilitation Institute of Chicago, recently received their second patent on a "cough stimulator."
The device is the size of a personal cassette player and attaches to a belt around the wearer's waist. "But instead of wires coming out and going to your head phones, they connect to electrodes that attach to your stomach," Mr. Jaeger said.
When the wearer hits a switch, the electrodes, which are attached to the skin with an adhesive polymer, deliver electrical impulses, which stimulate the nerves and cause the stomach muscles to contract.
He and Dr. Roth, who are currently seeking approval for the device from the Food and Drug Administration, received patent 5,397,337.
 
Chiropractor's Idea: Pregnancy Cushion
 Peter J. Satto, a chiropractor in Baiting Hollow, N.Y., makes house calls. He said he got the idea for his "prone pregnancy cushions" when a patient got pregnant.
Patients who need the middle of their spines manipulated must lie on their stomachs, and chiropractic tables have adjustable midsections to accommodate pregnant women and others of large girth.
"But that table weighs something like a thousand pounds, and I needed something portable to take on house calls," Dr. Satto said. So he created a foot-thick foam cushion with removable sections that can be adjusted to accommodate most any belly.
"My patient said, 'Wow, this is really comfortable, could you leave this here so I can sleep on it?' " according to Dr. Satto. He recently patented the cushion and plans to market it to pregnant women.
Dr. Satto received patent 5,400,449.

HEADLINE: Global Business Activities Rose 40% in First Quarter

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
International mergers and acquisitions, joint ventures and minority investments rose nearly 40 percent in the first quarter, but there are signs that the recent increase in such activity may be peaking.
The weaker dollar and continued industry consolidation in the United States have particularly driven this trend, according to a survey of international transaction activity to be released today by the accounting firm KPMG Peat Marwick. 
 For the first time in several quarters, the United States slipped from its usual place as the No. 1 home for acquiring companies, because of stronger economic growth in Europe and the weakness of the dollar. Britain, whose marketing and food giants Grand Metropolitan and Cadbury Schweppes were aggressive acquirers, was the base for the most active companies in cross-border transactions during the first quarter, the new survey said.
In total, cross-border acquisitions, joint ventures and minority investments increased 39 percent, to $42.6 billion, in the first quarter from the first quarter of 1994, the survey said. Companies that make industrial machinery and equipment accounted for the most transactions: a total of 174 in the first quarter, while food companies accounted for the largest dollar volume of transactions.
Excluding joint ventures and minority investments, the volume of cross-border mergers and acquisitions rose a sharp 91 percent, to $27.7 billion, in the first three months of this year from $14.5 billion in the first quarter of 1994. The survey included all transactions in which the purchasing or investing company and the acquired company were based in different countries.
But the authors of the survey say the acquisition binge is coming to a head. "We may be entering into an advanced stage of the mergers and acquisitions wave," said Steve Blum, a partner with KPMG, "especially if the recent $23 billion bid for Chrysler is any indication."
Larger international mergers and acquisitions have been growing recently, the survey showed. There were nine cross-border acquisitions valued at more than $1 billion in the first quarter, up from six in the first three months of 1994.
The United States has been following the global trend. The volume of mergers and acquisitions in the United States totaled $73.25 billion in the first three months of the year, according to a survey released at the end of the first quarter by the Securities Data Company, a research consultant.
In the United States, the drug industry saw the most takeover activity, with volume for the first quarter exceeding $8 billion. Commercial banking and the food industry ranked the next-most-active sectors in the United States, Securities Data said.

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
$1 Million Question: What's in a Number?

BYLINE: By HARVEY ARATON 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
THE zip codes may have to be changed, and the area codes, too. Maybe the public school designations, all to the number no one here can get enough of. That is number 45. The holiest number of them all, now that 23 has been left retired, now that the Bulls have reestablished themselves as contenders and resumed tormenting the hated Knicks, whom they drubbed 111-90 yesterday at the United Center.
Number 45's are everywhere in this Michael Jordan-crazed city, on jerseys, T-shirts, caps, placards, walls. Number 45 displays dominate downtown storefront windows. "And at guard, from North Carolina, number 45 . . ." And the fans erupt as if they've been promised a free Lexus for retaining their stub. 
 "The 45 jersey is what everyone wants," said Maribeth Tinnes, the manager and buyer for Sports & Novelty on Michigan Avenue. "The demand is unbelievable."
Meanwhile, my poor 5-year-old at home still has No. 23 stitched onto his jersey, front and back. There has been no rush to the mall, no unconditional surrender to that marketing autocracy, the Republic of Jordan. We are holdouts, a traditionalist, skeptical and 45-less household.
So far, so good. My son hasn't asked for "the 45," though I did notice a look of deflation when his 14-year-old cousin showed up with "the 45" on the night of their recent pilgrimage to Madison Square Garden to witness Jordan's now-legendary "55."
That, I must admit, ticked me off. I don't care who's reaping the profits, Jordan, the National Basketball Association or its licensing partners. This jersey madness amounts to consumer exploitation.
Only months ago did we actually purchase "the 23," which I considered quite the tribute to Jordan's marketing longevity and appeal. More than a year after Jordan's retirement-turned-sabbatical, here was a pre-kindergarten student of the game still dividing his video time between "Lion King" and "Threepeat," highlighting the Bulls' last championship run.
If we have seen poor Charles Smith get his shot blocked four times, we have seen it 400 times. And there hasn't been one time when father and son haven't beamed as "Threepeat" concluded with Jordan asking one of his children over the phone from Phoenix, "Who hit the winning shot?" Pause. "John Paxson?" Laugh. "O.K., let me speak to mama."
That came across as genuine, sweet. I'm not so sure about Jordan's explanation for changing his number from the one hanging from the United Center rafters to the one he wore while waving at curveballs last summer in Birmingham, Ala.
"I think he was sincere when he said it was because he wanted his father to have seen him play his last game in 23," said Tinnes. "But let's face it, from the money aspect, for the retailer, this is great. We kiss the ground he walks on."
Here's why: Champion, the company which produces all N.B.A. jerseys, can't make them fast enough. Tinnes gets calls from desperate out-of-state retailers. She has hundreds of orders on computer, while waiting for a new shipment of 50 dozen.
"They won't even make it to the rack," she said.
This is in no way intended to question the pain Jordan has endured since the horrendous crime that took James Jordan's life in August 1993. But the bottom line for basketball's one-man cottage industry always seems to be the bottom line, like when he draped an oversized American flag over his shoulder at the Barcelona Olympics to cover the logo of a rival sportswear company.
With Jordan, the corporate spin can make you dizzy. Back in early November, more than 20,000 Chicagoans paid good money for a tacky retirement party for Jordan, who, according to Bulls Coach Phil Jackson, was already hinting at a possible springtime return. And while the Bulls' owner, Jerry Reinsdorf, was ridiculing news media reports of the comeback, where was Jordan? Shooting a fresh batch of "I'm Back" commercial spots, of course.
When Jordan finally played, he said he hoped to promote the game better than the gimme-gimme Generation Xers had in his absence. His first message to the kids who, like Maribeth Tinnes, kiss the ground he walks on? Forget Derrick Coleman and Chris Webber, too. Be Like Mike. Make the switch to 45, as soon as the merchandise hits the stores.
"Actually, the day Michael announced he was coming back, the 23's flew off the racks," said Tinnes. "People still wanted them because they don't think Michael will be able to duplicate what he did wearing the 45."
That's what I'd tell any kid, including my own. I'd say that while number 45 is just getting his career off the ground, 23 was the greatest basketball player of all time. Wear it proudly and economically.

HEADLINE: INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY: Where the Chips May Fall Next;
As U.S. Manufacturers Enjoy The PC Boom, Asia Plans For the Next Big Market

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

 BODY:
American chip makers have never been cockier -- and that could make a downfall all the harder.
Since reclaiming the lead in the global semiconductor market two years ago from Japan, the United States chip industry has been on a roll, led by the Intel Corporation, whose stock has surged lately on expectations of an exceptionally strong earnings report this week. 
 American chip makers now control 43 percent of the $102 billion global market, compared with 40 percent for the Japanese. Part of the comeback is the result of United States trade pressure in the late 1980's and early 1990's.
But a lot of it stems from a strategic shift: Realizing that it didn't pay to compete with Japan on price alone for products like memory chips, American companies have learned to focus on designing chips with greater complexity and higher prices.
As a result, from small Silicon Valley boutiques like C-Cube Microsystems Inc. to giants like Intel -- which in 1992 surpassed NEC of Japan to become the world's largest chip maker -- American companies are now the acknowledged global leaders in the "logic" chips that give intelligence to everything from automobile antilock braking systems to powerful desktop computers.
"We can take the Japanese on head-to-head today and that's where the cockiness is coming from," said T. J. Rodgers, chairman of the Cypress Semiconductor Corporation in San Jose, Calif.
But even as Silicon Valley celebrates winning the last battle, a new fight is looming for which American chip makers may find themselves ill prepared.
To begin with, the enemy is no longer Japan alone. From South Korea to Taiwan to Singapore to Hong Kong, rivals have used cheap labor and government subsidies to turn out large volumes of low-priced chips. From less than 4 percent of the world chip market five years ago, the non-Japanese Asian producers are now closing in on a 10 percent market share, according to the research house Dataquest Inc. The region's chip revenue -- $10.1 billion in 1994 -- is growing at an annual rate of more than 60 percent.
What's more, these emerging powers are no longer content simply to crank out commodity memory chips that sell for as low as $20 each. Some are now gearing up to compete with American industry in logic chips, which can command prices of several hundred dollars. Rather than compete with Intel's Pentium or Motorola's Power PC chips for the personal computer market, the Asian companies are looking beyond PC's to the next generations of computerized devices that, within a few years, could outpace sales of personal computers.
Last week, for example, Hyundai, the South Korean industrial giant that is also that country's second-largest chip maker, announced plans for a new production line in its billion dollar semiconductor factory in Seoul to produce a new type of digital video chip called an MPEG decoder. MPEG stands for Motion Picture Experts Group, the international organization that sets the standard on which such chips are based.
The MPEG chip is a key component for the emerging generation of television set-top converter boxes, video-game players and digital video-disk machines. But the tiny American leader in this emerging market, C-Cube, of Milpitas, Calif., is simply a designer and does not even have its own factories.
No wonder many experts and even some American chip makers fear that the American industry may be setting itself up for its second great fall.
"I find it a little scary," said John Moussouris, founder of Microunity Systems Engineering Inc., a tiny new Silicon Valley company that is setting up a small factory there to produce its own digital-video chips. "It's a premature reversing of the tide of the battle."
 
Too Many Eggs In a Few Baskets?
 On the surface, there are few signs of trouble yet. Last October in San Jose, several thousand executives gathered for the annual dinner of the Semiconductor Industry Association, the American industry's chief trade group. At the same gathering only four years earlier, Intel's chairman, Andrew S. Grove, had warned that the United States was in danger of becoming a "technocolony," subservient to Japanese competitors that were building higher quality and cheaper microchips. This time, it was all toasts and backslapping.
"We were inhaling a little of our own smoke," concedes Fred Hoar, a longtime Silicon Valley publicist who was the master of ceremonies for the evening. Considering the steep downturn of the entire Japanese economy since 1990, and the steep rise in the yen, some of the market forces now working in the Americans' favor have little to do with their own prowess.
Moreover, American strength may rely too much on a few sturdy pillars. More than one-fifth of the United States' market share, for example, is held by a single company, Intel, which led the world last year with sales of $10.1 billion. And much of Intel's success in recent years can be traced to two factors that may or may not be sustainable: the explosive growth of the personal computer market the last few years, and the dominance of the Microsoft Corporation's Windows software for PC's. Windows requires a chip made by Intel or one of Intel's clone-making imitators -- all of which happen to be American companies, like Advanced Micro Devices, Cyrix and Nexgen.
"One is never beyond danger in business," said Mr. Grove of Intel, which is based in Santa Clara, Calif. "A variety of bad news could come our way."
But Mr. Grove doesn't expect the bad news to entail a mass consumer defection from PC's.
Intel has ignored such potential emerging markets as video games and set-top boxes, betting heavily that consumers will continue to flock to new, improved versions of personal computers running Microsoft software. The company, for example, is now building a $1.3 billion plant in Chandler, Ariz., that it expects to start cranking out PC chips in 1997.
No one is predicting that the Intel-Microsoft axis will crumble anytime soon -- not when Microsoft is reporting record quarterly earnings, as it did last week. Still, many analysts do see much of chip-making's growth occurring elsewhere.
"In the next five years the center of gravity in the semiconductor industry will shift from Japan to Korea," said Keith Lobo, a longtime industry executive who is now president of Quickturn Design Systems Inc. of Mountain View, Calif., a maker of equipment used by chip designers. "And in the next 10 years it will probably shift from Korea to China."
 
Samsung Expanding Logic Chip Front
 Already, the Korean industry is making its mark, as Mr. Rodgers's $406 million-a-year company, Cypress Semiconductor, knows all too well. Cypress Semiconductor makes a type of specialized memory chip called a static RAM -- for random access memory -- that is used for the short-term information storage required by the fastest work stations and personal computers.
Today, Mr. Rodgers's dominant competitor is Samsung, a South Korean superpower that is the world's seventh-largest chip company and one of the fastest-growing. While most of the other world's top 10 chip makers had annual revenue growth of 20 to 30 percent, Samsung's revenue increased 61 percent, reaching $5 billion.
And Samsung is not satisfied simply to dominate the market for fast-memory chips. With low labor costs and easy access to capital at low interest rates subsized by the South Korean Government, Samsung, like its compatriot Hyundai, is racing to transform itself from a maker of commodity chips to a force in the logic-chip market. The same forces and ambitions are starting to propel other Asian chip makers, including the Taiwan Semiconductor Corporation and Chartered Semiconductor of Singapore.
For Samsung, the secret to winning the next round of chip wars is to concentrate on building logic chips for "smart" consumer products -- cellular phones, digital VCR's, personal digital assistants like Apple Computer's Newton Message Pad or even programmable microwave ovens.
"I don't need the Intel microprocessor to go into a speciality consumer market," said Keith MacDonald, senior vice president for sales and marketing for Samsung's American branch in San Jose. "The winner of the next generation is going to be consumer products that we don't even know we need today."
Already, logic chips represent 25 percent of Samsung's business, and the company expects them to reach 30 percent by 1996.
 
Manufacturers Out, But Designers Are In
 Changes in the structure of Silicon Valley itself in the last decade may also contribute to the vulnerabilty of the United States semiconductor industry. Even as most chip making has moved out of the Valley, the region has increasingly become the world's leading semiconductor design center. But the designing is not restricted to American companies. Most Asian chip companies -- including Samsung, NEC and Hitachi -- operate design studios in the Valley to tap its rich talent pool.
And there is a trend among overseas chip companies to send their most promising technologists to Silicon Valley for training, then bring them back home to develop a domestic chip-design industry. Last year, for example, one in three degree candidates in Stanford University's graduate school of engineering were foreign students.
But with profits so high, few in the Valley seem ready to acknowledge that a new semiconductor battle may lie ahead. And certainly no one is lobbying for the Government trade-policy weapons that the American industry insisted were so necessary in the last chip war.
"I just scratch my head," said one former Government trade official, who helped fight the semiconductor fight against the Japanese. The official, who spoke on the condition that he not be identified, admitted a certain bitterness over what he considers the short memory and short-sightedness of the American chip industry today.
"I look at these guys in their gold chains and their Bentleys," he said, "and I wonder what I was fighting for."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Asians Agree On Disclosure To Halt Crises

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: SANUR, Indonesia, April 16

 BODY:
Asia's finance ministers gingerly approached the question today of how to keep a Mexican-style crisis from happening in their own hemisphere, agreeing to disclose far more information to investors and cautioning against growing addicted to the kind of monetary policy that sent Mexico to the brink of insolvency.
American officials had expected to spend much of the day discussing the dollar's sharp decline against the Japanese yen and its effect on Asia. But at their meeting here, finance ministers from 18 Pacific Rim countries steered clear of a detailed discussion of the problem, leaving it to the United States and Japanese to sort out between themselves. 
 Instead, Mexico was clearly the subtext of much discussion at the all-day meeting, and the Asian ministers alternately sought to understand Mexico's mistakes and to convince themselves that similar problems were unlikely in their very different business cultures.
But in a communique at the end of the day, they committed themselves to taking steps to increase investor confidence in some of the world's most promising emerging markets. Their hope is that the steps could forestall the kind of instant loss of investor confidence, and the torrent of money escaping the country, that brought Mexico to its knees in December.
Just hours after the meeting concluded here on the resort island of Bali, Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said that the United States would release an additional $3 billion in medium-term loans, called "swaps" because they involve the swapping of currencies, to help Mexico pay off many high-interest, short-term bonds that it issued last year in a vain effort to keep the country solvent.
The announcement was expected, and means that the Clinton Administration will have delivered approximately $8 billion of the $20 billion that it had committed to the Mexican bailout plan.
Mr. Rubin said that he saw reason to hope that the markets in Mexico were stabilizing and that the country was beginning to get back on its feet. "There are early signs that Mexico's policies and our support are beginning to have the desired effect," he said in a statement.
But Mexican officials say that it is still too early to tell whether the $20 billion package, along with commitments of another $30 billion in long and short-term aid from the International Monetary Fund and other nations, will prove enough to end the crisis. That depends on the speed with which international investors return to the Mexican market.
"It will probably be July before we can tell for sure which way things will go," one senior Mexican official said recently.
The meeting here of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation forum, a group known as APEC that includes most Asian countries and Mexico, the United States and Canada, posed some difficult hurdles for Mr. Rubin.
The fall of the dollar against the yen has left many Asian countries wondering if American influence in the region will wane despite President Clinton's moves to shape APEC into a more powerful regional body. Surprisingly, though, there was little discussion of the dollar at the closed-door meetings today.
"I think there was a sense that this was for the U.S. and the Japanese to work out, and people were being polite in public," a participant said.
Moreover, some Asian countries have seen Mexico as a cautionary tale that free trade, deregulation and economic reform can move too fast, and the result can be a loss of economic control. Their preferred model is Japan, which in the last 40 years has used control over foreign investment as a key element of its effort to protect fledgling industries.
Mr. Rubin acknowledged the tradeoff in his comments to the group today, saying "there is an inherent tension between the reform process and the growth it engenders, on the one hand, and the risk of economic and financial instability on the other."
In their joint declaration, the finance ministers said they would attempt to steer clear of reliance on short-term investments that, as Mexico showed, can leave the country as quickly as they enter. Instead, they said they would seek "flows that generate real economic returns and hense are less susceptible to sudden reversal."
That chiefly means direct investment in factories and other facilities that are difficult to uproot if investors get nervous. Indonesia, China and several other large Asian nations have been focused on direct investment for years, and thus are considered less susceptible to what Mr. Rubin called a Mexico "contagion."
But like Mexico before the crisis, some Asian nations disclose relatively little reliable economic data that would warn investors of impending trouble. Under its agreement with Washington, Mexico is now making detailed weekly reports on a variety of economic data.
On the dollar, Mr. Rubin and his aides were cautiously optimistic after their meeting with Japan's finance minister, Masayoshi Takemura, that Tokyo was becoming convinced that the strength of the yen was a bigger problem than the weaknesss of the dollar; in fact, the dollar has stayed stable against most other currencies.
Early on Sunday, Mr. Takemura surprised Mr. Rubin by agreeing that a plan Japan proposed on Friday was too nonspecific and had failed to impress the markets. He promised more specific announcements in the next two months to convince the financial markets that Japan is serious about encouraging imports, a move that in theory should help weaken the yen.
