HEADLINE: 25th Earth Day to Have a Political Accent

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 16

 BODY:
The environmental movement's most concerted campaign in a generation is about to get under way as environmental groups around the country work to use the 25th anniversary of Earth Day to rally opposition to a reversal of environmental legislation.
Trying to influence lawmakers of both parties as they meet with constituents during the Congressional recess, the groups are reviving all the usual organizing tools of a movement that came of age in 1970. They are also using new lobbying tactics that evolved after the first Earth Day, when millions of people took to the streets and helped persuade Congress to pass dozens of environmental laws in the ensuing decades. 
 With the Republicans who control Congress now trying to make fundamental changes in those laws to reduce regulatory costs, leaders of large environmental groups said they had two goals for the Earth Day celebrations on the weekend of April 22: to spread the word about Congressional plans to as wide an audience as possible, and to persuade lawmakers that mainstream public opinion does not support the environmental course Congress has taken.
It is an attempt fraught with political danger. If the public does not respond or if Congress senses greater strength among those who want the regulations changed, the environmental movement risks being relegated to the fringes of the debate just as legislation to roll back regulations comes before the Senate. That is where environmental groups believe they have the best chance of stopping provisions already passed by the House.
"This ultimately comes down to a battle for the center," said Geoffrey Garin, a pollster at Peter D. Hart Research Associates who helped design the environmentalists' campaign.
The Republican leadership, especially in the House, argues that last November's elections showed a shift away from what they call extremist environmental policies, and some Republicans are even using Earth Day as a forum for their agenda.
Senator Slade Gorton of Washington, for example, who is proposing major revisions to the Endangered Species Act and who successfully sponsored a bill to suspend existing environmental laws to increase logging on Federal land, has scheduled what he calls a "timber family hearing" in Olympia, Wash., the state capital, on April 22 to present a side of the debate that he says has been "largely unreported and untold."
But environmental groups say that most did not vote for a Republican Congress to turn back environmental regulations and do not recognize the extent of the environmental changes now moving through Congress.
More significant, they say, polling and focus groups suggest that the views of environmentalists are basically shared by mainstream voters, including independents. And, they say, voters become angry when they are told that corporate interest groups are lobbying for changes to environmental laws that would provide financial benefits to businesses.
Members of Congress, at home until after Earth Day, will be sure to notice the rallies and concerts, campus seminars, petition drives, letter-writing campaigns, phone calls and faxes and other lobbying efforts.
In keeping with the times, the advocates are also planning to make calls to radio commentary shows and send a blizzard of E-mail on the Internet and the major commercial on-line services.
Diane MacEachern, the president of Vanguard Communications, a public relations company that works on environmental causes, said that by putting a prototype "letter from home" on the on-line services and the World Wide Web, she hoped to mobilize new participants in the environmentalists' efforts.
"The language of the letter to Congress is not raise-your-fist language," she said. "It should resonate with people who may feel somewhat alienated from a more demonstrative environmental movement, but who still feel that clean air and water are important to them and their communities."
Several addresses, known as home pages, on the Intenet's World Wide Web carry information about the campaign. An example is the electronic address http://www.econet.apc.org:80/earthday/.
Compuserve, America Online, Prodigy and E-World are also carrying information about the campaign.
In some states there will also be television advertising, on a million-dollar scale that is modest by national standards but larger than environmental groups usually muster.
In an unusual concerted effort, environmental groups with millions of members have combined their mailing lists and their messages. Depending on their tax-exempt status, which can limit partisan political activities, some groups are focusing on broad educational themes while others are directly trying to influence Congress.
Rather than focusing on specific issues like wetlands or endangered species, their message is a broad one: Do not retreat from the commitment to environmental protection.
"We now have over 30 of the major national groups all galvanized to make Earth Day not only a celebration of 25 years of achievement, but also a statement that the surreptitious rollback going on in Congress cannot be allowed to succeed," said Fred Krupp, head of the Environmental Defense Fund and chairman of Earth Day activities for a committee of executives of large national organizations loosely known as the Green Group.
"You will see an outpouring before Earth Day, on Earth Day and after Earth Day that will affect the outcome in the Senate," he added. "It won't affect every senator, but it will affect the outcome."
The environmental groups are most immediately worried about risk-assessment legislation in the Senate that would subject major regulations to procedural barriers and cost-benefit analysis, giving industries new opportunities to challenge rules protecting public health, safety and the environment.
Opponents say that a strict version favored by industry groups, a measure that passed the House and is sponsored by Senator Bob Dole of Kansas, the majority leader, would effectively undermine 25 years of environmental laws.
Brent Bahler, a spokesman for a pro-business group called Citizens for a Sound Economy, said the group was aware of the environmentalists' lobbying and would also be campaigning during the recess in support of the legislation. Radio advertisements to be broadcast in Washington beginning on Monday, he said, will emphasize that "the debate is not about dismantling regulations that protect the environment, but that the bills are formulated with balance in mind."
Environmentalists are focusing much of their advertising and lobbying campaign on states like Maine, with two moderate Republican Senators, and Nebraska, with two centrist Democrats -- states that also have the advantage of cheap television advertising and smaller populations.
Earth Day activities from coast to coast, including a concert and rally on the National Mall in Washington and demonstrations in many large cities, will urge voters to call members of Congress. There are thousands of smaller events planned for Earth Day; the Audubon Society alone has hundreds of chapters planning local events.
The strategy of the environmental groups was worked out in months of meetings and public opinion research after last November's elections. Before then, the groups were riven by dissent over the direction of the Earth Day anniversary, which would have been partly underwritten by corporations.
The corporate forces that have been lobbying for changes in environmental laws are now mainly viewed as a target, not a partner, of the environmentalists on Earth Day.
The anti-corporate theme is reflected in a petition being circulated by all the environmental groups that, along with calls to prevent pollution and to preserve wilderness areas, urges Congress to "end the giveaway of public assets," including subsidies for mining, logging and oil exploration, and to "get the big money out of politics" by enacting changes in campaign finance laws.

HEADLINE: Dollar Falls Sharply in Japan

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Monday, April 17

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply against the Japanese yen in Tokyo today, and traders attributed the selloff to market disappointment during the weekend meeting of Japan's Finance Minister, Masayoshi Takemura, and Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin.
The dollar slid as low as 81.74 yen and then recovered somewhat after the Bank of Japan intervened to buy dollars for yen. By late morning the dollar was quoted at 82.07 yen, down from 83.30 late Friday in New York. 
 Meanwhile, Japanese stocks recovered from early selling set off by the plunge of the dollar. The Nikkei index of 225 issues closed up 256 points, or 1.6 percent, at 16,304.15.
Mr. Takemura and Mr. Rubin met in Indonesia early Sunday on the fringes of a conference of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum's finance ministers.
 The United States and Japan jointly voiced concern about the steep decline of the dollar. But they did not announce fresh, strong action to rein in the surge of the yen against the dollar. On Friday the Bank of Japan cut its discount rate by three-quarters of a percentage point, to a record 1 percent, but the financial markets were mostly unimpressed.
 The rate cut was aimed at supporting a new economic package that the Japanese hoped would reduce the nation's huge trade surplus by stimulating the economy.
But the package failed to include targets for cutting the surplus or raising imports.

HEADLINE: NEW JERSEY DAILY BRIEFING;
Dover Would Lower Sales Tax

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: DOVER

 BODY:
Some municipalities want to raise taxes. Not Dover. It wants to cut its 6 percent sales tax in half. "We have asked the state to declare us an urban enterprise zone and let our retailers charge only 3 percent tax," said Mayor Stephen Shukailo. "We would attract more customers. And instead of sending the sales tax we collect to the state, we would spend it to upgrade the exteriors of our businesses."
Mr. Shukailo said Dover suffers from an image problem. The town's per capita income is the lowest in Morris County, and its unemployment rate is 10.4 percent. DAVID STOUT

SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: Gap in Wealth In U.S. Called Widest in West

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 12

 BODY:
New studies on the growing concentration of American wealth and income challenge a cherished part of the country's self-image: They show that rather than being an egalitarian society, the United States has become the most economically stratified of industrial nations.
Even traditional class societies like Britain, which have inherited large differences in income and wealth over centuries, going back to feudal times, now have greater economic equality than the United States, according to the latest economic and statistical research, much of which is to be published soon. 
 Economic inequality has been rising in the United States since the 1970's. Since 1992, when Bill Clinton charged that Republican tax cuts in the 1980's had broadened the gap between the rich and the middle class, it has become more sharply focused as a political issue.
Many of the new studies are based on the data available then, but provide new analyses that coincide with a vigorous debate in Congress over provisions in the Republican Contract With America.
Indeed, the drive by Republicans to reduce Federal welfare programs and cut taxes is expected, at least in the short term, to widen disparities between rich and poor.
Federal Reserve figures from 1989, the most recent available, show that the richest 1 percent of American households -- with net worth of at least $2.3 million each -- have nearly 40 percent of the nation's wealth. By contrast, the richest 1 percent of the British population has about 18 percent of the wealth there -- down from 59 percent in the early 1920's.
Further down the scale, the top 20 percent of Americans -- households worth $180,000 or more -- have more than 80 percent of the country's wealth, a figure higher than in other industrial nations.
Income statistics are similarly skewed. At the bottom end of the scale, the lowest-earning 20 percent of Americans earn only 5.7 percent of all the after-tax income paid to individuals in the United States each year. In Finland, a nation with an exceptionally even distribution of income, the lowest-earning 20 percent receive 10.8 percent of such income.
The top 20 percent of American households in terms of annual income -- $55,000 or more -- have 55 percent of all after-tax income.
"We are the most unequal industrialized country in terms of income and wealth," said Edward N. Wolff, an economics professor at New York University, "and we're growing more unequal faster than the other industrialized countries." In coming months, he will publish two papers that compare patterns of wealth in Western countries.
Liberal social scientists worry about poor people's shrinking share of the nation's resources, and the consequences in terms of economic performance and social tension.
Margaret Weir, a senior fellow in government studies at the Brookings Institution, called the higher concentration of incomes and wealth "quite divisive," especially in a country where the political system requires so much campaign money.
"It tilts the political system toward those who have more resources," she said, adding that financial extremes also undermined the "sense of community and commonality of purpose."
Robert Greenstein, executive director of the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, a Washington research group, observed, "When you have a child poverty rate that is four times the average of Western European countries that are our principal industrial competitors, and when those children are a significant part of our future work force, you have to worry about the competitive effects as well as the social-fabric effects."
Conservatives have tended to pay less attention to rising inequality, and some express skepticism about the statistics or their significance. Marvin H. Kosters, an economist at the American Enterprise Institute here, said he thought the gap, as measured, was being used as a false villain. "I think we have important sociological problems," he said, "but I don't think this gets at it all that well."
Murray L. Weidenbaum, professor of economics at Washington University in St. Louis and chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Ronald Reagan in 1981-82, said he thought the measures tended to overstate the gap by overlooking Government programs like food stamps or Medicaid.
Still, he said he was uncomfortable with greater concentration of wealth "unless there's a rapid turnover" in which "this year's losers will be next year's winners."
He noted that many wealthy people have bad years and that a lot of middle-class people, like graduate students, briefly look statistically as if they are starving. The United States, he said, has "very substantial mobility."
Mr. Weidenbaum said he doubted that the Republican agenda, if it became law, would have any substantial effect on the disparity in wealth. He added that the static effect might be somewhat more concentration, but that the dynamic effect would produce a bigger economic pool for all to share.
There is little agreement as to why inequality is rising faster in the United States than elsewhere. Explanations include falling wages for unskilled workers as automation spreads, low tax rates on the rich during the 1980's, relatively low minimum wages, the decline of trade unions and the rapid rise in the 1980's of the stock and bond markets, in which rich people are heavily invested.
The most common view seems to be that Americans have witnessed the more extreme effects of several international trends toward greater economic inequality. "While many of the countries experienced many pieces of inequality, the United States is the one country that seems to have experienced all the pieces," said Peter T. Gottschalk, an economics professor at Boston College.
Mr. Wolff's papers are based on data that run through 1989. But Census Bureau figures show that the trend toward greater income inequality continued during the first year of the Clinton Administration. While incomes rose for the most affluent two-fifths of the nation's households as the economy expanded in 1993, the rest of the country suffered from falling incomes, after adjustments for inflation.
"U.S. wage distribution is more unequal than other countries and we do less in terms of tax and transfer policy" to cushion the disparities, said Timothy M. Smeeding, an American who is director of the Luxembourg Income Study Project. Mr. Smeeding is preparing two papers drawing international comparisons of income.
The project, based in Walferdange, Luxembourg, is supported by the national science foundations of nearly two dozen countries including the United States, and has gathered Government data from the member nations showing that the United States has the greatest inequalities in income distribution.
Most economists believe that wealth and income are more concentrated in the United States than in Japan. But while data show that wealth is more equitably distributed in Japan, the Government there has not released enough detailed information to make statistical comparisons possible.
Anecdotal information strongly suggests that Japan has a more equal distribution of income. The chief executives of Japanese manufacturing companies, for example, make an average of 10 times the pay of their workers. American chief executives in manufacturing are paid 25 times as much, according to a 1994 study by Towers Perrin, a management-consulting company.
Professor Gottschalk said Canada and the Netherlands seemed to have minimized disparities involving higher wages for highly skilled workers, because the number of college graduates over all had sharply increased in those countries. But other trends toward inequality, like a widening wage gap between experienced and inexperienced workers, had affected them, as well.
When American inequality began to increase is also debated, with various economists putting it anywhere from the mid-1970's to the early 1980's. The double-digit inflation and stock market slumps that followed the quadrupling of oil prices in 1973 temporarily produced greater equality, as the stocks and bonds of the rich lost value. But that effect gradually disappeared, with Mr. Wolff's data showing that the concentration of wealth among the richest had consistently exceeded Britain's level since 1978. British records are especially complete, making such comparisons easier.
The comparison with Britain is all the more striking because President Reagan and former Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher pursued broadly similar economic policies in the 1980's.
Rising housing prices have increased the holdings of the British middle class and limited the growth in inequality there. But Mr. Gottschalk said most evidence indicated that income inequality had risen much faster in the United States and Britain than elsewhere.
Richard V. Burkhauser, an economics professor at Syracuse University, said that in studying thousands of people in Germany and the United States over seven-year periods in the 1980's, he found that the two countries had roughly the same level of social mobility.
As part of the Contract With America's tax provisions, the House on April 5 approved an increase in individuals' exemptions from the estate tax. By the Treasury's estimate, this would cut in half the number of people subject to the tax -- to one-half of 1 percent of the estates of those dying each year.
Republicans have argued that the overall tax-cut provisions would reduce annual tax bills by roughly equal percentages for rich and poor. Democrats say that because the annual tax bills of rich Americans are much larger, reducing them by about the same percentage means that most of the money would go to the rich rather than the poor or the middle class, further concentrating wealth and income.
 In addition, the chart misstated France's ranking in an index of wealth concentration. The index's rankings ran from 0 (meaning everyone has the same amount of wealth) to 1 (a theoretical case in which only one person has all the wealth). France's ranking was 0.30, placing it between Italy and Canada; it was not 0.25, which placed it between Germany and Finland.

CORRECTION-DATE: April 22, 1995, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
A chart in Business Day on Monday with the continuation of an article about growing disparities in wealth and income in the United States misstated the source of data on the concentration of wealth in industrial nations. It was Timothy M. Smeeding of the Luxembourg Income Study Group, not Edward N. Wolff, author of "Top Heavy: A Study of Increasing Inequality of Wealth in America."

HEADLINE: Court Rejects Coupon Settlement In Suit Over G.M. Pickup Trucks

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER 

 BODY:
A Federal appeals court yesterday threw out the settlement of a huge class-action lawsuit that would have given $1,000 coupons to owners of 5.7 million older General Motors pickup trucks that are suspected of posing a fire hazard in sideways crashes.
In its ruling, the three-member panel of the United States Court of Appeals for the Third Circuit, in Philadelphia, said the settlement was worth little to consumers and agreed with the arguments of opponents of the deal, who had called it a "sophisticated marketing program" aimed at selling more G.M. trucks. 
 The coupons would be good only for the purchase of G.M. pickups, which can cost $7,000 to $33,000.
The ruling, which returns the case to a lower court, is the latest step in a long dispute involving full-size Chevrolet and GMC pickups made between 1973 and 1987, which are equipped with side-saddle gas tanks. Safety advocates have said the tanks, which are outside the vehicle frames, are a fire hazard in sideways collisions, an assertion that G.M. has denied.
The car maker's offices were closed yesterday for the Easter Holiday, and a G.M. spokesman reached at home, Ed Lechtzin, said the company had not had time to review and consider the court's lengthy opinion.
"Until we have had time to study the opinion it would not be proper to speculate on the possible outcomes in this matter," he said.
Clarence Ditlow, the executive director of the Center for Auto Safety, which appealed the settlement, said, "The court has recognized that the settlement was worthless and that the only beneficiaries of it were G.M. and the lawyers."
The ruling struck down an agreement approved by a Federal District Court in Philadelphia in December 1993. The appeals panel held that the $1,000 coupons would be virtually worthless to poorer truck owners and rental companies financially unable to buy new pickups.
The panel said the lower court had failed to investigate the value of the coupons adequately.
The members of the panel were Judge Edward R. Becker, who wrote the opinion, Judge Samuel A. Alito Jr. and Judge John R. Gibson of the Eighth Circuit, in St. Louis. The Philadelphia case had consolidated 34 class-action lawsuits and covered truck owners in 49 states around the country and the District of Columbia.
A similar program involving coupons had been approved by a state court in Texas to resolve the claims on the gas tanks by 645,000 owners of older G.M. pickups in that state. But last year by a Texas appeals court rejected that settlement on much the same basis as Federal appeals court did yesterday. The Texas Supreme Court is now reviewing an appeal brought by both G.M. and plaintiffs who agreed to the settlement.
In October, Transportation Secretary Federico F. Pena said a Federal inquiry had concluded that the trucks posed a fire hazard and sharply criticized former G.M. officials for apparently knowing the risks but selling the vehicles anyway
"G.M. management in place at that time appears to have made a decision to favoring sales ahead of safety." Mr. Pena said at the time.
But then in a turnabout, Mr. Pena dropped a threat to try and force G.M. to recall the pickups when the car maker agreed a month later to spend about $51 million on car safety and research programs.
The Government's decision was viewed as a big victory for G.M., which averted both a potentially lengthy court battle and possible payments of over $1 billion to fix and repair the trucks. Had the Transportation Department issued a formal finding that the trucks had a safety defect, the families of people killed in crashes involving the pickups could have been given powerful ammunition to use in lawsuits against the company.
The proposed coupon plan was intended to cover only economic losses that might result from any reduction in the trucks' resale value. Those participating in the proposed settlement could still seek damages for further injuries.
Analysts have said that if all the owners took advantage of the $1,000 offer, the company's obligations would total $5.7 billion. But G.M. has said that the settlement will not be a financial drain on the company.

HEADLINE: Shellshocked by Yen, Companies In Japan Still Find Ways to Cope

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 17

 BODY:
The Mazda Motor Corporation is shutting its Japanese factories for two days this month and two next month to cut production of cars bound for the United States that it can no longer sell. Mitsubishi Materials is shutting a zinc smelter in northern Japan. Sumitomo Metal Industries, a steelmaker, is planning to eliminate 1,500 more people from its work force by March 1997.
These measures, which are at least partly due to the sharp appreciation of the Japanese yen, is beginning to mount. Economists and even Government officials say the recent surge in the exchange value of the yen threatens to send Japan back into a recession from which it was just emerging after three years. The pressure is expected to worsen now that the Government's emergency economic plan, announced Friday, has failed to halt the yen's rise. 
 In New York today, the dollar fell to a record low for the end of a trading session, selling at 82 to the dollar, down from 83.30 on Friday. It also traded at a record low against the mark. [Page D22.]
Japanese corporate executives seem shellshocked by market trends over which they have no control.
The nation's big companies have become adept at dealing with the yen's rise over 20 years. They continue to cut costs, move production offshore, buy imported parts and, where possible, raise the price of their exports. From all evidence, these blue-chip companies should be able to adjust, though not without some pain, in the next year or two.
"There are no smart short cuts that will effectively cope with the situation," Yoshihiro Wada, Mazda's president, said last week, adding that his company had no other way but to speed the introduction of basic countermeasures.
Corporate Japan has been adjusting more or less continuously as the yen has strengthened from the early 1970's, when 360 of them made up a dollar. By the end of last year, many big Japanese companies were getting accustomed to an exchange rate of 100 yen to the dollar, even though they had bitterly complained two years earlier, when the dollar began a fall from 125 yen.
With the economies of Asia and the United States growing strongly, there has been room for Japanese exports, even as they become more expensive.
And some segments of Japan's domestic market, at least partly insulated from foreign competition, are growing strongly, taking some of the pressure off companies.
Auto sales, for instance, were up 11.2 percent in March over March 1994, as consumers replaced cars they bought in the late 1980's boom years. Personal computer sales rose 35.5 percent last year. With increasing domestic demand and cost cuts made during the recession, many big Japanese companies will see profit increase despite the strong yen.
A survey of 200 blue-chip companies by Nihon Keizai Shimbun, Japan's leading financial newspaper, found that the companies expected profit to increase 5.1 percent this fiscal year, even if the yen traded at 85 to the dollar. If the yen moved to 80 to the dollar, profit would decline, but only by 1.2 percent.
Much of the assembly of low value-added consumer products, like television sets, has already moved out of Japan. Much of what is left of Japan's exports are high-value components and machinery and products in which the Japanese face little competition, like flat-panel displays for computer screens, some types of lithography equipment for making computer chips and laser-printer mechanisms.
Such components can take more time to replace than finished consumer products. Given the strong yen, for instance, the number of complete automobiles that Mitsubishi Motors has been selling to the Chrysler Corporation plummeted to 16,000 in the last fiscal year from 73,000 two years earlier. But Mitsubishi is still exporting 400,000 engines a year to Chrysler, a number that has not changed much because it is hard for Chrysler to find an alternative.
For that reason, Japan's exports seem to be showing less sensitivity to changes in exchange rates. Peter Morgan, an economist at Merrill Lynch in Tokyo, estimates that a 10 percent rise in the yen will reduce Japanese export volume only 2 percent. Last year, despite the rise of the yen, exports rose 9.3 percent in dollar terms and stayed about even when measured in yen.
Still, monopolies are not absolute and many companies are reluctant to raise prices on exports.
When Kazuo Inamori, chairman of the Kyocera Corporation, said last month that his company would raise prices 10 percent and urged other Japanese concerns to do the same, he was met with derision. "That's easy for you to say," many other Japanese executives in effect responded. Kyocera supplies more than half the world market for ceramic packages for computer chips, giving it near-monopoly power.
Most other Japanese companies have not raised prices or have done so to a minor degree. Their executive declare that the yen's recent surge might be only temporary, but beyond that, they are afraid of losing market share.
Toyota two weeks ago raised prices in the United States by an average of only three-tenths of 1 percent, far less than the rise in the value of the yen. Mazda raised its American an average of 2.2 percent on April 1.
Such a failure to keep pace with the yen's surge subjects the companies to the threat of anti-dumping suits because the price of their goods in the United States is now less than in Japan. But some officials say that American companies must prove they are being injured to win a dumping lawsuit, something that may well be difficult for American auto makers to prove.
"American companies are enjoying their best profit, so there is no way for them to file a dumping case," said Taizo Yokoyama, a managing director of Mitsubishi Motors.
Even in industries in which Japan is strong, there is reluctance to raise prices. The Sharp Corporation, the world leader in liquid crystal displays, said it was considering raising prices for such products, but had not yet decided to do so. A factor working against such a price increase is that production volume for these screens is sharply increasing, which tends to lower costs, offsetting upward pricing pressure from the yen.
Japan's steel companies, mired in red ink, are still expected to recover their profits despite the yen, said Peter D. Edwards, a senior analyst at Schroder Securities in Tokyo. In steelmaking, capital costs and the efficiency of factories matters more than the exchange rates, he said. And for some types of flat steel products, prices have risen sharply because of strong demand, offsetting the effects of the yen.
Some analysts say that the high yen, rather than being a burden, is a blessing in disguise for Japanese companies. It has forced them to move factories to other parts of East Asia -- and has made it easier for them to pay for such factories. That puts the Japanese companies in a strong position as these countries become the fastest-growing markets for cars, videocassette recorders and other products.
But the ability of big companies to cope does not necessarily mean that Japan's broad economy will do as well. An electronics company that makes its products in Malaysia might be more competitive against its American and European rivals than if it made them in high-cost Japan. But the overall economy will not be better off because some workers will have lost their jobs.
Moreover, the big threat to the Japanese economy comes not only from reduced exports but also from increased imports at low prices. Daiei, a major supermarket chain, for instance, last year began selling imported Belgian beer for 128 yen a can, compared with about 225 yen for Japanese-brewed beers.
Such imports put pressure on domestic producers to lower their prices -- and their revenue and profit. Fear of such a deflationary spiral is one reason that Japanese bureaucrats, while espousing deregulation, are hesitant to disband all barriers and let imports flood in.
So far, unemployment remains at a rate of 2.9 percent, and this country's lifetime employment system, though frayed, is still intact. But people wonder how long that can go on. The Sony Corporation, for instance, has moved 42 percent of its output overseas and is aiming for 50 percent. Yet it has kept its Japanese factories operating.
"If we shut down a factory, the impact on the local community is enormous," Nobuyuki Idei, Sony's new president, said recently. So the company must instead slim down on a "very long-term diet." Mr. Idei said, though, that if the yen continued to get stronger, "I think we have to face real difficult decisions, more drastic actions."
While big companies can cope, the task has been much harder for little companies that usually supply parts to the big ones. These businesses have been forced to sharply cut their prices. And many of them lack the wherewithal to move overseas when their big customers do.
Hiroshi Kishida, who runs a small Tokyo metalworking plant that mainly makes parts for photocopiers, said orders had dropped to half of peak levels and he had borrowed money to stay in business. "Orders don't come to us because the big companies have moved production overseas," he said.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Chase Reports Profit Dip in First Quarter

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The Chase Manhattan Corporation reported yesterday that its first-quarter profit slid 28 percent as a result of losses in Latin American markets. The company, which is coming under increased pressure from some shareholders to improve its stock price, also said it would step up a cost-cutting campaign.
Other big banks that earn most of their income from domestic businesses fared better as borrowing rose. 
 The Nationsbank Corporation's earnings rose 6 percent, First Interstate Bancorp's profits jumped 15 percent, the Bank of New York Company's profits rose nearly 20 percent and the First Chicago Corporation's profits were flat.
Bucking the trend, the PNC Bank Corporation said earnings fell nearly 39 percent because of losses on investment sales.
Chase Manhattan, the nation's sixth-largest bank, said its trading revenue fell 58 percent, to $94 million, compared with that in the first quarter of 1994, but it was up 22 percent from the fourth quarter -- better than analysts had expected.
Chase said that it cut 1,640 jobs, or 4 percent of its work force, in the first quarter and that it expected to cut costs further through the end of the year. It said that its work force now totaled 35,050 employees.
 Early this month, the Heine Securities Corporation, a New Jersey money management firm, disclosed that it had acquired a 6.1 percent stake in Chase, prompting speculation that the banking company may be acquired.
Chase said it reduced some positions in emerging-market debt, which caused a $92 million loss. The securities plunged in value with the Mexican financial crisis that erupted in late December.
The bank earned $260 million, or $1.29 a share, compared with $364 million, or $1.80 a share, in the first quarter of 1994. The results exceeded Wall Street's expectations.
Nationsbank, the No. 4 bank, said its average loans rose 13 percent, to $103.8 billion, compared with last year, an increase Nationsbank attributed to rising business and homeowner borrowing.
Net interest income -- that is, the interest from loans and investments minus what the bank pays for deposits and its own borrowings -- rose $25 million, to $1.34 billion.
Nationsbank, based in Charlotte, N.C., earned $443 million, or $1.60 a share, compared with $417 million, or $1.52 a share, for the comparable period a year ago.
First Interstate said real estate loans rose 77 percent and consumer loans were up 13 percent from a year ago. Over all, loans increased 27 percent, to $9.6 billion.
In a sign that the Los Angeles-based bank is putting its bad loans problems behind it, First Interstate did not set funds aside for possible loan losses, allowing more money to flow to the bottom line.
First Interstate earned $212 million, or $2.66 a share, compared with $169.4 million, including a one-time gain of $14.7 million, or $2.21 a share, in the first quarter a year earlier.
The Bank of New York said credit card loans were up 21 percent, to $7.6 billion, and the number of card accounts increased by 16 percent, to 5.7 million, from 4.9 million a year ago.
Securities-processing fees rose 11 percent, to $98 million, from $88 million in the first quarter of 1994.
Bank of New York earned $213 million, or $1.12 a share, compared with $178 million, or 93 cents, in the quarter a year earlier.
First Chicago said its credit card business had strong growth in the quarter. Card charges rose 18 percent, to $12.3 billion, and fees were up 4 percent, to $191.2 million.
Trading profits totaled $50.4 million, compared with a $25 million loss last year.
First Chicago earned $195 million, or $2.03 a share, compared with $194 million, or $2.05 a share, a year ago.
PNC Bank said it lost nearly $41 million on sales of interest rate-sensitive securities. That, combined with higher borrowing costs and interest payouts on deposits, drove net interest income down 9 percent, to $392.2 million. PNC earned $125.7 million, or 54 cents a share, compared with $205.7 million, or 86 cents a share, in the quarter last year.

HEADLINE: Washington Memo;
Debate on Flat Tax Revives Simplicity vs. Fairness Issue

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 17

 BODY:
Three years ago, when Edmund G. Brown Jr. made his proposal for a flat tax the keystone of his campaign for the Democratic Presidential nomination, the idea fell -- well -- flat.
Bill Clinton mocked it as a sop to the rich that would wreck Social Security and inflict a crushing blow to the poor. In New York, where Mr. Brown finished third in the primary behind Mr. Clinton and Paul S. Tsongas, voters who were interviewed after they left their polling places were decidedly unenthusiastic about Mr. Brown's tax plan. 
 Now, in yet another indication of how the political winds in the country have shifted, several candidates for the 1996 Republican Presidential nomination and some of the top Republican leaders in Congress are advocating replacing the graduated income tax with a flat tax.
People who spent the weekend struggling to meet today's deadline for filing 1994 income tax returns should not get their hopes too high. There is almost no chance that the current tax system, with all its forms and tax brackets, will be overhauled this year or next. But if a Republican is elected President next year, the prospects for a flat tax will be much improved.
Even President Clinton, while still not a champion of the idea, is taking a much less strident tone about it than he did during the heady days of the New York primary.
"Anything we can do to simplify the tax code, consistent with fairness and not exploding the deficit, we ought to do," the President told interviewers on CNN last week. "The first time I heard about a flat tax, I thought it sounded like a pretty good idea."
But Mr. Clinton went on to say, "Every analysis that I have seen done indicates that the flat tax proposals that are out there now will increase the deficit and increase taxes on all Americans with incomes of under $200,000 a year."
Meantime, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, who seems to delight in taking positions on economic matters at odds with the President, has said that he is working on, if not a flat tax, then a flatter one than what the nation has now.
The general idea of a flat tax is that instead of taxpayers paying a larger percentage of their income in taxes as their income grows (up to nearly 40 percent of taxable income now for the wealthiest Americans), everyone would pay the same rate. Most, if not all, deductions would be abolished.
Rather than struggling every April with columns of numbers and pages of forms, taxpayers theoretically could simply fill out a postcard with their income on one line, minus personal exemptions for themselves and their dependents on the next line, times the tax rate on the third line and the resulting tax they owed on the fourth.
There is no mystery why the idea has taken root. Almost everyone agrees that the current tax system is wrongheaded.
For companies and self-employed people, the Internal Revenue Code can be frustratingly complicated and frightfully expensive to comply with. The tax law rewards consumption and penalizes saving, exactly the opposite of the nation's economic interest. And in many instances it is patently unfair: to some working married couples, for instance, who pay much more in taxes than do unmarried contemporaries who cohabit and file separate returns.
But in many respects a flat tax is like universal health insurance, a balanced budget, gun control and mandatory prison sentences. The more the layers of the problem are peeled away, the less attractive the solution becomes. That, politicians find, is often the case with seemingly simple solutions to hideously complicated problems.
As a rule in tax policy, simplicity and fairness are at odds with each other. The simpler a tax system, the more unfair it tends to be. The fairer one is, the more complicated it is likely to be.
Perhaps the biggest political hurdle to a flat tax is that in almost all instances, middle-income taxpayers would owe a little more than they do now in taxes, and the wealthy would owe much less.
The chief Congressional proponent of a flat tax, Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the House majority leader, advocates a flat tax rate on wages and pensions of 20 percent for three years, falling to 17 percent thereafter. Interest, dividends and capital gains would be exempt from taxation.
The personal exemption would be $13,100 for each adult and $5,300 for each child, meaning that a couple with two children and income below $36,800 would owe no income taxes. But beyond that, no deductions would be allowed: not for mortgage interest, not for charitable contributions, not for anything.
The Treasury has calculated that a plan similar to Mr. Armey's would raise nearly $200 billion a year less than the current system, would lower the taxes of people with incomes above $200,000 a year by more than 25 percent and could raise almost everyone else's taxes.
Mr. Armey does not take serious issue with the Treasury's estimate of the revenue loss. Part of the appeal of his plan, he says, is that Americans would get a tax cut. He expects Congress to find offsetting spending reductions to keep the deficit from growing.
As for the rich getting a windfall, Mr. Armey and his allies say the problem is overestimated. Affluent people, they believe, would earn so much more by putting to productive use what they would otherwise pay to the Government that they might even end up paying more in total taxes.
If that does not sound like a persuasive argument, try this one: Americans spend tens of billions of dollars a year -- hundreds of billions, by some estimates -- keeping records, hiring accountants, paying revenue agents and otherwise complying with the current tax system. What if all that money could be saved? Even if it all went into the pockets of wealthy Americans, they would invest it in ways that would put others to work, and everyone would be better off.
If the idea of a flat tax does not founder on the shoals of fairness, it faces two other serious obstacles.
The first one is that the Republican chairmen of the tax-writing committees are not enthusiastic. Representative Bill Archer of Texas, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, and Senator Bob Packwood of Oregon, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, agree that the current system needs to be completely rewritten. But they favor some form of tax on consumption, like a national sales tax.
Mr. Archer plans to hold hearings on the matter beginning in June. But he says he sees no chance of big changes in the tax system until after the 1996 elections.
The other obstacle is that far fewer Americans may be worried about the complexity of the current system than politicians think. Almost three-quarters of all taxpayers take the standard deduction. That means they do not have to itemize their deductions, and can generally submit their returns now on two pages.
For them and for the vast majority of other Americans, almost no record-keeping is required anymore. Employers send statements of wages, salaries and taxes withheld. Interest and dividend statements are sent by banks and companies. The only deductions most people can take are for mortgage interest, state and local property and income taxes and charitable contributions.
But try telling that to the folks in the line at the post office tonight. They most likely had to deal with the child-care credit, or capital gains, or Schedule C for the self-employed. Or maybe they had more than one employer, or had moving expenses or some other complication.
For these people, the tax experience can be maddening. And a flat tax could look mighty good -- even if some fat cat on the other side of town made out like a bandit.

HEADLINE: Life in the Metropolis Found Lacking

BYLINE: By BRETT PULLEY 

 BODY:
People living in the New York, New Jersey and Connecticut metropolitan region are less satisfied with the quality of life in their communities than are residents of four other parts of the country, according to polls released yesterday by a regional planning group.
The polls, by the Regional Plan Association, found that only 35 percent of people living in the New York area said they were very satisfied with their quality of life, compared with 43 percent in Los Angeles and 52 percent in Seattle, for example. 
 The polls also found that 42 percent of the people living in the New York area would move out tomorrow if they had the opportunity -- about the same number found for the Los Angeles area.
The association is using the results of the polls to help draw an outline for future planning, transportation systems, economic development, environmental issues, governance and social policy in the New York region.
In addition to polling residents of the New York area, the association conducted a second poll, in the metropolitan areas of Los Angeles, Atlanta, Seattle and Dallas / Fort Worth, which census data show are the country's fastest-growing metropolitan areas outside the Northeast.
In the New York region, the poll found that 11 percent of the residents ranked high taxes as the thing they most disliked about their community. In the four other regions, the number was 4 percent or less.
Within the New York region, 21 percent of the people living on Long Island said that high taxes were what they disliked most about their communities, compared with just 2 percent in New York City.
In all regions, crime was identified by nearly one in four people -- regardless of age, race or economic status -- as the single most important factor affecting the quality of life.
Officials of the Regional Plan Association said they will use the data to find what can be done to improve those things that people feel are important to the quality of life.
"We're thinking about the national economy as competitive regions," said Robert Yaro, the association's executive director. "We can no longer take for granted that the major industries are bolted down here in the Northeast no matter what we do."
When asked how satisfied they were in general, 35 percent of the people in the New York area said they were very satisfied, compared with a high of 52 percent in Seattle. In the Atlanta area, 49 percent said they were very satisfied, and in the Dallas / Fort Worth area the number was 47 percent.
Prepared by the Quinnipiac College Polling Institute in Hamden, Conn., the poll of the New York metropolitan region questioned 1,500 people and had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points. The poll of the other regions questioned 400 people each, and had a sampling error of plus or minus five percentage points. In comparing data from the two polls, the sampling error is six percentage points.
The association posed nearly 50 questions, asking people to rank what they liked and disliked most about their communities, the importance of various issues, problems in their communities and their outlooks for the future.
Although residents of the Los Angeles region, like those in the New York region, said that high taxes are a big problem, only 1 percent of those polled in the Los Angeles region said that high taxes were the thing they disliked most about their community, compared with the 11 percent in the New York region.
Residents in all regions considered employment, affordable housing, safety, good schools and clean air and water as issues most affecting the quality of their lives. However, people in the New York metropolitan area -- which is known for its transient and enterprising population -- were slightly more concerned about the economy and less concerned about family, church, and faith than people in other regions.
"People have families here and they care about their church and they go to their synagogues, but business and enterprise have always been important here," said Mr. Yaro.
Fifty-three percent of the people in the region said that good public transportation was very important to their quality of life, compared with 34 to 40 percent in the other four regions. Also, residents of the New York region were more satisfied with their public transportation systems than others were.
A high percentage of people in both the New York and Los Angeles areas cited the high cost of housing and the lack of good jobs as big problems. A larger percentage of people in Los Angeles also said that racial tensions were a big problem.
When asked their impression of the quality of life in the New York region, only 1 percent of people living in Los Angeles, Atlanta and Dallas, respectively, answered "excellent." At least 13 percent of people polled across the country had lived in the New York region previously. People in all four of those regions rated their own quality of life much higher than the quality of life in the New York region.
Residents of the New York region apparently agree, as evidenced by the 42 percent who said they would move away immediately if they had the opportunity.
"The bright young people needed to fuel New York's high-tech economy are increasingly footloose," Mr. Yaro said. When asked what type of community they would move to, 50 percent said suburban areas and 33 percent said rural areas.

(Source: Regional Plan Association/Quinniplac College Polling Institute)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Bonds Close Mixed; Traders Cite Weak Dollar

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday, with the 30-year bond falling under pressure from rising commodity prices and a weaker dollar.
The prices of shorter maturities advanced, bolstered by Government reports on Friday that showed weak industrial production and capacity utilization. Yesterday was the first opportunity for traders to react to the data because the market was closed for Good Friday. 
 Buyers were concentrated in securities with maturities of five years or less, said Theodore Ake, Government trading manager at Kemper Securities Inc. in Chicago. "The long end of the market was paying more attention to the dollar's slide, and to the rise in gold, silver and oil," Mr. Ake said, "while the front end, or shorter maturities, was more tuned to manufacturing and the central bank activity."
The price of the 30-year bond fell 17/32 of a percentage point, to 103. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, rose to 7.37 percent, from 7.33 percent on Thursday, and was its highest in six days.
But rates at the Treasury's weekly bill auction dropped sharply. The average rate for a new three-month bill dropped 14 basis points, to 5.56 percent, while the rate for a six-month bill declined 15 basis points, to 5.69 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Despite the weakness in the 30-year bond, 'the bond market rally may not be over," said Ken McAlley, who is head of U.S. Trust Corporation's fixed income division. "The wild card is the severely depreciated U.S. dollar," he said.
The dollar tumbled to new lows against the Japanese yen and the German mark yesterday, hurt by expectations that economic measures introduced by Japan on Friday would not be effective in curbing the surging yen. A weaker dollar hurts United States bonds by making them less attractive to foreign investors.
The market was also weighed down by a sharp rise in commodity prices, including crude oil. The Commodity Research Bureau's index of 21 commodities rose 1.37 points yesterday, to 236.
In early trading, bullish technical factors coupled with the effects of Friday's weak production data briefly overshadowed the inflationary concerns raised by a weak dollar and higher commodity prices.
On Friday, the Federal Reserve said industrial output fell in March by three-tenths of 1 percent, the first decline since September. The report provided further evidence that the economy is slowing.
Few economists now expect the Fed to raise short-term interest rates when its policy-making committee meets in May.
A Reuters poll of economists shows expectations for another interest rate increase to come this summer, a marked shift from earlier surveys, when March or May were picked as the most likely time for a move. Among the reasons given were that data over the last two months have been weaker, with the March employment figures weak enough to keep the Fed on hold unless there is a significant turnaround.
"Today's technicals, along with the cash flows, were positive for the market on the short end, and will likely remain that way all week," Mr. Ake of Kemper Securities said. "While fundamentals, for today at least, were negative for the long end of the market. So far, the market has been very selective on what it has focused on. The soft landing is the predominant trade most people are working off right now."
In the municipal bond market, prices were up amid investor expectations that this week's supply of new bonds will push yields down even further, traders said.
Portfolio managers expect the new issues will run up in price because of the lack of supply compared with last year and the need for funds to buy in large blocks. According to Bloomberg Fair Value Analytics, yields on 30-year insured municipal bonds have fallen 73 basis points, or 12 percent, since January amid a 47 percent decline in new issues for the first quarter.
Following are the results of yesterday's regular Treasury weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills:

HEADLINE: Comptroller Backs Bonds To Aid Irish

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi said yesterday that he supported the idea of purchasing bonds with New York City pension funds to help economic development in Northern Ireland.
Mr. Hevesi, who as Comptroller is the investment adviser to New York City's $51 billion in pension funds, last year proposed establishing an Ireland Development Bank, which would issue bonds to support economic development in Northern Ireland. The bank would primarily lend to small businesses. 
 "Promoting prosperity is a powerful means for ending division and conflict," Mr. Hevesi said, "especially if the economic development programs are administered with the full and equal participation of all the communities in Ireland."
In a news conference with Archbishop John Cardinal O'Connor at the Cardinal's residence in midtown Manhattan, Mr. Hevesi discussed a proposal to establish a bond issue that could be offered to pension funds and other investors interested in channeling money into job-creating ventures in Northern Ireland.
"I'm sure that our pension funds would favorably consider these bonds," Mr. Hevesi said. He added that he was not making any "irrevocable commitment to anything because we have boards of trustees that would have to carefully review this."
But he said that the proposal to create the Ireland Peace Bonds and the development bank had been "constructed so that it would be attractive" to various pension funds.
Mr. Hevesi's proposal is loosely based on Israel Bonds, which were issued in the 1950's and raised about $1 billion a year for Israel.
Colleen Roache, a spokeswoman for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, said that the administration did not know the details of Mr. Hevesi's proposal but that the idea merited further study.
The proposal to create a development bank came during a trip Mr. Hevesi made to Northern Ireland last summer to monitor fair employment practices. Under the proposal, the development bank would receive its initial capital from the British, Irish and United States Governments in addition to the European Union, which would each have to approve the creation of the bank. Each member would provide $25 million in capital and another $25 million in guarantees over a five-year period.
"Ireland Peace Bonds would target the 40 million Irish-Americans and others who would like both a good investment and an opportunity to promote economic development in Ireland," Mr. Hevesi said. "With government guarantees, institutional investors in the United States could find the bonds to be very attractive."
About $5.5 billion of the city's pension funds are invested in stocks and bonds outside of the United States, Mr. Hevesi's office said.
Mr. Hevesi is not the first city comptroller to take an interest in investment in Northern Ireland. In the 1980's, Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin advocated measures to put pressure on American companies that did business in Northern Ireland to seek an end to discrimination against Catholics there.

HEADLINE: Stocks Retreat From Early Gains, With Dow Falling 12.80

BYLINE: By ANTHONY RAMIREZ 

 BODY:
The stock market seemed to defy gravity for part of the day yesterday, but it came down to earth in the last hour of trading, pulled down by a variety of factors, including a surge in oil prices following Iraq's refusal of a United Nations plan for the sale of Iraqi oil.
The surge for most of the day in stocks had come despite a surprising rise in the price of gold and silver, usually a sign of declining market confidence; a sharp drop in the bond market; and the fall to record lows for the dollar in New York trading. 
 After rising as much as 30 points, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 12.80 points, to 4,195.38, while the broader Standard & Poor's 500 dropped 3.10 points, to 506.13. The smaller-company Nasdaq composite index declined as well, finishing at 830.82, down 1.82 points.
This week, there are few economic reports that might move markets. So traders may be anticipating this Friday's quarterly expiration of two kinds of stock options, known as "double witching." Traders typically bid stock prices down before expiration, when trading is hectic and prices typically fall.
One economic report, however, may move markets beforehand. The February international trade deficit, due tomorrow, may further weaken the dollar. Even though Wall Street forecasts an improvement to a deficit of $10.2 billion, from $12.2 billion in January, the figures are volatile and often catch the market by surprise.
Yesterday, propelled by record earnings and an all-time stock high from Microsoft, the stock market staged a broad-based rally for much of the session. Another technology stock, Intel, reported higher-than-expected earnings after the market closed but traders were probably anticipating strong results.
Microsoft, which was the most active stock at almost 12 million shares, kept its early gains, rising 4 7/8, to 77 3/8. But Intel, after rising as high as 97 1/2, fell 1, to 94, in the late-session rout.
"The biggest factor was the resurgence in commodity prices," especially crude oil, said Todd Clark, managing director for equity trading at Rodman & Renshaw. Crude oil for May delivery rose 58 cents, to $19.73 a barrel, the highest since April 6 and approaching the August 1994 high of $20.55.
On Sunday, Iraq rejected as an infringement of its rights as a nation a United Nations plan to allow the sale of $2 billion in Iraqi oil to ease economic distress in Iraq. After its invasion of Kuwait, Iraq was banned from selling oil by the United Nations. The rejected plan would have increased the supply of oil on the world market, thus weakening prices.
Other traders could not attribute the failed rally to any one cause but doubted it would be long term. "It came like a bolt," said Paul Hennessey, senior vice president for equity trading at the Boston Company. "But it's just an aberration."
One factor behind the rout was likely the continuing weakness in the dollar, which fell because of worldwide trader disappointment that Japan did not follow its cut in interest rates last week with a substantive plan to further open its markets to other countries, including the United States.
The dollar fell to another record low of 82.00 yen, down 1.30 yen, and to a record low of 1.3675 German marks, down 0.0189 mark.
Among the biggest gainers yesterday was the Thermolase Corporation, a developer of lasers for cosmetics purposes, which rose 9 3/4, to 23, because of Government clearance of a laser-based hair-removal device. Its parent, Thermotrex, which will make the laser, rose 5, to 21 1/2. TRW Inc., the diversified conglomerate, rose 4 1/8, to 72 1/4 after reporting stronger-then-expected earnings.
Among the biggest decliners was the Learning Company, a developer of educational computer software, which fell 5 1/2, to 24 3/4, after management warned of possibly falling profits for the next few quarters.
Novellus Systems, a maker of equipment used to make computer chips, fell 5, to 63, when management also warned of a profit squeeze. And Compuware, a developer of computer software, fell 4 3/4, to 23. Management said it expects to post lower-than-expected earnings.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Falls as Japanese Plan Fails to Impress Some Traders

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The dollar tumbled against the yen and other leading currencies as dealers remained skeptical about Japanese efforts to curb the advance of the yen.
Concerns about Japan's economic package, which was announced on Friday, increased after American officials said that Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin had expressed disappointment with the Japanese efforts during a meeting with Finance Minister Masayoshi Takemura in Indonesia on Sunday. 
 Mr. Rubin's remarks lessened speculation that the two countries would act in concert to bolster the dollar, dealers and analysts said.
The dollar's decline against the yen yesterday prompted dealers to sell the American currency for German marks, as well.
"Rubin's comments reiterated that the U.S. was disappointed with the package," said Karl Halligan, vice president for strategic trading at CIC Bank New York, "and the market immediately sold dollars and bought yen."
Concern that American and Japanese officials had made little progress toward opening the Japanese auto market to imports from the United States also weighed on the dollar.
It fell as far as 81.74 yen, its lowest level in a week, when it touched a postwar low of 80.15 yen. Buying by the Japanese central bank helped the dollar recover somewhat. In New York trading late yesterday, it settled at 82 yen, a record low in New York, down from 83.30 on Friday.
The dollar also fell to a record low against the mark, at 1.3675 marks, down from 1.3915 on Friday.
It fell sharply against the Swiss franc, as well, ending at 1.1265 francs, down from 1.1515.
But price movements yesterday might have been exaggerated because foreign-exchange centers in many countries were closed for national holidays. "We'll see where the dollar really is when trading begins in Tokyo and London tomorrow," said David De Rosa, director of foreign exchange trading at the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York.
On Friday, Japan introduced a plan to spur its economy that included increases in public works spending and pledges to speed deregulation. In addition, the central bank reduced the discount rate to a modern low of 1 percent from 1.75 percent in an effort to weaken the yen by making deposits denominated in yen less attractive to buyers.
Currency dealers said they were disappointed with the Japanese economic package because it did not specify how soon and how much officials intended to reduce the trade surplus with the United States, which rose to a record $66 billion last year.
"Until they come out with some strong numbers that people can hang their hats on, I don't think anyone is going to stand in the way of this market," said Jim Raphael, a currency dealer at NatWest U.S.A. Bancorp in Jersey City.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 468 words

HEADLINE: When to Lift the Iraq Embargo

 BODY:
The United States and Iraq are engaged in a cynical tug-of-war over a United Nations Security Council plan to let Baghdad sell $2 billion worth of oil over the next six months to pay for food, medicine and other necessities. Washington calls the plan humanitarian help for the Iraqi people. Baghdad says it is a violation of Iraq's sovereignty.
In truth, the plan is a political maneuver manipulated by both sides in the larger struggle over economic sanctions imposed on Iraq by the Security Council at the end of the Persian Gulf war. The sanctions include an embargo on oil sales until Baghdad eliminates all efforts to make weapons of mass destruction. The United States wants to maintain the oil embargo even if Iraq meets that condition. To deflect mounting international criticism that it is being inflexible, Washington proposed sweetening an exception for oil sales for humanitarian purposes. Iraq is resisting the partial easing of the embargo because President Saddam Hussein hopes the Iraqi people will blame the United States, not him, for their hardships. 
 The embargo should not be lifted now because Iraq has yet to comply fully with the requirements on disarming and international monitoring. When Baghdad is in compliance, the United States should allow Iraq to sell its oil. Maneuvering over a partial lifting is a disservice to the Iraqi people because it creates the illusion that the Iraqi dictator might use the oil revenue to help them, something he has shown no interest in doing.
The U.N. arms inspector Rolf Ekeus has just reported that Iraq is still concealing evidence of efforts to make biological weapons. There are signs it may also be hiding parts of its nuclear program.
The U.N. inspectors cannot account for 17 metric tons of material that could be used to breed germ warfare agents like anthrax. They are not sure whether the material was consumed to grow bacteria or is being hidden. Iraq imported the material between 1988 and 1990, but contends it was distributed to hospitals for diagnostic purposes, a contention the inspectors dispute.
Concern about the continuing Iraqi concealment of its nuclear program was recently aroused by the disappearance of one of Iraq's nuclear experts, who reportedly fled to Greece with documents showing that Iraq was still engaged in weapons design and nuclear research. American officials have vouched for the authenticity of some of the documents. The International Atomic Energy Agency is convinced that under its watchful eye Iraq cannot make a warhead, even it could keep parts of its nuclear program going.
There is a clear, simple way for Saddam Hussein to uphold Iraq's sovereignty, end the embargo and actually help his people. He can give the U.N. inspectors the access and information they need.

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 593 words

HEADLINE: The Rich Get Richer Faster

 BODY:
The gap between rich and poor is vast in the United States -- and recent studies show it growing faster here than anywhere else in the West. The trend is largely the result of technological forces at work around the world. But the United States Government has done little to ameliorate the problem. Indeed, if the Republicans get their way on the budget, the Government will make a troubling trend measurably worse.
Some inequality is necessary if society wants to reward investors for taking risks and individuals for working hard and well. But excessive inequality can break the spirit of those trapped in society's cellar -- and exacerbate social tensions. 
 After years of little change, inequality exploded in America starting in the 1970's. According to Prof. Edward Wolff of New York University, three-quarters of the income gains during the 1980's and 100 percent of the increased wealth went to the top 20 percent of families.
The richest 1 percent of households control about 40 percent of the nation's wealth -- twice as much as the figure in Britain, which has the greatest inequality in Western Europe. In Germany, high-wage families earn about 2.5 times as much as low-wage workers; the number has been falling. In America the figure is above 4 times, and rising.
Interpreting these trends requires caution. Inequality rose here in the 1980's in part because the United States created far more jobs -- many low-paid -- than did Western Europe. Low-paying jobs are better than no jobs. Rising inequality in the United States has also been caused in substantial part by middle-class families that moved up the income ladder, opening a gap with those below them.
About half of Americans move a substantial distance up or down the income ladder over a typical five-year period. In a mobile society, where workers rotate among high- and low-earning jobs, earnings gaps are less frightening because any given job would be less entrapping.
But mobility has offset none of the increased inequality in income. Studies at the Maxwell School at Syracuse University show that mobility in America is not higher than in Germany. Nor does mobility here appear to be higher today than it was in the early 1970's.
The best guess about the factor behind burgeoning inequality is technology; the wage gap between high- and low-skilled workers in America doubled during the 1980's. College graduates used to earn about 30 percent more than high school graduates, but now earn 60 percent more. Prof. Sheldon Danziger of the University of Michigan estimates that trends in private pay rates explain about 85 percent of recent increases in inequality; Reagan-Bush tax cuts for the rich and spending cuts for the poor explain much of the other 15 percent.
But even if government is not the main actor, it could be part of the solution. Changes in the Canadian economy during the 1980's also hit hard at low-wage workers. But there the Government stepped in to keep poverty rates on a downward path. In the United States, poverty rose.
House Republicans are now pushing the Federal budget in the wrong direction. At a time when employers are crying out for well-educated workers, the G.O.P. proposes to cut back money for training and educational assistance. America needs better Head Start, primary and secondary education. It needs to train high school dropouts and welfare mothers. The G.O.P. policy would leave the untrained stranded. That would harm the nation's long-term productivity -- and further distort an increasingly tilted economy.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Observer;
Hooked On Jail

BYLINE: By RUSSELL BAKER 

 BODY:
Whatever the problem, the solution is now obvious: jail.
You have heard the following statistic: The United States now has more people locked up than the country that used to hold the world record but whose name eludes me, probably the late Soviet Union or the South Africa of apartheid days. 
 What about China? It is never listed as a contender, possibly because China does not have jails. It has re-education centers.
The Chinese do not want them called jails, and we humor the Chinese in this. It is good business, and as President Coolidge observed, "The business of America is business."
Presidents Bush and Clinton have both insisted that this Coolidgean wisdom be engraved on the skull of every State Department employee assigned to the China division.
If they referred to re-education centers as "jails," the dirt-cheap garments Americans now buy at the Dirt-Cheap Mart might be denied us by an offended China.
The Chinese, as is well known (as Radio Moscow used to say in the old days before issuing some utterly doubtable fact), are sticklers for good manners. Call a spade anything but a manually operated excavating-technology implement, and China may no longer invite you to share its dirt-cheap threads.
If China is not a contender, the United States seems sure to become the jail champion of the world at any moment. American prisons are bulging. More and better prisons are on drawing boards all over the country.
Prison construction seems to be the last government activity of which Americans still heartily approve despite the monumental costs. Economists constantly point out that keeping someone in prison costs more than a Harvard education.
This may be true, but it ignores Harvard's reluctance, demonstrated just the other day, to grant its blessings to persons with felonious histories. It also ignores the law-abiding taxpayer's temptation to ask why, if the Government is handing out Harvard educations, preference should go to crooks.
The taxpayer is simply not going to sit still for felons being sentenced to Harvard educations. He is ready and even eager, however, to see his famous taxpayer's dollar devoted to the newest thing in cellblocks.
Here is where a little common sense can be applied to cutting the cost of government. As Governor Pataki has finally noticed in New York, top-drawer space needed to warehouse our nastiest customers is being wasted on small fry.
At present a great deal of expensive cell space is occupied by offenders who can't even be described as underworld bush-leaguers. These are the ho-hum drug dealers and users locked up because Governor Rockefeller years ago decided that jail would solve the drug problem.
It would be inviting the Furies to say that history has proved Rockefeller wrong. Embalming fluid is the only cure for people truly wedded to discredited ideas. Believers in supply-side economics will enter Eternity insisting that President Reagan's decision to cut taxes and raise spending had nothing to do with creating his legacy of the trillion-dollar deficit.
In the same way, believers in the jail solution to the drug problem will insist that the iron doors continue to clang.
Very well, but should they be the very best iron doors that the taxpayer's dollar can buy? Is maximum security vital to teach the corner peddler a lesson he won't forget?
Obviously, the answer is to build a small, cheaper, lower-security drug jail. Small, cheap, minimal-security -- those are the specifications for many of the problems we hope to solve with jail.
Soon, obviously, the public is going to insist that people be jailed for smoking. All well and good, but does it make economic sense to waste a magnificently punitive institution like Attica even on the most hardened, incorrigible smoker?
The solution: smoke jail. A few pine shacks and a wire fence. Next problem: people's use of insensitive speech that hurts other people's feelings. Solution: insensitivity jail where offenders can do some low-budget brooding on how bad it would hurt their own feelings to be called "jailbirds."
Next problem: the cruel lampooning of decent earth-loving people just because they want to stamp out fur coats, sugar and fatty foods. Solution: Joke jail. And next --
Well . . . maybe re-education centers.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Stocks Reverse Course On Dollar Drop and Oil Surge
 
The stock market fell in the last hour of trading after rising for much of the day, brought down by rising oil prices and the continued weakness in the dollar. The Dow was up as much as 30 points before closing down 12.80 points at 4,195.38. 
 Traders said the market was pulled down by a surge in oil prices after Iraq's rejection of a United Nations plan for limited oil sales and after the dollar declined against the yen and the mark. It settled in New York at 82.00 yen and 1.3675 marks. Bonds also fell. D12.
Japanese companies are coping with a surge in the yen that economists say threatens to send Japan back into a recession from which it was just emerging. A1.
 
Court Rejects Truck Settlement
A Federal appeals court in Philadelphia threw out the settlement of a class-action suit that would have given $1,000 coupons to owners of General Motors pickup trucks with so-called side-saddle gas tanks. A1.
 
Latin American Losses Hit Chase
Chase Manhattan, citing losses in Latin America, reported that its first-quarter profit slid 28 percent to $260 million and said it would step up its efforts to cut costs. D4.
 
Intel and Sun Exceed Estimates
Intel and Sun Microsystems reported revenue and earnings that far exceeded the most optimistic of analysts' expectations. Intel's earnings were up 44 percent and Sun posted an 87 percent increase. D2.
 
Eli Lilly and Upjohn Profits Rise
Eli Lilly reported an 18.9 percent increase in net income, while Upjohn posted a 12.5 percent gain, as drug companies emerged from their best quarter in several years. D6.
 
Time Warner Selling Six Flags Stake
Time Warner has agreed to sell control of the Six Flags theme park business in a $1 billion deal that will help reduce its debt. The company also reported a smaller loss and increased cash flow for the first quarter as its five main businesses each posted operating gains. D9.
 
Robert Pittman will leave Six Flags at the end of the summer after the company balked at his compensation demands, investment bankers say. In addition to an estimated salary of $2 million to $3 million, bankers said Mr. Pittman wanted an equity interest in Six Flags. D9.
 
Two Executives Leaving Chiron
Two Chiron executives, David Martin and William Gerber, are leaving to join smaller companies in which Chiron owns minority stakes. D2.
 
Flat Tax Idea Making Comeback
Several aspirants for the Republican Presidential nomination and some top Republican leaders in Congress are advocating replacing the graduated income tax with a flat tax. A1.
