HEADLINE: Asia First: A Foreign Policy

BYLINE: By Michael Lind; Michael Lind is a senior editor of Harper's Magazine.

 BODY:
The United States is approaching the year 2000 with a grand strategy designed for 1950. Although America spends almost as much as the rest of the world on defense, neither party is seriously questioning the continuing need for alliances designed for the cold war.
With the illusion of the "last superpower" long shattered, we have to think about American interests in terms of four other great powers: Japan, China, Russia and Germany. And for the next century, we must concentrate on Asia. It contains most of the world's population and much of its industry, and Japan and China are the only powers with the potential to be formidable rivals. 
 An "Asia first" foreign policy would entail maintaining an economic and military balance between Japan and China, ending America's military agreement with Japan, increased cooperation with Russia on Asian affairs, forcing open Japan's and China's markets to U.S. goods, and dismantling NATO.
In the very long run, China may be the greatest threat to our interests. A China with only a quarter of America's per capita income would surpass us as the world's largest economy and, perhaps, as the pre-eminent military power. It has already replaced the Soviet Union as the major military supplier for anti-American regimes, and is insisting on great-power hegemony over the South China Sea.
Seeing Japan's success in exploiting the open U.S. market while placing barriers on foreign investment at home, China is building up a huge bilateral trade surplus. Americans who hope that capitalist development will inspire a democratic and peaceable China will almost certainly be disappointed: after all, it took military defeat and occupation to bring democracy to capitalist Germany and Japan.
History warns us, however, against overestimating China's potential -- and underestimating that of Japan. Japan's economy is superior to ours in many areas of finance and technology. If it chose to, Japan could become a high-tech military superpower overnight.
Ominously, many Japanese politicians and intellectuals are taking the line that the East Asian model of capitalism -- stressing national community and strong government at the expense of individualism -- is superior to "decadent" American liberal democracy. "This is a nation of Asian people with Asian blood," Shintaro Ishihara, one of many Japanese politicians arguing for a "re-Asianization" of Japan, has said. Reversing the 19th century slogan "Datsu-ah, ny-o" ("Leave Asia, enter the West"), many Japanese leaders now recite the trendy slogan "Datsu-o, nyu-ah" ("Leave the West, enter Asia").
 Those who argue that the U.S. can best restrain Japan by continuing to insure its military security must answer an obvious question: what do we get in return? As the Asian market becomes more important than ours for Japan, our leverage with Tokyo in trade talks will continue to diminish, no matter how many troops we have there. Why should U.S. troops serve indefinitely as the security guards of a latter-day Greater East Asian Co-Prosperity Sphere from which many American products are effectively excluded?
Besides, in the event of American-Chinese conflict, Japan is more likely to act as an opportunistic intermediary than a local ally, if its recent record of undercutting U.S. positions on human rights and arms proliferation in China and North Korea is any indication.
It is too early to tell whether Japan or China will be a greater challenge. The most prudent policy would be for the U.S. to keep its distance from both, weighing in on the side of the weaker whenever one grows overly strong.
In the interim we should remove most of our troops from Japan and replace the U.S.-Japan security treaty with more flexible agreements. Japan should assume responsibility for its own defense, with the two nations cooperating with others on regional security. (U.S. forces should remain in South Korea, however, until peaceful unification.) Treating Japan as an equal, not a dependent, may also mean pushing for it to be given a permanent seat on the United Nations Security Council and allowing it to develop a nuclear weapons program if it seeks one.
A new realism in our Asian policy would mean rejecting the counsel of those who would continue to appease Japanese mercantilism on the theories that an overvalued yen or a domestic consumer revolt will soon eliminate its trade surplus. Our deficit with Japan is really worse than it appears, because Japanese subsidiaries in other Asian countries are exporting to the U.S. The problem has festered for so long only because many of America's Asian experts and policymakers are supported by Japanese business interests and U.S. companies with stakes in Asia. (The second largest "soft money" contributor to the Republican party in the first two months of 1995 was the United States Asia Commercial Development Corporation).
The Clinton Administration should follow up its successful tough line in trade talks with China by giving Japan a stark choice between opening its market to the estimated $50 billion in American imports that is lost every year and our setting up equally restrictive barriers. The Administration should also begin negotiations with the European Union to form a trans-Atlantic common market limited to industrial countries that practice liberal capitalism and two-way trade.
Although our foreign policy should focus on Asia, we of course cannot ignore Europe's great powers, Germany and Russia. Fortunately, neither are strong enough to be world-class threats.
Economists predict that by the year 2020, there will be one German pensioner for every German worker. Countries with low birth rates do not engage in conquest, for lack of cannon fodder. The European Union's inability to set a common policy toward the Balkans, though tragic, should reassure Americans worried about the emergence of a German-dominated superstate.
The Russian Republic combines a population only slightly larger than Japan's with a third world economy, an enfeebled Government, an insubordinate military and chaos on its borders. Eventually, no doubt, some regime, more likely authoritarian than democratic, will forge some degree of order and prosperity. A hostile Russia with nuclear weapons would be a threat -- but more like a large Iraq than another Nazi Germany.
Yet it is in America's interest for there to be a moderately strong Russia to act as a military counterweight in Asia to Japan and China. We should continue to support Russia's territorial integrity and give it economic aid.
We cannot expect Russian cooperation in Asia, however, if we antagonize Russia by extending NATO into Eastern Europe. Thus we should replace NATO with a pan-European security organization that includes Russia and the U.S. The Western Europeans as a group, or the Germans independently, would assume separate responsibility for their own defense, permitting the U.S. to pull out most of its troops and end its implausible nuclear guarantee of Europe.
"The commonest error in politics is sticking to the carcasses of dead policies," wrote the Marquess of Salisbury, one of Britain's greatest statesmen, in 1877. "When a mast falls overboard, you do not try to save a rope here and a spar there, in memory of their former utility; you cut away the hamper altogether." The United States-Japan alliance and NATO have been rendered irrelevant by cold war success. The new slogan in Tokyo ought to be adopted in Washington as well: "Leave the West, enter Asia."

HEADLINE: Japanese Issue Threat to Quit Talks on Cars

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 18

 BODY:
Japanese officials said today that they would withdraw from trade talks with the United States on automobiles and parts if the Clinton Administration moved further toward imposing sanctions during the negotiations.
The warning came as Japanese and American officials reported little progress after two days of discussion here. The Administration is pressing Japan to remove barriers to importing American cars. 
 Frustrated by the lack of progress after two years of talks, Mr. Clinton's economic advisers decided last week to threaten Japan with punitive tariffs if the two sides failed to agree within three weeks.
American officials said no overt threats were made at today's talks, but one official said that the Administration "was resolved to address this one way or another if negotiations fail."
Secretary of Commerce Ronald H. Brown, was blunter, saying today on a CNBC program that Washington would consider using sanctions against Japan if the talks were unsuccessful.
President Clinton said at his televised news conference tonight that the United States was not at risk of a trade war with Japan, but that some difficulties remained to be resolved. He accused Japan of being protectionist in some areas, but that progress had been made in many others.
Earlier in the day, the Japanese distributed a position paper to reporters that said, "If the U.S. Government should announce retaliation against Japan in an effort to create negotiating leverage, we may be forced to suspend negotiations and proceed immediately" to the World Trade Organization. There, the Japanese say, they would charge that the United States was violating world trade rules by unilaterally seeking to impose sanctions.
Under Secretary of Commerce Jeffrey Garten, the chief American negotiator today, said in an interview that the talks focused on two American demands: that Japan make sure more auto dealers sell American cars and that Japanese auto makers purchase more American components. The United States is seeking to extend an agreement, negotiated by the Bush Administration in 1992, under which Japanese car manufacturers agreed to increase the use of American parts.
After today's talks ended, Yoshihiro Sakamoto, a vice minister of international trade and industry, said that as long as the United States insisted on expanding the voluntary plan, there would be no agreement.
A Japanese official contended that the issue was not one for Government negotiations, but the responsibility of private business.
Mr. Garten said the United States had not set any deadline for reaching agreement. He said lower-level talks would be held next week involving technical experts from the two countries, and added: "We made very little progress today. Large gaps remain in all the major areas."
The two sides continued to put forward very different reasons that American automobiles and parts had captured such small shares of the Japanese market.
The United States contended that Japan maintained many subtle trade barriers, like a heavily regulated system of repair shops with close links to Japanese auto makers.
Washington also argued that the refusal of many Japanese dealers to sell American cars had denied General Motors, Ford and Chrysler "the shelf space" that would enable Japanese consumers to look at their cars.
The Japanese argue that the Big Three have such a small share of their market because they have not tried hard enough to sell their cars in Japan. Mr. Sakamoto noted that 80 percent of the cars sold in Japan had engines under two liters in size, and said that hardly any American cars had engines that small.
"There is a basic difference in perception," Mr. Garten said. "We are saying the Japanese market is closed, especially in relation to other industrial countries. They are saying we aren't trying hard enough."

HEADLINE: Starts of Home Construction Decline for a Third Month

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Construction starts on new homes fell in March for the third consecutive month, the Commerce Department reported yesterday, reinforcing a growing view that the economy is a lot weaker today than it was at the end of last year.
Ground was broken for new homes -- single-family houses, multi-family town houses and apartments -- at an annual rate of 1.2 million buildings, the lowest level in two years. The decline was 8 percent from the February level, or more than double the drop that forecasters had expected. Builders finally pulled back, apparently because of a growing inventory of unsold new homes, among other problems. 
 "At some point, builders had to start realizing that there were more unsold homes out there than there were people to buy them," said David Wyss, director of research at DRI/McGraw-Hill, an economic consulting service in Cambridge, Mass. "I think that realization has finally come, and they are starting to cut back."
The sharp drop in home construction was the latest bit of unfavorable news about the economy. Industrial production, including auto and truck manufacturing, has fallen from last year's levels. Job creation is less than it was last year, retail sales have weakened, and inventories of unsold merchandise have risen, making corporate America reluctant to churn out more goods until people buy what has already been made.
"The signs of slowdown are almost across the board," Alan S. Blinder, vice chairman of the Federal Reserve, told the Dow Jones Capital Markets Report in an interview.
Many economists now say the national economy will grow in the current second quarter at an annual rate of 2.5 percent or less, roughly half the pace of last year's booming fourth quarter. "Housing is the sector that really tells you when higher interest rates are biting into the economy," Lawrence H. Meyer, an econoimic consultant in St. Louis, said. "And they are biting; there is no question about that."
As the Federal Reserve raised interest rates in 1994, rates for 30-year fixed-rate mortgages rose as high as 9.2 percent last December from a low of 6.9 percent in October 1993. The 30-year mortgage has since eased back to 8.5 percent, but lenders have discouraged home buyers by raising first-year "teaser" rates on variable-rate mortgages to more than 6 percent from 5 percent or so last year. The bargain-basement teaser rates were withdrawn because lenders were losing money on these deals, Lyle Gramley of the Mortgage Bankers Association said.
The biggest drop in housing starts, 20 percent, occurred in the West, probably because of the heavy rain and flooding in California last month, Lewis Alexander, chief economist at the Commerce Department, said. The declines in the rest of the nation were much less; multifamily- home construction took the biggest hit. Building permits for future residential construction also fell, having been issued in March at an annual rate of 1.231 million, a decline of 4.4 percent from February.
Inventories of unsold new homes have risen rapidly since late last year, when less than six months were needed to sell off the stockpile. Home sales have since declined, raising the inventory level to 7.5 months of unsold homes.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Housing Construction" shows new private housing started and permits authorized during the month from Oct. '93-March '95. (Source: Commerce Department)

HEADLINE: Treasury Chief Goes to India And Is Upstaged by Iranian

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, April 18

 BODY:
Nobody told Robert E. Rubin that his first venture abroad as Treasury Secretary would be as much fun as one of Hillary Rodham Clinton's elephant rides.
But then again, no one told him he would have to stay one limousine behind the state visitor whom India is really out to impress: President Hashemi Rafsanjani of Iran, a country the Clinton Administration calls an "outlaw nation" that must be economically isolated. 
 For the last two days, since their planes touched down at Delhi airport two hours apart, Mr. Rubin and Mr. Rafsanjani have been engaged in a contest of dueling motorcades, one zipping into New Delhi's stately government residences as the other glided out.
This afternoon, they missed each other by three minutes. There was no risk that they would run into each other at dinner. The Indian Finance Minister put on a quiet meal for the Treasury Secretary, while the rest of the Government was across town, listening to Mr. Rafsanjani speak to a special session of Parliament convened in his honor.
At lunch today, after a morning spent passing dozens of banners declaring "Long live India-Iran Friendship," a somewhat chagrined Mr. Rubin acknowledged that the timing of his celebration of India's economic opening could have been better. "Clearly, we would have rescheduled, if we had known in a timely fashion," he said.
In fact, Mr. Rubin said that until last weekend, when he was attending a meeting of finance ministers in Indonesia, he was unaware that Mr. Rafsanjani and his delegation of 100 officials would be fellow travelers.
So, apparently, was Frank G. Wisner, the American Ambassador here. Mr. Wisner said he first heard about Mr. Rafsanjani's trip when he returned from the tiny kingdom of Bhutan over the weekend, and by then it was too late to call things off.
American officials here said they had apparently missed several articles in the Indian press during the last 10 days or so previewing Mr. Rafsanjani's trip and speculating on the meaning of India's sudden embrace of a country with few friends.
Ostensibly, Mr. Rafsanjani and Mr. Rubin have similar agendas, talking commerce. In fact, the Iranian arrived with an accord that will give India much-sought-after access to Central Asian republics.
There is a lot of vague talk about building a pipeline from Iran's oil refineries to India's power-hungry west coast. But since the Iranians are decidedly short of money, and the Indians short of credit, it is unclear who would pay for it.
But there is considerably less than meets the eye to the economic accords, especially when compared with India's deep ties to the United States, its biggest trading partner and supplier of investment capital. So American officials were speculating today that they had been caught in the middle of an effort by India to try to gain an edge over Pakistan by striking up deals with a Muslim country, and to make sure that Iran provides little aid to Muslim militants in Kashmir.
"I don't think this is about us," an American official here said today. "But it would have been nice if someone let us know."
Indian officials did not seem to know much today about the latest rise in tensions between Iran and the United States. In recent weeks Washington has terminated a deal between Conoco Inc. and Iran to develop an untapped part of Iran's oilfields. It has been trying to tighten the economic noose, perhaps even stopping American companies from buying Iranian oil and selling it to third countries. Iranian oil is barred from the United States.
On Monday, Secretary of State Warren Christopher, who has led the effort to isolate Iran, failed to persuade China to stop supplying nuclear goods to Teheran, which is suspected of building a bomb.
India already has a bomb, perhaps several, but American officials said they doubted that that is what Mr. Rafsanjani meant when he talked about "technology transfers" between the two countries. American officials here say they have seen no intelligence data to suggest India has given any country nuclear aid.
Mr. Rubin, a former Wall Street executive who is still feeling his way in the realm of geopolitics, said today that he had simply said his piece to Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao and did not get into the details of Iran's behavior. "These are very sensitive and difficult areas," he said today.
Asked why the Treasury Secretary went ahead with the trip, the fourth American Cabinet mission to India this year, Mr. Rubin's spokesman said the absence of advance warning and "the closeness of our relations with India" led to a decision to go ahead.
But the contrasts have been hard to miss. Prime Minister Rao broke protocol and came out to the airport on Monday, but it was to greet Mr. Rafsanjani, and not the top economic official of India's biggest trading partner and investor.
There is some speculation here that the comparatively cool reception given to Mr. Rubin could carry a political message: After three years of privatization, Mr. Rao has been criticized as moving too fast and pursuing economic growth that has yet to trickle down to the poor.
Now there are signs that he is slowing down. Opposition leaders who won election last month in Maharashtra state are threatening to open an investigation into a major power project won by Enron Corporation, a Houston energy company.
Aware that many in India think that their economic policy is dictated by Washington, Mr. Rubin is carefully avoiding controversy and pressure.
S. L. Rao, the director general of the National Council of Applied Economic Research, said: "If the impression develops, and it is developing, that America is delving deeply into the details of economic policy in India, it will have a backlash. We need a little room, and time."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Houston Post Bought and Closed by Rival

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, April 18

 BODY:
The country's fourth-largest city abruptly became a one-newspaper town today, after the 111-year-old Houston Post was sold to the Hearst Corporation, owner of the larger Houston Chronicle, which immediately shut it down.
The owner of The Post, Consolidated Newspapers Inc., said the rising cost of newsprint had discouraged potential buyers who might have been willing to keep the paper operating. Instead, the best offer came from Hearst, whose chief benefit in the deal is the elimination of The Chronicle's competition. 
 With the death of The Post, Houston becomes the largest city in the country with only one major daily metropolitan newspaper, joining a growing list of communities in which the economics of the newspaper business have led to a death struggle among rival dailies.
While rumors that The Post was up for sale had been circulating here for weeks, the suddenness of the newspaper's collapse left many Post employees stunned that the paper was not even accorded the journalistic equivalent of a decent burial -- publication of a final commemorative issue. This morning's issue, the last ever, said nothing of the sale.
"The thing that bothers me the most is not even being able to say goodbye to our readers," said Steve Sucher, 42, a features editor at The Post. "That's kind of a newspaper tradition. But I guess this shows what's happening to tradition in the newspaper business."
The closing of The Houston Post ends a 94-year rivalry between the city's two dailies. In recent decades, The Chronicle, which was bought by Hearst in 1987, has clearly become the dominant paper in town.
The Chronicle's current reported circulation is 412,337 daily and 606,707 on Sunday, while The Post's is 287,215 daily and 316,852 on Sunday.
Still, The Post had acquired a loyal following and a reputation as a somewhat pluckier, more colorful newspaper, right down to its delivery trucks, emblazoned with the slogan "The Houston Post -- A sign of intelligent life."
The dollar value of the sale to Hearst was not disclosed, though a Justice Department approval of the sale of The Post valued its assets at around $120 million.
Consolidated Newspapers said it had held unsuccessful talks with about four dozen prospective buyers who might have kept the paper running. Among those who had looked at The Post were the Rev. Pat Robertson, the head of the Christian Broadcasting Network, and the A. H. Belo Corporation, which publishes The Dallas Morning News.
In a statement today, officials of Consolidated Newspapers said the rising cost of newsprint had made the price of a sale prohibitive to all prospective buyers except Hearst. Last year, the statement said, the newsprint bill for The Post was about $26 million; this year, the price was expected to be more than $39 million.
"The recent unprecedented rise in the cost of newsprint has made it impossible to see viability for the city's second newspaper," said William Dean Singleton, president of and chief executive of Consolidated Newspapers.
The Post was owned for many years by the Hobby family of Houston, which sold it in 1983 to the Toronto Sun Publishing Company. That company sold the majority of its stake in the newspaper to Consolidated in 1987.
"This had to happen but that doesn't really make it any easier," said Paul Hobby, a grandson of the first Hobby to own The Post. "Economically, this is inevitable."

HEADLINE: Long March Of the Arms Contractors;
They Migrate South For Cheaper Labor in The Lower-Cost States

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

DATELINE: MARIETTA, Ga.

 BODY:
For years, the Lockheed Corporation centered its aircraft manufacturing in Burbank, Calif., where thousands of workers built prosperous lives on wages that reached as high as $20 an hour. That factory is closed now and wildflowers grow through crevices in the concrete that surrounds the shuttered buildings. The new heart of Lockheed's operations beats most strongly today here in Georgia, where the company makes its military planes with lower-cost labor.
The nation's manufacturers of military hardware, an industry that still employs nearly 1.5 million people, are migrating. Like Lockheed, they are transferring operations to Georgia, Colorado, Louisiana, Florida, Mississippi and other low-cost states. In doing so, they are joining the rest of corporate America in its itinerant search for cheaper wages, fewer unions, less regulation and easier tax policies. And gradually the South and the Rocky Mountains are becoming the new centers for military spending, edging aside the Northeast and the Pacific Coast. 
 "As we consolidate and become more efficient, we do think of things we never would have thought of in the past, like states where we can be more competitive," said Daniel M. Tellep, chairman of the Lockheed Martin Corporation, the recently created amalgam of Lockheed and the Martin Marietta Corporation that forms the nation's largest military contractor. "In many cases that means going to the South and the Rocky Mountain states."
The Pentagon may be spending less to develop and manufacture weapons and equipment -- $70 billion in the 1994 fiscal year versus an inflation-adjusted $137 billion in 1985 -- but the South and the Rocky Mountains are getting an ever bigger share of the declining outlay.
The shift is even more striking compared with 1976, before the Reagan arms buildup, when the outlay for weapons and research was not very different from today, adjusted for inflation. But the shares going to the Southeast and the Rocky Mountain regions have doubled compared with 1976, while the Northeast and the Pacific Coast regions have lost 15 percent or more.
"To be a bigger share of a shrinking pie is not the best position to be in, but it is better than being a shrinking share of a shrinking pie," said Donald Ratajczak, director of economic forecasting at Georgia State University in Atlanta. "Because of the shifting, the defense cutback has not been a blow to the economies of the South."
That cannot be said of Long Island, where the Grumman Corporation, now Northrop Grumman, was once the biggest employer. It stopped making any planes at all there last year, shifting what was left to Florida, Georgia and Louisiana. Nor is it true for the vast region in and around Los Angeles. Hughes Electronics, for example, recently transferred missile operations from Southern California to Arizona and Colorado, shifting hundreds of jobs in the process.
In Massachusetts, the Raytheon Company, still the state's largest employer, is threatening to transfer missile work to Tennessee -- if the state does not grant the sort of concessions that Tennessee offers.
"We may end up being forced to go elsewhere, if we can't get $600 million out of our cost base in Massachusetts," said Elizabeth Allen, Raytheon's chief spokeswoman, happy to use the news media to pressure for concessions.
All this represents a striking turnabout. Until the late 1980's, military contractors stayed pretty much in place, serving as a bulwark in high-cost regions that lost other manufacturers. The Pentagon's generous contracts shielded them from the intense competition that drove so many other industries to cost-cutting and migration. But with the cold war's end, the Defense Department urged the contractors to slash costs so that it could buy as much as possible with a shrinking budget.
"Ten years ago, there was a lot of money spread around in defense and you did not have to look for ways to cut costs," said Al Hansen, a Lockheed vice president. "Now we meet weekly to do this."
The corporate response is making the Federal Government an increasingly visible participant in a movement that contributes to wage stagnation in the United States. "The cold war is over and the Pentagon should get the most bang for its declining budget," said Frank Levy, a labor economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "But on the other hand, the President keeps pushing for higher wages, and this strategy works against that."
There are other consequences. The movement exacerbates the already intense bidding war among the states to attract companies and jobs by offering tax concessions and outright gifts. It is a competition that some economists label a giveaway of public goods: schools, roads, municipal airports, public transportation and the like. The huge Lockheed plant here is soon to receive such a gift from the Cobb County government. The county will pay for a multimillion-dollar rail underpass so that traffic will not be held up when trains cross the factory's property on a line now at ground level.
Pentagon officials, however, say this largess serves the needs of national defense. They say they must find ways to buy enough weaponry despite their shrinking budget, and if competition among the states helps, so be it. The Pentagon, in fact, has given Lockheed, Hughes and other contractors tens of millions of dollars to help cover the costs of moving and consolidating.
"It makes economic sense to consider sharing the short-term costs to realize the long-term savings," Joshua Gotbaum, Assistant Secretary of Defense for Economic Security, said at a recent Congressional hearing.
Nothing illustrates the post-cold-war migration and its impact more clearly than the decision by Lockheed to shift its principal aeronautic operations from Burbank to Marietta. This Atlanta suburb has boomed in recent years with the construction of federally financed interstate highways -- five and six lanes in either direction -- that tie Cobb County to Atlanta and the rest of Georgia. Lining the interstates are mile after mile of shopping centers, gallerias, hotels, office buildings and one-story factories. Although Sherman fought here en route to Atlanta, the landscape has been so transformed that Cobb County seems to lack almost any history before the 1970's.
"We have roads going everywhere," said Timothy Mescon, dean of the new business school at Kennesaw State College, itself a young and rapidly growing university just off Interstate 75.
The Lockheed plant, a square half-mile of floor space next to Dobbins Air Force Base, dates from the dark ages before interstates. That is typical of the major military contractors, who are not building new plants as much as they are consolidating into what were once satellite operations. Lockheed Martin still has a big presence in California, including a top-secret advance design operation in Palmdale. But the center of its aeronautical operations has shifted to the South and the Mid-Atlantic.
The plant here, which Lockheed acquired in 1955, first to make C-130 propeller-driven transports for the Air Force and then giant C-5 jet transports, took on new life in the 1990's with the arrival of the P-3, a propeller plane designed to hunt submarines. It had been built in Burbank for years. Not long after, Lockheed transferred a host of administrators to Georgia and then its research teams, bringing a thousand engineering jobs here. "We de-staffed California in engineering, and staffed Georgia," said Mr. Hansen, the Lockheed vice president.
The engineers, many of them newly hired Georgians earning on average 10 percent less than the California scale, are now developing Lockheed Martin's next weapon, the F-22, a 21st-century supersonic stealth fighter for the Air Force. If the Pentagon gives the go-ahead, the planes are to be assembled here, rather than Burbank, where the prototypes were made. In anticipation, bright yellow tape sets off an acre of empty floor space reserved for the F-22.
Just having the F-22 in Georgia might persuade Congress and the Pentagon to pay for it. "Southerners have traditionally been more pro-defense than people in other parts of the country," said William B. Bullock, a Lockheed vice president.
Fitting this mold, House Speaker Newt Gingrich, who represents Cobb County in Congress, campaigns for the Pentagon to buy Lockheed's planes: the F-22, more P-3's, C-5's and the C-130J, an updated version of the C-130.
Aides to Mr. Gingrich consult regularly with Lockheed officials, according to Allan Lipsett, the Speaker's Georgia press secretary. "I think Mr. Gingrich considers it a good idea for defense contractors to come to the South," he said.
Lockheed's payroll here has remained at 11,000 since 1989, or 3,000 more than would have been the case without the exodus from California, Mr. Bullock estimates. Still, Martha Mossman, who works on the C-130 line, is nervous. In 15 years at the plant, neither she nor her husband, Donald, has ever been laid off from Lockheed. But he recently received a "warning" that this could happen to him in June, costing him a union job that pays $18 an hour, far more than he could earn elsewhere in Georgia.
Without new funds, work is winding down. Only four partly assembled P-3's remain on the line, their unpainted fuselages covered in steel scaffolding, and the C-130 line is also slowing. "We have been doing a lot of traveling," said Mrs. Mossman, ticking off recent tourist excursions to Hawaii and Mexico. "But this year we aren't going anywhere."
Lockheed is Cobb County's largest employer, representing nearly 6 percent of the work force. With so many new companies arriving here, Lockheed's impact on the economy is gradually declining. Still, any cutback would hurt if only because for every Lockheed job, three more exist at subcontractors and suppliers within 100 miles of the plant, Mr. Bullock estimates.
That, too, whittles away at labor costs. The Aidcorp, for example, a machine shop in rural Clayton, Ga., less than two hours away on the new highways, has doubled its employment since 1990 -- to 35 workers -- on the strength of the parts Georgia's military contractors farm out, particularly Lockheed. Its best-paid workers earn only $13 an hour, with nothing for sick days.
For all the growing concentration of military work here, however, the question remains: Will it stay? After all, Lockheed Martin also makes F-16 fighters in Fort Worth, having recently acquired that similarly huge and underused plant from General Dynamics.
"If we don't get orders for the C-130J and the other planes we make here, then we would move to Fort Worth in a wink," Mr. Bullock said. "And if the opposite happens, we could close Fort Worth and move the F-16 here."

HEADLINE: France Threatens to Withdraw Bosnia Force

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY 

DATELINE: PARIS, April 18

 BODY:
France, in the last stages of a presidential election campaign, threatened today to withdraw its 4,530 peacekeeping troops from Bosnia unless its diplomatic partners and the United Nations could insure their safety. The Government also demanded that the belligerents return to the negotiating table and extend a cease-fire set to expire at the end of this month.
A statement issued by Prime Minister Edouard Balladur, struggling to stay in the presidential race until the decisive runoff vote on May 7, said that if the safety of the peacekeepers could not be assured, France "would be forced to decide on a withdrawal of the French soldiers in Bosnia." The statement was issued after a special Cabinet session that was called after the killing of two French soldiers in Sarajevo last weekend. 
 Foreign Minister Alain Juppe flew to New York and asked the United Nations Secretary General, Boutros Boutros-Ghali, for an emergency session of the Security Council to discuss what French officials said was a deteriorating security situation in Bosnia.
"What we are looking for is action by the international community to avert the necessity of a withdrawal, not an excuse to leave," an aide to Mr. Juppe said.
But with some members of Mr. Balladur's conservative Government supporting him in the elections to succeed President Francois Mitterrand next month and others like Mr. Juppe supporting Jacques Chirac, the Mayor of Paris, politicians of all parties seemed intent on sending a message of reassurance to the voters.
At the United Nations headquarters in New York, Mr. Juppe denied that there was any "linkage between the French position on Bosnia and the electoral campaign," adding that French soldiers were being transformed into "hostages."
In a thinly veiled attack on the Bosnian Government, Mr. Juppe said peacekeeping troops in the Balkans were "assassinated, murdered sometimes by the same people they are trying to protect."
On Saturday, French television showed a brief film clip of one of the two French soldiers, wearing the blue helmet of the United Nations force, dying after being hit by snipers' bullets in Sarajevo. But with millions of people relaxing over the three-day holiday weekend, the incident neither transfixed the country nor transformed the election campaign, which has concentrated on domestic economic issues.
Today, with the United Nations saying the sharpshooters could have been from either the Bosnian Government or the Bosnian Serb side, Mr. Balladur's office said France would protest to both the Bosnian and Serbian authorities.
"The continuing degradation of the conditions in which the forces of the United Nations are currently performing their missions seriously endangers the security of the blue helmets, and could eventually call these missions into question," a statement from the Prime Minister's office said.
France, which has lost 33 soldiers in the former Yugoslavia, has repeatedly raised the possibility of withdrawal, most recently after the United States stopped enforcing the arms embargo against the Bosnian Government in November. NATO and the United Nations later drew up contingency plans for a withdrawal of the entire 23,600-member United Nations force from Bosnia after deciding not to use air strikes to halt a Bosnian Serb offensive against the Muslim enclave of Bihac.
Mr. Chirac, who is expected to emerge from the first round of presidential voting on Sunday as the front-runner in the runoff two weeks later, has said a withdrawal of French troops from Bosnia should be considered only as a last resort. On Monday, he called on the United Nations and the NATO alliance to threaten air strikes if the warring parties in Bosnia did not agree to extend their cease-fire.
The Socialist candidate, Lionel Jospin, criticized the Government for talking openly about withdrawal and said it undermined the chances of achieving a negotiated solution.
Jean-Marie Le Pen, the leader of the right-wing National Front, said France should stop being a martyr and pull its troops out of Bosnia before disaster struck. Philippe de Villiers, another rightist candidate, said, "We cannot go on allowing them to be shot at like rabbits."

HEADLINE: WMS to Get Bally Gaming in Stock Swap

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER 

 BODY:
WMS Industries said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire Bally Gaming International Inc., a producer of slot machines and video poker equipment, in a deal valued at about $127 million.
Under a stock exchange agreement, Bally Gaming shareholders will receive six-tenths of a share of WMS stock for each share of Bally Gaming, although the exchange ratio could increase if warranted, the companies said. Based on yesterday's closing stock prices, Bally Gaming stock would be worth about $11.85 a share under the plan 
 Shares of Bally Gaming, which is based in Las Vegas, Nev., rose yesterday by $1.75 a share, to $10.50, in Nasdaq trading. Stock of WMS, which is based in Chicago and also makes gambling machines and coin-operated amusement equipment, fell 37.5 cents, to $19.75, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange.
The stock market's failure to further bid up Bally Gaming stock may reflect a provision in the agreement that gives each company time to conduct a due diligence review before reaching a definitive agreement.
Bruce Turner, a gambling industry analyst with Salomon Brothers, said that he advised clients yesterday to sell their Bally Gaming holdings rather than wait for the deal to be completed.
Mr. Turner said he was concerned about several factors, including declining demand for gambling equipment in North America, licensing issues facing Bally Gaming in Louisiana and WMS's current absence of a license to sell gambling equipment in Nevada.
"It appears that aggregate demand for casino gaming equipment will decline or be flat over the next few years," Mr. Turner said.
The last few months have not been kind to Bally Gaming, which was spun off in 1992 as a free-standing company by the Bally Entertainment Corporation, an operator of casinos and health clubs. Last year, 17 suspected organized crime figures or associates were indicted in New Orleans on Federal racketeering charges that they secretly controlled a Louisiana distributor of video poker machines made by Bally Gaming.
Bally Gaming was described by Federal prosecutors as the "victim" in that scheme. But in January, the president of the Louisiana Economic Development and Gaming Corporation, a regulatory agency, denied Bally Gaming a license to sell gambling equipment to a huge casino in New Orleans, arguing that Bally had allowed itself to become "infiltrated" by organized crime.
That ruling, however, was overturned by the agency's directors, who awarded the company a temporary license. But Bally Gaming officials will still undergo further scrutiny before a final license is issued and gambling regulators in New Jersey and elsewhere have visited Louisiana to collect documents as part of their review of Bally Gaming's activities in that state.
Lou Tavano, a spokesman for Bally Gaming, said that the company believed the Louisiana dispute was resolved and would have no further impact. But Mr. Turner, the analyst, said that if the issue persisted WMS might inherit any problems.
"Those issues just don't disappear if there is any acquisition," he said. "Anytime you have licensing related issues in gaming you need to be careful."

HEADLINE: In Test of School-Voucher Idea, the Sky's Not Falling but Neither Is Manna

BYLINE: By KIMBERLY J. McLARIN 

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE

 BODY:
Five years into the nation's only school-voucher program, most parents say they are satisfied with the plan, which sends their children to private school at state expense, and attendance is up slightly. But academic performance remains about the same for these students as for public school students.
Despite the mixed results, the Governor of Wisconsin, Tommy G. Thompson, a Republican, has announced that he wants to expand the program -- now limited to 1.5 percent of the district's students -- and to allow parochial schools to participate. And from New Jersey to California, there are renewed calls for voucher programs as a check on deteriorating urban public schools. 
 The theory behind vouchers is that competition from private schools will put pressure on public schools to improve and give parents the ability to send their children to whatever school they want. Advocates have predicted that academic performance will soar, while opponents warn that the voucher plan will gut public school systems.
In Milwaukee, neither has happened. The program is so small in scale that it is hard to draw conclusions about whether vouchers are the answer for failing school systems. But this city does offer an interesting laboratory because of the racial tension that pervades the system and makes many black parents distrust the public school district.
For years, vouchers have been among the most provocative proposals for giving parents, particularly those living in troubled urban districts, more choice in their children's schooling. Transfers within districts have long been accepted. And many states, including Wisconsin, are experimenting with autonomous public schools, or charter schools, run by teachers and parents.
But vouchers have been rejected in all three states that have put them to a vote. Last year the Puerto Rico Supreme Court struck down a two-year-old voucher program that included parochial schools. Last week, however, the Ohio House of Representatives passed a voucher bill and sent it to the State Senate.
Milwaukee's 97,000 public school students are mostly black or Hispanic and largely poor. The system remains under a 1976 desegregation order that mandated busing. Most of the teachers and their union's leaders are white, a situation that stirs deep resentment in this largely segregated city. In the current academic year, the system has a budget of $735 million.
The superintendent, Dr. Howard Fuller, who declined to be interviewed for this article, is a former hospital labor organizer and was an administrator at Marquette University. He attended Milwaukee schools and holds a doctorate in education, but has never taught in secondary schools.
Although Dr. Fuller once argued for having a separate black school district, he now maintains close ties with the mostly white business leaders of the city. Both he and business officials believe in less bureaucracy and more autonomy for the schools.
Milwaukee's school system long suffered under the the widespread perception of failure. Forty percent of its students drop out between the 9th and 12th grades -- considerably higher than a district like New York City, which last year reported a dropout rate of 18 percent.
But sprinkled throughout the Milwaukee system are dozens of schools, some specialized, that are regarded as successful. And surveys have shown that most parents are happy with their children's education.
The voucher program overcame court challenges in its first two years -- primarily because of its limited size and narrow structure. The vouchers, worth $3,209 this year, are available only to families with incomes below $25,900 for a family of four, a figure that is 1.75 times the Federal poverty level.
The enrollment limitation means that 1,450 children are eligible. But only 830 children are enrolled this year. The program has never reached its maximum enrollment, in part because there is more demand for seats in elementary schools than are available. Last year 23 percent of the participants left for various reasons. Governor Thompson wants to expand the program to allow 3 percent, or 3,500 students, to participate.
Tuition at the private schools ranges from $1,000 to $3,950. Any participating school has to accept the vouchers as full payment, and if the tuition is lower than $3,209 the school keeps the difference.
Only 12 of the city's 23 private, nonsectarian schools participate in the program. Most that do participate have deliberately limited the number of vouchers they accept, usually far below the 65 percent of enrollment allowed.
Highland Community School, a Montessori program operating in a big Victorian house, has kept its voucher enrollment at just under a third of its 75 students. The school sat out the first two years of the program, worried about becoming dependent on voucher money, possible interference from the state and maintaining racial balance.
"It's been our goal all the time to have a balance, to have an integrated school both economically and racially," said the principal, Tim Souers.
The voucher program has siphoned $2.4 million out of $310 million in state aid. That amount is so small that even officials with the teachers' union, the Milwaukee Teachers Education Association, concede that it has not hurt the schools. But the union did oppose the initial voucher plan, and opposes the Governor's expansion plan.
What the union has supported is a quasi-charter school within the district, overseen by a community board that has broad powers to hire and fire personnel.
"Our members understand that public education as a whole is suffering in this country," said Linda Gaston-Mounger, a spokeswoman for the union. "They have been wanting to try innovations in the classroom in an effort to reach these students. And it's a sincere effort."
Academically, the voucher program's results have been mixed, according to a report made public last December whose principal author was Prof. John Witte of the University of Wisconsin at Madison.
Attendance among voucher students was slightly higher, up 2 percent. The report found great fluctuation in standardized test scores over the four years for both groups. Over all, however, the study concluded that voucher students performed about the same as their counterparts in math and reading -- in some cases, the difference was as little as a one-tenth of 1 percent.
The report and Professor Witte have been sharply criticized by those who support the voucher plan.
State Representative Annette Polly Williams, a Milwaukee Democrat who shepherded the voucher plan through the Wisconsin Legislature, said the findings were unduly negative and did not take into account the positive feedback she said she heard from parents.
Ms. Williams and other proponents assert that by using vouchers, private schools are able to educate children for less than the $7,031 that Milwaukee spends on each of its public school students.
And an audit of the voucher program by the state's Legislative Audit Bureau said Professor Witte's conclusions were too harsh, given the limited data available. "In fact, no conclusion can be drawn," the legislative report said.
But if the academic impact on students is debatable, many of their parents are clearly thrilled and are getting involved -- some schools actually require, and get, parents' volunteer efforts.
Bernadette Williams said that without the voucher program, her two children would be in public schools and she would be worried about them. Instead, Deandre, 7, and Kendra, 5, attend Urban Day School, where Ms. Williams volunteers so much time that many students believe she is a member of the staff.
Urban Day is a 28-year-old school for kindergarten through the eighth grade. Its nearly 600 students must wear uniforms.
"This school is like family to me," Ms. Williams said. "We do have input into whatever's going on."
Tony Higgins took his daughter Chronda out of public school two years ago, when she completed the third grade, and enrolled her in Urban Day after he clashed with her teacher about a series of issues, including the depiction of Christopher Columbus as the discoverer of America. "As African-Americans, we have little say in this system," he said. "There is a lot going on in the public schools that I don't agree with."
Mr. Higgins, now a college student, said he likes being able to walk into the school at any time to speak to his daughter's teacher. "I talk to the teacher four or five times a week," he said.
Some students also say they enjoy the private schools.
Johnish Nuell, 13, said that at her former school she had been suspended so often for talking in class and cursing the teacher that she lost count. At Urban Day she still has occasional disagreements with her teachers. But she also makes the "avid achiever" list, a half-step below honor roll.
"In public schools, the way the teachers teach, they don't keep you focused," she said. "The way they teach you here, they make sure you're focused and that you understand."
Vouchers have been a financial boon for most of the private schools that receive them. When the program began, four of the original seven schools were in serious financial difficulty, according to the Witte report. One went bankrupt and closed in the program's first year.
But another school, Bruce Guadalupe, recently moved from its old, cramped headquarters into a new, $3 million building. Money from the 188 voucher students (out of 356) was a help. Urban Day, with 259 voucher students out of 596, expanded its early childhood program. And Highland Community officials may open a second school.
But even Ms. Williams, the state legislator, is leery of opening the program to parochial schools, as Governor Thompson has proposed in his 1996 budget. She said she feared that the parochial schools would endanger the existing voucher program.
And voucher opponents continue to maintain that the use of vouchers can only lead to the destruction of the public school system. Americans should protect the idea of a public system as one that is constant and guaranteed to all, said Prof. Tony Baez of the University of Wisconsin at Milwaukee, who is a longtime advocate of changing the educational system.
"All this stuff in educational reform can be transitional in nature," he said. "The only thing we have to hang onto, and to hold accountable, are the public schools. But that doesn't mean it has to be a bureaucratic mess."

HEADLINE: City Council Orders Review of 33 Business Improvement Districts

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
The City Council has ordered the 33 business improvement districts in New York City to open their books for an investigation that seeks to determine whether they have amassed too much power without adequate oversight.
The review, called for in a letter to the districts' directors from Herbert Berman, chairman of the council's Finance Committee, seems mainly directed at one of the largest districts, the Grand Central Partnership, which has been the subject of growing scrutiny in recent weeks over allegations of financial wrongdoing and assaults on the homeless. 
 Since the first district was set up more than a decade ago as a means for business owners to clean, patrol and upgrade their neighborhoods, some officials and outside critics have grown uneasy about the power they have amassed as self-governing organizations.
They have broad authority to tax property owners, but while city officials sit on their governing boards, they operate largely outside the realm of government regulation.
"These are quasi-governmental entities, and the time has come to look at whether the rules of government ought to apply to B.I.D.'s," Mr. Berman said.
In an April 6 letter to all the B.I.D.'s, he demanded a broad new review of their books, including their incomes, the salaries their executives receive, and the contracts they sign to perform neighborhood services.
Yesterday, at an unusual meeting of the leaders of 27 of the city's 33 districts, several participants proposed the creation of an association to help govern the districts as a way of pre-empting more restrictive moves by the city. The meeting was closed to the public.
According to several leaders who attended, a chief concern of the district officials was that they distance themselves from the problems facing the Grand Central Partnership and its embattled president, Daniel Biederman. Mr. Biederman also heads the 34th Street Partnership, which covers the area around Madison Square Garden, and the Bryant Park Restoration Corporation.
Mr. Biederman's districts have won wide acclaim for completing extensive improvements in midtown, including the restoration of Bryant Park; providing new street signs and lights, and persuading homeless people to leave Grand Central Terminal.
But he, and particularly the Grand Central district, have also been the subject of harsh scrutiny recently. An outside audit conducted in 1994 found that Mr. Biederman and his staff had devoted time -- and had loaned small amounts of the Partnership's money -- to form a new business improvement district in Jersey City.
Last week, several former employees of a homeless outreach program operated by the partnership said they had been part of a "goon squad" that the partnership had to beat up and forcibly remove homeless people from bank automated teller machine vestibules. Partnership officials have labeled the accusations as "fiction."
Yesterday, Ruth Messinger, the Manhattan borough president, said she would soon seek an emergency meeting of the Grand Central Partnership.
"The purpose is to discuss the recent allegations and the proper role of board members of a quasi-public entity that has substantial authority to dispense what are essentially tax dollars," Ms. Messinger said.
Mr. Biederman did not attend the meeting of district executives yesterday, but sent two of his senior managers in his place. Through a spokesman, Bruce Cohen, he declined comment on the meeting or Mr. Berman's City Council review.
In an interview yesterday, Mr. Berman said his letter had set in motion a process that may lead to City Council hearings on the accountability of the districts and even to recommendations that changes be made in a 1981 law that established their financial structure.
Once a business improvement district is formed, property owners within its boundaries are assessed money by the city, which in turn passes the proceeds back to the districts' managers to pay for their services. But besides approving their annual budgets, the city exercises little oversight.
"When these things got started we thought it best that the city not be intrusive," Mr. Berman said. "Lately we've had a lot of complaints."
Although he declined to elaborate, the complaints referred to by Mr. Berman, and discussed at length at yesterday's meeting have been directly almost entirely against Mr. Biederman's Grand Central Partnership.
The meeting was presided over by Rudy Washington, the city's Commissioner of Business Services, and Barbara Wolf, the assistant commissioner who is the city's principal monitor of the districts' operations.
Although the meeting had been called weeks earlier, before the allegations involving the Grand Central Partnership emerged, Ms. Wolf said the discussion was dominated by questions of how the districts could create better ways to regulate themselves.
"It was a healthy clearing of the air," she said. If the district officials want to create a new organization, or new set of standards, to regulate themselves "we would heartily endorse the idea," she said.
Several of the executives who attended the meeting said the meeting reflected wide agreement that their efforts to improve their neighborhoods may be hurt because of the allegations against the Grand Central Partnership.
Gretchen Dykstra, president of the Times Square Business Improvement District, said most of her colleagues at the meeting agreed on the need for greater self-regulation but would resist more extensive controls by the city.
Nonetheless, she said the recent questions about the Grand Central district reflected a need for the city, through the representatives who sit on the districts' boards, to monitor the affairs of the districts more aggressively.
"This could all have been avoided if the mayor's representatives had stepped up to the bar and demanded more accountability," she said.

HEADLINE: Earnings Results Differ Broadly for Several Big Banks

BYLINE: By SAUL HANSELL 

 BODY:
Volatile trading markets led to strikingly different results among several large banking companies that reported first-quarter earnings yesterday.
Citicorp's profits surged largely because of increased revenue from currency trading, while the Bankers Trust New York Corporation posted a huge loss from its previously disclosed trading problems in emerging markets as well as a charge for a cost-cutting campaign. Chemical Banking had weak trading results, but its cost-cutting efforts helped increase its profits as well. 
 And Banc One, the huge regional banking chain, said earnings were off because of bad bets on interest rates over the last two years.
 Citicorp, the biggest banking company in the country, earned $829 million, or $1.53 a share, in the first quarter, up 50 percent from the quarter a year earlier. In the quarter a year ago, the company took an accounting charge related to retiree benefits. Ignoring the charge, Citicorp's earnings increased 36 percent.
The results surpassed Wall Street expectations of $1.39. Citicorp recorded $85 million in nonrecurring gains from the sale of real estate in emerging markets and restructuring of bank debt in Ecuador.
It also reported unexpectedly strong trading revenue of $344 million, mostly from currency trading, compared with $71 million a year ago. Citicorp is the largest currency dealer in the world and benefited from the increased volume prompted by the slide of the dollar against most leading currencies.
Notably, Citicorp said it broke even on its North American commercial real estate portfolio for the first time since the real estate crisis of the early 1990's. It lost $76 million a year ago.
Citicorp posted a return on equity of 18.8 percent, a relatively high rate of profitability for a commercial bank.
 
 
Chemical Bank
 Profits at Chemical Banking, the country's third-largest banking company, increased 21 percent in the first quarter, to $385 million, or $1.46 a share.The results included an after-tax gain of $51 million from the sale of its interest in a bank in the Philippines. The results exceeded Wall Street's expectations.
 Unlike Citicorp, Chemical said its trading revenue fell sharply to $56 million in the first quarter, compared with $185 million a year go. Chemical said the sharp drop was attributed to price drops in securities from emerging markets and the decline of the dollar against European currencies.
 Chemical's cost-cutting program reduced its overall expenses to $1.25 billion from $1.33 billion in the fourth quarter of 1994.
 
 
Bankers Trust
 Bankers Trust said it lost $157 million in the quarter, mainly because of losses from its derivatives business, compared with earnings of $164 million in the quarter a year earlier.
The loss of $1.22 a share was somewhat better than the $1.67 a share that analysts had expected it to lose.
Bankers Trust said it lost $122 million from selling derivatives to customers, compared with a profit in that area of $114 million in the first quarter last year.
The main source of those losses resulted from the devaluation of the Mexican peso and lack of liquidity for emerging markets securities. Derivatives, specially designed investments linked to the performance of an underlying asset or market, allow customers to speculate on or hedge themselves from the risk of various financial markets. When Bankers Trust sold derivatives based on Mexican pesos, for example, to offset its own risk it would have to trade in the peso every day. When markets are volatile this hedging can be difficult to accomplish.
Bankers Trust also said there had been a decline in demand for the higher-margin derivative products in which it had specialized. As a result of this downturn, the company said it would eliminate 1,000 full-time and 400 part-time jobs -- 10 percent of its total work force -- and would take a $35 million after-tax charge to cover severance costs. This is meant to cut the bank's costs by $200 million in 1995 and $275 million in 1996.
Profits from nearly all of Bankers Trust's other businesses were down sharply.
 
 
Banc One
 Banc One said profits declined 7 percent, to $303 million. The company earned 75 cents a share, about what Wall Street analysts expected.
 Banc One has been suffering because it had locked in low interest rates in 1993 and 1994, largely using derivatives. Because interest rates fell in the first quarter, the bank's unrealized derivative losses declined to $717 million on March 31 from $1.3 billion at the end of 1994. Nonetheless, its interest margin, the rate it earns on loans minus what it pays on deposits fell sharply to 5.33 percent in the first quarter from 6.05 percent a year ago.

HEADLINE: Steinway & Sons Is Sold for $100 Million

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Steinway & Sons, the piano manufacturer that has been a New York institution since its founding by Heinrich E. Steinway in 1853, was sold yesterday for $100 million to the Selmer Company, a maker of musical instruments.
A private company that is probably most famous for its Selmer saxophone, an instrument used by both amateur and professional musicians including President Clinton and Kenny G, Selmer is controlled by two young former Drexel Burnham Lambert investment bankers who purchased their stake in the company in 1993. 
 Under the terms of the transaction, Selmer and Steinway will continue to operate as independent entities, with no changes in management, plant locations, marketing strategy or total employment. Each company employs about 1,000 people.
"We are very excited," said Dana Messina, who along with his partner, Kyle Kirkland, controls Selmer. "We think it is quite an honor to become part of the team with Steinway."
Steinway has been producing concert grand and baby grand pianos for many of the world's most accomplished pianists from its factory in Long Island City, Queens, since shortly after the turn of the century. The sale marks the third time in its illustrious history that Steinway has changed hands.
In 1972, Henry Z. Steinway, the founder's great-grandson, sold the company to CBS for an undisclosed price, ending family control. Then, in 1985, a group of investors led by John P. Birmingham and his brother Robert M. Birmingham, bought Steinway for a price rumored to be in excess of $50 million.
In an interview, John Birmingham said "personal reasons" prompted the group to seek a buyer for Steinway about four months ago.
Without disclosing what his group paid for the company, he said the $100 million sale price "beats inflation by a little bit" over what was paid a decade ago.
Still, people familiar with Steinway and the piano industry's problems, said they were amazed the company fetched that much.
Over the last 10 years, critics have been quick to fault Steinway for what they say is a decline in the quality of its new pianos, which currently sell for as much as $75,800. In addition, the company has had to fight what some contend is a decline in demand, as well as compete with a huge supply of older Steinway pianos
The $100 million price is "an extraordinary number, and does not seem rational," said D. W. Fostle, author of "Steinway Saga," a book about the company to be released by Scribner's on May 1.
According to Mr. Fostle, sales of upright pianos in the United States have fallen since 1988 by more than 40 percent, and show few signs of coming back.
Competing with the huge pool of surviving Steinways is another serious problem.
"It's as if every Ford built since 1903 is still on the road and is as good as a Lincoln Continental," Mr. Fostle said. "There is no way to get rid of those pianos."
In the interview, Mr. Birmingham acknowledged that the piano market in the United States was mature, and that the company's biggest competition was from "our own used pianos." But he said the quality problems had been solved.
In coming years, Mr. Birmingham said the company was likely to find demand from aging baby boomers, as well as foreign markets.
Steinway employs about 500 people in the United States. The company also has a manufacturing plant in Hamburg, Germany. Last year the company had sales of a little more than $100 million.
Selmer, based in Elkhart, Ind., recorded earnings of a little less than $3 million on revenue of $101.1 million last year.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Argentine President Vetoes Patent Measure

BYLINE: By CALVIN SIMS 

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES, April 18

 BODY:
Bowing to pressure from the United States over the protection of intellectual property, President Carlos Saul Menem vetoed a key piece of drug-patent legislation today.
While Argentina currently has no protection for pharmaceutical patents, United States officials say that the legislation would not have adequately protected the patents of American pharmaceutical companies and that it violated provisions of the new world trade agreement. 
 They warned that approval of the law could have led to trade sanctions against Argentina and a loss of foreign investment capital.
Mr. Menem's veto sends the legislation back to the Argentine Congress, where it is expected to be altered to comply with provisions of the trade agreement.
Without such legal protection, drug companies in Argentina are free to infringe foreign patents. The United States pharmaceutical industry contends that it loses as much as $300 million a year in Argentina because of pirating of patents. Drug sales in Argentina are $4.5 billion a year.
At Washington's urging, Argentina, which has laws that protect copyrights, trademarks and the patents of inventions and processes, has been trying for several years to pass a law that would extend such protection to pharmaceutical products.
But more than a dozen drug patent proposals have been blocked or delayed in Congress by opposition from Argentine drug makers and legislators, who maintain that such patent protection would force the local manufacturers out of the market and cause a rise in drug prices.
The proposed patent law has been a political problem for Mr. Menem, who is seeking re-election in May and has had to choose between upsetting opposition politicians, who warned him not to give in to American protests, or to face the possibility of sanctions from Washington.
In the end, he chose to veto the most objectionable parts of the proposed legislation. Mr. Menem said he had vetoed provisions that conflicted with the trade accord, including a requirement that the patent holder manufacture the products in Argentina and that Argentine companies be granted an eight-year grace period when they would pay no royalties for using other companies' inventions.
"If the United States takes this position and Europe as well, what can we do?" Mr. Menem said in support of the veto.
Government officials said the President also feared the effect of trade sanctions on the financial markets here, which have suffered this year in the wake of the Mexican financial crisis.
Jorge Fraccia, executive director of the Argentine Chamber for Specialized Medicines, representing international drug companies that do business in Argentina, said his group was pleased with Mr. Menem's decision to send the legislation back to Congress. "We want to strike an equilibrium between our interests and those of the national industry," he said, "but overall we need the protection of our inventions."
Some of the top American-owned drug makers involved are Schering-Plough S.A.; Abbott Laboratories Argentina; Johnson & Johnson de Argentina; Dow Quimica Argentina, a unit of the Dow Chemical Company; Pfizer S.A., and Cyanamid de Argentina, part of American Home Products.
Pablo Challu, head of a trade group representing local Argentine companies, said that despite Mr. Menem's veto, his group would continue to push for the proposed law. Several legislators said they were building enough support for the two-thirds margin in Congress needed to override the veto.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Treasury Prices Are Mixed As 30-Year Bonds Decline

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
With the exception of some long maturities, prices of Treasury securities rose again yesterday, much as they had on Monday.
A surprising drop in housing starts during March fueled investors' optimism that the economy is slowing and inflation is subdued, but early gains in the credit markets evaporated under mounting concern over the weak dollar and rising commodity prices. 
 Housing starts fell 7.9 percent, to 1.211 million units on an annualized basis, the lowest since March 1993; economists were looking for a rise to 1.36 million units. The report minimized the chance that the Fed will raise interest rates at the next meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee in May.
The soft housing number put the bulls in the market back on track in the short- and intermediate-maturity ranges.
The 30-year bond fell 6/32 , to a price of 10226/32 , to yield 7.39 percent, up from 7.37 percent yesterday. But shorter-maturity bills rates were down an average of three basis points, outperforming the long end of the market for the second straight day.
Long bonds were under pressure from a rise in crude oil prices, which was attributed to the continuing weakness of the dollar; oil is priced in dollars. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the spot contract for May delivery climbed above $20 a barrel.
There was some concern that the housing numbers might not hold up, since the March report could easily be revised, said Anthony Chan, chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio, and that concern might have limited yesterday's gains.
Chris Moore, senior fixed-income analyst at Technical Data in Boston, a financial markets analysis firm, said that he was surprised that the market did not get more lift from the housing starts data, but added that the afternoon retreat resulted from concern over the dollar and rising commodity prices.
Concern over the dollar, Mr. Moore said, was tied to comments by Secretary of Commerce Ronald H. Brown in an interview with CNBC, suggesting that trade sanctions against the Japanese were possible. "Basically it is more and more of the same type of pushing between the two countries," Mr. Moore said. "The auto issue needs an early resolution. We need to see the two countries more amiable towards each other."
Mr. Moore said today's trade balance numbers for February were more likely to remind the market about trade talks between the two countries and weigh against the dollar.
"Essentially the market is very much in a neutral position, and needs to see compelling evidence about the economy" Mr. Moore said, adding that no such data were expected this week. Until that happens, Mr. Moore expects the yield on the long bond to move between 7.27 percent and 7.50 percent.
Yesterday the Fed's vice chairman, Alan S. Blinder, said in a Dow Jones interview that the housing sector was in "downshift," and was not a "disaster." He said he saw signs of slowing "almost across the board" and believes that a soft landing for the economy was a rather plausible outcome. Analysts say this view supports a steady Fed policy outlook for the present.
Municipal bonds were little chaged as investors took on one of the biggest single-day sales of new debt securities this year. States, cities and municipalities brought about $1.6 billion of new debt to market, with the day's largest sale a $325 million offering of Puerto Rico general obligation bonds priced through Lehman Brothers.
Traders noted that because the bonds were exempt from Federal, state and local taxes for all investors, they usually drew strong demand. That enabled underwriters to reprice the issue and lower yields about five basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point.
The bonds are priced to yield a maximum 5.85 percent for an issue due in 2024.
Other long maturities are priced to yield 5.823 percent for an issue due in 2022 and 5.65 percent in 2015. Shorter-maturity serial bonds are offered at prices to yield from 4.05 percent in 1996 to 4.70 percent in 2000; 5.15 percent in 2005; 5.45 percent in 2010, and 5.57 percent in 2013.
