HEADLINE: Allies Split on How to Deal With Serbia Curbs

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, April 19

 BODY:
Days before the Security Council must decide whether to extend a partial suspension of sanctions against Serbia, a dispute over how to deal with the Serbian President, Slobodan Milosevic, is fracturing the five-nation group guiding peace efforts in the Balkans.
Diplomats involved in informal talks on the issue say that the United States and Germany are arguing with Britain, France and Russia over the conditions under which, and for what length of time, Serbia and Montenegro -- the remains of the former Yugoslavia -- should be granted an extension. 
 Some sanctions against Yugoslavia were suspended last September in return for a Serbian promise to cut off strategic goods for Bosnian and Croatian Serbs. But few United Nations officials or diplomats familiar with the region believe that President Milosevic has sealed the borders entirely. A European official commented today that it was well known that arms were still being supplied to Bosnian and Croatian Serbs. News reports from the area have been confirming this almost daily.
Yet United Nations inspectors continue to report that the Serbian Government is meeting its commitment to halt supplies. In return, Serbia and Montenegro have been allowed since last September to operate a few air and sea links to the outside world and take part in international sports and cultural events -- as long as Secretary General Boutros Boutros-Ghali is able to certify every 100 days that President Milosevic is in compliance.
The dispute over the future of sanctions against Serbia and Montenegro did not deter the Security Council today from quickly adopting unanimously a resolution introduced on Tuesday by France calling for more protection for United Nations peacekeepers in Bosnia.
But as the next 100-day deadline on the sanctions exemption approaches on Friday, there has been at least one stormy meeting on this issue, said a diplomat, speaking on condition of anonymity. The United States and Germany want to cut to 45 or even 30 days the length of time between certifications. Britain, France and Russia, a country seen as increasingly more open in support of the Serbs, want to maintain the 100-day period.

HEADLINE: Blue-Chip Stocks Surge; Broader Market Retreats

BYLINE: By LEONARD SLOANE 

 BODY:
Blue-chip stocks surged yesterday to within a point of their all-time high, while the broader market ended lower.
Stocks and bonds were bolstered by a recovery in the dollar, which strengthened after a report showed that the United States trade deficit fell 24.6 percent in February. The Commerce Department report, which was better than economists' expectations, helped push the dollar higher against the Japanese yen and the German mark, and the Dow Jones industrial average followed suit. A stronger dollar makes American securities more attractive to foreign investors. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average rose 28.36 points, to 4,207.49, led by a sharp earnings-driven gain in the shares of Eastman Kodak. The record for the Dow was set last Thursday, when it closed at 4,208.18. But the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 0.45 point, to 504.92.
The Nasdaq composite index, heavy with technology issues, fell 9.19 points, to 816.55. Nearly 454 million shares traded hands on the Nasdaq market yesterday, making it the busiest session ever for the market.
"The Dow has not been giving an accurate portrayal of what the broad market has been doing," said John H. Sahughnessy, senior vice president of Advest Inc. "There's been a mild correction in most share prices. Sometimes you sell on the trumpets."
Blue-chip stocks were also helped by the gain in Treasury bonds. The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose yesterday as its yield, -- which moves in the opposite direction -- fell to 7.36 percent from 7.39 percent on Tuesday. Lower yields tend to make stocks more attractive to investors than bonds.
While the improvement in the dollar bolstered stocks yesterday, the market has also shrugged off sharp declines in the currency in recent months.
"We've had this confounding pattern all year," said Robert H. Stovall, president of Stovall/21st Advisers. "The countries with the strong currencies -- like Switzerland, Japan and Germany -- are having a bad stock market. And we, with the weakest currency among the major countries, are having a good stock market."
Turnover on the New York Stock Exchange was relatively heavy yesterday, with 378.1 million shares changing hands, up from 345.2 million shares the previous day. On the Nasdaq, volume was even stronger, reaching a daily trading record of almost 454 million shares, up 9.3 percent from its previous high of 415.4 million shares set on Oct. 13, 1993.
Declining issues on the New York exchange topped advances by 1,227 to 942. The big news on the Big Board was Kodak, which jumped 4 5/8 to a record high of 57 on a first-quarter earnings report showing an increase of 80 percent. Kodak's stock gain was responsible for almost half of the total advance in the Dow.
A handful of oil issues moved into higher ground, as the futures contract for May delivery of crude oil rose 2 cents, to $20.43 a barrel. Exxon was up 1/2, to 68 1/2 and Amerada Hess was up 5/8, to 50 1/8.
Capital-goods stocks were also strong, benefiting from robust capital spending by industrial companies. Ingersoll-Rand closed at 35 3/8, up 3/4; Caterpillar closed at 57 3/8, up 1; and International Paper closed at 73 7/8, up 1 7/8.
On the other hand, many technology stocks were lower, following some disappointing earnings reports. Bay Networks declined 3 13/16 , to 3311/16 , 3Com fell 1 1/8, to 52 3/4 and Cisco Systems slipped 3/4, to 38 5/8.
Drug stocks also slumped in the day's trading. Merck was off 7/8, to 42 1/8 and Pfizer was off 1 3/4, to 86 5/8. Among the health maintenance organizations, which analysts fear will suffer a margin squeeze, U.S. Healthcare led the falloff, sinking 6 1/2, to 33 1/4.
United Healthcare declined 4 1/4, to 39 3/8 and was the third most actively-traded stock. Humana closed at 21 7/8, down 2 3/4; Coventry closed at 24 3/8, down 3 1/8; and Oxford Health closed at 46 5/8, down 7 5/8.

HEADLINE: New Proposal for Coliseum: Use It to Hold Conventions

BYLINE: By SHAWN G. KENNEDY 

 BODY:
More than a decade after the city put the New York Coliseum in mothballs, setting off an often bitter series of negotiations over selling it to Mortimer B. Zuckerman, city officials now say the best thing to do for the time being is to use it as it was originally intended: a convention center.
Although officials say they still ultimately want the site redeveloped along the lines that Mr. Zuckerman proposed, they say the city and the Coliseum's owner, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, could make the most money in the short term with a convention center that would draw out-of-town visitors and their money. 
 City economists, who have been studying the issue for about six months, estimated that $30 million in taxes and 10,000 jobs would come to the city through a successful convention center at the Coliseum.
John S. Dyson, Deputy Mayor for Finance and Economic Development, said those figures were based on an assumption that at least 50 percent of the shows and events would be tailored for out-of-town visitors who would stay in hotels, eat in restaurants and shop in city stores.
In addition, the economists concluded that 500 to 1,000 jobs would be created for renovating the building, which has been largely vacant for more than a decade.
Since last July, when a plan by Mr. Zuckerman to build an office, retail and residential complex on the site fell through, city officials and members of the M.T.A. board have feuded over what to do with the site.
The board has been pushing to lease the building for 10 years or more in order to raise quick revenue, and has fielded offers for a television studio and retail stores.
But aides to Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, hoping to find a developer like Mr. Zuckerman to build a large, new complex, have urged the agency to go slow and not lock itself into a long-term lease.
The convention center idea, Mr. Dyson said, would be the best way to maximize income while awaiting a full-scale development proposal. "When we compared a convention center use for the exhibition hall with use as a television studio, high-end retail and other uses that have been proposed," said Mr. Dyson, "we concluded that it was the best use for the goal of generating jobs and revenue."
Although the transportation agency did not take a formal position, several board members called the proposal a good start and a hopeful sign the impasse could be broken.
"I'm not going to be smart enough to say that a convention center would be better or worse than other proposals," said Peter S. Kalikow, a real estate developer and M.T.A. board member. "But if we can get what we need, a way to generate revenue for the M.T.A., I don't think anyone here would be against it." In recent months Mr. Kalikow criticized the Giuliani administration over the amount of time it was taking to complete the study.
Mr. Dyson said the plan would have to be set up so that it did not drain business from the the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, the city's main convention site, whose completion in 1986 allowed the city to close down the smaller Coliseum.
Mr. Dyson said the economic analysis, which was prepared by the Economic Development Corporation, showed that the city needed more convention space and was losing business to other cities, like Chicago and Toronto, that have more convention space than New York City does.
Mr. Dyson conceded that the convention center use would generate only about $1.7 million in annual tax revenue for the M.T.A. but he said emphatically that the city was prepared to negotiate some sort of plan to share tax revenue with the transportation agency that would increase that amount.
But the revenues will not come until the city and M.T.A. spend money to upgrade the Coliseum. The study said the minimum cost would be $33.7 million, while a full-scale overhaul would cost $121 million. The study did not address who would pay for it.
Mr. Dyson, who holds a seat on the M.T.A. board, said that the city still favored a sale or redevelopment project that would include the entire site, but that by making its proposal, the city was living up to its agreement to submit to the M.T.A. its recommendation for some sort of interim use.
Mr. Dyson said yesterday that the convention center plan could include leasing the exhibition hall, and that the city might make the lease contingent on the operator's taking 50 percent of its bookings for events aimed at out-of-town visitors.
According to the economic analysis, out-of-town visitors to a convention or trade show spend, on average, $328 per day, while local visitors spend only $53 per day.
The report also said that while other cities were expanding their convention center space, New York City had been turning away potential convention business.

HEADLINE: Max H. Karl, 85, Pioneer in Mortgage Insurance

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT 

 BODY:
Max H. Karl, a lawyer who invented the modern form of private mortgage insurance, helping to put home ownership within reach for millions of families, died in his sleep yesterday at the Baptist Hospital in Miami. He was 85 and had retired to Miami.
He died of complications after heart surgery, his family said. 
 In the 1950's, Mr. Karl became frustrated with the time and paperwork required to obtain a home backed by Federal Government insurance, the only kind available at the time. In 1957, using $250,000 raised from friends and other investors in his hometown of Milwaukee, Mr. Karl founded the Mortgage Guarantee Insurance Corporation.
Unlike many mortgage insurers who collapsed during the Depression, Mortgage Guarantee would only insure the first 20 percent of loss on a defaulted mortgage, thus limiting its exposure and creating more incentives for savings and loan associations and other lenders to issue loans only to home buyers who could afford them.
The guarantee was enough to encourage lenders across the country to issue mortgage loans to buyers whose down payments were less than 20 percent of the home's price. The availability of credit helped fuel the home building boom of the 1960's and 1970's. Today, more than 12 percent of the nation's nearly $4 trillion in home mortgages have private mortgage insurance.
"Max had faith that young people would pay for their homes, and he was proven right," said Leon T. Kendall, an executive at the company from 1974 through 1990.
The success of Mortgage Guarantee, known as "magic" or M.G.I.C., allowed Mr. Karl to expand into other businesses. In addition to being the chief executive of Mortgage Guarantee, he founded the first municipal bond insurance company, now called Ambac.
Mr. Karl's quest for a special Internal Revenue Service ruling to exempt some company reserves from taxation made him a small figure in the investigation into influence peddling by Robert G. (Bobby) Baker, the former secretary to the Democratic majority in the Senate. Investigations into Mr. Baker's affairs found that in 1963 he bought 6,000 shares of Mortgage Guarantee stock with the help of a Texas banker shortly before the I.R.S. reversed an earlier policy and granted Mr. Karl the ruling he wanted.
Mr. Karl, who was never accused of any wrongdoing, told a Senate committee that Mr. Baker's first purchase of company stock was in 1959, when shares were for sale only to Wisconsin residents.
Growth of the mortgage insurance business accelerated after 1970, when a Federal housing law said that two Federal agencies, the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, could buy mortgages not guaranteed by the Government if they were privately insured.
M.G.I.C.'s fortunes took a turn for the worse after 1982 when Mr. Karl agreed to sell the company to Baldwin United, a fast-growing insurance company that failed the next year. In the scramble to find money to pay for Baldwin United's obligations, the M.G.I.C. that Mr. Karl founded was liquidated, and a new company bearing the same name was created in 1985 with start-up money from managers who included Mr. Karl and from the Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company. Mr. Karl helped rebuild the new company and retired at the end of 1989.
Before founding Mortgage Guarantee, Mr. Karl practiced law in Milwaukee from 1933 to 1957. A native of Milwaukee, he graduated from the University of Wisconsin with degrees in economics and law.
He is survived by his wife, Anita Davis; two sons, Robert and Kenneth; a daughter, Karyn Karl Schwade, and nine grandchildren.

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
Caterpillar Profit Jumps 56.3%, Beating the Analysts' Consensus

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., April 19

 BODY:
Extending its string of record earnings into the fifth consecutive quarter, Caterpillar Inc. reported today that net income rose 56.3 percent in the first quarter, lifted by strong demand for its products.
The maker of construction and farm equipment said net income increased to $300 million, or $1.50 a share, in the first quarter, from $192 million, or 94 cents a share, in the comparable period a year earlier. The results were adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split and exceeded the mean earnings estimate of $1.27 a share, based on a survey of 19 analysts by Zacks Investment Research. 
 Revenue rose 19.1 percent, to $3.91 billion from $3.29 billion. The volume of machinery and diesel engine sales rose 15 percent, Caterpillar said.
Caterpillar's shares rose $1, to $57.375, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Sales and earnings rose even though about 9,000 members of the United Auto Workers union remained on strike at eight of the company's factories in Illinois, Pennsylvania and Colorado. The strike started last June 21, when more then 14,000 members of the United Automobile Workers walked off the job, protesting what they called unfair labor practices. The company contends the walkout is over economic issues such as wages and benefits.
Caterpillar said its outlook for sales and profit for 1995 remained unchanged from the forecast it made in January. The company expects improved growth in Europe, Japan, other parts of Asia and the Middle East to offset a worse-than-expected slump in Mexico and other parts of Latin America. Demand in the United States is expected to be near 1994 levels.
Still, Caterpillar said, the dollar's plunge against such currencies as the Japanese yen and the German mark poses "certain risks" for the economic outlook.

HEADLINE: Preparing Students For the World Of Jobs

BYLINE: By Hedrick Smith; Hedrick Smith is author of a forthcoming book, "Rethinking America: A New Game Plan from the American Innovators -- Schools, Business, People, Work."

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The pressures of global competition have spawned a variety of successful experiments in rethinking how to educate the neglected majority of our high school students -- the 70 percent who will not finish four years of college.
Rethinking means new curriculums, new teaching methods, a new joining of academic skills and jobs skills and of classroom learning and work-site learning. 
 It means benchmarking America against the world's best systems and forging more partnerships between schools and business.
With notable successes in hand, the educational challenge today is to capitalize on our best models, to disseminate the best ideas of America's innovators and replicate them nationwide.
That effort was put on track by the last Congress, but it is in danger of being derailed by indiscriminate budget-cutting and block-grant fever in the new Congress.
That would be a major mistake. Reflect on John Torinus, a smart entrepreneur who runs Serigraph Inc., a high-tech graphics and printing business in West Bend, Wis. Mr. Torinus has his eye on markets in Japan, Brazil, the Mexican industrial corridor, on customers such as Toyota and Nippondenso as well as Buick and Black & Decker.
Five years ago, Mr. Torinus was in despair. Like many employers, he could not find qualified workers coming out of local high schools. "We had illiterates," Mr. Torinus says, "people who couldn't read blueprints, people who couldn't do simple decimals."
"If you want to meet the quality standards you need in international competition today," he insists, "you've got to have trained people -- very well trained."
In 1991, after seeing Germany's dual education system, Mr. Torinus was ready to gamble on something new -- bringing the German system to Wisconsin. The experiment would take average high school kids -- those turned off by school and itching to get into the work world. It was not aimed at dropouts or those bound for college.
In tandem with West Bend High School and with a former Wisconsin State School Superintendent, Bert Grover, and others, Mr. Torinus and the national association of printers helped devise a world-standard curriculum, tying together academic skills and job skills -- a system in which teen-agers would study part-time and work part-time, and receive pay for their work.
In 1992, Mr. Torinus's company took 11 high school apprentices into the two-year program, 8 more the next year, 10 more the third year, each at a cost of $3,600 a year.
The results were astounding. Mediocre students started making the dean's list. After they graduated, Mr. Torinus hired every young apprentice he could, but several apprentices, inspired by the combination of work and study, wanted to go to college.
The Wisconsin experiment has spread to other fields: insurance, banking, health, auto technology, electronics, biotechnology, engineering technology, tourism and manufacturing. First, two communities tried this approach; now it's in 30.
But it takes time and money to rewrite curriculums, retrain teachers, involve business, train industry mentors and set high standards.
And it takes seed capital to move from a few successful demonstrations to a nationwide system -- not for all students but for enough to provide the backbone of the future workforce.
So last year, Congress passed the School to Work Act, authorizing $250 million a year for seven years to develop this whole new approach to higher education. States had to compete for this Federal venture capital.
The first grants were awarded to Maine, Massachusetts, New York, New Jersey, Kentucky, Michigan, Wisconsin and Oregon. In addition, 36 local areas -- some middle class, some poor, some rural, some urban -- received startup money.
The amounts were modest, a few million dollars per state. But it was enough to spur communities into action and to attract more funds from states, local governments and businesses.
Another 20 states are due to get similar seed money this year; this will encourage innovative reforms that promise handsome dividends not only for students but for industry, which spends $30 billion a year on remedial education.
But those new grants may never be made. This fragile effort to make American education more globally competitive is threatened by the block-grant, budget-cutting mindset on Capitol Hill.
In its first 100 days, the House knocked $25 million out of the school to work reform plan for 1995 (the Senate cut $5 million and the two chambers must now reconcile the difference).
More serious cutting is threatened for 1996 during the second 100 days. John Kasich, chairman of the House Budget Committee, wants to lump all training into one block grant -- adult, youth, basic literacy and personal rehabilitation.
There is good reason to fear that under block grants, the fledgling school-to-work program will be devoured by larger, entrenched state bureaucracies committed to old programs. Block grants encourage governors to channel money in old ways. The inertia of the old mindset is to stick with old educational methods and to keep education and business separate.
A block grant is a crude instrument of reform. By lumping an intelligent and workable new program in with old programs that have not been effective, block grants risk suffocating a promising initiative in its infancy.
Rethinking education means not only rethinking how schools teach but how Congress legislates. In its zeal to trim the budget and devolve programs to the states, Congress is indiscriminately risking an innovative idea that could bring lasting benefits to America's economy and its children.

HEADLINE: U.S. Wealth Gap Is Also a Vietnam War Legacy

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your timely April 17 article on wealth inequality in the United States ("Gap in Wealth in U.S. Called Widest in West," front page), closely following publication of Robert McNamara's book "In Retrospect: The Tragedy and Lessons of Vietnam," prompts me to offer my opinion on the origin of the undesirable trend of extreme wealth inequality in the United States. 
 In all the publicity that has accompanied Mr. McNamara's book, practically the only mention I've noted of the economic consequences of the Vietnam War was in your April 13 book review: "And McNamara faults President Johnson for failing to be more forthright with the American public about the growing expense of the war."
This understates the facts substantially! Lyndon Johnson deliberately lied to Congress and the American people and escalated the war by stealth, ignoring the warning of his advisers that the result of a failure to raise taxes to finance the war would be a dangerous increase in inflation. Prior to the escalation of the war the United States economy of the early 1960's was a practically utopian equilibrium combination of solid growth without inflation.
Johnson's policy set the stage for and began the inflation of the 1970's, which was made worse by the irrational economic policies of President Nixon and the unsound ones of Jimmy Carter. The dollar lost nearly half its purchasing power in the 1970's. This resulted in massive shifts of wealth toward upper-income groups, who are the owners of businesses and property. The real income of the lowest 20 percent income class declined substantially, while before 1967, income distribution among classes had been very stable.
I am of the strong belief that the trend to extreme wealth inequality in the United States has its origin in President Johnson's failure to finance the Vietnam War with a tax increase and that this result is one of the most serious enduring consequences of the ill-conceived Vietnam War.
 
NEIL NAFTALIN
Minneapolis, April 17, 1995
 
The writer is a stock market analyst.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Brazil's Chief, In U.S., Says He'll Insist on Key Reforms

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

 BODY:
In a speech that points to the growing importance of foreign investment for Brazil, President Fernando Henrique Cardoso pledged yesterday that his country would not abandon steps toward legal reform and open markets, and he predicted that initial changes in the Constitution would be approved by the Brazilian Congress in three to four months -- much sooner than expected.
"Our Congress will discuss, change as it should, but our Congress will ultimately approve the measures that our country requires," he said. Mr. Cardoso, who took office in January after winning 54 percent of the votes, said Congress would "reflect public opinion" in approving his initiatives. 
 His proposals are considered crucial in opening Latin America's largest market, a country roughly the area of the continental United States with a population of more than 150 million, to foreign investment. Brazil is expected to spend about $70 billion developing its basic facilities and services in coming years, and is privatizing vast state enterprises and granting concessions to foreign investors in an effort to draw medium- and long-term capital.
Mr. Cardoso appeared at a lunch of the Brazilian-American Chamber of Commerce in Manhattan as part of his first state visit to the United States. In his speech, he reaffirmed his country's pledge to privatize the choicest of its national holdings, the telecommunications and oil industries, and, more important, to change laws that give preference to domestic companies in the competition for mining and other rights.
Brazil's newest currency, the real, was introduced by the preceding Government last July to stem rampant inflation. To maintain the real's strength, the Cardoso Government is seeking to make changes in constitutional, tax and social security policies, along with continuing to seek foreign capital.
Mr. Cardoso said yesterday that Brazilian states would be required to provide specific services in return for the federal money they receive. Otherwise, they could lose the revenue.
Bankers and investors said after his speech that they were impressed by his command of the situation in Brazil, though they had heard little that induced them to relax their caution.
"He was prepared to get into details, to say how many companies will be privatized this year, how long it will take," said Geoffrey Dennis, senior managing director for emerging-markets research at Bear, Stearns & Company. "It enabled us to put some markers down in the sand that we can measure him by."
Mr. Dennis said that he did not expect that the Brazilian Congress to enact major legislative changes by September, but that Mr. Cardoso could still make good on his word. "He can begin to make significant progress, and that's all that people will need to see," Mr. Dennis said.
More important than any specific statement the visiting President made, however, was his decision to appear in New York, particularly before continuing on to Washington. Speaking to investors first, and not seeking financial help during the trip from the United States or from international financial institutions, they said, signaled Brazil's determination to be seen as a potentially lucrative market.
"The very fact that you have a Brazilian President getting up and addressing the investment community, that's a major indication of how far Brazil has come," said Francisco Gros, chairman of Morgan Stanley Latin America.
Stephen E. Hluchan, treasurer of Minerals Technologies Inc., said the President's optimism and determination were persuasive, if inconclusive. "I think we're still in the mode of anticipation of what will happen," he said.

Mr. Cardoso, who took office in January, is on his first state visit to the United States. (Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times)

HEADLINE: YACHT RACING;
Dellenbaugh Chases a Miracle

BYLINE: By BARBARA LLOYD 

DATELINE: SAN DIEGO, April 19

 BODY:
What yachtsman with a yen to win wouldn't want to compete on one of the quickest, slickest, most talked-about sailboats in the world? And what if his crew -- an eager but relatively inexperienced group of female athletes -- were in close pursuit of the most sought-after prize in yachting?
Such were his prospects a month ago today when David Dellenbaugh became the tactician on Mighty Mary. The team was being billed as the first all-women's crew to compete in the 144-year history of the America's Cup. But when Dellenbaugh went on board, he changed all that. 
 "I basically went into this saying I wanted to impact this as little as possible," Dellenbaugh said during an interview here. "I told the team to do it the way they've been doing it, and I will fall into the cracks. My job is allowing everybody else to do their job as best they can."
As the only man on the syndicate's 75-foot yacht, Mighty Mary, Dellenbaugh was destined to become either a savior or a misfit. As it turns out, he's looking more each day like a man chasing a miracle.
By winning a race Monday against Stars & Stripes, the now "mostly" women's crew on Mighty Mary upstaged a veteran team led by Dennis Conner. But today, after being in a three-way tie for the lead, Mighty Mary lost to Young America. "I think we have as much chance as anybody to defend the America's Cup," Dellenbaugh said while preparing for today's race.
Anything can happen now. Mighty Mary has three more matches in the 12-race round-robin Citizen Cup finals. Including the semifinals, Dellenbaugh has guided the team through 15 races, 8 of which they have lost.
The team has had its trying times, such as in the semifinals race against Stars & Stripes when a wrong call from the foredeck caused Mighty Mary to go over the start line too early and have to re-round. Dellenbaugh, who steers at the starts, depended on perfect timing.
He is said to be frustrated on occasion by the women's lack of experience. But as their former coach, he knew that most of them are small boat sailors, or in the case of the grinders, not sailors at all. Only one, Dawn Riley, has ever competed in an America's Cup before. Without him on board, it's unlikely the women would have a chance at all.
Dellenbaugh's appointment by Bill Koch, the America<3> syndicate's founder and primary benefactor, came as a surprise to all but four of the 28 women. Unexpected and hastily planned, the change crushed any hope that an all-women's team could break the tradition of male domination over yachting's oldest trophy. While some of the women appeared disillusioned, others embraced the idea.
"The bottom line is, being new to the sport, you've got to see where your assets are," said Stephanie Maxwell-Pierson, a grinder on Mighty Mary who is an Olympic bronze medalist in rowing. "You find the talent and skill you need and take the next step."
Koch said the women proved that handling such a big boat wasn't a strength issue. But they needed more advice on tactics and starting sequences. Dellenbaugh, who had steered Koch's victorious America<3> in the 1992 cup races, seemed like the perfect candidate.
The 41-year-old Dellenbaugh is a homebody, a family man from Easton, Conn., who often races in local regattas on Long Island Sound with his wife, Susan, and increasingly, with his two young children, Rebecca, 6, and Emily, 4, on board.
Dellenbaugh practically grew up on sailboats, but it was a long way from gunkholing around his family home in Fairfield, Conn., to making it into the world-class ranks of sailing. After 1970's detours to Cornell for a degree in economics and night school at Boston State College for a master's in elementary education, his yachting breakthrough came in 1983. He was invited by Dave Perry, a top East Coast match-racer and rules expert, to compete in the Congressional Cup regatta in Long Beach, Calif. By 1986, Dellenbaugh was good enough to skipper his own boat, and finish in the top three.
His entry into America's Cup racing came through Buddy Melges, an Olympic medalist and America's Cup trials skipper in 1986. Through Melges, Dellenbaugh started sailing on Koch's 1992 cup team, which ultimately defended the cup against Italy. "I think Dave is the perfect catalyst to jell the women's team," Melges said recently. "He's probably one of the most tactful guys I know, so calm, so cool. That may be just what the women needed."
Dellenbaugh's association with the team began in August 1993 when the all-female idea was taking shape. Dellenbaugh said he would not have taken the job as tactician unless convinced that women wanted him to do it.
"How I personally feel about the idea is not important," Dellenbaugh said. "In my mind, if they feel it should happen, it's a good idea. And I feel almost all of them wanted it to happen."

GRAPHIC: Photo: David Dellenbaugh steering Mighty Mary into starting spot before race against Young America yesterday in America's Cup defender finals. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: BOXING;
Foreman Setting Sights Beyond Schulz

BYLINE: By TOM FRIEND 

DATELINE: LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 19

 BODY:
He is of the coffee generation. George Foreman skips rope, chops wood, slaps a 100-pound bag and drinks two cups a day, caffeinated. This heavyweight champion of the world is not only old enough to be his next opponent's father, but he also woke up two months ago a grandfather.
"I was in denial," he said. "People were asking me, 'George, you're a grandfather?' and I was like, 'Nope.' " 
 He is considered in the twilight of his career, but, at age 46, it is long past twilight and the street lamps are on. He is expected to fight only three more times before permanently hitting the highway in his brand new Greyhound bus. The question is whether Mike Tyson will land on his itinerary.
"To be honest with you, it'd be wrong for Mike Tyson to get out of jail and fight me right now," Foreman said today. "It'd be taking advantage of him. I'm too old for him. Ha, ha, got you."
In all honesty, Foreman wants Tyson tomorrow for $100 million -- with a straight-up, 50-50 split -- but Tyson is hiding under a rock, according to the Foreman camp.
"The toughest man on the planet is afraid of a guy who's older than dirt," said Foreman, who has starved himself and seems trim. "You can say, 'Yeah, but he's been out three years.' Can say anything you want. But I was out for 10 years and I came back screaming and begging for it. I had a great big old stomach; I'd sit down and couldn't get up."
So, because Tyson's version of a workout has been buying five BMWs and a home -- "I'm hearing good things about him lately; he's been contributing to the economy of Nevada," the champion said -- Foreman was forced to search overseas for an opponent. He reeled one in -- Axel Schulz, a 26-year old German with a crewcut. Schulz is here with a 21-1-1 record (10 knockouts), with an interpreter and with little chance of upsetting Foreman (73-4) on Saturday night at the MGM Grand's Garden Arena.
"A guy asked me, 'George, how can you fight a guy who's not even rated?' " Foreman said. "And I said, 'Tyson isn't rated either.' "
It is expected to be more a pep rally than an International Boxing Federation championship fight. After all, this is Foreman's first title defense since he unplugged Michael Moorer last Nov. 5. So much has happened since: Home Box Office purchased the rights to the Schulz fight for a record $9 million, Foreman turned 46 and the rest of the boxing world -- other than Tyson -- queued up to take his belt.
"Who doesn't want George?" said 40-something James (Bonecrusher) Smith. "Actually, I wish George would forget about fighting Tyson and fight only people over 40. Like golf, we could have a seniors tour. George is the perfect guy to start it; he's already champ."
Foreman, after sucking down a last-minute cup of coffee today, maintained at his news conference that he does not fight for the money -- although his purse Saturday night is $10 million, compared with Schulz's $350,000. He fights, he said, for the people who tug at his sleeve, who pat him on his stomach. Today, alone, he was asked to autograph a 20-year-old Ali-Foreman poster and a ticket from a Sonny Liston fight.
"Believe it or not, I was on the undercard that day," he said.
Each fight is his opportunity to brag about his age, and today he was asked what he wants to be remembered for.
"That I paid out every child support payment," he said, a survivor of four divorces. "The last one is 18 years old; I got no more child support payments. I did it!"
His life as a preacher means much to him, too, and his sermon at a local church was well-received last Sunday. After his last fight next November, he will ride off into the sunset in that bus of his.
"I told my wife as soon as I got the money, I'd buy this big old Greyhound bus and travel around the country preaching," he said. "These buses cost like $700,000. She looked at the account the other day, and she said, 'You know, you have enough money to buy the bus, George.' I said, 'But, but, but,' and she said, 'You've got enough to buy the bus.' So I've got to travel around the country as a preacher. It'll take me another 10 years. Then, I'm going to come back and take on all comers. Don't laugh; I did before."
He can manipulate, too; his slur campaign against Tyson is designed to lure Tyson in the ring. And Foreman laughed at the MGM's idea of building a Tyson statue. "Mike Tyson is a guy worthy of a statue built," he said, "and it should be inside where the pigeons can't get to it."
Nevertheless, Foreman's promotor, Bob Arum, said that Foreman would fight a European next July and then close out against either Moorer, Riddick Bowe or Tyson. "But the chances of Tyson are nil," Arum said. "They know George will kill him. They'd rather put him in with stiff-a-roni's."
If Tyson eludes him, though, Foreman will not lament.
"You realize I've been boxing 30 years?" he said. "I've been boxing, boxing, boxing. The sport's scary, makes you nervous, but I love it. Shame on me."

HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
BANKAMERICA CORP. (BAC,N)

BYLINE: Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
The BankAmerica Corporation said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose about 19 percent, as a stronger economy prompted consumers and companies to borrow more.
BankAmerica, the banking company based in San Francisco, said net income rose to $611 million, or $1.46 a share, compared with $513 million, or $1.27 a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier. 
 Earnings exceeded Wall Street's expectations of $1.43 a share, based on a survey of 23 analysts by IBES International Inc.
"BankAmerica is doing better than the average bank in an environment where revenue growth has been relatively hard to come by," said Carole Berger of Salomon Brothers. She said the acquisition of the Continental Bank Corporation of Chicago also contributed to higher earnings.
In the first quarter, net interest income rose to $2.05 billion, from $1.8 billion in the corresponding period a year earlier. Much of the gain reflected an increase in loans outstanding. Loans totaled $144.2 billion, up from $123.5 billion a year earlier.
The provision for credit losses was reduced to $100 million from $125 million. Reducing the provision leaves more money for the bottom line.
The net interest margin -- the spread between the amount a bank earns on its loans and the amount it pays in interest on deposits -- widened, to 4.55 percent, from 4.45 percent a year earlier. (Bloomberg Business News)

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Prices for Bonds Are Mixed As the Dollar Steadies Itself

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities were mixed yesterday as the dollar steadied.
The price of the 30-year bond rose 16/32 , to 1036/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from its price, fell to 7.36 percent, from 7.39 percent on Tuesday. Prices for Treasury bills and notes were mostly lower. 
 While the dollar's firming helped bolster bonds yesterday, there was concern that a sustained recovery in the dollar could dampen demand for Treasury bills and notes.
The recovery of the dollar came after the Commerce Department reported that the United States trade deficit in goods and services narrowed by 24.6 percent, to $9.01 billion in February, which was much lower than expected.
Rosanne M. Cahn, chief economist, equity research department at the CS First Boston Corporation, said that the improvement in the February trade figures might give the dollar a temporary bounce. But she cautioned that the improvement was "largely a result of temporary special factors."
"A drop in imports, especially autos, reflected the cyclical softening of the economy, and a rebound in aircraft exports were major contributors," she said.
The dollar's overnight move to new lows against the Japanese yen was offset by the weaker-than-expected trade number, according to Gary R. Thayer, senior economist with A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis. For the dollar to remain strong over the long term, he said, the United States would need to make a clear move to reduce the budget deficit or Japan would have to open its markets.
"As long as the weak dollar is not having an impact on the domestic economy the Fed will be able to maintain its steady policy," Mr. Thayer said. "If down the road the weak dollar leads to higher commodity prices, the Fed may be backed into a corner and raise interest rates again. So long as there is no spike in commodity prices, we may see the yield on the long bond continue in its recent trading range.
"The Fed's been lucky so far that the decline of the dollar has come at a period when other commodity prices have come down because of the soft economy."
Today's survey of regional business activity by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia should have little impact on the market, traders said. A moderate report is expected.
In other trading, municipal bond prices fell as some investors began to balk at some new debt sales, saying they were too expensive when compared with other fixed-income securities.
The average yield to first call of the Bond Buyer's municipal bond index of 40 actively traded issues rose 2 basis points, to 6.22 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
In the corporate bond market, bank debt offerings were viewed favorably because of good first-quarter earnings reports, as the Nationsbank Corporation and the Chase Manhattan Corporation came to market with $450 million of new bonds.
Another bank, the Old Kent Bank and Trust Company of Grand Rapids, Mich., a unit of the Old Kent Financial Corporation, also sold bonds yesterday. The Japan Finance Corporation for Municipal Enterprises sold $300 million of notes, in the first deal in four years by the Japanese Government's guaranteed borrower.
According to Merrill Lynch, which managed the issue, the American notes, which carry an interest rate of 7.375 percent and are due in 2005, were priced at 99.95 to yield 7.382 percent, or about 33 basis points more than the 10-year Treasury note. The issue is noncallable and rated triple-A by Moody's Investors Service and the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Signs of an Economic Slowdown Send Price of Copper Plunging

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Copper prices fell sharply yesterday as continuing signs of an economic slowdown weighed down the market.
Recent reports of weakness in housing and industrial production point to reduced demand from manufacturers, deflating expectations of increasing consumption that drove copper prices higher in January. 
 On other commodity markets, crude oil rose to its highest price in more than seven months while wheat prices fell. The Commodity Research Bureau index dropped five-hundredths of a point, to 236.82.
The expected drop in demand for copper from manufacturers comes just as producers are expanding output. Western copper production is expected to grow by 1.12 million tons, or 5.4 percent, this year, led by expansions in Chile, the United States and Canada, according to Resource Strategies, a consultant on metals.
"The robust manufacturing expansion is now clearly in question," said Richard Hirsch, vice president with Deutsche Sharps Pixley Metals Inc. in New York. "The weight of the negative figures is becoming too awesome to ignore."
The Commerce Department reported on Tuesday that new housing starts fell in March to their lowest rate in two years. Building and construction are the largest sources of demand for copper, accounting for about 40 percent of all copper used in the United States. And on Friday, the Federal Reserve said industrial production showed its first decline in six months, as high interest rates weakened demand for autos and home appliances, two other prime sources of copper consumption.
Copper for May delivery fell 5.3 cents, to $1.294 a pound, on the Commodity Exchange of New York, the lowest for an active contract since March 1. Copper reached $1.427 a pound on Jan. 19, the highest level in almost six years.
Crude oil staged a late-day rally as demand increased from refineries that have stepped up production of gasoline.
Last week, gasoline production rose by 357,000 barrels a day, or 4.7 percent, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Refineries are increasing their gasoline output to build stockpiles in anticipation of strong demand this summer and also to capture profit margins that are at their highest in weeks.
The May crude oil contract, which expires today, gained 36 cents, to $20.41 a barrel, the highest price for crude since Aug. 1. Expectations of increased production pushed gasoline prices down, traders said. Unleaded gasoline for May delivery fell 0.54 cent, to 63.15 cents a gallon.
Wheat prices fell amid forecasts for rain in the southern Plains states, where the developing hard red winter wheat crop needs moisture after an unusually dry spring.
At the Kansas City Board of Trade, hard red winter wheat for July delivery, representing the crop now in the ground, fell 3.25 cents, to $3.5375 a bushel.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Russian obstacles: disgruntled farmers and the new cartels.

BYLINE: By Peter Passell 

 BODY:
IS Russia poised for economic takeoff? After three years of on-again, off-again reforms and with the Pyrrhic military victory in Chechnya still fresh in the news, skepticism comes easily. But little by little, wary analysts are abandoning their caution. "Russia is a real market economy now," says Andrei Shleifer, an economist at Harvard who has advised the Russian Government on privatization.
That doesn't mean the path to affluence is strewn with rose petals. A big test of Moscow's political will to contain inflation looms this summer, when the 30 million Russians who still scratch a living from the soil demand a budget-busting round of subsidies to finance the harvest. The more fundamental challenge -- one the Government will no doubt face for years to come -- is the taming of the private cartels that are replacing public monopolies. "You can't sustain an efficient, continent-wide economy with concentrated economic power," argues Donald W. Green, managing director of Planecon, a Washington-based consulting firm. 
 By most measures the transition from central planning has done more damage to Russia than the Great Depression did to the industrial West. Mr. Green's firm estimates that output has been cut by nearly half since 1989 and will shrink more in 1995. Prices rose tenfold in 1993, fourfold in 1994 and will likely double in 1995.
But much of the lost production consisted of stuff only a commissar could covet: missiles to protect the empire from the capitalist hordes, television sets that spontaneously combusted, steel mills based on the latest 1950's technology. And while the data are murky, living standards certainly have not fallen as much as output: wages, corrected for price changes, have almost held their own since 1992. Extrapolating from World Bank estimates, the average Russian now consumes about twice as much as the average Chinese.
What's more, the pain of the transition has been spread more evenly than, say, the trauma of the 1980's debt crisis in the third world. Formal unemployment remains below 3 percent; urban public services, notably education and mass transit, are still adequate.
So hard times have not been as hard as advertised. But what explains the optimism that softer times are ahead?
For one thing, the Government seems determined to hold the line on inflation. Ruble credits are no longer flowing freely to the former Soviet republics to finance purchases from Russia -- and thus no longer feed price pressures back home. The Russian central bank has been stripped of its power to create money for any purpose other than covering the budget deficit. And reformers, led by the battle-tested Anatoly B. Chubais, have apparently made an austerity pact with Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, the pragmatic Prime Minister with a reputation for picking winners. The Economist magazine predicted that inflation could recede to a civilized 2 to 3 percent a month by the end of 1995.
Arguably more important, privatization of industry is a fact. Most small shops were sold for a song to their employees. And all but a core of protected state industries have been given away through voucher-based auctions. Today, six out of seven nonfarm workers are privately employed.
Privatization has given the enterprises enormous incentives to find competent managers, to pay attention to consumer demand and to treat capital as a scarce resource. As significant, it has weakened the silver cord linking the enterprises to Moscow, withering the influence of the old apparachiks.
The soft underbelly is agriculture. Still state-owned and still wretchedly inefficient, the farms' claim on the public purse is still hard to resist. Indeed, the rural vote will probably remain the swing vote in national elections for decades to come.
Not surprisingly, each year for the last three the Government has succumbed to pressure for handouts by late summer, when the farms typically run out of cash. This time around, though, Moscow may hold out, if only to meet its obligations to the International Monetary Fund to limit the size of the budget deficit. The deeper threat to a successful economic beginning, Mr. Shleifer suggests, comes from a source that did not exist two years ago: monopoly capitalists.
Big private enterprises (including the natural gas consortium, which has close financial ties to the Prime Minister) are working in tandem with the new private banking sector to build informal cartels and secure preferred access to capital. Indeed, the Government is reportedly entertaining a proposal to borrow directly from the private banks, using its minority shares in enterprise as collateral.
Top-down capitalism works in Japan -- and, for that matter, in France. But those countries have traditions of democracy, legal due process and enlightened bureaucracy, Mr. Shleifer notes. His big worry is that "Russia will turn into Latin America 30 years ago," where wealth was concentrated along with economic power, and growth mattered little to the elite.

HEADLINE: AT HOME WITH: Ossie Davis and Ruby Dee;
Art and Politics: Keeping It All Fresh

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
RUBY DEE had started to yawn when the telephone rang the other night in the Westchester County home she shares with her husband, Ossie Davis. It was one of their three children, instructing Ms. Dee to watch herself on television.
Ms. Dee dutifully clicked on the tube, and there she was, narrating a special on the life of Edgar Allen Poe in her voice of smoke and silk. The word "literary" rolled off her tongue, conjuring images of art with a capital A -- a tad exaggerated, a little campy. 
 "Oh really, Ruby," Mr. Davis joked at her pronunciation, his own voice a bottomless bass. Ms. Dee giggled good-naturedly.
After 46 years of marriage and more than three decades as established stars, Ms. Dee and Mr. Davis remain without peer in an industry not known for nurturing black people, older people or long marriages. Mr. Davis is 77, and although Ms. Dee adamantly refuses to take a number ("not as old as God," she said coyly), an educated guess has her pushing 70.
Curled up on their living room sofa together after a long day of rehearsals for their new show, "Two Hah Hahs and a Homeboy," they did what they like to do on quiet evenings at home: talk.
He speaks deliberately. She is emotional and elliptical, gurgling with opinion, a diva with a homegirl edge.
She tells the photographer, "Don't take these chins of mine." Her husband quietly ambles up the stairs to shave and change shirts. She is elfin, delicate and honey colored. He is a tall, big, dark-chocolate man. They are unlined, unbowed, upbeat.
At this point in their lives, after friendships with Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X (Mr. Davis presented his eulogy), after protest marches and award-winning performances, they say their approach to art and social struggle remains the same.
Over the years, Mr. Davis and Ms. Dee have been on perpetual call for benefits and rallies for organizations like the N.A.A.C.P., the Urban League and AIDS groups like Housing Works. Many of their numerous television appearances and productions have focused on human rights struggles. Through their company, Emmalyn Enterprises, for example, they produced the 1986 PBS special "Martin Luther King: The Dream and the Drum."
The couple say they have managed to remain fresh by working with younger artists, doing their own projects and finding work that puts them in the limelight as mature performers. They were introduced to a new generation of movie-goers in the Spike Lee films "Do the Right Thing" (1989) and "Jungle Fever" (1991).
Their current show, "Two Hah Hahs and a Homeboy," a two-act dramatic piece compiled by Ms. Dee, opens Saturday at the Crossroads Theater in New Brunswick, N.J. It stars Ms. Dee and Mr. Davis and features the music of their son, Guy Davis. It pays homage to Zora Neale Hurston, the Harlem Renaissance writer, and includes a piece about Guy's first haircut and Ossie Davis's version of the biblical tale of Joshua.
Ms. Dee gave the drama its name and said that she and Mr. Davis each represented a "Hah." They saw it as a way to use humor to deal with the social dissonance of middle-class blacks, whose upwardly mobility is slowed by discrimination.
"We had been talking for a long time about this revue we wanted to do of black America," Ms. Dee said. "It's this box you go in where you hear the histories and the stories and the jokes. Then you can come out and put on your suit and tie and get your briefcase and go on about your business, refreshed for the year."
"Why don't we build a place somewhere, Ruby?" Mr. Davis said, alluding to the need to find a respite.
"It's buying the myth of integration," Ms. Dee continued, ignoring him for the moment. " 'Oh, I'm not a black author, I'm just an author.' If you don't consider race, well, race won't consider you. But you realize you're black. It happens to us. It's like puberty."
Mr. Davis said: "What is being done in 'Two Hah Hahs' is our effort to reinstitute, to put the folk tales back in their place and update their content. Zora Neale Hurston insisted that if black folks lost their folk tales, they'd lose their identity."
If "Two Hah Hahs" reflects the couple's social commitment, their home, with its African art, grand piano and casually strewn pillows, mirrors their unaffected elegance. The sprawling living room is decorated in soothing tan and beige and punctuated with thriving plants. Ms. Dee and Mr. Davis have lived in the four-story house for 32 years. Because they spend so much time working or at various political and social functions, home is a refuge and a treat.
She was born in Cleveland and grew up in Harlem, and he's from Waycross, Ga. They met during rehearsals for the 1946 Broadway play "Jeb."
Mr. Davis starred in such Broadway plays as "The Green Pastures" (1951), "A Raisin in the Sun" (1959), "I'm Not Rappaport" (1986), "Anna Lucasta" (1988) and his own satirical farce, "Purlie Victorious" (1961). He has directed several films, including "Cotton Comes to Harlem" (1970), "Black Girl" (1972) and "Gordon's War" (1973).
Ms. Dee's stage credits include roles in "A Raisin in the Sun" (she later reprised her role as Ruth in the 1961 film), "Purlie Victorious" and "Anna Lucasta." She won an Obie Award in 1971 for "Boesman and Lena" and the Drama Desk Award for the play "Wedding Band" in 1972.
Even with a visitor present, they tend to talk to each other, interrupting with ease or offering commentary on what the other has to say, the equivalent of verbal love bites.
"He casts well," Mr. Davis said of Spike Lee, having appeared in three of the director's films.
"He casts well," Ms. Dee said with a smirk. "Did you get that?"
Both said they grew up believing that any individual achievement or failure reflected on "the race" and that it was imperative to do whatever you could to make things better. They said the goals were clearer and in some ways easier then: voting rights, access to public accommodations, desegregated schools.
"He thinks, and we both think, too, that questions about the economy and the social order is really . . . ," she said, her words coming too fast. "We need to write much more about how those things affect what we see. You cannot talk about the family, for example, without looking at our total economic structure."
Ms. Dee and Mr. Davis say they share the same goals and have the same political sensibilities, which has made them friends.
"We've never had an ideological difference that I know of, and we've gone through some tough situations," Mr. Davis said. "Malcolm X has sat in this house, and Robeson has sat in this house, and Huey Newton, and they were dangerous people."
They worry that the souls of black folks are being sullied by the commercial images of themselves as amoral losers, nasty comics and criminals.
"Ruby was talking to me the other day about the ideas, the images we give our children," Mr. Davis said. "The images our children know come from television and radio, and so the merchants tell us who we are, rather than Mom and Dad.
"We've sort of discarded our sense of history and culture all around. And our young people, black, white and otherwise, suffer from the fact that we no longer have a respectful relationship with our past."
"For one thing, we allow ourselves to accept whatever comes," Ms. Dee said. "We're forgetting how to fight, we're forgetting how to protest."
When their own two daughters, Nora and Hasna, and son were young, they tagged along on protest marches. They were considered exotic among the neighborhood children since their parents did not allow a television in their home; to them, television represented an industry that refused to hire black people in significant numbers or in anything other than stereotypical roles.
It would be a mistake, though, to think that Ruby Dee and Ossie Davis are weighed down with the burdens of human rights and artistic integrity. There is about them the sheer giddiness of survivors and the dignity of winners.
"The life is the fun," she said.
"We walk in the middle of humor every day, and we laugh," he said.
"And we fight, too," Ms. Dee said. "Yeah. I win."
They both laughed.

HEADLINE: Mending Ties, U.S. Praises Brazil Leader

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 20

 BODY:
President Clinton gave a warm embrace to President Fernando Henrique Cardoso of Brazil today, signaling that after years of tensions fed by military rule, corruption and hyperinflation, the United States wants to make Brazil an important partner on trade and security.
"With our two nations cooperating as never before, we stand at a moment of unparalleled opportunity," Mr. Clinton said in a Rose Garden news conference with the new Brazilian leader. "In the months and years ahead, I look forward to working with President Cardoso to forge an even stronger partnership between our nations and our peoples." 
 Administration officials said the Cardoso visit, only the second state visit by a Brazilian leader in 24 years, showed that with Mexico in turmoil, the United States was looking increasingly to Brazil to help promote democracy and fight drugs and crime.
With Brazil's economy growing strongly the last three years, investment is an important focus. Mr. Cardoso has given several speeches to encourage American investors, and President Clinton is telling exporters that Brazil could be a bonanza.
"With 160 million consumers, Brazil is one of today's biggest emerging markets, and it offers great opportunity," Mr. Clinton said.
From the Administration's point of view, Mr. Cardoso has done all the right things since coming to power in January: cracking down on inflation, pushing for a trade agreement for the Americas and agreeing to cooperate in combating drugs. Brazil also helped mediate the border war between Peru and Ecuador.
But Administration officials acknowledge that tensions remain.
The United States is disappointed that Brazil has not endorsed an indefinite extension of the nuclear nonproliferation treaty, and Mr. Cardoso has not yet persuaded Brazil's Congress to tighten enforcement of pharmaceutical patents held by American companies. One senior Administration official said Mr. Cardoso had provided assurances that he would push through stronger patent legislation soon.
In addition, Brazilian officials have repeatedly criticized the Administration's embargo against Cuba, saying it enables Fidel Castro to blame the United States for his country's woes.
But Mr. Clinton praised Mr. Cardoso's support of democracy, noting that Brazil's military dictators chased him into exile a generation ago. During his exile, Mr. Cardoso spent several semesters teaching at Stanford University and the University of California at Berkeley.
The United States and Brazil agreed to set up a committee to encourage American companies to help finance the $70 billion in basic investments Mr. Cardoso says his country needs in coming years.
Mr. Clinton and Mr. Cardoso also reaffirmed their commitment to negotiate a trade agreement for the Americas by 2005. Many Latin American officials have voiced the fear that this goal, set at a summit meeting last December in Miami, would be forgotten as a result of Mexico's current economic turmoil.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Weak Dollar And Its Costs

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

 BODY:
"A country which is responsible for the key currency of the world has the responsibility of maintaining reasonable stability of it," Michel Camdessus, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, complained earlier this week. Translation: Do something -- anything -- to halt the decline of the dollar.
Mr. Camdessus's frayed temper reflects the frustration of Japanese and European officials watching their hopes for vibrant recovery fade away. That is because their exporters are losing competitive edge as their stronger currencies make their goods more expensive to sell in foreign markets. But pleas for action are falling on deaf ears in Washington: American policy makers lack the will and doubt they have the way to buck up the buck. 
 Indeed, despite a doubling of short-term interest rates in 1993 engineered by the Federal Reserve, which tends to make the American currency more attractive to hold, the dollar still fell last year against the Japanese yen and the German mark.
Even more important, the dollar's weakness against the yen and the mark reflects different problems lacking a common solution.
The dollar, rebounding yesterday for a second day from its steady decline, gained in New York against the mark and the yen. [Page D3.]
With the economy performing so well on the domestic front, Washington has little incentive to tinker. Inflation is under control and the economy seems to be on a stable growth path. "Maybe there's room for a move on interest rates, but not much," said Robert Z. Lawrence, an economist at the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard.
All politics are local, goes the truism -- and that goes double for the politics of exchange rates. Hence the pressure to stabilize currencies is weaker in America than in Europe or Japan because the United States is less dependent on international trade.
And while Japan is blaming Washington for its currency woes, influential American economists see the current predicament of Japanese industry as rough justice: Only Japan, they say, is feeling much pain from the appreciation of the yen, and only Japan possesses the tools to deal with it decisively.
The same does not apply to Europe, where a show of official determination on both sides of the Atlantic might correct what is seen as a currency misalignment generated by a lemming-like rush to "safer" currencies. But the sort of show that Mr. Camdessus and many of the big names in the world of finance apparently have in mind -- coordinated changes in interest rates along with an effort by central banks to buy dollars in international currency markets -- would not necessarily be successful and could prove costly. Besides, acting without Japan would heighten that nation's sense of second-class status among the economic elite.
All this adds up to a formula for diplomatic stalemate, with markets left to determine the relative value of currencies. Europe may still manage healthy growth. But Japan's already wobbly recovery appears doomed unless the deeply divided Government breaks with tradition to cut interest rates and stimulate spending.
To be sure, a chronically weak currency is a sign of underlying economic stress. If Americans saved more and its Government borrowed less, the United States would not be so dependent on foreign money to support the dollar. And a continuing erosion of the dollar also erodes the ability of Americans to pay their way in the world.
At the heart of the dollar's problem is the fact that the Japanese economy has long been geared to produce more than the Japanese consume and invest at home. This resulting chronic surplus puts upward pressure on the exchange value of the yen. "The only mystery is why the yen didn't rise earlier," said Richard Cooper, a Harvard economics professor.
While eliminating all barriers to imports would help a bit, the only way is to attack the problem at its roots, argues Robert Hormats, vice chairman of Goldman Sachs International. That would require reducing Japanese savings, increasing domestic spending or some combination of the two. Big public works projects -- Tokyo's fix of choice when push comes to shove -- are slow to deliver results. By the same token, lower interest rates take months or years to stimulate private investment.
Cutting taxes, particularly taxes on consumer goods, would stimulate purchases and reduce the surplus that spills abroad. But the Japanese bureaucracy, echoing the austerity that defines traditional Japanese culture and reflecting a fear that an aging population must save even more for retirement, views "consumption as a bad habit," Mr. Hormats said.
Japan's reluctance to stop worrying and start spending is reinforced by the sense that United States profligacy is at fault. However desirable such a shift to thrift here may be, though, it will not change Japan's underlying savings machine -- an economy organized to prosper only when it is exporting far more than it imports. "Fiscal virtue in America wouldn't solve Japan's yen problem," Mr. Hormats said.
Explanations for why the yen is muscle-bound do not apply to the German mark and the other European currencies tied to the mark. Europe is not running chronic trade and "current account" surpluses with the rest of the world. William Brown, chief economist for J. P. Morgan, links the mark's strength to a "flight to quality" from the weaker currencies of Italy and Spain.
Nor does Europe have the painless option to drive down currency exchange values on its own by cutting interest rates and taxes or by increasing government spending. Unlike Japan, Germany and its neighbors are no longer experiencing economic stagnation, which means that government stimulus risks overheating the economy.
Professor Cooper expects the dollar's weakness against the mark to solve itself since there are no fundamental economic forces propping up the German currency. And by that logic, the dollar-mark exchange rate should be a candidate for successful intervention: A flurry of official pronouncements, accompanied by well-timed central bank purchases of dollars and sales of marks, may speed a shift in market psychology much the way the Plaza accord of 1985 initiated a then-desired decline in the exchange value of the dollar.
But a coordinated drive to realign the mark and dollar that leaves the yen to twist slowly in the wind will almost certainly be taken by Tokyo as an attempt to isolate Japan. And, thanks to the current, bizarrely timed threats by the Clinton Administration to punish Japan for its failure to roll out the red carpet for imported auto parts, tensions are already high.
As a result, Japan will probably be left to dig itself out the old-fashioned way, slashing costs and prices at home -- and accepting hundreds of billions of dollars worth of lost output -- to restore its competitive position in world markets. But the route of deflating the economy into prosperity is hardly a sure thing. "The yen could appreciate in tandem," Professor Cooper said, "trapping Japan in slow growth."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Dollar Surges 2.3% Against Yen And Also Advances vs. the Mark

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar rose solidly for a second consecutive day yesterday, deriving strength from overseas buying and speculation that a meeting of finance ministers from the large industrial nations may act decisively to defend the wobbly currency.
A rally in the United States stock market and technically related purchases of dollars also helped to shore up the dollar, foreign exchange traders said. 
 "Everyone is getting the opinion that really, the market is very short of dollars," said Ivan Sands, manager of foreign exchange and sales at the New York branch of Credit Lyonnais, the large French bank. "Everybody is realizing the extent of the problem."
In New York late yesterday, the dollar surged 2.3 percent against the yen, settling at 83.16 yen from 81.30 yen on Wednesday. It was the sharpest one-day gain by the dollar against the yen since May 10, 1994, when it rose 1.75 yen. The dollar rose to 1.3837 marks from 1.3720 marks.
In Tokyo early yesterday, the dollar climbed against the yen as large Japanese insurance companies and other institutional investors reversed their recent trading and began buying dollars. Some dealers said the buying was prompted by a report on Wednesday showing that the United States trade deficit narrowed sharply in February.
The apparent change of attitude toward the dollar suggested that many Japanese companies, which have been deeply hurt by the dollar's 16.5 percent depreciation against the yen this year, believe the dollar is at or near a bottom for now.
"For those who've been selling the dollar, you've got to ask yourself whether you're doing the right thing," said Hubert Pedroli, foreign exchange manager at the New York office of the Credit Suisse investment firm. "You have to be able to step back and say these are silly levels to keep selling."
Others who had sold the dollar short, or bet the dollar would decline further, then scrambled to buy dollars instead to limit their losses. That buying further lifted the dollar.
Some currency dealers are also betting that the Group of Seven finance ministers, meeting on Tuesday, may take some decisive action to support the dollar.
The seven nations -- Britain, Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan and the United States -- worked together in 1985 to weaken the dollar and then again in 1987 to halt the dollar's decline.
While some dealers are skeptical that the nations will take concrete steps to help the dollar, they do not want to be caught short if steps are taken.
"When you get these finance ministers together, who knows what can happen?," said Hillel Waxman, chief foreign exchange dealer at the New York branch of the Bank Leumi Trust Company.
Traders said there was no underlying economic news driving the dollar higher yesterday. The dollar dipped briefly on news from the Philadelphia Federal Reserve that local economic activity, a barometer of broader trends, was weakening and inflationary pressure was low. But the dollar quickly recovered.

HEADLINE: Mexican Talks With Rebels Are Delayed

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: SAN ANDRES LARRAINZAR, Mexico, April 20

 BODY:
More than a year after a first round of peace talks failed to end an armed uprising in the southern Mexican state of Chiapas, Government representatives delayed resuming the talks today until their safety was guaranteed by the rebels.
Surrounded by hundreds of sympathizers of the Zapatista rebels, representatives of both sides were scheduled to meet in a hastily erected building on top of the town's concrete basketball court to discuss, among other things, proposals for a permanent truce to ease tensions and end the 16-month-old rebellion. 
 But in an indication of how complicated a task it will be, the Government delegates refused to enter the building because of the rebel sympathizers, some of whom wore traditional ribboned hats and carried signs saying, "We are all Zapatistas." The Government said their presence violated the neutrality of the talks, and it refused to allow its delegates to enter San Andres until their safe passage could be guaranteed.
Rosario Ibarra de Piedra, an opposition member of Congress who had come to witness the talks, ridiculed the Government's position. "What did they expect," she said. "If the talks had been held in New York City, there would have been sympathizers."
The standoff is the latest frustration to arise from the uprising, which began with 12 days of armed skirmishes in January 1994 that left more than 145 dead. Since then, there has been practically no violence, but the threat that the two sides might again clash has hung heavily over the state, damaging investor confidence in Mexico and raising political tensions that affected last year's presidential election.
The situation has changed drastically since February, when the Government arrested several people it accused of being rebel leaders, identified the masked spokesman who had been known only as Subcommander Marcos as a radical college professor, and sent a huge force of federal troops into the rebels' highland forest stronghold. The rebels, who are mostly Mayan Indians, have been surrounded since then, while attempts were made to reopen formal peace talks.
Masked representatives of the Zapatista National Liberation Army arrived here to cheers Wednesday night with what their leaders said was a specific proposal for a permanent truce. Government negotiators also said they had come with a plan for lowering tensions and eliminating the lingering military threat.
But Government officials said they were seeking more than a resolution of the military aspect of the rebellion.
"In terms of military force, the Zapatistas no longer have any," said a Government official close to the negotiations. "What we need to do here is resolve the deeper issues in a way that does not leave behind any resentment that can become another problem in the future."
Although they are surrounded by Mexican troops, the Zapatistas still represent a formidable public relations threat with support throughout Mexico. The Government, beset by economic and political problems, feels it must take the rebels seriously, and many Government officials fear that an outburst of violence or a terrorist attack would severely set back Mexico's attempts at recovering from the economic crisis caused by the devaluation of the peso in December.
The current Government plan is for the negotiating sessions with the rebels to continue for several months, perhaps till the end of this year. Each round of talks will deal with specific themes. In later sessions, the Government will take up rebel demands concerning land rights and the brutal poverty in which the Indians of Chiapas live.
This threadbare community, about 15 miles northwest of San Cristobal de las Casas, is a Zapatista stronghold that mirrors the conditions the rebels have said forced them to take up arms. Nearly all the 15,000 residents of the area speak a variety of Indian languages; more than half have never attended school; less than 15 percent of the houses have plumbing, and only 25 percent have electricity.
Government officials have made it clear that they will not expand the talks to include national issues, like democratic reform, that the rebels have tried to place on the agenda. Nor, officials said, will the Government succumb to pressures from conservative parts of society that want to see a quick end to the rebel movement.
"The policy of the Government is not based on pressures but on meeting the goals and objectives of the people of Chiapas," said another Government official close to the talks.
Today's planned talks follow a preliminary session on April 9 between rebels and the Government that was meant to beat a deadline imposed by the Mexican Congress. Arrest orders against rebel leaders had been suspended for a month by a special amnesty law but would have become effective again on April 10 if the rebels had not taken steps to begin the long-stalled process of negotiation. As long as the talks continue, the Government has pledged to keep the arrest orders suspended.
Both the Government and rebel leaders are declaring their openness to discuss all issues and to work for a solution to the conflict that has dragged on for 16 months at great cost to Chiapas and to Mexico.
It is clear that part of the Government's strategy is to differentiate these talks from those that failed in February 1994. Then, the Government was represented by an independent peace commissioner, Manuel Camacho Solis, who personally attracted nearly as much attention as the rebel leader Subcommander Marcos, who has become a national hero.
Those talks were held under wide publicity in the cathedral of San Cristobal de las Casas. After several days, delegates emerged with a 32-point preliminary settlement, which eventually was rejected by the rebels.
This time, the Government is represented by officials of the Interior Ministry and a bipartisan Congressional commission. The rebel contingent is not led not by Subcommander Marcos, who did not show up, but by Commander Tacho and other Maya Indians who speak only halting Spanish.
This round of talks is expected to last for two days.
