Strong Company Earnings Lead to Big Stock Rally
The Dow rallied 39 points in some of the heaviest trading of the year, closing at a record 4,270.09, as traders focused on the exceptionally strong earnings being reported for the first quarter. Traders also said the frenzy of a "double witching" session might have contributed to the advance. 
 Some traders were troubled, however, that broader indexes did not share as much in the advance, indicating that portfolio managers were buying a small group of blue-chip stocks as part of a short-term strategy rather than a long-term investment. In currency markets, the dollar closed down slightly at 82.70 yen and 1.369 marks in New York. Page 41
 
Prices of Treasury securities were little changed as investors declined to make sizable purchases going into the weekend without stronger evidence that the economy was indeed slowing. 50.
 
Bank Hires Salomon Executives
Union Bank of Switzerland, under a multimillion dollar two-year contract, hired five former Salomon managing directors. The executives, who start work on Monday, may also bring more junior Salomon staffers with them to the bank. 39.
 
Du Pont to Sell Conoco Assets
Du Pont plans to sell $650 million worth of assets in its Conoco oil subsidiary to help finance the $8.8 billion repurchase of a block of its stock from Seagram. In addition, Du Pont plans to sell $3 billion worth of its stock, rather than the $3.5 billion initially projected, from the 156 million shares purchased from Seagram earlier this month. 39.
 
Euro Disney Narrows Loss
Euro Disney said its net loss narrowed to $49 million in the fiscal first half, aided by increased attendance at its theme park and savings under its refinancing plan. The results were enough to raise Euro Disney's stock 8.7 percent on the Paris stock exchange, closing at $3.07 a share. 51.
Southwest Airlines Profits Down
Southwest Airlines reported a 72 percent decline in first-quarter earnings, to $11.8 million, largely because bigger rivals matched its low fares. But the carrier's stock surged 14 percent to $21.50, on the New York Stock Exchange, after it said the pricing competition had eased and it had corrected problems with its reservation system. 38.
 
The Moving Industry Consolidates
With UniGroup's acquisition of Mayflower and further consolidations likely in the moving industry, consumers face the prospect of higher prices and fewer companies from which to choose. 39.
 
Earnings Rise at Colgate
Colgate-Palmolive said earnings rose 4.6 percent, to $156.5 million, in the first quarter, fueled by improving results in the United States and strong results in Latin America. 38.
Kellogg Net Up 6.6%
 
Kellogg said that its first-quarter earnings rose 6.6 percent, to a record $196 million, or 89 cents a share, saying that strong cereal sales overseas made up for flat business in North America. The company said its cereal sales in the United States declined 2.7 percent during the quarter. 41.
 
Federal Budget Deficit Grows
The Federal Government's budget deficit widened to $49.9 billion in March from $32.3 billion a year earlier. Much of the deficit resulted from a quirk under which transfer payments and tax refunds were moved up to March 31 from April 1, analysts said. 47.
 
Tourists Packing New York
Thanks to the Easter and Passover holidays, the warm weather and favorable foreign-exchange rates, New York City is suddenly having a surge of tourists. The city is packed, and New Yorkers seemed to welcome the company, believing that what's good for the city's economy is good for them. 25.
 
Hiring Program May Be Streamlined
The Clinton Administration is considering loosening rules governing how contractors on Federal projects report how many of their employees are women or members of minorities. The intention is to streamline the complex regulations in an attempt to make the Government's affirmative action program more "user friendly." 7.

HEADLINE: City Hall Agency Will Review The Audits of Business Zones

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
In the latest move to bring more public scrutiny to New York City's 33 business improvement districts, a City Hall auditing agency will routinely review outside audits of the districts, city officials said yesterday.
The new review process was approved Wednesday at a meeting of the agency, the Audit Committee, and was announced jointly yesterday by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi and Public Advocate Mark Green, who all have representatives on the committee. In the past, the committee has confined its oversight work to such large public institutions as the city's Housing Authority and the Health and Hospitals Corporation. 
 The effort to impose greater oversight on the improvement districts came after a series of questions about one of the largest, the Grand Central Partnership. An outside accountant's analysis showed that the partnership had engaged in unusual bookkeeping last year in its efforts to help create a BID in Jersey City, and several former employees have said in recent weeks that the partnership's outreach program for the homeless had involved a "goon squad" that beat people up. Partnership officials have denied any wrongdoing.
Business improvement districts are nonprofit organizations authorized by the city to collect fees from property owners to provide street cleaning, security and other services.
Mayor Giuliani said the BID's had done "an extraordinary job improving New York City's quality of life," but he said the new financial reviews were necessary because of the huge amount of public money they control.
"Because BID's serve as a public-private partnership and receive monies levied by the public, it is perfectly appropriate that they be subjected to reviews and audits on a regular basis," the Mayor said.
Apparently in an attempt to head off more public scrutiny and red tape, executives of the Grand Central Partnership have asked the audit bureau within the Comptroller's office to review the partnership's books, Mr. Hevesi said. The review would be separate from that of the Audit Committee.
Mr. Hevesi said he had agreed to the partnership's request, and offered similar audits by his staff to any other BID that requests them.
The Audit Committee said it would review audits of the BIDs by outside accounting firms that are required each year. If the outside accountants recommend changes in bookkeeping or financial practices, the Audit Committee said it will assure that the changes are made.
Several changes were recommended by the outside accountants who reviewed the books of the Grand Central Partnership last year, including that it end the practice of using partnership money for such purposes as helping to start the proposed Jersey City BID.
Although the Audit Committee said it would review the finances of all BID's, it said only the seven largest, each of which collects more than $1 million a year in property assessments, would be reviewed annually.

HEADLINE: U.S. Offering to Raise Level Of Talks With North Korea

BYLINE: By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 21

 BODY:
In a last-ditch effort to rescue the nuclear freeze agreement with North Korea, Washington offered today to raise negotiations to a senior level.
North Korea confirmed that it had broken off talks with the United States on implementing a $4.5 billion nuclear accord and blamed the failure on the United States. 
 Kim Jong U, the senior North Korean negotiator, told reporters in Berlin before heading back to North Korea that Washington's "inflexible and unreasonable" demands had blocked an agreement.
[But in a statement Saturday in North Korea, the Foreign Ministry left open the possibility that it might resume the talks. The statement said North Korea was studying the proposal by the United States to hold higher-level talks.]
The dispute centers around North Korea's insistence that an American company, rather than a South Korean one, be designated as the primary contractor in building two light-water nuclear reactors. The Americans insist that in deference to the South Koreans, who will be paying for a large portion of the deal, the reactors be South Korean models and that a South Korean company be the primary contractor in the decade-long project.
North Korea repeatedly threatened to resume the operation of some nuclear facilities today, the target date for hammering out the details of the accord reached six months ago. That agreement is to provide North Korea with $4.5 billion in nuclear reactors and other economic assistance in exchange for its freezing and eventually dismantling its nascent nuclear weapons program.
In a briefing for reporters, RobertC. Gallucci, the chief United States negotiator, declined to say whether he considered the situation at an impasse or whether the United States expected North Korea to carry out its threat to restart its nuclear facilities.
Senior Administration officials have said that such a resumption would force the United States to seek economic sanctions on North Korea.
"The talks in Berlin have broken down," Mr. Gallucci said, adding, "I don't know what they're going to do. I just would prefer to say that we will wait and see what they do, and as we have in the past we'll respond to what they do."
A number of Republican lawmakers have called for economic sanctions against North Korea if it resumes its nuclear program. Senator Frank H. Murkowski, the Alaska Republican who recently visited North Korea, said on Thursday that he would ask President Clinton to urge American allies to impose economic sanctions on North Korea if it does so.
Earlier today, Secretary of State Warren Christopher told reporters that he wanted to raise the level of the talks and proposed to North Korea that Mr. Gallucci represent the American side.
If the higher-level talks can be opened, they would take place in Geneva, senior State Department officials said.
Although the proposal to upgrade the talks suggested a concession by Washington, Mr. Gallucci insisted that the United States was not rewarding North Korea for obstruction by upgrading the talks.
"We're not in the reward-penalty business here," he said. "We're trying to solve a problem that exists between our two Governments in the implementation of an agreement that's very important to our security and those of our allies in the world."

Seoul Accepts Russian Arms
 SEOUL, April 21 (Reuters) -- South Korea said today that it had agreed to take $450 million worth of arms, raw materials and civilian helicopters from Russia by 1998 as repayment of Moscow's debts.
The two countries are to formally sign the agreement early next month in Seoul, a spokesman of South Koreas Finance and Economy Ministry said. He said $171.5 million in raw materials and defense equipment would be shipped this year.
South Korea promised a $3 billion loan in aid to the Soviet Union just before the two countries established diplomatic relations in September, 1990. Only $1.47 billion was handed over before the program was suspended after the collapse of the Soviet Union.
Russia assumed responsibility for the loan, but at the end of 1993 Moscow had fallen behind in its repayments, the ministry spokesman said.
The Defense Ministry said Russian weapons to be brought to South Korea would include tanks and military vehicles and small arms. The ministry said the Russian arms would not be deployed militarily but used to work out strategies against North Korea, which uses weaponry that was mostly supplied by the Soviet Union or based on Soviet designs.

HEADLINE: Corrections

 BODY:
A chart in Business Day on Monday with the continuation of an article about growing disparities in wealth and income in the United States misstated the source of data on the concentration of wealth in industrial nations. It was Timothy M. Smeeding of the Luxembourg Income Study Group, not Edward N. Wolff, author of "Top Heavy: A Study of Increasing Inequality of Wealth in America." 
 In addition, the chart misstated France's ranking in an index of wealth concentration. The index's rankings ran from 0 (meaning everyone has the same amount of wealth) to 1 (a theoretical case in which only one person has all the wealth). France's ranking was 0.30, placing it between Italy and Canada; it was not 0.25, which placed it between Germany and Finland.

HEADLINE: A Switch at the M.T.A.

 BODY:
The abrupt resignation of Peter E. Stangl as chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority yesterday removes from the scene a dedicated advocate for the New York City region's subway, bus and commuter rail systems. Mr. Stangl has fought hard if unsuccessfully to make the city and state live up to their financing commitments to a five-year, $9.6 billion rebuilding plan enacted in 1993. Commuters can only hope that Gov. George Pataki's choice to succeed him as chairman, E. Virgil Conway, uses his access to demand that the state and city not gut the system.
With the onset of the worst fiscal crisis in two decades, both New York's Mayor, Rudolph Giuliani, and Governor Pataki have reduced their contributions to the authority. With Washington's subsidies also shrinking, the cutbacks are jeopardizing transportation services and capital improvements. Now that he has appointed a new chairman loyal to him, Mr. Pataki should disclose his own views of how to insure that recent impressive gains in ridership and quality of service are not jeopardized. 
 Mr. Conway, a banker who has served on the M.T.A. board since 1992, is a friend of Mr. Pataki. He could help the authority by serving as its advocate, not merely as the Governor's point man in exacting further spending cuts. But he needs to learn how to stand up to the Governor and fight for mass transit passengers. Mr. Conway's announced decision to work only part time sends an initial disturbing signal. The chairmanship of the M.T.A. is a job demanding full attention.
Mr. Stangl departs to join the Bombardier Transit Corporation, but he promises to obey ethics laws barring him from doing business with the authority for two years. He leaves with a record of achievement in one of the real government success stories of recent years. The region's transit systems are vital to its economic future and need the Governor's full attention if they are to be maintained.

HEADLINE: THE CAPITALIST;
The Lying Game

BYLINE: By MICHAEL LEWIS 

 BODY:
LIKE MOST AMERICANS, I LEARNED early on the importance of honesty from the story of George Washington and the cherry tree. But it was only recently that I discovered the story's provenance, and thus its true significance -- as an illustration of the market economy at work.
It first appeared in Mason Locke Weems's best-selling "The Life of Washington," published in 1800, and reissued many times with fresh material. The author, a man of the cloth, set the story down in the fifth edition of his book as follows (we join the action at its climax): 
 " 'George,' his father said, 'do you know who killed that beautiful little cherry tree yonder in the garden?' This was a tough question, and George staggered under it for a moment; but quickly recovered himself; and looking at his father, with the sweet face of youth brightened with the inexpressible charm of all-triumphant truth he bravely cried out, 'I can't tell a lie, Pa, you know I can't tell a lie, I did cut it with my little hatchet.' "
The whole thing, it turns out, is a charming fraud -- as historians have long known and that you might surmise from its copious quotation of a private conversation that occurred years earlier (or from the parson's claim in the book that the story's "too true to be doubted"). Weems made it up from scratch to achieve his twin aims of enhancing the myth of Washington and attracting buyers to his new-and-improved "Life." Thus the single most powerful American contribution to the notion of honesty illustrates a somewhat different moral: it pays to lie, if you have the knack for it. And if you lie as well as Weems you can make a lot of people happy, simply by telling them what they think they want to hear.
OF COURSE THE OFFICIAL RULE OF THE market is that honesty is the best policy -- or, at least, that any deal mutually beneficial to both buyer and seller requires honesty. And certainly, as every book on salesmanship explains, the appearance of honesty in business is extremely important. Why else the preternatural love of eye contact, firm handshakes and the prefixes "frankly" and "to be honest with you"? (Ever noticed that the people who have trouble looking you in the eye -- nerdy scientists, for example -- are precisely those who are trying their hardest to tell you the truth?)
But as every book on sales technique also implies, a shrewd salesman can manipulate the truth for profit. If he couldn't, there would be no need for books about sales technique. What's less apparent, perhaps, is that many lies in business are good not only for the liar but for the person lied to. Lest you doubt my word:
 
The Lie That Makes Us Feel Better About Ourselves. The most successful car salesman in American history, Joe Girard, mailed cards to his customers every month that read simply: "I Like You." At the end of his career he was mailing out 13,000 cards a month. Obviously this was deceptive; Joe could not possibly have liked all 13,000 tire kickers. Just as obviously, his 13,000 customers enjoyed being deceived, or Joe wouldn't have been so effective. Why they enjoyed being deceived, however, is maybe not so obvious. Perhaps some actually thought Joe liked them. Most probably knew Joe's flattery was false. But even false flattery is flattering in its peculiar way. In lying to his customers Joe was saying: You are important enough to abase myself before.
 
The Enabling Lie. Watching the N.C.A.A. basketball finals this month I was asked to believe that Nike shoes will replace my cynicism with hope; that the Hyatt Hotel chain is my best friend; that Doritos, Michelin tires and the Mazda Miata all delight small babies; that the 1995 Chevrolet Monte Carlo awaiting me in the showroom is "all new" (but then why does it have the same name?), and that Donald and Ivana Trump were reconciled over the new cheese-filled crust from Pizza Hut.
What's interesting about these lies -- and the layer upon layer of deception in all advertisements -- is that they are offensive only when they are ineffective. Having swallowed a couple of lies like these myself I know that the better the lie, the happier it makes me. When I wear Air Jordans I actually do feel as if I play better; when I receive a package by Fedex like one of those important execs in the ads I actually do feel ever so slightly more important than when I get one by regular mail. I do not harbor resentment towards those who fooled me. I am grateful. (Thanks for the great lie!)

The Lie That Forces Reality Into Line With Our Expectations. We Americans have a talent for demanding the impossible. Hence, stockbrokers. If there were such a thing as a gift for always picking winning stocks, any person so possessed would be picking them for himself, not for you. Millions of Americans nevertheless expect that there should be someone out there who will tell them how to turn a little money into a lot, effortlessly. This belief sustains a large part of Wall Street, and its myriad petty deceits. In return, the brokerage industry provides those who wish to be lied to with a great deal of hope and an entertaining pastime.

The Lie Whose Ill-Effects Fall Miles Away. Perhaps the job market offers the clearest view of this peculiar phenomenon. We positively delight in the lies we tell to sell ourselves to a potential employer. The classic American success story begins with a long-shot applicant lying about his qualifications for a job he does not deserve. Of course, if the lie is exposed immediately the career in question ends before it starts, and the liar is reviled. But once a lie has worked, and the liar is safely ensconced in his new job, he is widely praised as enterprising, for having lied well. Those to whom he has lied chuckle knowingly -- after all, they got a successful employee. The liar brags about his lie to friends and family, thus insuring that others will learn to lie. Only the honest fool who didn't get the job gets the shaft -- and who cares about him?
COME TO THINK OF IT, MAYBE THAT story about Washington and the cherry tree was never meant to illustrate the virtue of honesty. Maybe it was meant to illustrate the secret of business success. After all, it ends with the young Washington rewarded for telling the truth. He avoids a spanking, receives great dollops of paternal love and admiration, and winds up with his picture on the dollar bill. Shrewd George! It isn't that he told the truth, but that he sized up his customer and told him what he wanted to hear. Instinctively, he knew to tell the truth only when it paid.

GRAPHIC: Drawing

HEADLINE: THEATER;
George Wolfe and His Theater of Inclusion

BYLINE: By DONALD G. McNEIL Jr. 

 BODY:
FOR YEARS, THE JOSEPH PAPP Public Theater had the rudest box office in town. Among the staff members, it was even a matter of pride. One of the first things George C. Wolfe did when he took over as producer at the Public in March 1993 was to dismiss them.
Ticket sales can still be rushed, as might be expected when clerks at three windows try to handle five theaters for impatient patrons who won't take "sold out" for an answer. But the mood these days is far friendlier. 
 George Wolfe's invisible welcome mats say "inclusion." He wants everyone in New York City in his theater.
As he whirls upstairs and down, directing, teasing, buttonholing, shouting, shadowboxing, lunching, comforting and glad-handing, the Energizer bunny of the Public is reshaping the institution -- and not just the season, but the staff, the lobby, the look of the advertising and the mission. And, as a self-proclaimed "former spoiled child," he has unfailing trust in his own taste and wants things his way.
If this means dismissing some Papp loyalists, he'll do so. Like the Public's founder, he won't back away from a fight. But also like him, Mr. Wolfe has the ability to woo new writers while still going steady with celebrity talent. The result this season has been a list of productions that fairly shouts to be heard.
The 1994-95 program is everywhere, printed in a cockeyed jumble that suggests a nightmare while nose-down in a thesaurus: "Blade/Diva/Prince/Merchant/Silence/Dog/Dancing/Language/Him/Simpatico/People." Morale seems high. The lobby is friendly: staff members step up to patrons asking, "Can I help you?" Audiences of a youth and diversity that other producers would kill for mingle in the large space on Lafayette Street whose new signs, lively cafe tables and general bustle turn it into a playgoer's Grand Central.
The train station notion is Mr. Wolfe's. His two favorite words are "journey" and "collisions." He welcomed a musical, "The Petrified Prince," not so much to have a hit -- which it was not -- as to let the young composer Michael John LaChiusa and the director Harold Prince "go on a journey together." The "collisions" among his advisers -- the associate producers, Kevin Kline and Rosemarie Tichler; the director of play development, Morgan Jenness, and the literary manager, Shelby Jiggetts -- produce the season.
He wants the Public's traditional -- read "uptown white" -- audiences for Sam Shepard's horse-player saga "Simpatico," for example, or Stuart Greenman's "Silence, Cunning, Exile," inspired by events in the life of the photographer Diane Arbus, to collide in the lobby with new audiences drawn in to see the Harlem gangsters in "Dancing on Moonlight," the Hispanic boxers of "Blade to the Heat" or the gay Asian lovers of "A Language of Their Own."
If it works, the chain reactions will convert them to subscribers -- the solid base he must have on which to build his $10 million annual enterprise. To entice these new audiences, Mr. Wolfe says, he and his staff are creating "cultural bread crumbs" for different groups. The purpose? "To have this building vibrate with this city's energy and be inclusive, in a healthy, nontoken way."
To that end, he has hired a director of community affairs and group sales, Donna Walker-Collins, whose major assignment is to make black, Asian and Hispanic audiences feel wanted at the Public: "I use myself as an example," said Ms. Walker-Collins, the former director of marketing for Dance Theater of Harlem. "I've been in the arts for 20 years, and I never wanted to come to the Public until I bought tickets to 'Fires in the Mirror.' It felt cold -- I felt I wasn't welcome here."
Her first act was to arrange tours for 400 representatives of schools, churches and professional associations. She has opened the Public's five theaters to readings by, among others, the Nuyorican Poets Cafe and concerts by Haitian groups. She has had black actors do their favorite Shakespeare monologues at a Harlem theater. She helps organize panel discussions on homophobia in sports (linked to "Blade"), on how neighborhoods deify gangsters (linked to "Dancing on Moonlight"). Then she works to convert visitors to ticket buyers.
"Ultimately," she said, "what George wants is a blur -- that's his word -- of all the people in New York."
Mr. Wolfe finds the figures encouraging. Box-office income is expected to reach $1.5 million by May, up from $759,000 two years ago when his predecessor, JoAnne Akalaitis, was in charge. There are 6,000 Public members now, versus 3,200 subscribers two years ago.
 
Offering a Little Something For Almost Everyone
 This season, the first one that can really be called his, Mr. Wolfe has generated an electricity the Public hasn't felt since the heyday of Joe Papp. There will be 13 productions in all, including two this summer in Central Park: "The Tempest," which Mr. Wolfe is directing, and "Troilus and Cressida." In Oliver Mayer's "Blade to the Heat," the season opener, which Mr. Wolfe also directed, props lunged on stage like pit bulls as Latin boxers beat one another, spewing gouts of blood into the audience. In his play "Simpatico," Sam Shepard directed Beverly D'Angelo, Marcia Gay Harden, Ed Harris and Fred Ward. Christopher Walken starred in "Him," his own play, as Elvis resurrected as a diapered sumo wrestler and a snood-wearing waitress. Ron Leibman played Shylock in a very fey Venice.
"This season reflects George's taste, flair, insight and theatricality," said Bernard Gersten, the executive producer of Lincoln Center Theater, who was Mr. Papp's partner in running the Public until 1978. "It's a very successful transition to a new era."
Thus far, however, it has not been very successful with critics. That bothers him "not at all," Mr. Wolfe said. "Not . . . at . . . all," he repeats. "Because when one of them didn't get it, somebody else did. When you're doing adventurous programming, that's one of the risks you take. I could program a 'fabulous, I love it' kind of hit season right now. I'm more interested in breaking boundaries, telling a story, defying a truth that has been accepted."
He targets market segments as smoothly as any cola company. "Dancing on Moonlight," which has social and political references, can reach for a black mainstream audience, Mr. Wolfe said, like "East Texas Hot Links," by Eugene Lee and unlike "The America Play," by Suzan-Lori Parks. That play, he said, appealed to three groups "with blurred boundaries": black and white intellectuals as well as downtown audiences.
He hopes that "A Language of Their Own," about four gay men, two of whom are Chinese, will bring in an Asian audience, a gay audience and some of the "traditional, white, Upper East Side audience because of the artists involved, i.e., B. D. Wong and David Drake."
But every time he concocts a season, he says, someone grumbles, "The Public's going black, or the Public's going gay. . . . " This season, 4 of the 13 works have gay themes. Mr. Wolfe, who is gay, says there is no calculation to "order George up five homosexual plays."
"I pride myself on being available to as many people's stories as I possibly can," Mr. Wolfe said. Last year, "3 of the 11 plays had black artists at their cores, and it was 'the Public's going black.' " (And then, he said, some blacks complained that he was "only doing artsy black things to appeal to white intellectuals.") Next season will be "relatively female," with more plays by and about women.
"As a person of color," Mr. Wolfe said, "I was trained from very early on to see 'Leave It to Beaver,' 'Gilligan's Island' or 'Hamlet,' and look beyond the specifics of it -- whether it be silly white people on an island, or a family living in Nowheres, or a Danish person -- to leap past the specifics and find the human truths that have to do with me. I'm interested: Is the reverse possible? Can people who are not of color leap past the specifics of who these people are and get inside the dynamic of who they are as individuals?"
Now, he added, he is hunting for a play that "taps into a certain rage that I think white people are feeling right now."
"When England began going through cultural and social upheaval" under a conservative government, he said, "the writing -- by Caryl Churchill and David Hare, among others -- seemed to spring from that experience. A similar upheaval is happening now in this country and I haven't yet found plays from a white perspective reflecting how white Americans are feeling as they are being 'assaulted' by these changes.
"I want to have the kind of plays in the Public where the whole building becomes a giant snapshot of where America is. So in the pursuit of trying to tell very different stories -- to present these colliding points of view -- I am intrigued by the 'silent majority' in America, which all of a sudden has become incredibly vocal. Where are the plays that dissect or celebrate that rage? I would be very curious to see them."
 
Making New Friends And Maybe Even Money
 Mr. Wolfe has given the Public's image a new look too. For 20 years, Paul Davis's posters were its signature; clean close-ups of faces with as few words as possible: Sam Waterston agape as Hamlet, the "Streamers" parachutist. The new look, by Paula Scher of Pentagram, is mostly words, a wall of graffiti that cries: "Yo! Read me if you can!"
"We were trying to cleanse the visual palate," Mr. Wolfe said, "and also have a very contemporary, very 90's edge. I was looking for something that had a certain attitude, that said, 'Yeah, I'm here. Deal with this. Hop on board.' "
But even as people do hop on, the Public is not getting rich. The paradox of its economics is that because of its relatively small theaters, short runs, $15 to $35 ticket prices and Shakespeare in the Park giveaway, putting on more plays means losing money faster. There are exceptions: a sellout one-man show like Danny Hoch's can turn a profit; the expensive musical "The Petrified Prince" was underwritten by the Canadian producer Garth Drabinsky to see whether it was Broadway material.
A big season, though, can have other rewards. Three-quarters of the Public's income comes from foundations, corporations and private donors, and they would rather underwrite a hot theater than pay the debt service on a failing one. Donations and grants, $4.8 million two years ago, are projected to reach $7.3 million this year.
And a big season increases the chances of another "Chorus Line." The musical made the Public $40 million but that stream has dried up. The theater's endowment and cash reserve fund now total $10 million; annual interest of $600,000 goes into the operating budget.
The audience isn't the only body becoming more diverse, larger and, as a result, producing more money. Under Mr. Wolfe, the board has grown to 25 members, from 20. Nine are women; five are black; all are being pressed to raise funds more vigorously. And members say things are looking up: "In the worst year under Joe," said Larry E. Condon, the vice chairman, "we drew down $3 million from the reserve fund to pay for the season. Last year, we drew down $1 million. This year, if we're really lucky and find a sponsor for summer Shakespeare, we might break even."
 
The Not-So-Long Road From Kentucky to Broadway
 George Wolfe gets comfortable, popping off his shoes and sprawling on his leather office couch. As the cataract of words pours out, his hands pantomime them as elegantly as a signer for the deaf.
He can be combative and provoking. He can tease about race -- using humor with an edge to unsettle. The touchiness under the teasing is understandable. Here is a man who could flag down just about any job he wants on Broadway, but often he can't get a cab in front of his own theater.
He doesn't feel like going over what he calls "that 'Negro on parade' stuff" again: Born 40 years ago in small, pretty Frankfort, Ky., where his father was a clerk for the state department of corrections and his mother the principal of a private black grade school, and where he missed "101 Dalmatians" because blacks couldn't go into the Capitol Theater. He had good grades, good manners and "good hair"; high school theater conquered his stutter and brought him celebrity. After a year at a black university, Kentucky State, he moved to Pomona College in California.
It was after he arrived in New York and wrote "The Colored Museum," his 1986 skewering of black stereotypes, and "Spunk," a 1990 dramatization of three Zora Neale Hurston short stories -- two productions that impressed critics and audiences -- that he became well known. He wrote "Jelly's Last Jam," the life of Jelly Roll Morton in all its brilliance and self-hatred, and directed it on Broadway. That led to directing Tony Kushner's "Angels in America," for which he won a Tony Award. Next came Anna Deavere Smith's one-woman show "Twilight: Los Angeles 1992," which Mr. Wolfe also directed even as he began to put his stamp on the Public.
Raucous laughs break up his conversation, and he doesn't so much tell stories as do impressions of everyone in them. He describes panicky rehearsals for Mr. Kushner's "Angels": "Every day, someone in the cast would cry. [The actor, sobbing] 'I don't know what you want of me.' [Himself, consoling] I'd be patting him -- 'It's O.K., it's O.K.' [Turning to the nervous playwright hovering nearby] 'Tony, it's fine, it's wonderful, it's brilliant.' [Aside, to audience] 'You're killing me with these rewrites, Kushner.' "
Robin Wagner, the "Angels" and "Jelly's" set designer, who is on the Public's board, describes Mr. Wolfe rushing into his office many times saying, " 'I only have an hour.' And 8 or 10 hours later, everyone would have gone home, and we'd be there, with the lights on, still going over details."
 
As the Third Year Begins, A Relaxing of the Shoulders
 As Mr. Wolfe reshapes the Public, people have been let go. The cutbacks began out of necessity under Mr. Papp, who died in 1991, but there were long tenures and high salaries. On Jan. 1, time was up for Jason Steven Cohen, the managing director, who started as a stage manager 22 years ago, had risen to be Mr. Papp's right hand after Mr. Gersten left and shared leadership with Ms. Akalaitas during her tenure. He left gracefully but disappointed.
No dismissal has been painless. Mr. Wolfe calls them "serious, grown-up stuff" that he hadn't had to do before. "I try to do it respectfully. But my larger agenda is to transform this institution into the most effective, taut, muscular machine that I possibly can."
Joe Mantello, whom he directed in "Angels" and who went on to direct "Love! Valour! Compassion!" on Broadway, assessed Mr. Wolfe's management style this way: "George is a patient tyrant. He's going to get his way, but he's nurturing, and he gives you all the room in the world. He sees very clearly what he wants, and you end up there -- but feeling that you've done it all on your own."
What he has lost to the job, Mr. Wolfe said, is time for novels, movies and "this fantasy George who cooks." One victim is his New Year's gumbo blowout that started in 1982 with 20 friends, no money and three frozen shrimp and expired last year with 400 in a rented loft and lobster and crab in the pot.
Mr. Wolfe, who lives in SoHo, hangs out with friends. He visits a spiritualist in the Bronx named Candy because he's "fascinated by societies that honor their ancestors and have connections to something invisible." That's where his writing comes from, he says. "It's like a checkup. I don't ask, 'Should I do "The Petrified Prince" this season?' "
Recently, he said, a sense of clarity has set in. He has made it through the winter and into his contract's third year. "And now, I have completely made it mine -- things are in place so it can finally be my vision. Systems are in place. The board is in place. So there's a kind of relaxing of the shoulders.
"Last year, the signal was 'We're not dead.' This year, the signal was 'Energy is emanating out of this building -- this is where you come to see new work.' That's been accomplished."

HEADLINE: Shanghai's Fields of Green

BYLINE: By MARTHA WEINMAN LEAR; MARTHA WEINMAN LEAR, the author of "Heartsounds," is working on a memoir.

 BODY:
WE wanted a day in the country. No problem, our guide said. Everyone in Shanghai knows the same two English phrases: "joint venture" and "no problem."
We had been there a week and had overdosed on the city. Reflecting an entrepreneurial zeal possibly unmatched anywhere on earth, Shanghai today almost out-New Yorks New York: There is that kind of energy in the streets. The suits are glued to cellular telephones. The city is one big construction site -- bamboo scaffoldings rising like defoliated forests all over town, and whatever isn't a new shopping plaza elbowing all the mom-and-pops off the block is a high-rise bank or office building or glitzy hotel, and in these hotels the joint venturists sit, genially talking billions over breakfast. 
 It all makes the adrenaline flow. But after a few days, that loud hum of life and money starts getting to you, and you think it might be nice to relax in the countryside.
So: "No problem," the guide says, and at 7 A.M. on a Wednesday, we head out of the city.
The plan is to drive 60 miles west, through what has been described by Shanghainese as typical farmland, to the village of Zhou Zhoung, which dates to 1086 and is said to be one of the best-preserved ancient villages in China. An hour and a half each way, two hours to explore, and we're back easily in time for lunch. That's the plan.
An hour later, we have clocked three miles. Despite the economic explosion, most salaries are still extremely low -- our guide, who writes copy for a radio station, earns 1,000 yuan (about $110) a month -- and most people still travel by bicycle.
There are 13 million people in Shanghai. There are also 3.5 million bicycles, and at 8 on a workday morning every one of them seems to be out there playing chicken with the cars (350,000) and buses and pedestrians, and nobody blinks. The gridlock is like nothing I have ever seen.
We inch onward between rows of tenement housing with laundry-laden bamboo poles hanging out the windows. At 8:30 we have gone 12 miles. The guide announces that we now are in countryside. I look around. Walls of billboard. Real estate, mostly: "Shang-Min Garden," "Shanghai Elite Villas" "Investment in the Land -- Che Dun Town." Overhead, bilingual banners of exhortation arch across the road: "Be a Good Host to Our Distinguished Guests"; "Develop Highway and Vigorously Develop Shanghai." Behind the billboards, buildings newly risen and rising by the dozens: Yangtze New World Hotel, Rainbow Hotel (with its Gold Coast Club), People's Construction Bank of China, China World Trade Center . . . This is countryside?
"Used to be," our guide says. She explains that if we had gone looking for countryside in the old days, meaning before 1992, when China's hot market economy turned torrid, this is where we would have found it. Today it is an industrial development zone called Hong Qiao, one of three such zones ringing the city.
Who is doing all this building? we ask.
"Chinese Government. Foreigners. Many joint ventures, yes, yes. Here was all farms, very pretty," she says, gesturing toward the Galaxy Shanghai, the Shanghai Plaza, the Beverly Hills Bar, the Shanghai International Convention Hotel, the billboards for Shang Ling (appliances) and Zero Italy (sneakers).
Still, we are hopeful. Traffic has thinned a bit, we're zooming along now at 20 m.p.h. I see, between cars, glimpses of green. I see a field with incipiently growing things. A few haystacks. Two narrow canals, one with a sampan sweetly afloat. And up ahead is . . . what is it, a barn? A big shed? But no, it is the Shanghai Dong Fashion Company, followed by another field, followed by another factory.
So it goes for an hour more: promises, promises, wee teasers of green, countryside always just around the bend. By midmorning it hits me, quick study that I am, that we will not find the Shanghai countryside because there is no Shanghai countryside. There are only industrial development zones stretching on to the Himalayas.
Now the guide says that we are approaching the ancient town of Zhou Zhoung, and I think, well, if we can't have bucolic, we will at least have historic. Thus heartened, we arrive, and are greeted by a huge banner stretched across the road. It says:
"Welcome! Ancient Town Zhou Zhoung Worthy Paradise for Investors."
Four hours to get through Joint Venture Heaven, and now this. I feel cranky. But the village is a charmer, even though clogged with tourists (mainly Chinese; I saw no other Westerners). Ancient bridges arching over miniature canals, tiny squares full of vendors. One plies me with trinkets and I shake my head No. "No problem," he says.
WE wander through a maze of back alleys lined with little row houses made of stone. At almost every door is a wooden chamber pot. (You see these in midtown Shanghai too, in front of all the old houses on the side streets, in the shadow of the skyscrapers.) Who lives here, tradespeople? I ask. Tradespeople! The guide snorts delicately. These are privileged people. These houses have been in their families for centuries. (How ownership was maintained through the Mao years, I didn't ask and she didn't tell.)
I peer through a doorway and see a tiny, dismal room containing a coal grill, some pots, a plastic table, a shabby sofa, a stuffed Mickey Mouse on a shelf, and a woman sporting a terrific hair-do and wearing a suit that is, I would swear, an Armani. She beckons us in.
Our guide tells her that we are Americans. She smiles. She knows. I apologize for the intrusion. "No problem," she says, and then, in Chinese, cuts to the chase: "How much salary do you earn?"
Even in a Worthy Paradise for investors, this is a stopper. I stutter that a writer's income is deeply erratic.
She tsks. "It is better to be rich than to be a writer," she says, and I know absolutely that Confucius has spoken through this woman's mouth. Soon we thank her and depart. The guide is chagrined. "I know that in your country, it is not polite to talk about money," she says as we start back to Shanghai. "Chinese people never talked so much about money. Now they are always talking about salaries and stocks and joint ventures. Please do not be insulted."
No problem, I tell her.
Suddenly she points out the car window. "Look," she says, "countryside."
We are driving by a field, and in this field is a man wearing what used to be called a coolie hat, and he is bent beneath the weight of a bamboo shoulder pole, with buckets balanced at both ends. It is a freeze frame, a sliver of culture shock caught between Shanghai Aluminum Unison Products and Joint Venture Comfort Leather Products, and then it is gone.
"I am sorry there has not been more countryside," she says.
Listen, no problem.
Of course, we get back to Shanghai hours too late for lunch. We call our lunch date to apologize and he says, "Mei you wen ti," which means -- ah, but you know what it means.

SECTION: Section 9; Page 7; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1497 words

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVES;
Easing Well-to-Do Renters From Regulation's Tent

BYLINE: By ALAN S. OSER 

 BODY:
AT 215 East 68th Street, there have been 24 decontrol orders so far in high-rent apartments occupied by high-income tenants. At 265 East 66th there have been 28. At 800 Fifth Avenue, at 61st Street, the figure is also 28, and at 1385 York Avenue, at 73d Street, the figure is 33.
The champion recipient of decontrol orders seems to be 500 East 77th Street, which has 850 apartments. It received 68. 
 The ownerships of these five large rental buildings probably also filed the most applications with the state rent office in the Division of Housing and Community Renewal, asking the agency to pursue income verifications for over-$2,000-a-month apartments. Accordingly, they probably led in the number of decontrol orders denied, or dismissals, as well.
But all are illustrative of the consequences of peculiarly designed legislation that went into effect last year and is working to decontrol, ever so gradually, regulated apartments occupied by some of the city's wealthiest residents. It is now coming to the close of its first full year of operation, and a new cycle of owner applications is about to begin, with direct notices to tenants from owners inviting them to concede that they are overincome for their apartments. Those who don't reply or who reply with a denial will in time get the same inquiry from the state.
What makes the law peculiar is that it does not apply to apartments renting for under $2,000 a month, no matter how high the tenant's income. The $1,500-a-month apartment rented by a millionaire is unaffected. But if the rent is over $2,000 and the tenant's household income exceeded $250,000 in each of the two preceding years, the owner is entitled to a deregulated apartment. The income used is adjusted Federal gross income as reported on Line 19 of the New York State tax return.
"Many tenants thought they had to report what their income is, not a line on their tax return," said Bruce H. Wiener, a lawyer with the firm of Fischbein Badillo Wagner Itzler, in discussing what he said was a glitch that led to erroneous decontrol orders. "Many filled out the state form without reference to their tax return, or else that hadn't yet filed for one of those years," he said.
Glitches notwithstanding, the decontrol program has been in effect long enough to give a fairly clear picture of how many apartments it will affect in one year of operation. Its indirect effects, in inducing co-op purchases or custom-tailored lease renewals by wealthy people, may be even greater than its direct effects.
As of late March, the state agency had acted on 1,539 cases -- 69 percent of the 2,227 received in the first year's cycle of cases. It granted 853 decontrol applications and dismissed 686 cases. A total of 688 cases are still pending.
THE number of decontrol orders granted -- 853 -- is 13 percent of all the 6,500 regulated apartments renting for more than $2,000 and receiving no tax abatements under the Section 421a program. (Adding those apartments in produces 11,500 over-$2,000 regulated units.) While buildings are still getting tax abatements the apartments are not eligible for deregulation.
The great majority of the 853 decontrol orders went for apartments whose tenants failed to fill out and return the state income form, officials said.
Owners or tenants may file for an administrative review of the agency's action. There have been 220 such appeals, 97 from tenants and the rest from owners. One owner filed 92 appeals, all involving dismissals based on a failure to file on time.
In the state's "pending" category are the cases for which it has not been possible so far to match financial data submitted by tenants with tax data from the Department of Taxation and Finance. One major reason was that tenants with minors in the household listed them as required on the state form, even though minors don't pay a state income tax. That produced a problem in obtaining a "match." Without a match, the owner's application is to be dismissed.
The rent agency submitted 1,081 cases to the Department of Taxation and Finance for matching. Successful matching so far has produced dismissal notices of 422 deregulation applications, and decontrol orders in only 21 cases, suggesting that tenants who know they are overincome are likely not to return the state's form at all.
The problem concerning minors accounts for about two-thirds of the 688 cases that have so far produced no match, state officials said. But they expect to succeed ultimately in making these matches. In most of the remaining unmatched cases it appears that no state income tax was filed, perhaps because the tenant works for the United Nations, or because the tenant's primary residence is in another state. In the latter case, the information may be useful to owners in pursuing a nonprimary residence action. Tenants are not entitled to a regulated apartment unless it is their primary residence.
A subject of much discussion and skepticism when the law was passed was how successfully the tenant-supplied information could be matched with income tax data. Owners were dubious. However, it appears that a match will eventually be made in 77 percent of the cases. It is a better ratio than many had predicted, but perhaps still a sign of a flawed method.
WHAT is striking in the entire procedure is that it has worked mainly to decontrol apartments indirectly. Most of those who were decontrolled didn't respond to the state notice at all. They thereby won themselves more time as regulated tenants, while the bureaucratic wheels ground, than they would have had by conceding as much on earlier inquiry forms from owners. But eventually they received decontrol orders. Some will say, perhaps in court, that they never received the state notice.
Many of those who are under-income complied with the system and successfully protected their occupancy rights. Decontrol was denied. But to protect their occupancy they probably will have to be ready to submit to the procedure annually. Many tenants have already received landlord notices for the second cycle, involving income earned in 1993 and 1994.
The decontrol provision expires with the rent-stabilization law itself in 1997. In the 1996-97 legislative session all rent regulatory law will be up for renewal or reconsideration.
In pure-rental buildings, many tenants receiving decontrol orders will negotiate a new nonregulated rent before their lease expires. "Most of the cases haven't come up yet because the leases are still running, but in the few that have, settlements are being reached in a third to a half the cases, and the tenants are staying on on a deregulated basis," said Jeffrey Turkel, a lawyer with the firm of Rosenberg & Estis. Owners have given two- , three- or in some cases five-year leases to advance rents to market levels.
But rents may be so far from market levels that a tenant may decide to move. At the Pavilion, the 850-unit 1963 building that occupies the full block from 76th to 77th Street between York Avenue and John Jay Park, roughly 5 percent of the over-$2,000 apartments are renting at about 60 percent of market value, said Gary Jacobs, executive vice president of Glenwood Management, the owner. The tenants are paying somewhat more than $2,000 a month for units that could be rented for about $3,200.
"A number of tenants have moved out," Mr. Jacobs said. "To me it proves the theory that any regulation creates gridlock." In many other cases the tenant's rent is already at or close to the rent obtainable for a vacancy, so the law has little impact.
IN co-ops, long-term renters are more inclined to buy their apartments if they know sponsors will not be obliged to renew their rental leases.
"As leases expire we are asking people either to buy or move so we can sell the vacancy," said Arnold Goldstein, whose company, Samson Management, converted the 74-unit co-op at 1150 Fifth Avenue, at 96th Street, four years ago. The 1929 building has 44 preconversion renters, 17 of them living there so long that they are rent-controlled.
Four decontrol orders have already been received, though two are being contested. In seven other cases, eight- and nine-room apartments are renting at close to $2,000 a month, and will be above it in a year or so. They have an as-is sale value of about $600 a square foot, Mr. Goldstein says, or $1.2 million for eight rooms and $1.8 million for nine. Co-op owners pay about $2,900 a month in maintenance for the eight-room units and $3,300 a month for nine rooms.
Tenant lawyers say that an undetermined issue is how high a sponsor can raise the rent of a deregulated rental in a co-op. They maintain that these apartments are covered by a provision of the General Business Law that says in buildings accepted by the Attorney General for conversion, renters shall not be subjected to "unconscionable rent increases beyond ordinary rentals for comparable apartments during the period of their occupancy."

HEADLINE: YOUR HOME;
'Trapped' In a Co-op

BYLINE: By JAY ROMANO 

 BODY:
IN 1989, when Emily Nomer and her husband, Daniel Manzanares, bought their first home -- a one-bedroom co-op in a building near Union Square in Manhattan -- their intention was to upgrade to a larger apartment as their family grew.
Six years and two children later, they are still living in their one-bedroom apartment; they have partitioned off part of the living room to create the second bedroom they so desperately need. They would like to buy a larger apartment but cannot because to do so they would have to sell the one unit in which they now live. And they have discovered -- along with nearly every other unit owner in the building -- that their apartment is virtually unmarketable. 
 "We didn't know the rules would change," Ms. Nomer said, explaining that the sponsor, instead of making efforts to sell apartments in the building, is now renting them. "As soon as realtors find out that the sponsor still owns 80 percent of the building, they back off. They know that the banks just won't lend."
Indeed, real estate experts say, Ms. Nomer and her neighbors are not alone. Thousands of unit owners are literally "trapped" in co-op apartments they cannot sell because buyers cannot get financing when the sponsor owns a majority of the units. "I've seen it over and over and over again," said James Samson, a Manhattan lawyer who specializes in co-op and condominium law.
The problem, Mr. Samson said, affects a significant number of buildings that were converted to co-ops at the end of the conversion boom in the late 1980's. In many cases, he said, the recession that followed the boom made it difficult for sponsors to sell all the units in their buildings. As a result, he said, they rented units they could not sell.
Under ordinary circumstances, Mr. Samson said, that strategy would be a temporary one. But since, according to the state's rent-regulation codes, unsold apartments in converted buildings become exempt from rent stabilization or rent control when the existing tenant moves out, sponsors soon discovered that if they waited long enough, they could rent vacated apartments at market rents. In the last few years, as the rental market improved, it became more profitable for sponsors to rent their unsold units than to sell them. "The result can be catastrophic," Mr. Samson said.
Victor Miller, board president of the co-op association at 200 East 16th Street, couldn't agree more. "I bought into a promise that this was going to be a housing corporation set up for the benefit of potential owners," Mr. Miller said. "Instead, it's run more like a tenancy than a housing corporation."
The building at 200 East 16th Street, Mr. Miller said, was converted to a co-op in 1989 when the sponsor sold 40 of the 194 apartments. "He has not sold one additional unit since," Mr. Miller said. "We've had a tremendous amount of tenant turnover in the building, but all the sponsor does is mark the rent up and rent the apartments out. There's no incentive for him to sell. We're viewing this as a false conversion."
In August 1994, Mr. Miller said, the co-op association filed suit against the sponsor seeking a court order compelling him to sell the units he owns in the building.
Jonathan M. Landsman, the lawyer who filed the suit, said that it is the first of its kind in New York. "One of the causes of action is that the sponsor breached the contract with the co-op corporation when he intentionally stopped selling units," Mr. Landsman said.
Jack Feldman, an owner of Sigfeld Realty, the sponsor of the building, is contesting the suit and denied that the building was a "false conversion."
"That's a lot of baloney," Mr. Feldman said. "We've been constantly trying to sell units, but the market was weak. The renting is only a temporary situation. I'm renting because I've got to cover my expenses. I'm stuck here, too."
Marc Luxemburg, president of the Council of New York Cooperatives, said that there is usually no time limit by which a sponsor must sell his units specified in offering plans. Moreover, there is nothing in the law that prohibits the sponsor from renting unsold units.
But Mr. Luxemburg also said that sponsors have a contractual obligation to purchasers to complete the offering according to the offering plan, provided the sponsors do not suffer unreasonable economic harm. And whether the actions of the sponsor are intentional or not, the result is usually the same: apartments in the building become essentially unmarketable.
"It's impossible to get a mortgage," said Margaret S. Scott, president of Mortgage Advisory Services in Manhattan. For a prospective purchaser to obtain a co-op mortgage that meets the requirements of the Federal National Mortgage Association, Ms. Scott said, the building usually must be 80 percent owned by tenant-shareholders. But in some cases, she said, Fannie Mae, which purchases mortgages from lending institutions, will, like most banks, accept 51 percent. Some mortgage companies will provide financing in buildings that have as few as 35 percent of units sold. Those, however, are rare.
"If you have one person -- the sponsor -- owning most of the building, lenders are afraid that the sponsor could go bankrupt," Ms. Scott said. "They'd be relying too much on one person."
The result of those fears, experts say, can be devastating.
"The fact is, there are people who are trapped in their apartments in New York," said Arthur I. Weinstein, a Manhattan lawyer and vice president of the Council of New York Cooperatives. And, he said, it is necessary that prospective purchasers be made aware of the potential problem they may have reselling units in buildings where sponsors own a majority of the units, even though that may serve to exacerbate the plight of unit-owners, including the one trying to sell to the prospective purchaser.
Mr. Luxemburg said there are potential problems in nearly 1,500 buildings in New York State that still have unsold units. "It's a significant problem," he said. "And unfortunately, the sponsors don't think they're doing anything wrong. It needs to be pointed out to them that they have promised to convert their building to a co-op at some time in the reasonable future and not keep it as a rental from now until kingdom come."
Mr. Samson, who represents several co-op corporations in buildings where sponsors have stopped selling apartments, said the only way to persuade a sponsor to sell is to provide him with an economic incentive. "You've got to stop him from renting," Mr. Samson said, adding that it is often easier and more effective to get a court order prohibiting a sponsor from renting apartments than it is to get an order compelling the sale of the units. "You've got to make the economics of selling more attractive than the economics of not selling," he said.
Another way to do so, at least prospectively, would be to eliminate the ability of the owner to collect market rents on what were formerly rent-stabilized apartments.
"The easy way to solve the problem," Mr. Samson said, "is to close the loophole." But that would require legislation. "And that may be impractical," he said.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/Atlantic City;
A 74,000-Square-Foot Shopping Center Passes Go

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
IN large and economically vibrant cities, it might not be all that big a deal: A 74,000-square-foot shopping center with a Thriftway supermarket, a CVS drug store, a variety store, a low-priced apparel store and maybe a Taco Bell.
But in Atlantic City, the April 6 groundbreaking for Renaissance Plaza, a few blocks inland from the Boardwalk and bounded by Atlantic, Arctic, New York and Kentucky Avenues, was a big deal indeed. Caterers served mahi-mahi and other fancy foods under a big tent. Mayor James Whelan showed up, as did the chairman of the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority, Fredrick P. Nickles, New Jersey State Senator William Gormley and assorted businessmen and community leaders. 
 "This is the kind of project where everybody wins," Mayor Whelan said.
The hoopla and the Mayor's ebullience were both understandable. Renaissance Plaza is a visible symbol that, after shooting snake-eyes for years, Atlantic City is finally on a construction roll. A $270 million convention center is scheduled to open in late 1996. New hotel rooms are going up. Developers are talking about movie theaters, shopping malls, even a factory outlet.
"Yes, everything has been slow, but things are moving now," Mr. Nickles said.
For Atlantic City residents, Renaissance Plaza is more than a symbol of growth. Indeed, Harold Friedland's 43,000 square foot Thriftway will be the first supermarket to operate in Atlantic City in 25 years.
"Most chain stores avoid the inner city," said Mr. Friedland, who operates six Thriftways in low-income areas of Philadelphia and of Wilmington, Del. "But there's no competition, so you do great sales volume even at fair prices."
Still, until recently the shopping center had been stymied by low funds and high bureaucracy. Indeed, Atlantic City officials have been talking about shopping centers, new hotels and a rebuilt boulevard off the Atlantic City Expressway for nearly 10 years. Nearly every project has died, or been mired in the courts, or fallen victim to political infighting and red tape.
"You just can't keep debating if you want a shrub on the left or right side of a street," said a frustrated Arthur M. Goldberg, chairman of Bally Entertainment, which owns two Boardwalk casinos. Kenneth B. Platt, the city's planning director, acknowledges the criticism. "There have been dry runs, dead ends, false starts," he conceded.
Apparently, the stalemate is over, in part due to the Casino Reinvestment Development Authority (CRDA, and pronounced CREE-da). CRDA, which expects to collect some $1.4 billion over the next 20 years from a 1.25 percent levy on gaming revenues, provided some $5.5 million of Renaissance Plaza's $13 million cost. Mr. Nickles predicts that, through direct subsidies to hotels, CRDA will spend some $100 million to generate some 2,000 new hotel rooms.
Several hotels have already signed on for subsidies. TropWorld is building 628 new rooms, using the air rights over its stand-alone garage. Donald Trump's Taj Mahal and Bally's Grand and Park Place hotels are building new rooms, too.
CONSIDERING that every study of Atlantic City's visitors shows that they are primarily day-trippers, the emphasis on hotel expansion might seem curious. It is not. The budding hope throughout Altantic City is that over the next few years the tiny town -- just 48 blocks long and about 4 blocks wide -- will again be a haven for family vacations and business meetings.
"Decades ago Atlantic City was a real family resort, and we want to reclaim that heritage," Mr. Platt said.
The push comes just in time. As long as Atlantic City was the only gaming game in town -- Las Vegas, after all, is not within easy driving distance -- there was little real pressure to change the status quo. But then the mammoth Foxwoods Casino opened in Ledyard, Conn. Riverboat gambling grabbed hold in some southern cities. And New York State and Pennsylvania began talking of installing gaming as well.
"Atlantic City needs a new competitive edge," said Robert Minutoli, a senior vice president of the Rouse Company, the Maryland developer that wants to build an entertainment complex on the Boardwalk.
The casino hotels already are scrambling to offer enjoyments beyond gaming. Several of the hotels are replacing their Boardwalk delis with far more upscale fare. Resorts International has plans for a California Pizza Kitchen, a Starbucks coffee house and a TCBY frozen yogurt shop. Planet Hollywood just opened in Caesars Atlantic City. And a Warner Brothers store is already thriving in Trump Plaza.
The city is relaxing rules that prevented the hotels from setting up Boardwalk cafes. And it is allowing the casinos to expand into hotel retail space, something that was strictly forbidden before. The hope is that some of the good shops in the hotels will supplant the fast food and souvenir shops in the Boardwalk's stand-alone retail space.
Off-Boardwalk development remains more problematic. Atlantic City has many trash-strewn vacant lots, but they are scattered around, making it hard to assemble sites for large developments. And the always-present prospect of unfettered casino expansion has resulted in skyrocketing land prices, making many projects unprofitable.
Now CRDA and other city agencies are buying land and leasing it to developers at palatable rates. "Without the CRDA intervention, this project would not have worked," said Louis P. Meshon Sr., president of Montgomery Group Affiliates, the Plymouth Meeting, Pa., developer that is building Renaissance Plaza.
Other out-of-state developers are spotting profit opportunities now, too. The Rouse Company wants to build a Boardwalk center with a Monopoly theme that would capitalize on the well-known link between the properties on the Monopoly game board and Atlantic City's streets. Forest City Rattner, which owns Brooklyn's Metrotech as well as a couple of Brooklyn shopping centers, wants to build an Italian-themed center on about 30 acres adjacent to the Showboat Hotel. Forest City's project would include a factory outlet mall, as well as two movie theaters, exhibition spaces, restaurants, a children's entertainment area and more.
Unfortunately for Atlantic City, many potential projects physically overlap. Showboat, which wants to expand onto the adjacent land itself, has sued to stop the Forest City project. And last December, while Rouse, CRDA and various city officials argued over where Rouse's entertainment complex should be, Bally's Mr. Goldberg quietly spent $7.5 million for a four-acre piece of land near his Park Place casino that Rouse considered vital to its project.
"Everything was taking so long, and the land was a junk-filled eyesore," said Mr. Goldberg, who plans to have exhibitions, stores and another casino on the land by the end of 1996. Most of the developers expect that compromises will be found. "There are options being explored that don't involve Goldberg's land," Mr. Minutoli said. A senior executive at Forest City, although he would not talk for attribution, said, "We are pretty sure there's a way to work things out so that Showboat can expand too."
IN the meantime, city officials are pursuing business visitors. They recently signed up a trade show from India, to be held in Atlantic City's old convention center this June. "We sent three people to India for two-and-a-half weeks to get that show," Mr. Platt said. "We are hoping it will establish a precedent for international shows."
Before that can happen, Atlantic City will have to fix itself up. Although Mr. Platt insists that the city is relatively safe and has huge pockets of neatly kept, middle-class housing, he concedes that its image remains that of an underclass town whose visitors had best stick to the Boardwalk.
"Our infrastructure has been neglected, and the dingy atmosphere gives visitors a feeling of discomfort," he said.
The city and CRDA together have pumped nearly $50 million into housing, roads and landscaping, and the city is building a $12 million baseball stadium.
And the city finally is spiffing up its front door. The Atlantic City Expressway, by far the most used entry to town, lets off onto a street bounded by a bus terminal and a little-used park, with some oversized promotional signage straight ahead.
Over the last five years several architects and developers submitted plans, many of which suffered the local equivalent of a pocket veto. A $2 parking fee that the city expected would raise $200 million for redevelopment only raised $100 million.
For a time the city thought Rouse would build its entertainment project along the entranceway, but the developer was far more interested in the Boardwalk.
Now CRDA has allocated some $35 million to move the bus terminal and create a boulevard-like, tree-lined street from the Expressway to the Boardwalk. And most officials insist that, this time, plans will result in progress.
"Now that the convention center is under construction, we no longer have the luxury of planning forever," Mr. Platt said.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
A Widow Takes Charge at a Real Estate Business

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD 

DATELINE: BRONXVILLE

 BODY:
LAST Monday marked the one-year anniversary of a tragic day at Houlihan/ Lawrence, the largest residential real estate company in Westchester County. The company's headquarters in a white clapboard building is where Peter Bailey Seaman spent most of his time while he was chairman and chief executive from May 1990 until April 1994, when he died of a brain tumor at age 42.
During her husband's illness, Nancy M. Seaman said, it was just assumed that in the event of his death she would take control of the company. "We never talked about it because we always assumed that Peter was going to recover," Ms. Seaman said. "Up until the time he died, we still hoped and believed he would make it." 
 After his death, Ms. Seaman stepped in and the change of leadership has been remarkably smooth, according to staff members and executives in the industry. "Had we not been informed, we might not have known there had been a personnel change," said P. Gilbert Mercurio, executive vice president of the Westchester County Board of Realtors. He attributes that, in part, to the way Mr. Seaman restructured the company, giving more power to branch managers. "And from an organizational standpoint, they have a very high quality staff," he said.
Throughout Mr. Seaman's stewardship, his wife, who was a 50 percent ownership partner, was involved in many of his major decisions.
"It wasn't a matter of Nancy starting with the company after Peter died, she was always there," said Ebie Wood, regional manager for the central region, which has seven branch offices.
Ms. Seaman, 41, holds a master's degree in business administration from Indiana University, and was most recently the United States marketing representative of Beiersdorf, the German manufacturer of Nivea skin care products. "After my daughter was born six years ago, I decided not to work for a while," she said. "I had waited so long to have her, I wanted to be with her."
In an interview, it's clear that Ms. Seaman considers herself to be carrying out her husband's legacy, although she seems equally determined to do it in her own way. A picture of Mr. Seaman, wearing a Houlihan/Lawrence cap, adorns her desk. In another part of the office are several photographs of the couple's two children, a 6-year-old daughter, Callie, and 3-year-old son, Jamie.
"My children are my life now," she said. "I'm torn about being away from them. When I'm not working, all my activities are centered around them."
She said it seemed ironic that in a year that was so personally wrenching, the company posted its most successful sales figures.
Volume increased from $400 million in 1993 to $900 million in 1994, Ms. Seaman said. She attributes that almost entirely to her husband's groundwork. "Peter had a three-year plan that had been completed," she said. "He restructured the company and turned it into a profit center. So when the economy improved we had all our ducks in a row and could take advantage of it."
Houlihan/Lawrence is the largest residential real estate company in the county in terms of employees. "They have 330 licensees, either brokers or sales agents, which is about 10 percent of our total membership," Mr. Mercurio said. The national chain Coldwell Banker is next with just over 300, Mr. Mercurio said. "After that, the numbers drop off dramatically," he added.
ALTHOUGH the realtors board has no company-by-company comparison of sales volume, Mr. Mercurio said, "it wouldn't surprise me if Houlihan/Lawrence had the No. 1 position."
Houlihan/Lawrence is a home-grown company that holds a dominant position in an industry that has increasingly been taken over by national affiliations, Mr. Mercurio said. "I don't know of any neighboring company in the same position," he said.
Before the Seamans bought Houlihan/ Lawrence, Mr. Seaman was the owner and chief executive of Harbor Fuel, an oil company on Nantucket. Before that he was director of marketing at Chesebrough-Ponds. When the Seamans bought Houlihan/ Lawrence in 1990 it had a blue-chip reputation but was losing money. Mr. Seaman reduced staff by 50 percent and created three regional centers, each with its own manager. "The offices were decentralized, and each had greater autonomy," Ms. Seaman said.
One of her first moves was to create a chief operating officer position, and hire Scott Rogers, a family friend who had his own sporting goods company in California. Mr. Rogers has just completed a national study looking at areas of opportunity for Houlihan/Lawrence. While Ms. Seaman was not prepared to disclose specifics, she did say that she saw growth for the company. "There's a lot of opportunity in new construction," she said. "We'll be making some announcements in two or three weeks."
She also just hired an outside marketing team to buttress the work of the staff. "This will be the year of marketing," she said, "After last year, we'll be riding the crest of the wave."
Ms. Seaman proudly noted that during her husband's illness and after his death the company did not lose any major performers to the competition. "Instead of jumping ship, people were jumping on," she said. One of them was Pat Bentley, the manager of the Katonah office, who left the same position with Coldwell Banker in September. "I think it's possible to make a difference here," Ms. Bentley said, "to make your voice heard."
TO many people in the company, Ms. Seaman's management style has brought some subtle changes. "She relates to people and their families because that's so important to her," said Debra Dalton, vice president of corporate administration.
Since over 90 percent of the agents are women, working for a woman chief executive has a special significance, according to Vera Blendermann, manager of the Bronxville office. "They like her approach," she said. "She writes notes of appreciation. And she's started sending out letters to everyone who buys something with us, asking if they were pleased with our service."
She also increased the number of agents who were eligible for incentive bonuses. "It tells people how committed she is to performance," Ms. Dalton said, "and gives them incentive."
On the inside cover of the corporate directory there is a full-page tribute to Peter Seaman, thanking him for setting the company's course. "Because of you we sail on in strength," it says.
To Ms. Seaman, the same could be said of her. "Peter made me feel like I could do anything," she said. "Three weeks after his terrible diagnosis, we were in Florida. It was a beautiful night, and he said 'we are so lucky.'
"I didn't understand it then, but one and half years later, he had conveyed to me how fortunate I was to have had what I did with him. And I was left with so much, my children, this company. I do feel lucky."
