HEADLINE: ART;
Among a Judge's Choices, Some Extremes Between Extremes

BYLINE: By VIVIEN RAYNOR 

 BODY:
EVERY year for the last 25, the Stamford Museum and Nature Center has cast its net in the art pool and invited a judge to sift through the catch.
The results, exhibited under the title "Connecticut Art," have been surprisingly varied considering the limitations imposed by geography and the predictable recurrance of a few regulars. Still, the shows are generally more interesting for what they reveal of the judges' personalities than for the news they bring of the scene. 
 This time the judge was Eugenie Tsai, who has been making her mark as director of the Whitney Museum's branch in Stamford and as a curator of its shows. (Her most noteworthy achievement last year was the show of the electronic art of Nam June Paik and the walls of tiny paintings by Ik-Joong Kong.) Of the 174 contenders converging on the Nature Center, Ms. Tsai took 74, awarding 4 the customary group show.
At one end of the esthetic spectrum is Janet Baldi's study of cupboard shelves loaded with crockery, glass and kitchen utensils. The still life, painted in browns and creams and illuminated from below, is one of the few examples of photographic realism.
At the spectrum's other end is Mary Dwyer with small naive images that pertain to Chinese immigration at the end of the last century. "Laying the Railroad 1872" depicts a Wyatt Earp-type gunman and a row of laborers wearing white clothes and black caps and waving tiny American flags.
Between the two extremes are other extremes, like Rick Shaefer's imaginary landscape versus the drawing of hummocky grassland by Virginia Zimmermann. Mr. Shaefer's scene has the look of a chiaroscuro engraving but is actually a drawing in what appears to be black ink and watercolor. The foreground is filled with flowers and insects worthy of a botanical illustrator while, behind, sits a romantically rocky landscape fading into infinity. The sense of recession is also present in Ms. Zimmermann's "Country Road 14" but the image measures about three feet by four feet, the medium is charcoal and the technique illusionist.
Weak drawing and a timid way with paint would seem to be handicaps. But for Morton Hollinger's purpose they are almost prerequisites. Representing this painter is a nightclub interior occupied by women in pastel chiffon dresses and men in tuxedoes, all of whom seem to be performers. Though the period is the 1930's, as celebrated by P. G. Wodehouse, the listless atmosphere bespeaks the W. P. A. rather than the jolly world of Bertie Wooster and his gentleman's gentleman, Jeeves.
Ann Chernow's woman partly illuminated by a table lamp, a blue-toned etching with aquatint, catches the eye; so does Elisa Khachian's watercolor of a fish in water that can also be read as a paisley-like pattern. But for sheer magnetism there is nothing to equal "Caroly Koffler, M. D., Ph. D," a portrait by Arthur Koffler. Although the drawing, particularly the eyes and mouth, is first-rate, it is the almost fauve color applied in small dabs that holds the viewer enthralled. Just as remarkable is the artist's response to a model who is far from young. Where some would turn her into a picturesque senior citizen, Mr. Koffler portrays her as a dynamic personality first and an elderly woman second.
The sculpture tends to be rather fanciful. Joseph Fucigna is represented by a large metal piece involving a polygonal shape suspended like an exhaust over a polygonal base. Between the two is a pair of metal strips curving outward and a stubby form covered like a gear shift with black leather or plastic. This construction, which hovers between art and craft, stands adjacent to Janet Lage's tall box, which contains twigs visible through a pane of glass on the top and around which snakes a long branch dabbed at each end with red paint.
Rather more memorable are the efforts of Eleanor White and Doug Morrill. Having filled several small cages with mildewed sandwiches, Ms. White lashes them together and suspends them on a wall. Mr. Morrill's "Birds in Cage" consists of wood forms trapped in a structure filled with crisscrossing wires. In a companion work, the birds, now serpentine in shape and cleft at one end, ripple up and out of the cage, parallel to each other.
The line dividing imagination from mere imaginativeness is fine and too often is crossed by the sculpture and assemblages. But relief is provided by the black and white photographs of Joanna Nichols and Robert Zott. Ms. Nichols depicts a pair of Brahman bovines who stand close, protecting the calf between them.
Mr. Zott fills half a wall with six pictures of tombstones, each inscribed with a name that is also a color, beginning with white and ending with black. In deadpan confirmation of the sequence, the prints range from very light to very dark in tone.
This "Connecticut Art" reflects many moods, none of them too serious, fortunately. It remains on view through next Sunday.

HEADLINE: Big Demand And Short Supply Lift Rents In Manhattan

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO 

 BODY:
RENTING a place to live in New York hasn't been easy or inexpensive in recent years. Yes, rents fell somewhat in the early 1990's, thanks to the recession and a decline in the quality of life in the city. Since then, however, rents, particularly in Manhattan, have crept back up to -- and in some cases moved beyond -- the highs that occurred in the real estate boom of the mid- and late 1980's.
"Rents have been rising and are continuing to rise for most apartments," said Nancy Packes, president of Feathered Nest, a rental agency in Manhattan. "The only exception has probably been large three-bedroom apartments on the Upper East Side. And that's only because there's a small market for them, and people are buying them now rather than renting them." 
 As it did a decade ago, the lack of available units combined with the city's unusually high percentage of renters (New York City has one of the lowest home ownership rates in the nation) hinders many apartment hunters.
The process is particularly arduous for young newcomers to the city, who can't afford four-figure monthly rents, much less the $2,000 to $3,000 needed to pay a broker to find such apartments.
"When I saw how much it would cost for a broker, I said, 'No way,' " said Matt Hoffberg, a 24-year-old software writer from Greenwich, Conn., who is looking for a studio in Manhattan, preferably in the East Village, or to a share a larger apartment for about $500 a month.
For households with six-figure incomes, finding a rental in the city -- Manhattan is usually the desired location -- is much easier, especially if an employer is paying for relocation costs and a broker's fee.
Even so, sticker shock strikes many.
"In Munich, this would be worth about $1,000 a month -- at most," said Andrea Bochmann as she surveyed a $3,000-a-month furnished apartment in a doorman building in the Turtle Bay section of Manhattan earlier this month.
And even with a broker setting up appointments and guiding the way, the apartment-hunting process can be exasperating and exhausting. In New York, bedrooms are often too small, natural light almost nonexistent and neighborhoods bleak if not decrepit.
"I hate it," said Ms. Bochmann, a journalist who has looked at about 10 apartments in Manhattan in search for a one-year rental. She is moving to Manhattan with her husband, Fritz, a psychologist, and their 9-year-old daughter, Laura, because her husband has a fellowship at a local hospital.
As with the co-op market, it is difficult to ascertain average rents in the city. No government agency or private group collects such data on a citywide or even Manhattan-wide basis. Brokers have their own surveys, but they tend to focus on high-end properties, such as doorman buildings in Manhattan, and ignore the tens of thousands of new New Yorkers who take leases on walkups and other apartments elsewhere in the city or in New Jersey.
Furthermore, no reliable data exist on what percentage of prospective tenants use brokers or rely on newspaper ads, bulletin-board postings and word of mouth.
"Generally, people don't use a broker if they are looking for an apartment under $1,200 a month," Ms. Packes said. "Most people under that level will go directly to the landlord because they don't have the cash flow to pay a broker and make a security deposit. People in the higher price range are willing to pay for the service of having someone screen the properties for them."
People who use brokers also appear to be much more likely to be relocating to the city from elsewhere. A survey by Feathered Nest last year showed that 57 percent of the company's clients were looking for an apartment in Manhattan as part of a new job relocation.
Changes in marital status or a personal relationship, along with moving closer to their workplace and needing more space were the next most popular reasons for renting an apartment. Those reasons were chosen by only six percent of the survey's respondents, however.
Ms. Packes said the rising demand for rentals has made apartment hunters are less fussy. She said that fewer tenants were moving just because they wanted to live in a different neighborhood and more were moving because they wanted a better deal or more space.
"The importance of a view has diminished to the vanishing point," she said.
Ms. Packes also noted that the percentage of people renting because they have sold their apartments has almost doubled in the past year from 3 percent to 5 percent.
"Clearly, the experience of people waiting for the market to come back from the late 1980's gave some people trepidation about buying again and made them question the theory that real estate only goes up in value," Ms. Packes said.
The Feathered Nest survey covered about 1,800 apartment rentals in 1994. More than a third of them, 40 percent, came relocated in New York from another part of the United States. Twenty-five percent came from another country. (Ten percent came from the New York suburbs, 25 percent from elsewhere in Manhattan and 2 percent from Brooklyn, Queens, Staten Island or the Bronx.)
The favorable currency exchange rate is a big plus for corporate transfers from places like Germany and Japan, where the dollar has declined in value substantially over the past year.
"Usually people that come over here wind up being able to rent nicer places than they have at home," said Kelly Miller-Taylor, a broker with Feathered Nest. "That's particularly true with the germans and Japanese, not so much with the Italians, because their currency has been having problems, too."
Though the prices vary widely depending on the neighborhood and amenities offered, rents, according to a recent survey by the Halstead Property Company, a Manhattan real estate broker, showed that the average monthly rent for a studio apartment is $965, for a one-bedroom unit, $1,800; for a small two-bedroom, $2,650, for a large $3,340 and more than two bedrooms, $4,600. The survey, according to the company, is based on 6,781 properties.
"It is as tight as '89," said Brian Edwards, director of leasing for the Halstead Property Company. "The middle of the market, apartments renting for, say, $1,500 to $3,000 a month is even tighter."
He noted that at The Orleans, a former hotel and Columbia University dormitory, at 100 West 80th Street at Columbus Avenue on the Upper West Side in Manhattan, a two-bedroom, 1,050-square-foot apartment that rented for $2,500 18 months ago recently rerented at $3,400.
A one-bedroom, 875-square-foot apartment in the doorman, pre-war building that rented for $1,800 18 months ago now rents for $2,200. And a 900-square-foot one-bedroom apartment that rented for $2,500 now goes for $2,900.
"Can you imagine that?," Mr. Edwards asked. "Two thousand, nine hundred dollars for 900-square-foot one-bedroom apartment?"
He added that most of the tenants in the building were singles and two-income couples with no children. "I don't think we have put anyone in that building who has less than $200,000 a year in income," Mr. Edwards said.
He also said that the rising rents are making some tenants consider buying, particularly those paying rents of more than $3,000 a month for large luxury apartments in prime areas of Manhattan. "But when they go out to buy, they see that purchases are getting tight, too," Mr. Edwards said.
"Then they get into bidding wars, and they get angry, when they can get the kind of apartment they want," he added.
"The biggest demand is for two bedrooms," Mr. Edwards said. "Then for three bedrooms."
Turnover is also thought by brokers who track the market to be low nowadays. (About one-third of all market-rent apartments are in co-op's, where many sub-tenants can usually live no longer than two years. The other third are in condos, where the landlord may want to move back in. The other third are in rental buildings.)
"When prices are rising, no one moves," Ms. Packes said. "When prices are falling, everyone moves."
Outside of Manhattan, in places like Brooklyn Heights, Cobble Hill, Park Slope, and Hoboken, N.J., rents can be as much 30 percent cheaper for comparable apartments, according to brokers.
Elsewhere, rents can fall even lower. "Rentals are pretty strong," said Jim Hayden, a independent broker in Flushing, Queens. "One bedrooms are going for $700 to $800 a month, two bedrooms for $850 to $1,000, depending on size and location."

Why are rental apartments so expensive in New York? Supply and demand, basically. Though their numbers may be declining, there is still a steady stream of new arrivals to the city, many of them seeking rentals because they have no intention of staying more than a few years before moving elsewhere for career opportunities or to the suburbs to raise a family. The number of desirable apartments, however, is small, as there is little new construction going on these days, though there are a few buildings being built.
"There is a lot of talk going on but lot much is getting funding," Ms. Packes said. "A great deal of planning for new construction took place based upon the rent increases of 1993 and 1994, but the planning process still takes a good deal of time and only a few projects have begun construction."
The co-op conversions in the 1980's also diminished the size of rent-stabilized market and increased the demand for market-rent apartments. (It also, however, added a new supply of market-rent co-op apartments sub-leased by unit owners.)
More important, though, about 500,000 apartments in New York, about one-third of the city's total, have also been effectively removed from the market because of rent-regulation, which grants families the right to live in relatively inexpensive apartments.
Thus, many struggling New Yorkers arrive in Manhattan to learn that a 700-square-foot one-bedroom apartment will cost them $1,500 to $2,000 a month, but there are millionaires living in rentals three times larger in prime locations and paying about the same or even less. (Rent-controlled apartments are those built before 1947 that have been continuously occupied by a tenant, or a legal successor, since 1971. When rent-controlled apartments are vacated their rents rise to market level and they become rent stabilized. Apartments built between 1947 and 1974 are also rent-stabilized, which means that the rents are adjusted annually by the New York City Rent Guidelines Board, which determines the permissable levels or rent increases for one and two-year leases, as well as any other adjustments, such as vacancy allowances, the increase in rent that's allowed when an apartment becomes vacant.)
The rent-regulation system, which remains in place largely because of the political clout of those who live in the apartments, was reformed slightly last year when the state deregulated apartments occupied by households earning $250,000 or more for two consecutive years in units with an authorized rent of at least $2,000 a month as of Oct. 1, 1993.
Even so, rent-regulation remains one of the biggest barriers to finding an decent rental in New York. Indeed, an article in The Economist recently noted that a poll of the members of the American Economic Association in 1992 found that 93.5 percent agreed that a ceiling on rents reduces the quality and quantity of housing. And economists rarely agree on anything.
"It's a factor, no doubt," Ms. Packes said. "There is no doubt that rent-regulation benefits a small number of people and makes the costs higher for a similar number of people."

HEADLINE: 2 Years After Windfall, a School Secures Its Role

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER 

DATELINE: HIGHTSTOWN

 BODY:
The ink wasn't quite dry on his diploma from the Peddie School in 1927 when Walter H. Annenberg, then a graduating senior, gave the prep school $17,000 to build a new track.
It wasn't his biggest gift to his alma mater -- not by a long shot -- but it was the earliest. Since then Mr. Annenberg, the publishing executive and former United States Ambassador to Britain, has given Peddie $140 million more, most notably a check for $100 million in 1993, the largest single donation ever to an independent secondary school. 
 Now, two years later, the fruits of Mr. Annenberg's philanthropy are taking shape at this five-year boarding and day school, which has shot from the back benches of private education to the front rows of the well-endowed elite like Andover, St. Paul's and Hotchkiss.
For starters, there has been a fivefold increase in applications since the Annenberg gift was announced 21 months ago -- many. school officials readily acknowledge, from families who in the past would have regarded Peddie as a virtuous but slightly shopworn entry in the private education sweepstakes.
But the intent behind the gift was not to turn Peddie into a school for bluebloods, said the headmaster, Thomas DeGray.
Rather, he said, a major part of the proceeds from the school's $117 million endowment will be used to subsidize talented students from families who could not otherwise afford the $20,750 annual cost of attending the 131-year-old school in central New Jersey.
As he spoke, students changing classes walked outside his corner office in Annenberg Hall to cross a broad green quadrangle toward the old library building, just a stroll from gleaming athletic and multimedia art centers and other structures built with previous Annenberg gifts.
"One of the huge challenges Peddie faces is to not be like so many private schools that pride themselves on being exclusive," said Mr. DeGray, who became headmaster six years ago.
Instead of family pedigree or even superior test scores, the school looks for "curiosity, excitement and willingness to learn" in its applicants, he added.
It is a policy subscribed to by other private schools. But harsh economic truths force most to accept the inane but wealthy student, along with the inspired one, to help pay the bills.
The difference today is that Peddie, thanks to the gift from Mr. Annenberg, can put his money where its principles are.
The only condition Mr. Annenberg placed on the gift was that $5 million a year was to be used to assist students and faculty members and not to put up new buildings. But his generosity frees up other funds that can be used for that purpose.
About $3 million a year from the endowment goes directly to scholarships, said Peter Quinn, admissions director. Forty-eight percent of some 300 boys and 200 girls (40 percent are day students) now receive financial aid that averages $13,000 a student per year, he noted. In the next school year 85 students will receive full academic scholarships, Mr. Quinn said.
Before the gift, 27 percent of the students were given annual scholarship grants averaging less than $10,000, he said.
Another $2 million a year is earmarked for other projects, including faculty raises that will lift average salaries of $28,000 by 8 to 12 percent over three years.
But most of this money is directed into an ambitious program to make the school one of the most technically advanced campuses in the nation. Thanks to earlier Annenberg gifts, the school was already moving in innovative ways to integrate computers and studies. The $100 million just speeded up the process.
Peddie, Mr. DeGray said with the smile of a lottery winner, has the best of both worlds: the appetite for innovation and the means to feed it.

HEADLINE: SCHOOLS;
2 Years After Windfall From Annenberg, School Secures Its Goals

BYLINE: By JON NORDHEIMER

DATELINE: HIGHTSTOWN

 BODY:
The ink wasn't quite dry on his diploma from the Peddie School in 1927 when Walter H. Annenberg, then a graduating senior, gave the prep school $17,000 to build a new track.
It wasn't his biggest gift to his alma mater -- not by a long shot -- but it was the earliest. Since then Mr. Annenberg, the publishing executive and former United States Ambassador to Britain, has given Peddie $140 million more, most notably a check for $100 million in 1993, the largest single donation ever given to an independent secondary school. 
 Now, two years later, the fruits of Mr. Annenberg's philanthropy are taking shape at this five-year boarding and day school, which has shot from the back benches of private education to the front rows of the well-endowed elite like Andover, St. Paul's and Hotchkiss.
For starters, there has been a fivefold increase in applications since the Annenberg gift was announced 21 months ago -- many, school officials readily acknowledge, from families who in the past would have regarded Peddie as a virtuous but slightly shopworn entry in the private-school sweepstakes.
But the intent behind the gift was not to change Peddie from a mix of students from different backgrounds into a school for bluebloods, said the headmaster, Thomas DeGray.
Rather, he said, a major part of the proceeds from the school's $117 million endowment will be used to subsidize talented students from families who could not otherwise afford the $20,750 annual cost of attending the 131-year-old school in central New Jersey.
As he spoke, students changing classes walked outside his corner office in Annenberg Hall to cross a broad green quadrangle toward the old library building, just a stroll from other structures built with previous Annenberg gifts.
"It is almost easier to identify what buildings on campus were not given by the ambassador," Mr. DeGray commented before returning to the subject of insuring that the school uses the money to invest in human resources and not more brick and mortar.
"One of the huge challenges Peddie faces is to not be like so many private schools that pride themselves on being exclusive," said Mr. DeGray, who became headmaster six years ago.
Instead of family pedigree or even superior test scores, the school looks for "curiosity, excitement and willingness to learn" in its applicants, he added.
It is a policy subscribed to by other private schools. But harsh economic truths force most to accept the inane but wealthy student, along with the inspired one, to help pay the bills.
The difference today is that Peddie, thanks to the gift from Mr. Annenberg, can put his money where its principles are.
The only condition Mr. Annenberg placed on the gift was that $5 million a year was to be used to assist students and faculty members and not to put up new buildings. But his generosity frees up other funds that can be used for that purpose, and the school has opened a campaign to raise more than $15 million from other alumni for capital improvements, including a $9 million student center, school officials said.
About $3 million a year from the endowment goes directly to scholarships, said Peter Quinn, admissions director. Forty-eight percent of some 300 boys and 200 girls (40 percent are day students) now receive financial aid that averages $13,000 a student per year, he noted. In the next school year 85 students will receive full academic scholarships, Mr. Quinn said.
Before the gift, some 27 percent of the students were given annual scholarship grants averaging less than $10,000, he said.
Another $2 million a year is earmarked for other projects, including faculty raises that will lift average salaries of $28,000 by 8 to 12 percent over three years.
But most of this money is directed into an ambitious program to make the school one of the most technically advanced campuses in the nation. Thanks to earlier Annenberg gifts, the school was already moving in innovative ways to integrate computers and studies. The $100 million just speeded up the process.
Peddie, Mr. DeGray said with the smile of a lottery winner, has the best of both worlds: the appetite for innovation and the means to feed it.
Unless the financial markets have another bad year. Peddie's endowment fund lost $500,000 in its portfolio of investments in 1994, he said, the smile chased by a sigh. "But fortunately," he said, "things have picked up, as have interest rates, and we expect a return of 8 to 10 percent for the foreseeable future."

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
In This Fight for Schools, Tax Anger Took 2d Place

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON; Iver Peterson is the Trenton bureau chief of The New York Times.

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
Why do we live here?
Some of us do because this is where our parents lived. Some of us were moved here by our employers. An awful lot of us moved here when the kids started coming and we had assembled the downpayment for a house in Bergenfield or Passaic or West Windsor. But dig deep enough into all the reasons people live where they do in New Jersey and you will find a common thread: We live here for the schools. 
 Tuesday's astonishing victory for local school budgets in 72 percent of the elections -- a year after barely half won approval -- will echo through the coming months of state budget votes, teacher contract negotiations and Assembly elections, because it gives us a pause from the notion that New Jersey is in revolt against taxes. The vote reminded everyone that when it comes to schools, New Jerseyans, angry or not, are still willing to pay.
People are used to thinking of New Jersey mostly as a vast, undifferentiated suburban landscape, but you could also say it is a vast school system. No other state can match New Jersey's ranking: top 10 nationally both on standardized tests and on the amount of money spent per pupil.
No doubt Governor Whitman and a lot of others wish our schools could act a little more like, say, North Dakota's, which keep costs low and scores high. Call them wasteful, call them unresponsive, but as Tuesday's large approval rate for local school budgets showed, an awful lot of people here are willing to pay the second-highest property taxes in the country to support their schools. (The highest? New Hampshire, but they don't have an income tax.)
As a result, the post-vote political debate now turns on what the approval rate means for Mrs. Whitman and her administration's war on school waste.
For Mrs. Whitman's adversaries on the issue of cutbacks in aid to education, the vote was a vindication. Voters, they reasoned, sent a clear signal to Trenton that while tax cuts are important, education is more important, perhaps even at the risk of higher local levies.
The school boards and teacher unions, who tend to be surprisingly like-minded considering they represent opposite sides of the bargaining table, agreed that the vote was proof of a shift away from the Governor's fiscal stringency. After all, they point out, last year's widespread rejection of school budgets -- only 51 percent were adopted -- was taken by the Governor herself as a warning to school boards that her message of fiscal frugality was getting through.
"Most voters were not misled by the administration's attempt to undermine public confidence on school operations," said Dennis Testa, president of the New Jersey Education Association, the state's largest teachers union. A big victory for children, Mr. Testa added, although, as the Governor likes to remind us, less than half the money will ever reach the classrooms.
Across the state, superintendents who are barely on speaking terms with the Governor also called the vote a victory, while the School Boards Association called the vote a reminder to Mrs. Whitman to send them enough money to keep local property taxes from rising further.
How does the Whitman team take it? In stride. The Governor can easily say the high approval rate proves only that voters made their choices based on local concerns, which is what she has said she wanted all along. Had more budgets been defeated, however, the administration could have taken pride in spreading the notion of fiscal austerity. It's a wash.
It would be unfair to say that the Education Commissioner, Leo F. Klagholz, and the rest of the Whitman school team were disappointed in the voting, although a larger 'no' vote would have made their job of wringing the fluff out of the school system a little easier. And it would have thrown more rejected budgets into his office for final judgment.
Indeed, Dr. Klagholz is right to call the school vote a partial vindication of his policies. All school budgets operate under a state-imposed cap that limits the annual increase to a fixed percentage. Last year, that permissible increase was around 3.5 percent, and this year, the cap was lowered statewide by 1.5 percent. By definition, therefore, budget increases this year were smaller than last year's. And anyway, politics works best when both sides come away with something to cheer about.
But the school vote won't change the long-term direction of New Jersey fiscal policies, if only because the Governor cannot stray from the course she has set. Next year at this time, with her full 30 percent income tax cut in place and her national ambitions more sharply illuminated, the fight will be over her promise to limit the growth of state spending to the rate of inflation, which means tax cuts by another name.
With more cuts, it is likely that next year schools will get no more state aid, and probably less, than they did this year. And we will all get another chance to prove how much we love our schools.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (97%);

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 3574 words

HEADLINE: Big Risks, Big Losses, Big Fight

BYLINE: By LESLIE WAYNE 

DATELINE: CHARLESTON, W.Va.

 BODY:
IT'S a long way from Wall Street to the narrow mountain roads leading here. But Morgan Stanley & Company knows the route all too well. The fanciest firm in finance, Morgan Stanley is embroiled in a messy lawsuit that boils down to one simple question: Who is to blame when state investment funds embrace risk and lose big -- the brokers who became rich on the state business or the state itself. The case, to be decided shortly by the State Supreme Court, has implications for Orange County, Calif., and other municipal finance calamities.
The case here began in 1983, when Kathryn M. Lester, a young secretary-turned-trader, was put in charge of West Virginia's $2.2 billion municipal investment fund. Supervising her were a flock of politically connected bosses, several of whom ended up discredited or in jail. Her formal training was in home economics, but with a mind for numbers and a stomach for aggressive trades, Ms. Lester quickly turned the sleepy fund into the most successful in the nation. She made billion-dollar bets and earned millions for her state, displaying a "Working Girl" savvy in her wheelings and dealings. 
 Her magic made West Virginia one of Morgan Stanley's prime accounts and turned the salesman who called on her, Michael G. Maher, into a rich man. The trading was active -- in one three-month period the volume of trades came to nearly $20 billion. In just one year Mr. Maher, then 32, took home $1 million, almost all from his dealings with Ms. Lester.
But this cozy relationship came to a crashing end in 1987. Interest rates shifted against Ms. Lester and pressure increased from her bosses to make continued high returns. As a result, she undertook bigger and dicier bets and Morgan Stanley helped by arranging a laundry list of highly risky, highly leveraged, highly complicated trades -- even lending the state millions so it could bet with money it did not have.
What was once a winning streak now turned sour and, when the losses were toted up, they came to $280 million -- a financial disaster that forced the state to raise new taxes, including a food tax that hit the poor the hardest.
"You've got the stupidity of a state agency versus the greed of Morgan Stanley," said Rudolph L. DiTrapano, a lawyer representing the state. But numerous interviews and an examination of thousands of pages of court documents show that there was greed on both sides and plenty of stupidity to go around. Some of the discredited political bosses were people Morgan Stanley relied upon for assurances that everything in West Virginia was on the up and up.
For the last six years, the two sides have battled in court, with Morgan Stanley flying platoons of executives and lawyers into the white-knuckle airport on a mountaintop near here. Court documents now number more than 6,000 pages and there have been more than 120 depositions.
Morgan Stanley lost the first round when a lower court ordered it to pay $56 million to the state. Next month, in an action being cheered on by the rest of Wall Street, the firm will ask the State Supreme Court here to overturn that ruling.
The dollars in the case are small by Orange County standards -- Merrill Lynch is being sued for $2 billion in that matter, a debacle that sent the California county into bankruptcy last December after losing about $1.7 billion in its highly leveraged investment pool. But the issues are so similar that West Virginia is being watched closely as a trial run.
What's more, the case here is coming to a head as hundreds of similar lawsuits are just being filed -- cases in which low-paid and, often, poorly trained state employees say greedy brokers led them astray with securities they did not understand.
"We're beginning to see the tip of the iceberg in these cases," said Dale Wainwright, a Houston lawyer who represents brokerage firms in these cases. "It's a question of who is responsible. Can a public fund shift the responsibility to someone else?"
West Virginia says yes. It claims that Morgan Stanley sold naive state officials speculative securities, knowing full well that West Virginia law barred them.
"Morgan Stanley is just like used car salesmen," said H. Craig Slaughter, the state's director of investments. "They don't think about truth and justice, just the American way of making money at any cost. Don't they have any reponsibility to their clients?"
Morgan Stanley says it did no wrong. It never acted as a financial adviser to the state, it maintains, serving instead simply as a middleman executing the state's trades. If any speculation took place, the firm argues in its court papers, it is the state that is liable.
Still, six other Wall Street firms that did business with the state, including Salomon Brothers and Goldman, Sachs, have paid $28 million to settle their involvement in the losses. And Morgan Stanley and the state also discussed a settlement. It was only when they couldn't agree on an amount that the dispute wound up in court.
Now, Morgan Stanley says it is standing on principle -- if it loses, it claims that Wall Street could be turned into a giant insurance policy. "This is our line in the sand," said Peter F. Karches, a Morgan managing director. "It's outrageous. It's like if people lose money, they can come and try to pick our pockets."
 
The Politicians
Financial Wizardry Or Ignorance?
Supervising Ms. Lester was a rogue's gallery of politicians. Her immediate boss, Brooklyn-born Arnold Margolin, was hailed as a financial whiz, but never worked as a trader. He went to prison in 1990 for lying about the losses and covering them up.
Next up the chain-of-command was the state's treasurer, A. James Manchin. A political fixture best known for judging beauty contests and leading parades, Mr. Manchin later testified that he did not even know that when a number was in parenthesis it was a loss. Others remember him referring to visits from "Stanley Morgan" and "the Salomon Brothers."
Mr. Manchin resigned from office in 1989 under threat of impeachment. He promoted the investment fund in a cascade of news releases and on a weekly radio show. Later, a state investigation found, he was siphoning from the fund for his own political operations. Today, Mr. Manchin admits, "math is not my long suit" and he travels the West Virginia countryside giving lectures on patriotism at local schools.
At the top of the political heap was former Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr., who headed the state's Board of Investments. He is now in prison for extortion, unrelated to this case.
In fact, this sordid tale of West Virginia politics has hurt the state in the court of public opinion. "We have an inferiority complex here," said Mr. DiTrapano, the state's lawyer. "We've always been victimized by corrupt and incompetent government officials, more so than by outsiders. We look back and see how fast we lost money in the fund. It was shocking and embarrassing. So a lot of people thought that we deserved it because we were dumb."
While the case pits the state against Morgan Stanley, both sides have focused on Ms. Lester, a plain-spoken native Midwesterner, in their arguments. The state has built its case by portraying Ms. Lester, now 42, as a naif. Morgan Stanley has argued that Ms. Lester was a sophisticated investor whose success was derailed by inept politicians.
Evidence introduced in court showed that Ms. Lester, who graduated from Michigan State University, was sometimes a keen trader, other times confused. Now a divorced mother of two, she was forced to resign from her $40,000-a-year job in November 1987 and has supported her family by managing a day care center and working as a paralegal.
Ms. Lester fell into finance almost by accident. While she and her former husband were living in Washington in 1981, Ms. Lester was hired as a secretary at the National Bank of Abu Dhabi there. The bank's computers were not programmed to carry trading positions, so she calculated them by hand. Soon, she was asked to be an assistant government bond trader.
"I've always loved math and I just took to it," said Ms. Lester in a recent interview. "I knew what they were talking about. It just made sense."
When her husband moved to Charleston in 1983 to work as a lawyer, she took a job in the state treasurer's office, in part because the regular hours allowed her to be home early with her infant son. Ms. Lester, then 30, thought she had landed her dream job. Since the director of investments knew nothing about bonds, she started to educate him and persuaded him to try to make money by trading small amounts, $5 million to $10 million. By the end of the year, the investment director resigned and she was appointed to succeed him to run the state's investment fund.
In quick order, she overhauled the department. She set up a trading desk with video stock quotes and direct telephone lines to brokerage houses. She encouraged salesmen from Wall Street to visit -- but only if they provided educational seminars for her staff. She swapped market information with traders at different firms and she talked on the speaker phone with top Wall Street economists like Henry Kaufman, Edward Yardeni and Allen Sinai.
In addition to buying and holding bonds, Ms. Lester actively traded part of the state's portfolio -- taking advantage of market volatility, or small daily price fluctations, to make money. But she did this with discipline: if a trade lost money, she would sell immediately and take the loss rather than hoping for a recovery. If a trade made money, she took profits and put some in a rainy day fund to cover future losses.
Mr. Lester's counterpart at Morgan was the young salesman, Mr. Maher, who was just about her age. A Georgetown University finance major, Mr. Maher is the son of a Manhattan textile executive and the grandson of a member of the New York Stock Exchange. While in college, he took a year off to work at Merrill Lynch.
In 1983, the same year Ms. Lester followed her husband to West Virginia, Mr. Maher started working as a bond salesman at Morgan Stanley. Eager for new clients, Mr. Maher started calling on Ms. Lester in 1985 and she began sending business his way. The two clicked, talking daily about their children and long bonds on a direct telephone line that linked her desk with his.
Given Ms. Lester's active hand, Mr. Maher had struck pay dirt. Soon, West Virginia became his No. 1 client, accounting for more than 90 percent of his business.
The account was so active that Morgan Stanley's volume of trades in Treasury notes with West Virginia was more than 10 times greater than with all other Government entities combined -- "it was a relatively big account for us," admits Mr. Karches, now head of the fixed-income division at the firm. (Mr. Maher did not respond to requests for an interview. Still at Morgan Stanley, he is now on a leave of absence that the firm says has nothing to do with the case.)
"We were earning incredible amounts of money," Ms. Lester said. "And I made Wall Street work hard. They wouldn't get our business unless they called us and gave us information. When volatility was high, we would be trading $100 million to $150 million a day and we were getting 4 to 5 percent more for our investors than banks. And as we increased the business, the guys got bigger that came down."
Today, the state's lawyers take swipes at Ms. Lester's close relationship with Wall Street. "All the women in the Treasurer's office loved it when these fancy guys came down and went to lunch with them," said Debra Hamilton, a lawyer for the state. "They did a lot to feed the ego of Kathy Lester and Arnie Margolin on what a great job they were doing."
West Virginia's fund became the top performing municipal investment fund in the nation -- a fact that Mr. Manchin, the state treasurer, trumpeted widely. Mr. Manchin also commanded an army of "field officers" who drove around the state convincing local muncipalities to invest, and promising more double-digit returns.
But by 1986 the markets weren't cooperating. Volatility was decreasing, which meant that to get the same returns, Ms. Lester had to trade in increasingly large amounts -- something she now says she was ordered to do by Mr. Margolin. In addition, Mr. Manchin started making low-interest loans to West Virginia businesses from the fund -- which put a drag on potential returns.
"I was told to trade in more size, more size," said Ms. Lester. "But I said that would be more risk. I was told that as long as I stuck to my discpline, everything would be fine. I was encouraged to take bigger and bigger positions. I didn't feel comfortable, but I felt that there was enough liquidity in the market to get out if we had to."
 
The Concerns
Executive in Firm Drops In for Visit
As trading in West Virginia increased, so did the concerns of some Morgan Stanley executives, primarily John J. Mack, then head of the fixed-income division and now the firm's president. The firm was in nasty litigation involving securities it had sold to Johns Hopkins University that the school later said it did not understand. Fearing a similar situation in West Virginia, Mr. Mack wanted a ground report. He ordered Mr. Karches, then Mr. Maher's boss, to fly down and meet with Mr. Margolin and Mr. Manchin.
Mr. Mack, fearing Ms. Lester might be trading without proper authorization, even cut off trades with the state for a few days in November 1986, until Mr. Karches could investigate. When he came back, Mr. Karches was impressed. "They told me they were big boys in West Virginia and had newspaper articles plastered on the wall to prove it," Mr. Karches said.
Mr. Karches was also warned that if Morgan Stanley didn't want to trade with the state, plenty of other Wall Street firms were eager to take up the slack. Mr. Karches now claims the threat "didn't hold much water with me."
Morgan Stanley says this trip was proper "due diligence." The state claims it was a whitewash. "It was really a cover-your-rear trip," said Mr. DiTrapano, the state's lawyer. "They came here wanting to be told that everything was O.K. so that they could continue trading. They were predisposed to see and hear what they wanted to hear. These guys weren't standing on principle when there was so much money to be made."
Based on Mr. Karches's glowing report, Morgan Stanley resumed business -- and in even bigger amounts. By the end of March, Ms. Lester made an extremely risky bet: She obligated the state to buy $1.5 billion in seven-year Treasury notes a few days before the notes were actually issued. The catch was that the state did not have the money to pay Morgan Stanley and other dealers. She was gambling that bond prices would rise by the time these securities were issued, and that the state could flip them for a quick profit.
But disaster struck. With the state on the hook for $1.5 billion, President Ronald Reagan announced trade sanctions against Japan on March 27, 1987. Japan responded by dumping seven-year notes on the market -- the exact ones the state was obligated to buy -- causing them to plummet in value.
Ms. Lester argued with Mr. Margolin and said the state should continue its trading discipline -- sell the $1.5 billion position and get out. This strategy would have cost the state about $22 million, which could easily be covered by the rainy day fund. But Mr. Lester said she was overruled by Mr. Margolin -- a point Mr. Margolin confirmed in a deposition. Mr. Margolin, believing bond prices would rebound, allowed her to sell only a third of her position. This left the state on the hook to buy $1 billion of the seven-year Treasuries -- with money it did not have.
So the state decided to borrow $550 million from Morgan Stanley using the Treasury securities as collateral. Ms. Lester had approached Salomon Brothers with the same deal, but it refused to touch it. Even though this information was relayed to Morgan Stanley -- which the state contends was a red flag -- Morgan Stanley still agreed to make the loan, which took the state far beyond its borrowing limitations.
In addition, Ms. Lester began in 1987 to dabble in the futures and options market with Morgan Stanley. In a celebrated audio tape played many times in the fraud trial, Ms. Lester appeared confused as to whether she was buying or selling an option -- Ms. Lester says today that she was just asking for a confirmation. These options, too, turned into money losers.
By April 1987, Morgan Stanley, seeing that the state's trading had become more erratic and undisciplined, cut off all business. This came after the company tried to get an exculpatory letter from the state's Attorney General saying that the trades it had made with the state were not speculative -- and the Attorney General refused. The following November, Ms. Lester was forced to resign.
"I have made skads of money for the salesmen at Morgan, I have made skads of money for the state," said Ms. Lester. "I feel that all I've done in life has been to make skads of money for other people."
 
The Liability
Challenging Award Of $32.6 Million
Morgan Stanley's appeal to the State Supreme Court asks for reversal of an unusual 1992 decision by Judge A. Andrew MacQueen of Kanawha County Circuit Court, who dismissed Morgan Stanley's case and ruled in favor of the state without holding a trial. He found Morgan liable to the tune of $32.6 million which, with statutory interest at 10 percent a year, brings Morgan's obligation to $56 million. Oral arguments are scheduled for May 10 before the State Supreme Court -- in West Virginia, there are no appeals courts between the circuit and the supreme courts.
"My decisions didn't have much to do with whether Kathy Lester was a successful investor or whether Morgan Stanley was trying to take advantage of her," Judge MacQueen said in an interview. "The state and Morgan Stanley together engaged in transactions prohibited by the law. You didn't have to find that Morgan Stanley did this for a bad purpose. Those transactions were prohibited and the beneficiaries of the fund, the citizens, are entitled to protection."
Morgan Stanley does take heart from another legal decision here, which it claims as a victory. One of the charges against Morgan Stanley -- that it committed fraud -- was split off from the main case and heard before a Charleston jury in 1992. After a 10-day trial, the jury found the firm guilty of "constructive fraud," which is essentially fraud without premeditation. But it levied minimal damages -- $4.9 million and not the $35 million sought by the state.
The state calls the verdict a "fluke," and Morgan Stanley is appealing it, too. Judge MacQueen presided over this case as well and remembers the costly razzle dazzle of Morgan Stanley: his courtroom was filled with a battery of television screens that carried a rolling text of taped audio conversations between Ms. Lester and the firm so the jury could easily follow them. "Oh, Lord, it was fancy," Judge MacQueen recalled.
Morgan Stanley's big challenge is to gain sympathy before a hometown crowd. Even Judge MacQueen commented from the bench that the money lost in the debacle belonged to him, too. So, in court, Morgan Stanley's lawyers made sure to point out that John W. Davis, the founder of Davis Polk & Wardwell, their New York law firm, was a West Virginian and the only one ever to have run for President. (He lost to Calvin Coolidge in 1924). And they exhorted the jury not to turn the state's motto, "Mountaineers will always be free" into "Mountaineers will always be freeloaders."
Still, the local peculiarities intruded. In midtrial, one juror, a religious fundamentalist, was dismissed after he told other jurors that Morgan Stanley was the embodiment of Satan since one of its documents had the number 666 on it -- in some minds, the number of the Devil.
The West Virginia Supreme Court is expected to decide the case this summer. In the first round of oral arguments, held last January, Morgan Stanley received a blistering attack from Chief Justice Richard Neely. A Yale law graduate, Justice Neely is a product liability expert and has long argued, ironically, that out-of-state defendants with deep pockets have an unfair disadvantage before hostile local courts. Justice Neely retired from the court on April 15, but may be recalled for this case.
Justice Neely, who called Mr. Manchin a "simpleton" from the bench, turned on Morgan Stanley and referred to audio tapes of Morgan employees talking about "getting caught." He said it was clear the investments Morgan Stanley sold the state were speculative.
"There is nothing you can say to convince me that this was not speculation," Justice Neely said from the bench. "This stuff is just for blow-dried Harvard Business School types who think they can beat the market.
"If you look at all of these telephone conversations," he told Morgan Stanley's lawyers, "you see that your people knew that these folks here were behaving like jackasses. They didn't understand when they would sell $100 million. They didn't know if they had sold a put or a call." The Morgan Stanley people, he added "went away shaking their heads." The brokerage firm, he concluded, "Sent guys down here to stroke these folks and blow smoke."
In New York, Morgan Stanley's in-house lawyer, Monroe Sonnenborn, is still optimistic. "We didn't do anything wrong," he said.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 11; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1281 words

HEADLINE: For Sale: Corporate America's Big Blue Period

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
IN the glory days of I.B.M., when shirts were white and the ink was always black, there was the art collection. The founder, Thomas J. Watson Sr., gathered thousands of the finest paintings and hung them in offices worldwide, a sign of the company's lofty pedigree.
Now, I.B.M. has come down a peg or two, squeezing $6.5 billion out of its cost structure in the last three years alone and cutting staff by half in the last decade. And it is selling much of its art collection. 
 In a series of auctions scheduled to begin in May, Sotheby's will sell about 300 paintings, drawings and prints valued at about $25 million -- a token nod toward belt-tightening for a company that spends about $500 million a year on advertising alone. The collection goes on view at Sotheby's in Manhattan on Friday.
The most valuable I.B.M. holdings are in late 19th century and early 20th century American paintings and drawings, and some rare Latin American paintings, drawings and prints. Less significant is its small collection of contemporary art. There are blockbusters like Frank Weston Benson's "The Sisters," which Sotheby's expects to sell for $1.5 million to $2 million; Frida Kahlo's "Self-Portrait with Money and Parrot," expected to bring $2.5 million to $3 million, and Diego Rivera's "Dance in Tehuantepec," estimated to sell for $3 million to $4 million. These paintings are the sort that rarely come onto the market.
Only a handful of works are in this category. A surprising number of paintings, prints and drawings have prices of $100 and up. "There is also a lot available to the young collector in the $800 to $1,500 price range," said August Uribe, head of Sotheby's Latin American department in New York.
That the works come with the cachet conferred by I.B.M. and have been off the market for 50 years or so, experts say, adds to the appeal. While many of the best works have been lent to exhibitions, most of the art has been in storage for 30 years.
Not everything is a masterpiece. Some of the works have lower price tags for good reason: they may not represent an artist's best period, subject or medium.
Watson, who bought his first painting for $40 in 1902, was given to grand proclamations on art. "Art breaks the monotony of life, which is one thing the human mind cannot endure," he declared in 1936.
But Watson, who died in 1956, became a large figure in the art world. President Franklin D. Roosevelt appointed him Commissioner General for the American section of the International Art Exposition in Paris. And by 1946, his company had acquired 30,000 pieces of American folk art, textiles, ceramics, prints, paintings and sculpture.
Big Blue had a sophisticated eye, paying $6,500 in 1943 for George Bellows's "Easter Snow (Easter Sunday)," which Sotheby's expects to auction for $1.5 million to $2 million. In 1945 it paid $3,000 for James A. McNeill Whistler's "The Shop," a watercolor expected to sell for $80,000 to $120,000. And for $4,000, the company snapped up John Singer Sargent's "A Waterfall," which now carries a price of $200,000 to $300,000.
"In any auction this large there will certainly be some buys," said Vance Jordan, a New York-based dealer of American art. "There are many things that are so rare you can't get them today."
American art -- paintings, watercolors, drawings and prints -- is the collection's biggest category and one of the most affordable. But many works have been in storage for decades and may be damaged.
Among the American watercolors, experts say, are significant works whose prices in the auction catalogue make them potential bargains. They include John Marin's "Near Taos, New Mexico," a 1930 work that Sotheby's has priced at $30,000 to $40,000. Experts say it may be overlooked in the auction, because collectors of Marin tend to prefer his New York subjects.
Enthusiastic bidders may want to go higher than the upper estimate, but beyond $50,000, experts say, they will not be getting a bargain. Whistler's "The Shop" is considered rare because it is larger and more elaborate than many of Whistler's watercolors of shopfronts. The Sotheby's estimate of $80,000 to $120,000 is low, art experts say, and the watercolor could bring $250,000 or more, if the work has not faded.
Everett Shinn's "The Bar at McSorley's" has a low estimate of $25,000 to $35,000. Painted in 1908, the subject of the watercolor is so popular that the selling price may exceed its high estimate, but paying more than $50,000 would be too much, experts say.
International Busoness Machines' American prints are also reasonably priced. Two of the rarest are Childe Hassam's "The White Kimono," estimated to sell for $10,000 to $15,000, and Marin's "Brooklyn Bridge and Lower Manhattan," expected to bring $10,000 to $12,000. Nancy Bialler of Sotheby's print department in New York said the estimates were reasonable and made sense for collectors who were starting out.
Other good buys include Thomas Hart Benton's "Fire in the Barnyard," which is expected to sell for $800 to $1,200. It is considered a rare image, so an auction price of less than $3,000 would be considered a real bargain. Edward Hopper's "Night Shadows," is an early impression of a famous image. Its auction estimate of $8,000 to $10,000 is considered sound. And a group consisting of three woodcuts and three etchings by Leonard Baskin, priced at $800 to $1,500, is something to consider.
Among the biggest bargains are probably the Latin American works, partly because many of the Latin American collectors who often dominate the bidding for the art from their region may be distracted by the political and economic turmoil there.
"In the area of Mexican prints, we have some icons priced around $1,000," Mr. Uribe of Sotheby's said. "And drawings by top-flight artists can be had for under $20,000. That's something you can't do in other fields." The reason, Mr. Uribe said, is that Latin American collectors often favor paintings over drawings, because many of them live in tropical climates in which works on paper do not survive well.
Mr. Uribe cited several important prints that were candidates for bargain sales, based on the estimated prices in the auction catalogue. Jose Chavez Morado's "Dance of Death," which depicts the day of the dead, a subject with a long history in Mexican art, is well priced at $800 to $1,200, though anything more would be too much, experts say.
But Jose Clemente Orozco's, "The Rear Guard," priced at $4,000 to $5,000, is considered by experts to be such a magnificent image that even at a price significantly higher than the upper estimate it would be a steal. The same is true for two prints by Jose Guadalupe Posada, "Calavera of the Zapatistas," a revolutionary image expected to sell for $2,000 to $3,000, and "The Female Dandy," priced at $1,000 to $1,500.
Buyers who know the market will probably be willing to pay far more than the high estimates. They will do the same for two prints by Rivera, each estimated to fetch $10,000 to $15,000. Both considered masterpieces, "Open Air School" is based on an 1926 mural from the Ministry of Public Education in Mexico City, and "Fruits of Labor" is a scene of children and peasants. Even a price as high as $25,000 would be considered good. And Rivera's "Zapata," will likely go for twice its estimate of $18,000 because experts consider the image so important.
Far less significant are I.B.M.'s contemporary prints. A group of works by Robert Rauschenberg, from his "Stoned Moon Series: Horn," is conservatively estimated at $2,500 to $3,500. More unusual is Ellsworth Kelly's "Nine Squares," which is expected to bring $6,000 to $8,000.

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.

 BODY:

Bronx Firm's Winning Bid Travels Electronically
The HSM Software and Computer Company, a small minority-owned business in the northeast Bronx, recently won a $52,000 contract to provide New Jersey Transit with security designs for a new light rail transit system. The company bid on the contract electronically, after getting help from the South Bronx Overall Economic Development Corporation, a nonprofit agency known as Sobro. Two months ago Sobro started a program, Defense Diversification Using Electronic Commerce, in which experts go into small businesses in the Bronx to show employees how to bid electronically for Government contracts. By 1997, the Federal Government will require all government contractors to bid electronically.
 
 
An Italian Designer's Journey From Milan to Madison Avenue
 Martino Midali, a popular clothing designer in Italy, is trying to make his mark in the United States. 
 Mr. Midali, who has 11 stores throughout Italy, will open his first American venture, in 700 square feet at 1015 Madison Avenue, between 78th and 79th Streets, on Thursday. He hopes to open a two-story flagship store in SoHo in September, but has not yet signed a lease.
Mr. Midali, 42, began designing clothes in Milan in the early 80's.
 
 
 
Game Plan for New Herman's: Service Skates and Skis It Sells
A new Herman's Sporting Goods Store will open in May on the northeast corner of Lexington Avenue and 86th Street, the former site of a Chemical Bank branch. Besides offering Herman's usual array of sports equipment and clothing, the 15,000-square-foot store will emphasize service and repairs of skis, tennis rackets and Rollerblades.
Craig Letts, the president of the company's real estate division, said that last week Herman's signed a lease for a store in midtown, but he declined to provide further details.

HEADLINE: If Only There Was a Warren Buffett for Mutual Funds

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
YOU need more than $22,000 to buy a single share of Berkshire Hathaway, run by Warren Buffett, the billionaire investor. But a mere $1,000 will buy a stake in a copycat fund managed by one of Mr. Buffett's biggest fans.
Robert G. Hagstrom Jr., author of the best-seller "The Warren Buffet Way" (Wiley, 1994), plans to duplicate Mr. Buffett's investment strategy in Focus Trust, a mutual fund that came to market on Monday. 
 Make no mistake, though, fund investors will be betting on the ability of Mr. Hagstrom, not Mr. Buffett. The fund will not duplicate Berkshire Hathaway's holdings. Although he has never met Mr. Buffett -- only talked with him on the telephone -- Mr. Hagstrom seems anything but daunted by investors' great expectations and his own modest experience.
Mr. Hagstrom, 38, has been managing money only since 1989. He joined Lloyd, Leith & Sawin, which handles $105 million in assets for 90 Philadelphia families, in 1991, after working as a portfolio manager for First Fidelity Bank in Philadelphia. Before that, he was a stock broker.
Now, he speaks as though he has found the holy grail of investing. Reduced to its simplest terms, the Buffett way is to value a business that you understand, pay a sensible price for the stock and then hold on to it.
"Most mutual fund managers go outside their circle of competence," Mr. Hagstrom said, meaning they invest in businesses they do not understand. By sticking to a few companies he knows well, Mr. Hagstrom expects to avoid what he calls mediocre performance in most of the fund industry.
Copying great investors is hardly a new idea. A venture called Wealth Monitors tried the approach in the mid-1980's, buying stocks owned by famous managers like Mr. Buffett and the Bass brothers. But Wealth Monitors "didn't buy all of them, just some, and it turned out that they picked the wrong ones," said John Rekenthaler, editor of The Five-Star Investor, an investment newsletter from Morningstar Inc., the fund research company in Chicago. The fund folded after five years.
More successful has been the Sequoia fund, created from a Buffett partnership in 1970. Sequoia has returned 18.6 percent annually to investors for the 15 years ended in March, compared with 13.77 percent for all equity funds, Morningstar said. Dazzled investors will have to look elsewhere, though, since the fund closed in 1982.
"In an industry that prides itself on mimicking, I don't know why no one came out with a Sequoia II," Mr. Hagstrom said.
Sequoia's success is no mystery. Berkshire Hathaway is its largest holding, accounting for just over 27 percent of its $1.7 billion in assets.
Will Focus Trust consider buying Berkshire Hathaway stock? "At the right price, yes," Mr. Hagstrom said, declining to be more specific. The problem is that the stock price has run up about 10 percent this year -- far more than the company's components -- in a feat attributed largely to the popularity of, you guessed it, Mr. Hagstrom's book.
Not all the companies owned by Berkshire Hathaway are good values either, he said. The prospects for Geico, the insurance concern, are not as dynamic as they were when Mr. Buffett bought the stock, Mr. Hagstrom explained. Nor does he care for commercial banks, like Wells Fargo.
Focus Trust has no sales charge, but expenses are quite high. Initially, the expense ratio is pegged at 1.75 percent of assets. That estimate is based on a $25 million fund, but the ever-optimistic Mr. Hagstrom figures it should fall to roughly 1 percent if the fund reaches $100 million -- quite a leap from its initial $120,000.
The seven guiding tenets of the fund are outlined in a page of its prospectus labeled "Investment Adviser -- Shareholder Principles." Three are of particular significance:
* Management considers that they are partners with the shareholders and will invest in the fund.
Mr. Hagstrom says that all the principals in his Philadelphia firm own shares, and some have substantial amounts. As the manager of the fund, Mr. Hagstrom said that he would invest all his equity in it.
* The fund will invest in a few outstanding businesses that have favorable long-term prospects, and are available at sensible prices.
Like Mr. Buffett, Mr. Hagstrom plans to create a concentrated portfolio and to hold his stocks for long periods.
"There are a lot of bright stock pickers, but they're reverting to the mean by owning so many stocks," he said. "Can you understand and value 100 companies annually? If you can, I tip my hat to you."
Mr. Hagstrom expects to own 12 to 15 stocks. Few mutual funds make such bold bets. Among the 1,509 funds tracked by Morningstar, only 24 own fewer than 20 securities. Mr. Hagstrom admits that the failure of one stock would have a bigger impact on Focus Trust than on a more diversified portfolio, but he emphasizes that he will buy strong companies.
* The fund is not interested in constantly buying and selling mediocre businesses where economic gain depends more on profiting from short-term price swings.
Mr. Hagstrom estimates the fund's turnover at 25 percent a year, adding that the figure was a compromise with his lawyers, who would not let him go lower. "If I make mistakes with 2 or 3 out of 12 holdings each year, that's the turnover you get," he said. "I can't imagine that I'd make that many bad calls."
He wants shareholders to buy for the long term. "I'd rather have a smaller fund with more responsible, long-term shareholders than a larger group of shareholders that are constantly buying and selling based on short-term performance," he said.
Focus Trust will levy a redemption fee, equal to 2 percent for people who sell their shares within one year of purchase and 1 percent for sales in the second year.
Simple as Mr. Buffet's investing strategy may sound, there is no guarantee Focus Trust will prove to be a Sequoia II.

HEADLINE: Even Now, There's Money to Be Made in Japan

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
MUTUAL fund investors would be hard pressed to find a more contrarian bet than Japan. The Japanese economy is in serious trouble, in part because the soaring yen makes its goods so expensive in falling dollars.
But after a devastating first quarter, a number of portfolio managers and investors have started creeping back into Japanese equities. And so far, the wager has paid off. 
 The bellwether Nikkei 225 index, which fell more than 18 percent in the first three months of 1995, has risen 5.1 percent this month. To some, that looks like a classic example of what the trade calls a "dead cat bounce" -- a reaction to the fall, not a sign of life. But other signs point to renewed interest in Japan as well.
Three weeks ago -- for the first time this year -- investors put in more money than they withdrew from the five largest Japan stock funds, according to AMG Data Services, a fund research company in Arcata, Calif. Last week, a four-week moving average showed $2.7 million in new cash, double the amount a week earlier, for those funds.
Some managers are also encouraged by technical analysis, which uses charts of previous performance to predict future stock prices. Several times in the last three years, the Nikkei average has fallen close to 15,000, as it did in late March, and then rebounded sharply, gaining 20 to 30 percent over the next two quarters.
"The Japanese market offers the opportunity for a very profitable move over the next six to nine months," said Charles E. Cain, president of Cain Asset Management, a New York money manager who specializes in picking mutual funds for clients.
One mutual fund that's been buying in Japan is Merrill Lynch Pacific. "As the Japanese stock market has dropped, we've been adding to our position all year," said Steve Silverman, manager of the fund, which carries a 5.25 percent sales charge. It now has 65 percent of its $1.5 billion in assets in Japan, up from 56 percent at the start of the year. The fund, up 0.9 percent this year, doesn't try to predict the market's overall direction. However, Mr. Silverman said, "We're finding a lot of individual companies that look like great values."
Japanese funds have moved higher this month in large part because of the falling dollar. The Japan Fund, which is the largest of the group specializing in Japan with $487 million in assets, has risen 3.9 percent, to $9.39 a share. To the extent that mutual funds investing in Japan don't hedge their currency risk, American investors benefit from a stronger yen and a weaker dollar.
The opposite, of course, is also true, which explains the vast difference in performance among the nine Japanese funds tracked by Lipper Analytical Services, a funds research company. For the year through Thursday, the tiny Wright Equifund-Japanese, whose $9.7 million in assets aren't hedged against currency effects, gained 0.7 percent. Warburg Pincus Japan did hedge its $24.5 million in assets -- and declined 21.3 percent through Thursday. (Both funds are too small to appear in this newspaper's daily mutual fund listings.)
If the currency trend reverses, as it showed signs of doing last week, the top and bottom performers could switch places, because the funds that hedge would benefit. The stock market also stands to benefit from a weaker yen, since the Japanese economy is dependent on sales of its products abroad.
"What's caused the Japanese funds to rise so far this month -- the strength of the yen -- is negative for the stock market," Mr. Cain said. "If the yen stabilizes or comes down, in the long run that will be good for Japanese stocks. I'm inclined to believe that will happen."
The technical signs are promising for the Nikkei index, Mr. Cain said. The Nikkei average's weekly closing prices have ranged from about 15,000 to 21,000 for nearly three years. Each time the index has fallen sharply and hit the lower level, it has rebounded, reaching the upper limit within several months.
The recent strength could be setting the stage for an upward move in the Nikkei average of 20 percent to 30 percent by the end of the year.
To take advantage of that possibility, Mr. Cain said he is considering buying some Japanese specialty funds. "A well diversified position within a portfolio would measure about 15 to 25 percent" of assets, he said.
Of course, the yen might continue to strengthen, the Japanese economy might slump further and the Nikkei average could fall below 14,500, the level it last visited in August 1992.
Some international specialists consider that more than a mere possibility. David Herro, portfolio manager of the $877 million Oakmark International fund, has no assets in Japan, and doesn't plan to start investing there anytime soon.
"If anything, the fundamentals in Japan are getting worse instead of better," Mr. Herro said. While interest rates might appear to be almost as low as they can go -- the Bank of Japan lowered its discount rate to 1 percent recently -- Mr. Herro said that because Japan is in a deflationary cycle, real interest rates are two to three percentage points higher. "That's not as low as one might expect for this economy," he said.
Mr. Herro predicted that the Japanese economy must go through much more fundamental restructuring before it can strengthen significantly. "The stock market is off 50 percent from its highs, but that was an inflated high," he said. "It's still overvalued by 20 percent to 40 percent."
Clearly, Japan has serious economic problems that aren't likely to be solved in a few months. But with pessimism about Japan so widespread and the Nikkei average down so far this year, some money managers see immediate promise in a few sectors of the Japanese economy.
About 27 percent of Franklin Pacific Growth fund's $51 million in assets is invested in Japan. William Howard, the portfolio manager, owns companies that should hold up relatively well in a slow or declining economy and that he expects to do well in the next five years. He likes East Japan Railway, a passenger rail company; Mitsubishi Oil, a refiner that's exploring for oil off the coast of Vietnam, and Nippon Telephone and Telegraph.
Mr. Silverman, manager of the Merrill Pacific fund, favors Ito-Yokado, a big retailer. While many economists cite a reluctance by Japanese consumers to spend as a reason for the faltering economy, Mr. Silverman said, "If people are going to shop, they're going to shop at Ito-Yokado."
He also disputes the notion that Japanese companies can't change, noting that Ito-Yokado owns Southland Corporation, the United States parent of the 7-Eleven convenience store chain. "Everybody says the Japanese can't restructure," Mr. Silverman said, "but they've done a great job of restructuring Southland."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: MIDTOWN;
Late Late Show, Low Low Price, Big Big Guards

BYLINE: By JESSE McKINLEY 

 BODY:
Sure, the city that never sleeps. But can you go see a first-run movie at 2 A.M.?
Well, yes, actually. A 42d Street theater has been offering a "super late show." 
 Wedged between a video sex shop and the shuttered Empire theater at 244 West 42d Street, the Movieplex 42 has managed in the last year to build a regular following for its late late show on Friday and Saturday nights, sometimes selling out first-run flicks that have begun as late as 3 A.M.
"They're coming from all over, hanging, chilling out after from the club," said Steve Oden, 26, a security guard at the theater. "Friday night you get a lot of teens out clubbing, but Saturday is more laid back, with lots of couples."
Scott Wexler, controller for the six-screen Movieplex 42, which in previous incarnations had run kung fu and adult films, said the theater fills a void. "We felt there was a need for it," Mr. Wexler said. "People in New York stay up late."
In addition to its insomnia-friendly hours, the Movieplex attracts customers with low prices ($6 compared with the usual $8) and, once they are inside, lets them slip from one theater to the next, a kind of do-it-yourself double feature.
"I appreciate the hours," said Aaron Garrett, 33, of Harlem, who has been going to the theater for about three months, generally after working 12- to 15-hour shifts at the Harlem Music Hut. "But it's also a painful economic situation. It's only a little difference, but I can use the money."
The late late show resonates for old New York movie buffs like Andrew Sarris, the film critic, who recalls the glory days of 42d Street movie palaces during the 1940's and 50's. "Times Square was always an all-night place," Mr. Sarris said. He said he once watched 11 straight movies in a Times Square all-night movie house.
Industry trend-watchers don't see the super late show becoming a national phenomenon. They say the appeal is special to Times Square.
Pete Gotthold, district manager of United Artists Theater Circuit Inc., the 2d largest theater chain in the country, is impressed by the crowds at Movieplex's late late show. "But I don't see it catching on," he said. "If it'll work anywhere, it's Times Square."
Stephen Farber, film critic for Movieline magazine, based in Los Angeles, and author of several books on the movie industry, said he knew of no 2 A.M. movies in L.A. "It's an interesting idea that some theaters might try to tap into that underground audience," he said, though he said he doubted theaters in Los Angeles would follow the lead. "You can't even find something to eat here after 10 P.M."
Security is tight at the Movieplex, though the most serious problems usually involve cigarettes. "If you got 'em, don't smoke 'em" is a running reminder from the five-man security force, which roams the theater. "Show some respect," announces Samson Supreme Ware, a towering security guard who got his job after attending the late late show so steadily that he got to know the theater's staff. "There's kids in the audience."
That may be a reach considering the hour (you can catch the audience yawning and stretching a lot) but the crowd is young enough to engage in the traditional movie rites of spring. Ty Abbensetts, 25, and his two pals, Ralph (Polo) Harrell, 28, of Washington Heights and Billy Mimms, 24, of Brooklyn, have been going to the late late movie for about three months to meet girls.
"The later the movie, the better," said Mr. Abbensetts, eyeing the crowd by the popcorn stand. "Everything else is closed, and dull, and you can hang at home, but it's better around here. People like to hang.
"Sometimes," he added, laughing, "you come solo and you leave with company." JESSE McKINLEY
