HEADLINE: BEHIND THE WHEEL/Ferrari 456GT and F355 Berlinetta;
Ever Exotic, but Less Eccentric

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL 

DATELINE: SANTA BARBARA, Calif.

 BODY:
IT can't be all fun and games managing Automobili Ferrari these days. Sure, you still get to drive fast cars where nobody worries about speed limits. And, no doubt, you can still work in a few long lunches to discuss the merits of Nicasil-coated cylinder liners and ZF Servotronic variable-assist steering over fresh porcini and aged Barolo. But no longer is every Ferrari the factory makes sold before it reaches the showroom floor.
Too many Italians, it seems, now regard expensive sports cars as symbols of political scandal. And too many Americans with money to burn would rather be seen in Range Rovers. 
 Yet more devastating, car collectors have been singed by the hot winds of deflation. While rare models from the 1950's and 1960's still fetch millions of dollars, newly minted exotic cars are just as likely to depreciate under their dust covers.
Ferrari, which is now owned by Fiat, has responded with a flexibility that would make the business school gurus proud. To compete more effectively with other sports cars -- notably the high-end Porsches -- it is aiming at a variety of niche markets and it is promoting amateur racing in Europe. And to keep the faith with collectors without restricting total sales, it is putting out more models in shorter production runs.
Most important, Ferrari is embracing up-to-date technology -- anti-lock brakes, air bags and computerized suspensions -- to make cars that are almost as easy and safe to drive as they are nice to eyeball. Indeed two Ferraris introduced in the American market in the last year are probably the best-handling and best-mannered road cars Ferrari has ever built.
Start with the $225,000 456GT, the first Ferrari with a back seat -- albeit one best suited for the vertically challenged -- since 1985.
The 456GT looks like more a luxury coupe than a sports car, stretching as long as an E-Class Mercedes sedan and weighing considerably more. The luxury feel is reinforced by the interior, with its wide, electrically adjustable front seats and comfort features that might have been borrowed from the 7-series BMW.
Wait, there's more unusual news: this Ferrari behaves in traffic. You probably wouldn't think of driving the 456GT to the supermarket, but you could. The 5.5-liter, 12-cylinder engine, which produces 436 horsepower and offers adequate torque at very low r.p.m., is built to run in third gear without complaint at 40 miles an hour. And thanks to a conservative layout with the engine up front, the 456GT runs quietly enough to hear the compact disk player.
But the real appeal -- what makes it a Ferrari rather than a BMW dressed by Armani -- is the 456GT's explosive acceleration and extraordinary handling at high speed. Tromp on the throttle from a standstill, shift cleanly into second at around 6,000 r.p.m. and you'll reach 60 in about 5 seconds. Better yet, get behind a Sunday driver on a steep uphill grade, downshift to second, floor it, and feel the 456GT respond like an Indy car.
The sheer mass of the 456GT ought to make it a pain to maneuver on curves. It ought to, but doesn't: the sophisticated steering, oversized Pirelli P Zero tires and computer-controlled hydraulic shock absorbers provide an uncanny sense that this car could take 30- mile-an-hour hairpin turns at 70.
While the front-engine 456GT is positioned as the ultimate "grand touring" car, the F355 is aimed at those yearning for the experience of racing without setting wheel to track. This gorgeous little sports car is pure testosterone -- a guided missile that proves Ferrari can match the technology of Porsche and Acura in an "entry level" vehicle costing $130,000.
The V8 engine, positioned in front of the huge 18-inch rear wheels, displaces just 3.5 liters and weighs only 370 pounds. But the high-compression, five-valve-per-cylinder design, along with the use of titanium in highly stressed parts, permits it to shove enough air and gasoline through the combustion chambers to develop 375 horsepower without benefit of a turbocharger.
With a computerized suspension similar to the 456GT's and a half-ton less weight to lug around, the F355 performs like a pair of wings. It is a bit faster than the 456GT below triple-digit speeds, and it feels much faster because the driver sits just a few inches from the ground.
The F355 is also inviting to those with little experience driving exotic cars. Like all Ferraris, it has a stiff clutch, close-set pedals and a steel-gated gearbox to remind owners of Ferrari's racing heritage. But this is a forgiving version of the venerable six-speed transmission, one that can be moved crisply between gears after just a few minutes' practice.
Those who care to find fault with these cars, particularly with the 456GT, won't have far to look. The interior fit and finish of the big Ferrari are not up to the standards of Mercedes or Lexus. The controls are clunky compared with a Porsche's. And while both Ferraris are magnificent road machines, no straightforward comparison of price to performance would put either in the "best buy" class.
But there is nothing straightforward about the appeal of Ferraris. These two models look great and sound better. And unlike many of their predecessors, they have been designed to provide extraordinary thrills to ordinary drivers.
 
INSIDE TRACK: Ferraris aren't getting cheaper, but they're sure getting better.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: April 23, 1995

SECTION: Section 13; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 4125 words

HEADLINE: How I Got My Child Into Nursery School

BYLINE: By JANNY SCOTT 

 BODY:
ONE evening last December, I found myself sitting on the floor of the West Side Montessori School gymnasium with 50 other mothers and fathers, gathering survival tips for one of the most notorious passages of Manhattan parenthood.
We were deep into the annual nursery-school hunting season (September through March). The school's director was offering advice on getting through the preschool admissions process with our self-respect intact. 
"You are the consumers," she insisted, as we sat there like 3-year-olds, twitching and squirming and rearranging our legs. "I know you probably don't feel like it, but you are in charge of making the match."
Yes, indeed -- in charge was not exactly what we were feeling. Nor is "consumer" the first word that comes to mind when one contemplates the role of parent in the arcane process of landing a child in certain Manhattan nursery schools.
The very mention of the exercise evokes exaggerated shudders. People roll their eyes in hyperbolic disgust and launch into the kind of horror stories normally inspired by terms like "co-op board," "jury duty" and "D.M.V."
In the popular imagination, the preschool sweepstakes has come to embody almost everything uptight and irritating about Manhattan: snobbery, competition, money, pathological ambition, misplaced notions of status.
For here you can find hundreds of families scrambling for scarce spots in schools where their children may spend no more than 15 hours a week but that charge as much as $9,600, a figure that will go up the next year.
The standard advice is to apply to a half-dozen schools. But finding those schools may require investigating 8 or 10. That takes time and money: some schools want an application fee of as much as $50 before you set foot in the door.
And in the end, it is the schools that do the bulk of the choosing. Their decisions arrive in the mail on the same fateful March day. The drill is sickeningly familiar: fat envelope, good; skinny envelope, bad.
The entire business is all the more painful because children are involved. They are being judged -- or are being judged through their parents. Parents stumble through, wondering, "If we fall short, will our child pay the price?"
"It's the most humiliating part of living in Manhattan," a friend assured me matter-of-factly as I embarked upon the search last fall. I'd been in New York long enough to know that she was saying a lot.
Now that it's over, I have learned a few things. Some would have been nice to know in advance. Maybe then I would have felt a little more like a smart shopper. (In charge? Dream on.)
I have learned that nursery schools differ in distinct ways. They come in all shapes, sizes and philosophical stripes. Some left me dazzled, some depressed. The longer I looked, the clearer the differences became.
I believe it can matter where a child goes. Not all schools are equally suited to all children. Maybe some children flourish anywhere, but others may be happier and more stimulated in one environment than in another.
But I've also learned it may be impossible to make well-informed decisions. Reliable, unbiased information is scarce. You get only a glimpse of most schools. You rarely meet the person who would teach your child.
And of course, the decision will probably not be yours. "Have you chosen a school?" people kept asking me. But I wasn't the chooser, I kept thinking. I was just vying to become one of the chosen.
I did find the process less appalling than people had said. It seemed more rational, less of a free-for-all. The hysteria seemed to emanate less from school administrators than from parents plotting to win them over.
I also know that the nursery-school frenzy is not exclusive to New York. In Los Angeles, some people sign their children up at birth. Here, there are many good schools to consider; some cities have two or three. But in the end, I am left feeling that the outcomes are unfathomable. After six months of applications, interviews and comparing notes, I remain mystified about how New York City preschools really decide whom they're going to admit.
Administrators say they look for a balance of sexes, ages, skills and backgrounds -- in short, a sympathetic mix of pupils and families. But how do they measure skills and compatibility with so little exposure to parent or child?
Skeptics say the schools go by the parents -- where they went to college, whom they know, what they do, how much they make. But few of the many schools that I looked at ever tried to explore most of those things.
When it was over, I heard of children being rejected by schools that their parents had considered fallbacks, welcomed by ones assumed impossible to get into, turned down where their families had pull and accepted where they had none.
So why go through it?
 
A Toe in the Water: The Initial Briefing
 In my case, my daughter will soon turn 3. She seemed, to my husband and me, to be ready to graduate from her current routine -- classes and play dates with nanny in tow -- to something more challenging. Like, say, school.
We didn't want to be negligent parents. In two more years, she would be kindergarten bound. Within limits, it seemed smart to help prepare her to make the leap -- preferably into the school of our choice.
But having decided that, we knew nothing about nursery schools. In Manhattan alone, there are at least 175 privately run preschool programs, dozens of them within walking distance of our apartment on the Upper West Side.
An added problem was that we were planning to move -- to somewhere else in Manhattan, but we didn't know where. To cover our bases, we decided to look at schools on both sides of Central Park, in case we ended up moving across town.
So my first foray into the field was to a forum on preschool admissions held by the Parents League of New York at which four preschool administrators patiently gave some 100 tightly wound parents a preview of what was in store.
We convened in the auditorium of an East Side private school at 9:30 A.M. The audience was dressed for work and left the fearsome impression that they were intending to confront this problem as they would any other corporate merger.
The speakers hashed out the question of what age to send a child, how to start looking in your neighborhood and work your way farther afield, when to contact schools, what to look for on a tour.
Start applying a full year before your child is to begin school, they said. Call each school the day or week after Labor Day. Ask about age-cutoff dates, application fees, tuition. Then ask to have application materials sent.
When touring a school, ask how it handles "separation" problems, they suggested. Ask about teachers' credentials, drop-in visits by parents, toilet training, religious holidays, the length of the school day.
Under cross-examination from parents, the administrators flatly denied the "feeder-school theory": that certain nursery schools feed into certain exclusive kindergartens and grade schools. They insisted that grade-school classes were made up of graduates of dozens of preschools.
"Beware of advice from friends," a Parents League organizer warned. Seek out "neutral, appropriate information." Shun "park-bench rumor" skewed by other people's limited experiences and preconceptions.
Armed with that advice, off we went.
 
The Continuing Search For 'Neutral Sources'
 Unfortunately, neutral sources turned out to be hard to come by. Gossip is a hot commodity among fretful parents. All parents have biases based in part on their own upbringings, and school administrators are advocates for their own schools.
The Independent Schools Admissions Association of Greater New York publishes a directory that describes all of its member schools, but the information offered comes from each school itself.
Another book, "The Manhattan Directory of Private Nursery Schools," by Linda Faulhaber (Soho Press, 1995; $20) goes only slightly further. And "The Manhattan Family Guide to Private Schools," by Catherine Hausman and Victoria Goldman (Soho Press, 1994; $22), while more opinionated, concentrates on grade schools.
So after reading the books and talking to friends and friends of friends, I went to one other seminar, this one conducted by Barbara Katz, the assistant director of the Parenting Center at the 92d Street Y.
Though the 92d Street Y has its own nursery school, Ms. Katz was as close as I came to a source of "neutral, appropriate information." She led the audience through the preschool maze. But she also said more.
She offered a number of remarkable observations and pieces of advice -- remarkable not only for what they revealed about schools but also for what they revealed about parents.
* Don't be rude to the secretary. It won't be forgotten.
* Don't send your nanny on the interview with your child. "That happens all the time," she said. "They're not impressed."
* It's wrong to contribute to a school in hopes of getting in.
* Don't let the process change your opinion of your child.
* Remember whom all this effort is for. (Wrong answer: Your ego.)
* If you love one school, it might help to write and tell them. But never send those letters to multiple schools. "Word gets around these schools," Ms. Katz warned cryptically. "They talk."
Were we to conclude that we were up against some sort of nursery-school cartel? Was she suggesting that schools conspired? It was a weird feeling, the dawning of the sensation that I would never understand the rules of the game.
 
 
At the Battle Station: The Countdown Begins
 Labor Day loomed. At the top of the page marked Tuesday, Sept. 6 in my calendar was scrawled the injunction "CALL SCHOOLS!" At 9:01 A.M., I started dialing the dozen or so schools on my tentative list.
Some answered immediately and said they would send their materials. Other lines were perpetually busy. Some had messages saying to call on Thursday. At one school, a woman's voice barked: "Call back in October. You're too early."
By late morning, I was feeling a little like an unemployed actor trying to drum up a theatrical agent over the phone, making cold calls to beg them to consider my 8-by-10 glossies and my curriculum vitae.
But within a week or two, application packets started arriving. They ranged from a glossy magazine with the look of a corporation's annual report to a one-page brochure decorated with a student's stick-figure portrait of herself.
The Bank Street School for Children, near Columbia University, sent a 20-page booklet, a four-page application, an invitation to one of five open houses, the tuition schedule and an explanation of the $1,000 interest-free loan required of every new family.
The package from the Horace Mann School for Nursery Years was dominated by a spiffy color brochure for its main school that noted, "Our distinguished alumni consistently excel, often reaching the pinnacles of their professions and sometimes making history."
What to think? Did a glossy magazine mean a school was well run -- or squandering money on self-promotion? Was I supposed to have been thinking about positioning my 2 1/2-year-old to make history?
The content, in some cases, was even more baffling.
Some brochures talked vaguely about a "child-oriented curriculum" and "learning through experience." Some alluded to the "balance between freedom and structure" or a "structured yet flexible setting."
It was a new language, dense with buzzwords that seem to have meaning to those steeped in early-childhood education but that would come to be significant to a rube like me only after repeat exposure.
In other areas, however, the differences were stark. For a 3-year-old child attending school five half-days a week, tuitions ranged from about $5,000 to nearly $10,000. Application fees ranged from $30 to $50.
One school would require attendance at a weekly chapel service. Others celebrated Christmas and Hanukkah and Kwanzaa. Most were nonprofit, some profit-making. Some would give preference to members of their affiliated churches.
Quite a few required that I file an application and send in my check before I could make an appointment to tour the school. Others would let me see the school first, then decide whether I still wanted to apply. Some offered to waive the fee for financial-aid applicants.
The applications were mostly one-page questionnaires: child's name, date of birth, health status, parents' address, employers. Only one of more than a dozen asked where my husband and I had gone to college.
A few were more elaborate. A school called the Ark, on East 79th Street, wanted a short essay describing our child's personality, strengths and weaknesses, "what you like best about your child" and what we expected from a preschool.
Christ Church Day School, on Park Avenue, had distributed its quota of applications by the time I got through. So it sent a "wait-list application." It might or might not be "activated," depending on how many people applied. In the upper left-hand corner were the words: "Family Photo: Please Attach."
 
 
Stage Two: Embarking On the Grand Tour
 In early October, I began touring. In most cases, the tours lasted about an hour. I was usually part of a group of a half-dozen to a dozen parents who were shown around by an administrator and given a chance to talk to the director.
At a few schools, the tours were one-on-one. One school had a large open house, complete with wine and cheese. About 100 parents heard presentations, then toured the building. No children were in view.
At another open house, the director warned us about sibling preference. So many siblings of students had applied in the previous year they had filled the entire morning program. Only afternoon slots were left.
In some ways, the schools seemed to have a lot in common. Class sizes and student-teacher ratios are set by the city. The classrooms were well stocked with art supplies, blocks, dress-up clothes, Legos and other toys of that ilk.
But upon examination, philosophical and other differences emerged. Some were quite traditional and structured. Some used Montessori methods. A few looked like giant playrooms presided over by their idiosyncratic directors.
One school had a spectacular gym that a very active child might love. Some had pets, others didn't. One school with no outdoor play area escorted the children to Central Park -- but not to the park's playgrounds (too chaotic).
Some had big libraries. Some expected parents to be actively involved in raising money -- which, in one case, went to support an impressive financial-aid program that had made the school one of the few that was truly diverse.
At one school, we were shown a class of 3-year-olds seated in tiny chairs as the teacher called on them one by one. We passed by again 15 minutes later. The children appeared not to have moved.
How did that school handle separation? Simple, the director explained: parents said goodbye at the front door. If a child balked? The crying stopped, she assured us, by the time the child got to class.
One administrator estimated that 95 percent of the students came from two-career homes. At another school, the ratio was about 50-50.
The mothers in evidence at one school seemed to be in uniform: velvet headbands, patent-leather flats. I left that school in a cold sweat from the horror of being trapped in a world from which I like to believe I have escaped. If my daughter were to go there, would she end up in velvet headbands, too?
 
 
The Cold Season Comes, And With It, Audition Time
 Winter arrived. All but one of the seven schools that we had decided to apply to required an "interview" with my daughter. In most cases, she was to come play at the school for a half-hour with a few other children.
At the first interview, the director led three children and three mothers into a small classroom full of toys, then appeared to barely notice the children while she engaged the mothers in conversation.
At the next interview, the six to eight parents were corralled along the wall, where they crouched on a row of small chairs and were ignored by two rather formidable teachers who led the children through various puzzles, art projects and games. The atmosphere there seemed stern.
At other places, it was cheerful. At one school, eight applicants charged around the room while a gaggle of youthful teachers tagged along, occasionally stopping to scribble notes.
"Look, she signed her name," one marveled, showing me a piece of paper my daughter had covered in swirling crayon. I giggled foolishly. In the lower right-hand corner were a few scratchy lines that I might otherwise have mistaken for a few scratchy lines.
At another school, our first choice, the interview coincided with toddler nap time. When we arrived, my daughter was wired. On the elevator ride up, another applicant imploded. He and his mother were not seen again.
But inside the classroom, my daughter seemed to rise to the occasion. She chatted with the guinea pig and served plastic broccoli to a teacher. From the sidelines, I struggled with the confused feelings of a classic stage mother.
I wanted her to do well -- and, of course, I thought she would. I wanted the teachers to be dazzled -- why shouldn't they be? But what if they weren't? She was clearly being sized up -- which seemed to mean I was, too.
 
 
Nothing to Do but Sit Back And Endure the Suspense
 By mid-February, all that was left to do was wait.
Our first response came from a school that, because it was not a nonprofit one, did not belong to the Independent Schools Admissions Association of Greater New York. For that reason, it did not abide by the standard notification dates.
My daughter was in, if we wanted the spot. The school had enclosed a contract to sign and return with a $1,215 deposit. The deadline for responding was March 3 -- four days before we were to hear from the rest of the schools.
I called the director. Yes, it did mean we would have to sign up before knowing if we had choices. And yes, if we signed and reneged, we would not only lose our deposit but also be liable for the unpaid $4,860 tuition balance.
It seemed like a lot to pay to preserve an option. The director sounded a little apologetic. But it was the one thing the school had over the other schools in the association to which it couldn't belong, she explained.
We decided to pass. The next response came from one of the association schools. The letter was dated March 7, the official notification date, but arrived on March 2. It was postmarked March 1.
This time, the letter said they were putting my daughter on the waiting list. It said some additional acceptances were likely to be made in several weeks. We were to contact the school in writing if we wanted to stay on the list.
I admit it, I was shaken. For the first time in six months, I couldn't help but wonder: What if we're shut out? I had prided myself on not letting the process get to me. That night, I barely slept.
I recovered my composure and got through the next week. Then on March 9, I returned home from work, put the key in the mailbox and knew the moment had arrived. There were five white envelopes lurking inside.
Thin, fat, fat, thin, thin. She had been offered a morning spot at the school that was our first choice and an afternoon spot at another. She was wait-listed at the other three. We were given until March 16 to make up our minds.
But the most striking thing about the outcome was that she had been offered a place at every school on the West Side to which we had applied. On the East Side, in every case, she had been put on the waiting list.
Luckily, we had found another apartment on the side of town that matched. But I am left wondering: Was it something we said? Do schools simply assume that outlander applicants won't accept their offers? Or was it something else?
Go figure.
 
Does Nursery School Really Matter?
 Any parents who have ever embarked upon the private nursery-school rat race have probably allowed themselves occasionally to wonder: Does it really matter where a 3-year-old child goes to preschool?
The answer appears to be yes and no. Experts in early childhood education say that poor schooling can harm very young children but that private preschools in New York City do not appear to fit that description.
Furthermore, several researchers said they knew of no evidence that differences between nursery schools' philosophy and approach leave any mark that lasts through first or second grade.
Nevertheless, they said those differences can affect a child's happiness in school. And that can affect self-esteem and motivation. They said certain children in certain environments can be turned off of learning.
For example, a shy or cautious child might not thrive in a large class with a lot of activities going on simultaneously, some said. Similarly, an active child might become frustrated in a highly structured setting.
"Are you meshing your child with the kind of program where he or she will flourish?" asked Alice Sterling Honig, a professor of child development at Syracuse University.
Professor Honig and other researchers cited several critical determinants of the quality of a nursery school: the ratio of children to adults, the size of the classes and the extent of the teachers' training.
In New York City, they said teacher-student ratios and class sizes in private preschools tend to be more than acceptable since they have been set by city and state agencies that license and charter schools.
As for teachers, several said at least one in every class should have training in early childhood education. They said some schools do more than others to encourage their teachers to further their education.
In research, Professor Honig has found that over 60 percent of the variation in the quality of teachers' interactions with children can be traced to the extent of their training in child development and early childhood education.
Beyond those factors, several researchers said there was little proof that differences between, say, "academic" and "progressive" preschools were likely to affect a child's prospects in elementary school.
But they said some children would be happier in one place over another. Jeanne Brooks-Gunn, a professor of child development at Teachers College at Columbia University, said it would have been "a disaster" to have placed her very active son in a school that stressed sitting still and doing drills.
"Not a disaster in terms of his educational attainment when he hit first or second grade," she said. "But I think it wouldn't have matched his temperament. He wouldn't have been as happy."
Ellen Galinsky, co-president of the Families and Work Institute in New York City, said a result of a poor fit between school or teacher and child could be that the child begins to develop a poor self-image.
In Ms. Galinsky's view, the most important aspect of a child's preschool experience is the quality of their relationship with their teacher -- the warmth of that relationship and the teacher's responsiveness.
"It's that teaching connection between the adult and child in which the teacher encourages the child to think or see something in a new way, to see the world as a place worth learning about," she said. "That isn't automatic in a good school."
When it is absent, a child may begin to lose interest and begin to feel badly about him- or herself. At that point, she said, a parent could consider asking that her child have a new teacher or changing schools.
As for the materials used in the classroom, several experts said the types of materials matter less than how they are used.
"The issue is that there be a lot of them and that they be challenging for children and designed to help them learn," said Barbara Willer, public affairs director for the National Association for the Education of Young Children.
"The research suggests that as long as the approach is an active-learning approach that focuses on hands-on experiences, the specifics are less important," she said. "It's more an issue of how they're being used."
Similarly, Ms. Willer said, it is hard to generalize about whether it is good if a school mixes, or does not mix, children of different ages in the same class. According to Ms. Willer, it depends on how it is done.
A parent's role, she said, continues long after admission.
"I don't know that it's possible for anybody to get all the information that they need in the pre-admission visit," she said. "I think probably more important for your child's success is the ongoing relationship you have with the school." JANNY SCOTT

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Sizing Up a School Questions to Ask"
 Some questions reveal more than others about a school's personality. Here are a few that might be useful:
 -- How does the school handle the separation process for new students leaving their parent or caregiver for the first time? Is the process gradual or quick? (The answer may offer insight into a school's overall approach -- progressive or traditional -- and may help parents decide if they or their child would feel comfortable there.)
 -- How much, and in what ways, do teachers intervene if a child refuses to share? What if one child hits or bites another?
 -- How and what will the children learn?
 -- What is the school's policy on drop-in visits by parents? What other opportunities or requirements are there for parental involvement?
 -- What percentage of the children come from two-career families? (Some schools may be more accustomed than others to accommodating the schedules of working mothers.)
 -- What are the teachers' qualifications? How much staff turnover is there?
 -- How diverse is the student body?
 -- Does the school celebrate any religious or secular holidays? If so, how?
 -- How does the school help families applying to ongoing schools?
 -- How many places are really available to new families? How many applications does the school expect for those spots? (pg. 16)

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: April 23, 1995

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1269 words

HEADLINE: Diary

BYLINE: By BRETT BRUNE 

 BODY:

CURRENCY
Big Bird to the Rescue?
While the American dollar plunged last week to post-World War II lows against the yen, frustrations grew in Japan as hopes for a bright recovery there faced away. In Tokyo, Japanese protesters -- some in animal suits -- blamed the United States for pushing up the yen.
 
HEALTH CARE
It's Raining Mergers
The way health care companies are pairing two by two, you'd think the Flood were coming tomorrow. Last week -- in the second billion-dollar consolidation of home health care companies in 60 days -- Coram Healthcare agreed to buy Lincare Holdings for about $1.38 billion. On March 2, Abbey Healthcare Group and Homedco Group had announced plans for a $1 billion merger, themselves. The Coram half of soon-to-be Coram-Lincare was itself born of a four-way merger just last year. One analyst indicated the home health care business would, indeed, flood Coram-Lincare and Abbey-Homedco -- with money. She estimated that they would each command about 17 percent of the industry's $7 billion market next year.
 
COPING
Japanese Companies on Guard
Fearing a relapse into recession, several Japanese companies -- Mazda Motor, Mitsubishi Materials and Sumitomo Metal Industries are included -- have announced austerity plans. Big companies, at least, seem highly capable of coping with the export-threatening rise of the yen. But the Japanese economy might not fare as well. Indeed, analysts indicated last week, the country's lifetime employment system may be in jeopardy.
 
ARMS CONTRACTORS
A Moveable, Affordable Feast
Georgia's in. Washington's out. Where costs are low, military hardware manufacturing plants are bustling. Where costs are higher, wildflowers are growing around shuttered plants of the same sort. It's as if military contractors are collectively moving the party -- albeit a smaller, post-Reagan affair -- to any location where the tab will be most easily digested. Also on the in list: Colorado, Louisiana, Florida and Mississippi. In some cases, the companies are even seeking what economists say are gifts of public goods like roads, schools and municipal airports -- and getting them. Georgia's Cobb County, for example, is about to pay for a multimillion-dollar rail underpass to give a warm welcome to Lockheed Martin, the nation's largest arms contractor.
 
WEALTH
The Divided States of America
Picture a classroom of third-graders herded into two groups. Less than a quarter of them are sporting Hanna Andersson all-cotton separates. The rest are draped in itchy, ill-sized hand-me-downs. Hands on hearts, they chant, "I pledge allegiance to the flag of the United States of America, and to the Republic for which it stands: one nation, under God, economically divisible . . . ." This amendment to the egalitarian pledge seems fitting: New studies were shown to establish last week that America has become the most economically stratified of industrial nations. A very few possess much of the wealth. And, as a Brookings Institution fellow pointed out, because political campaigns in America are ruled by money, the financial extremes could well intensify. (In what could become a kind of reverse-Robin Hood legend, Republicans today are seeking cuts in Federal welfare programs and taxes.) And the country as a whole may end up suffering right along with those poorly dressed third-graders: One economics expert asserted that America, with a child poverty rate four times the average of its principal industrial competitors', could find itself at a big competitive disadvantage by the time today's children join the work force.
 
AUTOS
Mini-van Monday?
If the audacious billionaire Kirk Kerkorian succeeds in buying Chrysler -- mind you, this is a big if -- and the auto maker is left heavily in debt as a result, analysts believe the bottom lines of shareholders, along with mini-van buyers, would be affected. The analysts point to Philip Morris scrambling to cut Marlboro cigarette prices two years ago in an effort to stem the loss of sales to lower-priced competitors. Chrysler, it follows, would be forced to cut prices because with the debt on its books, "Ford and G.M. would have a field day" going after its product lines, said the automotive stock analyst Nicholas Lobaccaro. After Philip Morris announced its cut, the company suffered a sharp selloff that left its shareholders $13 billion poorer. With Chrysler, Mr. Lobaccaro predicted, instead of a Marlboro Friday, "you would have a mini-van Monday."
 
WALL STREET
Salomon Is Still Bleeding
Somebody get Salomon Brothers a tourniquet! Since a pay plan cutting the compensation of its managing directors was announced late last year, the investment bank has lost 10 percent of those directors. Three were added to the list last week -- even as the firm, which reported 1994 after-tax losses of almost $400 million, announced an easing of the restrictive pay plan. Analysts were skeptical about how effective the new plan would be. If it is shunned, management will probably have to pay still more to keep valued workers.
 
LENDING
Sure, It's Less Red Tape, but ...
Banks that make loans to small businesses are no doubt sighing in relief. Thanks to an overhaul of regulations aimed at encouraging banks and savings and loan associations to make more loans in moderate- and low-income areas, they face a lot less paperwork. But the relaxed reporting requirements, adopted last week, are more relaxed than some minority-rights activists believe is healthy. Under the new rules, banks do not have to collect and report information on the race and sex of their small-business borrowers -- as they have to do for home mortgages under the Community Reinvestment Act. The collection of those details was sought by community and consumer groups as a method of uncovering lending bias. But Federal regulators sided with bankers and Republicans in control of Congress and dropped the proposal. The Federal Reserve will, however, let banks, insurance companies and investment houses gather and publish data on business loans by sex and race -- on a voluntary basis.
 
MEDIA
The Last Word in Houston
What to read in Houston? Why, the Chronicle, of course. The choice between it and the Houston Post was eliminated last week when Hearst, the owner of the 94-year-old Chronicle, bought the 111-year-old Post from Consolidated Newspapers -- and shut it down. At a loss for words, printed or spoken, Post staff members embraced to comfort each other. Now, as the country's fourth-largest city, Houston is the largest city in the country with a single major daily metropolitan newspaper. It has plenty of company across the nation. In Milwaukee, the Sentinel merged with the Journal on April 2, and Providence, R.I., the Evening Bulletin is set to merge with the Journal on June 5.
 
SWINDLES
'I'm Not Entirely to Blame'
No doubt, this is the headline Steven Hoffenberg would like to have dictated about his guilty plea last week to criminal conspiracy and fraud charges in connection with a $460 million Ponzi-scheme that he ran through his flagship company, Towers Financial. After the Securities and Exchange Commission had accused him of being a swindler, Mr. Hoffenberg had directed the coverage of his own regulatory troubles in what was then his New York Post. (The Post is now owned by the News Corporation.) In his court appearance last week, Mr. Hoffenberg made accusations against Towers accountants. He did the same thing earlier with one of his lawyers. But no criminal charges against these people have materialized.

HEADLINE: Earth Days Have Become Earth Years

BYLINE: By Al Gore; Al Gore is Vice President of the United States and author of "Earth in the Balance."

 BODY:
Yesterday, even as our thoughts and prayers were focused on the tragedy in Oklahoma City, we took time to remember that 25 years ago, a simple idea for a teach-in exploded into a national event involving 20 million people that changed the course of history. Following the first Earth Day, our nation built from scratch the most advanced health and environmental safeguards in the world. It is a great American success story that proves the old-fashioned idea that individuals can make a difference, that when the people speak, their leaders can listen and do something about it. It ought to be a source of inspiration.
After all, in the past 25 years, we've cut air pollution by a third, even though we drive twice as many cars twice as many miles as we did then. We've cut emissions of lead by 98 percent, and countless children are the better for it. Twice as many rivers and lakes are safe for swimming. And where 25 years ago boxes and beer cans lined the roadways, today people of all ages are recycling in 6,000 community programs. 
 What now? Where do we go from here and how do we get there?
On the day after the first Earth Day, The New York Times wrote: "Conservatives were for it. Liberals were for it. Democrats, Republicans, and independents were for it. So were the ins, the outs, the executive and legislative branches of Government." Today, that support is still there. Recent polls show that 53 percent of the people think government action to protect the environment does not go far enough, while another 23 percent think we are on the right track. Only 16 percent think Government regulation on the environment has gone too far.
But this time, bipartisanship is hanging by a thread. The Republican Congress is pushing an extreme anti-environmental agenda. It would freeze all health and environmental protection, effectively repeal 25 years of health protection through a "risk assessment" bill and allow industry to hold up environmental safeguards through endless lawsuits. It would even require taxpayers to pay polluters not to pollute.
The Republicans have turned over the legislative process to lobbyists. The freeze on new health, safety and environmental standards was written by a coalition of wealthy special- interest lobbyists, who were even given a room off the House floor to write amendments and furnish talking points for lawmakers. The Senate committee used lobbyists to explain the legislation to staff. And the committee worked side by side with lobbyists to write loopholes into the Clean Water Act.
So this time, the future will bring two struggles: the first, to prevent the rollback of the gains we have made, and the second, to reinvent environmental protection in order to make further gains. On the first, we will fight. On the second, we will join with those who want to build on the lessons learned since 1970.
What have we learned? First, collaborative processes work better than adversarial ones. Second, flexibility works better than one-size-fits-all dictates. Third, Washington doesn't have all the answers, and we should shift some responsibilities from central bureaucracies to local communities. Fourth, pollution is often a sign of economic inefficiency, and you can make money by preventing it.
Here is an example of things to come. Recently, President Clinton announced 25 reforms to make environmental protection work better and cost less. Through Project "XL" -- our project in excellence in leadership -- we will move from a one-size-fits-all system to a system based on real results and common sense. It's the first program in the next generation of environmental protection -- cleaner for the environment, cheaper for business and taxpayers and smarter and safer for our children's future. And just last week, we unveiled our new national environmental strategy to promote development and export of a new generation of technologies to improve both environmental and economic performance. This strategy is one of the best examples of "reinventing government" -- where the Federal Government acts as a partner with industry and local governments.
We are also making use of the Government's purchasing power, with executive orders to cut the use of toxic substances by 50 percent by 1999 and to improve energy and water efficiency -- a move estimated to cut the Government's utility bills by $1 billion annually by the year 2005. Similarly, to boost recycling and to reduce the burden on landfills, the President signed an executive order directing Federal agencies to purchase recycled and environmentally preferable products. The Government is the largest purchaser of goods and services in the world, so it makes sense to put that purchasing power to work.
There have been other actions taken in this spirit. The Partnership for a New Generation of Vehicles between Government and industry will develop a new generation of vehicles up to three times more fuel efficient than today's -- and strengthen our competitiveness. A new incineration policy will result in a 95 percent reduction in emissions of dangerous pollutants. The proposed reform of the Superfund program will make life safer for the one in four Americans who still live near a toxic dump site, 14 years after Love Canal. Too much money that should have gone to clean up toxic dumps was spent on lawyers.
We are also pursuing new approaches on the international front. At the 1994 International Conference on Population and Development, in Cairo, the U.S. helped forge a historic consensus on a global program to stabilize population growth through increased availability of family planning services, a commitment to improving women's health, the empowerment of women and a reduction in infant and child mortality.
We are implementing a comprehensive national strategy to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions to 1990 levels in the year 2000 -- a commitment renewed last month in Berlin. Already, more than 800 of the nation's electric utility companies have signed voluntary pledges to limit greenhouse- gas emissions
Similarly, in London, the U.S. took the lead among the world's nuclear powers and achieved a global ban on ocean dumping of radioactive waste. The U.S. was the first of the nuclear powers to advocate the ban. We have also succeeded in creating a whale sanctuary in the southern ocean around Antarctica. Commercial whaling will now be prohibited in an enormous area of the ocean that is home to three-quarters of the world's whales.
So while others may conclude that the future of our environment is unclear, I am optimistic. And so is the President, who has made it clear that he will fight hard to prevent a return to the days before that first Earth Day 25 years and one day ago. As he said in Dallas on March 16: "I cannot and will not compromise any clean water, any clean air, any protection against toxic waste. The environment cannot protect itself. And if it requires a Presidential veto to protect it, then that's what I'll provide."

HEADLINE: When Republicans Don Democratic Masks

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your April 14 front-page picture of Representative Robert K. Dornan and the caption "The Happy Warrior" (some editions) typifies Republican exploitation of heroic 20th-century Democratic statesmen. From Newt Gingrich's claiming bipartisanship in the name of Franklin D. Roosevelt to Senator Jesse Helms's using Hubert H. Humphrey's name to promote his civil rights restoration bill, which would abolish opportunities for thousands of minorities and women, these flawed comparisons have demeaned these leaders and their causes. 
 The real Happy Warriors, Franklin Delano Roosevelt and Hubert Humphrey, were true to the "high endeavors" character of William Wordsworth's poetic hero. They showed they could lead their people beyond hardship, out of the shadows of discrimination and over the mountain of economic depression. They showed that by empowering people and creating opportunity, our nation would indeed be indivisible with liberty and justice for all.
In sharp contrast, the Republican leaders of today stand for division and partisanship, liberty for the few at the top of the economic ladder and justice for those who can afford it.
 
HUBERT H. HUMPHREY 3D
Attorney General
Minnesota
Minneapolis, April 18, 1995

HEADLINE: Yale Case Illustrates Swindle of Grade Inflation

 BODY:
To the Editor:
It is worrisome that a transfer applicant to Yale University could deceive an admissions officer about his record at a state college in California (Week in Review, April 16). But the most significant fact in this episode is that the student, whose grade point average at his state college was just 2.1 (out of a possible 4.0), had a record of 3.0 at Yale. 
 This is the problem that the country's private colleges and universities would prefer to ignore: grade inflation is now so widespread at our best colleges that a high grade point average has ceased to be at all unusual. Twenty-five years ago, private colleges and universities could expect to bestow outstanding honors to the top 3 or 4 percent of the senior class. Today, at the University of Pennsylvania, and typical of the situation nationally, fully 20 percent of graduating students qualify for highest graduation honors.
Grade inflation trivializes a strong college record and adulterates the value of the bachelor's degree. The phenomenon is accelerating rather than declining. A correspondent (letter, April 11) complained that graduate schools are relying too much on the Graduate Record Examination and other standardized tests. Indeed we are, for admissions committees are aware that high grades at a good college are no longer an adequate index of a student's knowledge or ability.
The real fraud is not that one student managed to swindle Yale, but that many, perhaps most, selective colleges routinely award stellar grades to students of average ability without regard to what this process has done to the quality of higher education.
 
PAUL J. KORSHIN
Prof. of English, U. of Pennsylvania
Philadelphia, April 16, 1995

HEADLINE: Doctors Go Jobless, Patients Do Without

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your April 15 front-page article featuring an unemployed eye surgeon confirms the decline in American health care. When I was growing up in the 1940's and 50's, my family saw an eye doctor every year; so did my own children in the 70's and 80's. Now, my family and I never see one. 
 On rare occasions I have visited a private eye doctor, whose fees are not covered by my health maintenance organization. A recent article told me that under some health plans if I develop cataracts, I may have them removed only in one eye. Meanwhile, eye surgeons cannot find work. Surely, health maintenance organizations are not matching the skills of doctors to our needs nearly as well as a single-payer system could.
 
ROSE ROSENGARD SUBOTNIK
Providence, R.I., April 16, 1995

HEADLINE: April 16-22;
When Good Republicans Make Bad Moves

BYLINE: By RICHARD L. BERKE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
"POLITICS is just like show business," Ronald Reagan once observed. "You have a hell of an opening, you coast for a while, you have a hell of a closing."
Well, the curtain has gone up on eight contenders for the Republican Presidential nomination. While their openings were hardly worthy of Hollywood (or of Ronald Reagan, for that matter), the debut announcement speeches do tell people something about the candidates. And some moments, and some passages, stood out:
 
Most Baffling Site Selection
 At a time when the Capitol dome is a backdrop only for attack commercials, Senator Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania defied conventional wisdom (and anti-Washington sentiment) by staging his announcement smack in the middle of what one rival, former Gov. Lamar Alexander of Tennessee, calls the "arrogant empire." He delivered his speech in the shadow of the Washington Monument, with the Lincoln Memorial right behind him. 
 Considering that Mr. Specter picked a popular tourist site, it was all the more surprising that he couldn't assemble more than 200 to stand around and watch him. His aides scrambled to stock the audience with unknowing passersby. They had little luck.
 
Most Venue Problems
 To drive home his message about restoring power to the states, Senator Bob Dole of Kansas planned an elaborate announcement at the steps of the Capitol in Topeka. But this was Kansas. And while no tornado materialized, foul weather forced the event inside, to a nondescript arena.
Mr. Dole tried again later in the week, in Raleigh, N.C., with another version of the speech. It was a beautiful spring day. The event was set for the Capitol. But local officials would not allow a political event at a Government building. So Mr. Dole moved into a hotel ballroom. At least, unlike the commentator Patrick J. Buchanan, Mr. Dole got to open his speech without interruption by protesters jumping on stage.
 
Most Dubious Opening
 Rather than cancel, Senator Richard G. Lugar of Indiana went ahead with his announcement on Wednesday, only hours after the explosion in Oklahoma City. He opened with a moment of silence for the victims. But few will know what he said.
"It's going to go down in history as the speech that shouldn't have been given the day it was given," said Kathleen Hall Jamieson, dean of the Annenberg School for Communication at the University of Pennsylvania. "He should have made a statement that it was inappropriate to announce on a day of national mourning. And he could not compete for press or psychological attention from the public."
 
Most Misspent Oratory
 Alan Keyes, a radio talk show host, brought the crowd to its feet as he vowed not to abandon the fight against abortion. His speech had the intensity, the fervor, of an old-time oration. But some in the audience -- at a conservative convention in San Diego -- wore buttons for other candidates. For much as they liked the show, many did not think Mr. Keyes has a chance.
 
Most Incongruous Theme
 Given that Senator Phil Gramm of Texas got several military deferments during the Vietnam War, it was surprising that he choreographed an announcement that looked like a show of military force.
There were uniformed cadets everywhere at Texas A & M University, where Mr. Gramm taught economics. The Senator arrived on stage by walking through cadets' raised sabers. And the event closed with the roar of cannons.
The police-state imagery delighted advisers to Senator Dole, a wounded hero of World War II. One critic said Mr. Gramm may as well have put a sign over his head proclaiming, "I never served."
 
Most Snickers
 Lamar Alexander, a millionaire, was skewered by the inside-the-Beltway commentators for taking to the stage as a populist in a plaid work shirt.
But Mr. Alexander, who is registering nowhere in the polls, at least got a little attention. "Every pundit in Washington, D.C., hated the plaid shirt," said Mark Merritt, Mr. Alexander's spokesman. "So we knew we were doing something right."
 
Lamest Portrait of a Nice Guy
 This, from Representative Robert K. Dornan of California, explaining why he has the temperament to be President: "Well, ladies and gentlemen, here's one Congressman that has never yelled at his staff; tried to motivate my children by example, not by harshness; that has never in subcommittee or committee or at a press conference ever showed anything but passion."
 
Most Memorable Line
 Mr. Gramm gets the honors. Not from his actual announcement speech, but from a speech in Dallas the night before, at the kick-off of his announcement tour. Surrounded by friends and supporters who raised millions for his campaign, he had offered these less-than-heartwarming words: "I have the most reliable friend that you can have in American politics, and that is ready money."

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Energy-Hungry, Asia Embraces Nuclear Power

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: HANOI, Vietnam

 BODY:
IT'S difficult to imagine the hulking towers of a nuclear power plant rising up from the emerald-green rice paddies of Vietnam, a nation so poor that most people still depend on cooking over an open fire and lighting their homes with oil lamps. But this month, the Vietnamese Government announced that it was considering a proposal from South Korea to build two nuclear reactors here at a cost of $3 billion.
Vietnam is one of the few Asian nations blessed by large deposits of fossil fuel -- it has huge tracts of offshore oil -- but its leaders are eager not to be left behind in the nuclear-power binge sweeping Asia. 
 Nuclear power is an industry in crisis in the West, the result both of the panic produced by the accidents at Three Mile Island and Chernobyl and of the multi-billion-dollar cost overruns that have plagued nuclear-energy projects throughout Europe and the United States. No new nuclear plants have been ordered in the United States since 1979.
But if the nuclear-energy genie is dying in the West, he is being reborn in Asia. The booming, fuel-hungry nations across the region are ordering and building nuclear plants at a rate not seen in decades.
 
Fail-Safe?
 There are already 115 commercial and research reactors in operation in East Asia, most in Japan, South Korea, Taiwan and China. In the next decade, dozens of new reactors are expected to built across the continent at a cost of more than $100 billion.
Asian leaders say they have no choice but to develop nuclear power given the explosive rate at which the demand for energy is growing. The International Atomic Energy Agency has predicted that power demands in Asia will triple by 2015.
But while reactors may power Asia's thriving economies into the next century, they also pose problems of safety and cost that the West has been tangling with unsuccessfully throughout the atomic age.
It is a subject now under scrutiny at the United Nations, where diplomats opened talks last week on extending the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. The 25-year-old treaty, which is about to expire, was designed to limit the spread of nuclear arms in part by allowing inspection of power plants to verify that atomic material is not diverted to weapons use. But evidence from North Korea has shown that a determined government could use civil nuclear programs as a cover for weapons development, and the spread of nuclear power in Asia has raised new concerns about proliferation.
Anti-nuclear advocates are dismayed. "It's the first world dumping old, dangerous technology on the developing world," said Jean McSorley, who directs anti-nuclear campaigns in Asia for Greenpeace. "We're encouraging them to repeat the same mistakes that we made."
Environmental groups say they take little solace from the fact that most of the plants now being built in Asia are of Western design, and that they incorporate hard-earned lessons about safety. They have called on Asian nations to shun atomic energy in favor of conservation and the use of safer energy sources. Solar energy, they say, would be a natural choice in much of sun-baked Southeast Asia.
No Asian nation has embraced nuclear energy more enthusiastically than China, which opened its first commercial complex only last year but has plans for 30 more reactors. Last month, it announced a shifting in national energy policy to encourage the development of nuclear power over hydropower and thermal energy, the priorities until now. "We are energetically developing nuclear power," said Yao Qiming, a government energy official. "It is our future."
Western companies are rushing in with proposals to build reactors. In January, China awarded three French firms a $3 billion contract to build two nuclear plants in Guangdong Province. Few in the industry were surprised when the chairmen of Westinghouse and General Electric, both of which design or build nuclear plants, showed up in Beijing last year for talks.
"The energy growth in Asia is just astonishing, and their move to nuclear energy shows that the nations of Asia understand the value of having a mix of energy resources -- and the value of nuclear energy," said Angie McBrien of the Nuclear Energy Institute, an industry lobbying group.
But if the Clinton Administration is eager to see American companies benefit from the development of atomic power in China, it has been dismayed by what has gone on in North Korea, the nation that more than any in Asia had proved the dangers of the unrestrained nuclear development.
 
Temptations
 Until last year, North Korea appeared bent on using spent fuel from a reactor to make weapons-grade plutonium. Under an agreement with the United States, the plant is to be shut down in return for safer reactors designed to limit the risk of diversion.
Negotiations to implement that agreement have been on-again, off-again. At the same time, some critics fear that other Asian countries that until now have disavowed ambitions for nuclear arms may be tempted to reconsider.
"My worst-case scenario is that every country in the region would get a couple of reactors with the idea that they want to keep their military options open," said Ms. McSorley of Greenpeace. The options are wide open in India and Pakistan, both of which have diverted nuclear material from power plants to the making of weapons that they might use against one another. Unlike most Asian nations, neither India nor Pakistan has signed the non-proliferation pact.
In Southeast Asia, Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia are all in varying stages of nuclear development. Indonesia is about to take bids for its first nuclear plant.
The governments of South Korea, Japan and Taiwan already support some of the world's most sophisticated nuclear-power programs. In South Korea, nuclear power provides more than 40 percent of all the electricity generated in the country; in Japan and Taiwan, the figure is about 30 percent. The Japanese Government has proposed the construction of at least 15 new nuclear reactors by 2010, and it is now pursuing the commercial use of fast-breeder reactors, which use plutonium for fuel.
The rush to nuclear power would not be so worrying if Asian leaders could guarantee that they would remain at peace. Since the Vietnam War, Asians have enjoyed a remarkable neighborliness. One reason for the region's economic success is that most governments have not been forced to spend a crippling portion of their budget on arms.
But military historians say it is only a matter of time before the collegiality of the region breaks down. In just the last few weeks, the Philippines, Taiwan and Vietnam have all raised the threat of military action over the potentially oil-rich Spratly Islands in the South China Sea, after China built a military-style platform atop a tiny reef. Asian diplomats have been alarmed by the recent dispute between two old strategic allies, the Philippines and Singapore, which came close to a diplomatic split over the execution in Singapore of a Filipino maid.
 
Tension
 Worried, Japanese scholars and nuclear experts have proposed a pan-Asian agreement to police recycling of nuclear material and prevent military diversions. Diplomats in the region have embraced the idea.
Proponents say an accord may be essential as Asian nations are forced to cooperate in waste disposal. Some land-starved countries are already having trouble disposing of spent fuel -- South Korea expects to fill all its storage sites in a decade.

HEADLINE: IDEAS & TRENDS;
Some Indians Buck a Stereotype

BYLINE: By GEORGE JOHNSON 

DATELINE: SANTA FE, N.M.

 BODY:
WHEN he is not happy with the powers that be in the New Mexico state government, Jacob Viarrial, the governor of Pojoaque Pueblo, has a foolproof way of turning up the heat. In a maneuver sure to stir up the environmentalists down in Santa Fe, he threatens to use the reservation, just a few miles from Santa Fe, as the site for a low-level nuclear waste dump.
That is what he told former Gov. Bruce King a couple years ago when the state tried to interfere with the pueblo's plans to open a gambling hall. And that is what he threatened earlier this year, when it looked as though the legislature might allow racetracks to compete with the state's proliferating supply of Indian-owned casinos. "With different people wanting to force us out of Indian gaming, we need to look at other areas," Mr. Viarrial said in an interview last week. "Right now we're looking at low-level, but if it looks lucrative enough we might go with high-level waste." 
 Since the first Earth Day, 25 years ago yesterday, America's natives have been romanticized as the original environmentalists. Millions of television viewers remember being struck (or bludgeoned) by what now is a parody of poignant public service advertising: a solemn warrior gazes tearfully at a pile of litter. How could the white man have done this to the land? When it comes to public relations, Indians have been considered good for the environment.
Environmentalists and Indians sometimes find themselves on the same side, but from the beginning, their relationship has been uneasy and fraught with ambiguity. Environmentalists like to play on the image of the Indian as protector of mother earth, yet they sometimes get nervous when they see tribes making environmental decisions on their own.
 
The Paternal Trap
 "Environmentalists quite often fall into the trap of a paternalistic or romanticized approach to dealing with Indians," said Kevin Gover, a Pawnee lawyer whose Albuquerque firm represents Indians in environmental disputes. "They say, 'The poor Indians don't understand the impact, so we have to protect them.' I've actually had environmentalists tell me, 'Well, that's not the Indian thing to do.' "
Several years ago Mr. Gover represented the Campo Band of Mission Indians in Southern California, who had received approval from the Environmental Protection Agency to open and manage a commercial landfill -- one of the few ways they could find to make a living from their less than hospitable land. Local environmentalists tried to block it with a bill in the California legislature that would have banned shipment of waste to the site.
"Every government balances economic interests with environmental values," Mr. Gover said. And that includes Indian tribes. But many environmentalists believe the tribes, like all communities, need expert help. Native Americans are among the most unfortunate victims of environmental degradation, and their shaky economic status makes them an easy target for those who see the beautiful but often barren Indian lands as a natural dumping ground for waste that no one else will take.
Though Mr. Viarrial insists he's serious about nuclear waste, many environmentalists think he's just playing a game of high-stakes political poker. For now they are more worried about the Mescalero Apaches in southern New Mexico, who last month voted for a potentially lucrative plan to store the highly radioactive wastes produced by nuclear power plants.
After the vote, environmentalists denounced the Mescalero government for strong-arming the tribe into reversing an earlier referendum rejecting the repository. The tribal government blamed outside agitators for misleading the people into opposing their own best interests. Fred Peso, the vice president of the tribe, said at the time that he considered opposition to the plan racist -- the assumption, he argued, was that only white people were competent to handle radioactive materials.
The tensions between environmentalists and Indians go back at least as far as the late 1960's and early 1970's when the battle over Blue Lake in northern New Mexico became a national cause celebre. Taos Pueblo got the National Forest Service to return the lake, which the tribe considered sacred, but only after fighting off bands of environmentalists. For all their talk about Indians as keepers of the earth, environmentalists thought the Federal government would do a better job of managing the land.
"Some environmentalists have had the feeling that Indians are not good stewards," said Stewart Udall, a former Secretary of the Interior whose law firm represents Navajo uranium miners with respiratory diseases. "I've always been critical of that."
Recently, Mr. Udall noted, tribes have been sending people to school to learn to be foresters. And in the last few years, environmental movements have been springing up within Indian reservations. A group of Navajos has been fighting their tribal government's logging operations in the Chuska mountains. And the opposition to the Mescalero dump was waged not only by outsiders but by a small group of environmentally inclined Mescaleros. In many of these cases, pro-business tribal leaders find the strongest resistance in an alliance of older, more traditional members and younger Indians who were introduced to the environmental movement in college.
"The Indians may have in their religion and culture a reverence for the land," Mr. Udall said. "But then they get into the pressures created by modern society. Unless they are reasonably well educated, they can't deal with them. "Now," he said, "many or them are just as sophisticated as the rest of us."
 
The Anasazi Way
 Throughout history both Indians and their conquerors have found that the struggle for day-to-day survival leaves little room for long-term environmental concerns. Archeological records show that the Anasazi, ancestors to many Southwestern tribes, stayed in one place for no more than a generation. When all the firewood had been burned, the soil depleted and the game eaten or frightened away, they would move to a new place and start the cycle over again. They had no choice. There were no trucks to move timber, no farm animals to fertilize the fields.
"That Indians treasured the earth and would never do anything to hurt it is not an accurate stereotype," said Jonathan Haas, the MacArthur Curator of North American Anthropology at the Field Museum in Chicago. "They were in tune with the earth in that they were totally dependent on it."
"Indians are people," he said. "Just like the rest of us, they do not always make the best decisions on the use of their land."

HEADLINE: THE NATION;
Prime Time Snubs Mr. Clinton for Reruns

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH KOLBERT 

 BODY:
TWO years ago, fresh from a series of appearances on "Larry King Live," President Clinton announced that he had been "liberated" by talk shows. Now that he could go "to the American people directly," he told broadcast journalists, he planned to "stiff" them on news conferences. Last week, the broadcast networks returned the favor.
On Tuesday, when Mr. Clinton gave the fourth prime-time news conference of his career, ostensibly to talk about welfare reform, only CBS interrupted its schedule to cover it. ABC and NBC decided to carry instead a repeat of "Home Improvement" ("Tim charms Jill's friends") and "Frasier" ("Frasier joins Niles and Martin on an ice-fishing trip"). 
 The two recalcitrant networks attributed their decision to the short notice the White House had given, and to a determination they had made that this particular news conference wasn't likely to produce any, well, news. But the fig leaf wasn't remotely big enough. The networks' decision was made on the basis of economics and was clearly revelatory of Mr. Clinton's sagging authority.
"You can look at news coverage of speeches and press conferences as a fairly good index of power in a society," said Michael Beschloss, a presidential historian. "The networks are voting with their feet. They're saying the Presidency is not as powerful as it was, especially under this President."
Presidential news conferences are relatively new, dating from only as far as Woodrow Wilson. (Teddy Roosevelt, for example, used to chat with reporters one-on-one while being shaved by the White House barber.) Wilson's idea to hold a question-and-answer session, according to Martha Joynt Kumar, a professor of political science at Towson State University in Maryland, was less about disseminating information than solving a problem: "He didn't like dealing with reporters," she said.
 
Slip-Sliding Away
 The live, televised news conference originated with John F. Kennedy, and since then every president has held them. Until the end of George Bush's tenure, the broadcast networks preempted programming for the President almost without question. In June 1992, however, all three major networks refused to run one of Mr. Bush's news conferences on the grounds that it seemed more of a campaign event than anything else.
Under Mr. Clinton the networks have become increasingly emboldened. During his two years in office, Mr. Clinton has held only four prime-time news conferences; of those, only two have been carried by all three major networks. In June 1993 when Mr. Clinton held his first prime-time news conference to press his economic plan, only NBC carried it, and only in part. All have been carried on the cable networks CNN and C-SPAN.
Last week's rejection of Mr. Clinton in favor of "Frasier" and "Home Improvement" was all the more telling because it came just 10 days after House Speaker Newt Gingrich's proto-presidential address. The networks treated Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gingrich exactly alike; CBS, which has this season's weakest prime-time schedule, broadcast both, preempting a made-for-television movie on Tuesday, while NBC and ABC broadcast neither. By skipping Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gingrich, NBC and ABC held on to millions of dollars of advertising revenues.
While there is general agreement among political scientists and politicians that the coverage of Mr. Clinton's news conference is an inauspicious development for him, there is some debate over how much responsibility the President bears for his predicament, and how much is due to forces beyond his control.
Michael Deaver, who directed communications for President Reagan, is part of the group that blames Mr. Clinton.
"My own feeling is if the President is leading and has something to say, the media is going to give him all the access he wants," he said. "I really don't think it has anything to do with the office; I think it has to do with the man."
Mr. Deaver was also critical Mr. Clinton's communications staff, saying it had failed to orchestrate the President's appearances in a way that would encourage press coverage. He said that he and his staff used to spend weeks planning a news conference -- conferring with the networks, choosing a propitious time and generally withholding comments from the President to increase the sense of suspense. The point, Mr. Deaver said, was "to build the drama so that people were anticipating it."
 
Always Time for O.J.
 Mr. Beschloss, on the other hand, argued that Mr. Clinton's difficulty breaking into prime time was part of a broader decline in Presidential power.
"The Presidency is constitutionally a very weak office," he said. From the 1930's until the early 1990's, the demands of the Cold War and a national taste for activist government allowed Presidents to transcend that weakness.
But now that the Cold War is over and activist government is in retreat, Mr. Beschloss said, the limitations of the office are reasserting themselves. Mr. Clinton's lack of network appeal, he said, "is just another symptom of the decline of the imperial presidency."
Whatever the underlying reason for their decision not to carry Mr. Clinton last week, Thomas Patterson, a professor of political science at Syracuse University who has written extensively on the press and politics, maintained that the networks should be faulted for it.
"They don't have too much trouble giving us O.J. Simpson," Mr. Patterson said. "And if Robert Shapiro is more important that the President, we're in trouble."
