HEADLINE: New Auction Gems: Common Folks;
Venerable Houses Woo Unstuffy Buyers With Unstuffy Stuff

BYLINE: By PATRICIA LEIGH BROWN 

 BODY:
On most Saturdays, Judith Weisman can be found prospecting at Christie's on Park Avenue, sifting through Fine, Important, Highly Important and Magnificent objets looking for a bargain.
On one chilly afternoon recently, Mrs. Weisman wore gold lame sandals that matched the Empire Style Ormolu Mantel Clock Surmounted by A Classically Clad Maiden Playing A Harp. Mrs. Weisman was surmounted herself by a fluorescent orange hairdo. 
 "You're buying wholesale," Mrs. Weisman explained as she inspected the sumptuous trifles that Donald J. Trump was auctioning from Mar-a-Lago, the Palm Beach estate variously called "Leg-o-Mar" and "Mal-a-Gro" by some in the crowd. "It's the hunt."
For Mrs. Weisman, who calls auctiongoing "the ultimate consumer recreation," venerable auction houses like Christie's and Sotheby's have become rarefied versions of Loehmann's: the ultimate places to find or try to find a deal. And there are an increasing number of new auctiongoers like her, the kind who covet A Set of Fourteen Sevres Style Porcelain Armorial Apple Green-Ground Plates or A Cylindrical Chinese Celadon-Glazed Ceramic Vase With Incised Bamboo Branches Beneath a Collar of Fretwork.
For Christie's and Sotheby's, whose centuries-old heritages are steeped in the stately homes of the British aristocracy, the presence of shoppers like Mrs. Weisman reflects an increasingly aggressive attempt since the 1980's to become user-friendly and broaden their upper-class image by appealing directly to private buyers. They call their new clients "privates" and sometimes, less charitably, "the street people."
"Now we have all walks of life," Phillips Hathaway, a vice president and director of European furniture at Sotheby's, said one recent afternoon as he strolled past a larger-than-life-sized cloisonne peacock with a price tag in its beak. "We kill ourselves to make it all look as accessible as we possibly can."
The look is accessible, all right. There is now a place to buy sandwiches at Sotheby's (albeit $5.00 ones filled with prosciutto and Camembert). And today's auctiongoers sit in front of automated currency conversion display boards that possess all the hauteur of the Keno lounge at Caesars Palace.
The courtship of the commoners -- the people who "might sit in Row 38 rather than first class," in the words of the chairman of Christie's, Christopher J. Burge -- has been intensifying. This weekend, for instance, Christie's East, the warehouse-like venue on East 67th Street for lower-priced Christie's merchandise, is having a benefit block party, complete with flying monkeys, in an attempt to "reach out" to potential buyers in their neighborhood.
The nature of what is being auctioned at the city's two most elite houses has also changed, reflecting the boom of interest in collecting practically anything, even old golf equipment. This spring in New York, you can certainly find the traditional fare, outstanding examples of work by Modigliani, Renoir, Matisse and Vuillard. But you can also buy John Travolta's White Suit from "Saturday Night Fever" (estimate: $30,000 to $50,000), or peruse the new category of Gumpiana (the Park Bench from "Forrest Gump," estimate: $6,000 to $8,000). You can even pick up the Original Tablets from the movie "The Ten Commandments" -- estimated at $30,000 to $50,000 and described by Christie's as "made of richly hewn fiberglass."
On a recent evening at Sotheby's -- where 256 animation cels from "The Lion King" fetched $1.99 million, a record for animation art -- over 200 neophytes paid $25 to learn the rudiments of bidding at auction in the house's latest marketing foray, called "Auction Adventures." First, they heard about "Easy Art" -- lower-priced categories like prints and photographs that are the artistic collecting equivalent of "easy listening." Then, armed with Sotheby's funny money, they attended a fake auction that tried to demystify the intricacies of paddle waving. Paddles bear the auctiongoer's assigned number.
"Get it up in the air so everyone can see it!" coaxed Hugh Hildesley, an auctioneer and the emcee.
The event was hardly plebeian: the room was filled with the kind of manicured crowd one might expect at a place where high cheekbones have always seemed requisite for admission. "What is the overriding emotion that links us all together?" asked David Redden, an auctioneer. He was referring, it turned out, to the "sense of discovery" to be had by bidding in new fields like moon rocks, or, as it is known at Sotheby's, "lunar material."
"It was sort of silly," Diana Howe, a mother of four from Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, said later. "But it was better than doing laundry."
Reaching people like Mrs. Howe, who had never been to an auction before and said she received a flier about "Auction Adventures" with her American Express bill, has become something of a mission, reflecting a broadening of the target audience. "There has been a subtle shift over a generation," said Matthew Weigman, a Sotheby's spokesman. In the 1980's, 70 percent of the people who bid at auction were dealers. Today, he said, 70 percent of the bidders are private buyers.
"The privates" often have more ready cash and are generally willing to pay higher prices than the dealers, who must mark up what they buy. And the quest to lure them reflects the economic realities of the auction business, which has been struggling to come back after the well-publicized slump in the art market of the early 1990's, said Laura Suffield, editor in chief of The Art Newspaper in London. "The simple fact is, times are still hard," she said. "So they are literally casting around the globe, trying to reach people who aren't part of the traditional auction culture."
Between them, Christie's and Sotheby's have recently opened offices in Shanghai, Bombay, India, and Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, an attempt not only to lure new buyers but to find art and objects to be sold. Objects and works of art now travel the globe seeking buyers, the way young upper-class Englishmen once took the Grand Tour. Chris Feiss, a vice president of Alex Brown & Sons of Baltimore, an investment banking firm, said private buyers have traditionally been underrepresented in the United States and "are clearly the fastest-rising segment" of the business.
The preferred privates are people like Bill Gates, the chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, who bought the Leonardo da Vinci "Codex Hammer," a set of illustrated scientific manuscripts, last fall for $30.8 million. But despite every "Codex" or "Portrait of Dr. Gachet," the Van Gogh that was bought in 1990 for $82.5 million by a Japanese businessman, Mr. Feiss pointed out, "the bulk of artworks and objects sold day in and day out are at much lower price levels." Of the 200,000 to 300,000 lots sold by Christie's worldwide every year, Mr. Burge said, approximately half go for under $5,000, and a quarter for under $1,000 -- a fact he called "terrifying."
Although the major profit makers continue to be Impressionist paintings and contemporary art, Diana D. Brooks, president and chief executive of Sotheby's Holdings Inc., said that "the most stable markets in this cyclical business are those that have the broadest participants: jewelry, porcelain, English and American furniture, American folk art, American paintings and collectibles." Although 85 percent of the lots sold at Sotheby's represent only 15 to 20 percent of the company's dollar volume, she said, "there aren't that many Impressionist pictures, so every year you have to sell a lot of other stuff.
"The more traffic you get, the assumption is, the more business you get," Mrs. Brooks said. "Traffic is as important to us as any store in the world."
The glitch has been image, particularly in the United States. "To most people, particularly those not from New York, going into an auction house is a terrifying experience," Mr. Burge said. "Most don't dare walk through the front door."
In London, the traditional center of the trade, where auctioneering has been considered a gentleman's profession for centuries, the housecleaning of the country estates of "gentlemen who had removed to the continent," as bankruptcy was euphemistically called, is a longstanding national ritual. Even among the general public, Mr. Burge points out, there are hundred-year accumulations of stuff. "Everyone in England inherited Granny's Staffordshire sheep and knows they're worth 25 quid," he said. But Americans have taken a dim view of auctioneering, Mr. Burge said, associating it with rough, fast-talking country auctioneers of the tobacco school.
Sotheby's and Christie's also suffered from a reputation of being stuffy and elitist, at best -- a notion, until recently, they did little to dispel.
Thus, the proliferation of "Easy Art" and accessible objects like a Highly Important Pez Dispenser -- a Figural Donald Duck Prototype that sold at Christie's two summers ago for $1,100, the record for a single Pez dispenser. "We've returned to our roots in a curious way," said Mr. Burge. "In 1766, when Christie's was founded, we sold everything, top to bottom, from warming pans and kitchen supplies to livestock."
"We can't ignore popular culture," he added, calling Pez collectors "a small but viable market."
"But let's not confuse it in our minds with high culture," he said. "We want to be accessible. But we don't want Christie's to be the greatest flea market in the world."
Nevertheless, a bit of the flea market pervaded Christie's East last week, where Margaret Hedberg was inspecting five "falling apart Victorian things to put your feet on," as she described a tattered collection of ottomans.
Tomorrow evening, there will be a "twilight talk" by Christie's jazz specialist, Richard Chapman, in preparation for Tuesday's sale of Dizzy Gillespie's trumpet and Jimi Hendrix's Stratocaster guitar.
Such artifacts, particularly those that encompass "Baby Boomerabilia," in the words of Christie's East president, Kathleen Guzman, can hook new young collectors, or so the theory goes. "Today it might be Pez," she said. "Tomorrow Hollywood posters. Fifteen years from now, Lalique glass. Who knows?"
Still, all the user-friendliness in the world cannot fuel the acquisition fever the way celebrity artifacts can, which is why celebrity sales like those of Rudolph Nureyev, Barbra Streisand, Andy Warhol and Elton John have brought record numbers of visitors and "Eyewitness News" teams to once-hallowed doors, further raising the profile of auctions as spectator sport.
But one icon in particular, whose apartment's contents are expected to be auctioned soon, is likely to reduce all others to footnotes.
"Have they announced Jackie yet?" asked Amy Page, editor in chief of Art and Auction magazine, speaking by telephone from Ireland recently. "I know otherwise sane people who have said they'd pay anything for an ashtray Jackie once owned."

HEADLINE: From the Bronx to the Budget Office

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
June E. O'Neill is now one of the nation's most influential economists in no small part because she stopped playing piano.
Ms. O'Neill recently completed her first month as director of the Congressional Budget Office, the aseptic agency that crunches Federal fiscal numbers for the House and the Senate. It is not a job she seemed destined to have. 
 As a child growing up in the Bronx, and as a student at the Bronx High School of Science, she dreamed of being a concert pianist. She studied music at Sarah Lawrence College and then spent four years at Juilliard, the customary last step toward the big stage. But when a divorce left her alone and with a child to support, she asked a college professor she knew for some practical career advice. Postgraduate work, he said.
"He said, 'How about starting out in the economics department?' " Ms. O'Neill recalled. "That seemed like a good idea, and I finally enrolled in the Columbia University department of economics. And I really got hooked on it."
Three decades and a doctorate later, Ms. O'Neill, now 60, holds one of the hottest economic analysis seats in Washington. (By coincidence, the truly flame-broiled seat, the chairmanship of the Federal Reserve Board, belongs to another former Juilliard student, the clarinet-and-sax artist Alan Greenspan.)
Ms. O'Neill comes to the budget office from the City University of New York, where she headed Baruch College's Center for the Study of Business and Government. She was also an adjunct scholar at the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research organization in Washington.
She commands a staff of about 220 analysts and managers, most of them career employees who perform much the same work no matter who is in charge.
Yet when Republicans decided in January to replace the incumbent director, Robert D. Reischauer, with someone to their liking, Democrats fretted openly that the new Congressional majority would politicize a customarily nonpartisan research agency. Ms. O'Neill scoffs at that, saying that to an outsider, any differences between her management of the budget office and that of predecessors will be tiny.
"We're not asked our views on policy, we're asked how much things cost," she said during a recent chat in her Spartan office, in an even more Spartan building at the least impressive foot of Capitol Hill. "I feel obliged to decline if someone asks me my opinion."
Which is not to say that she has no effect on policy. The conclusions of the C.B.O., as the budget office is universally known, carry enormous weight with Congress and the press, largely because the agency has an almost hallowed reputation for presenting the straight economic dope, whatever the political fallout.
"It's a terrific resource for Congress, and even more for the general public," said Gary Burtless, a social sciences scholar at the Brookings Institution. "Whenever they've reported on something that I know something about, they've been outstanding."
Maintaining that reputation means ignoring the prevailing winds. Although Mr. Reischauer was hired and paid by a Democratic-run Congress, only last year his budget office dealt a severe blow to the keystone of President Clinton's legislative program -- an overhaul of the health care system -- by concluding that it would cost the Government far more than the White House had estimated.
Similarly Ms. O'Neill, on the job barely seven weeks, has already nettled the Congress that hired her. Late last month the budget office concluded that welfare legislation backed by House Republicans would neither reduce the rate of out-of-wedlock births nor move as many of the poor into paying jobs as legislators were predicting.
Ms. O'Neill calls herself a free-market theorist, inclined in most cases against government tinkering with matters economic, and her writings tend to confirm it. Asked to describe how closely she swims to mainstream economic thought, she replied drily: "I don't know. I haven't seen any polls."
It is nevertheless clear why she caught the eye of Congress's Republicans. Her monographs on economic issues have appeared not just in the usual scholarly journals but in the conservative general-circulation National Review. In 1990, five years before the debate over affirmative action began to boil, she concluded in one article that the wage gap between young blacks and young whites stemmed mostly from differences in educational achievement and work experience, not from discrimination.
Earlier, she suggested in another monograph that reforms that Michael S. Dukakis had introduced as Governor of Massachusetts had failed to reduce the welfare rolls there.
And as Mr. Reischauer was forecasting last year that the White House's health care proposal would be very costly, Ms. O'Neill and her husband, David O'Neill, also an economist, were predicting that it would raise unemployment. And not by a little bit: their much-quoted research estimated that the plan would cause employers to shed 800,000 to 2.1 million workers, mostly in low-wage positions.
A stung White House, which pegged the loss at closer to 150,000 jobs, described the O'Neill study, sponsored by opponents of the Clinton plan, as "sloppy." But while the O'Neill estimate was higher than others, some independent labor economists said it was on the mark.
If Ms. O'Neill's conclusions often please the political right, associates say they are also rooted in solid research. And in the academic world from which she springs, her reputation is excellent.
Some economists make the world their oyster, but Ms. O'Neill has focused for decades on a single subject: how economic forces shape the labor market. When she attended Columbia, "it was really a new slant on economics -- the study of human capital," she said.
"The notion of applying economics to everything under the sun struck me as particularly intriguing," she said.
Ms. O'Neill was fortunate: her mentor was Gary S. Becker, the pioneering labor economist who first applied economic theory to issues like racial discrimination in the late 1950's. Mr. Becker was awarded a Nobel Prize for his work in 1992.
After a stint as a research associate at the Brookings Institution, Ms. O'Neill obtained her economics doctorate from Columbia in 1970 and moved to the White House to join the Council of Economic Advisers. Not much later, President Richard M. Nixon, horrified by an inflation rate of about 4 percent, imposed wage and price controls on much of the economy.
The experience underscored Ms. O'Neill's belief that generally, the less Federal intervention the better. "It was a regular control system -- they were setting prices, or boundaries of prices," she said, recalling that one day at the White House, "someone was running through the halls, shouting, 'There's no chlorine for the swimming pools!' "
"And there was a shortage," she said, "because they'd set the price too low."
After the Democrats took the White House in 1976, Ms. O'Neill moved to the Congressional Budget Office for three years, heading a unit that analyzed Federal spending on human resources programs, then went on to the Urban Institute, a private Washington research center.
She went to Baruch College in 1987, after a brief stint in the Reagan Administration heading the research unit of the United States Commission on Civil Rights.

HEADLINE: North Korea Threat Seen on Halt of Atom Talks

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

DATELINE: TOKYO, April 22

 BODY:
In what could be a threat to reactivate its nuclear program, North Korea said today that it would take a "necessary decisive measure" following the breakdown of its negotiations with the United States.
But its vaguely worded statement did not say what the action would be and seemed to leave the door open for renewed negotiations with the United States, as the Clinton Administration has proposed. 
 Talks in Berlin over how to carry out the October agreement to curtail North Korea's nuclear program broke down Friday. Under the agreement, North Korea would forgo any nuclear weapons program in exchange for two nuclear power plants and other economic aid.
The United States has insisted that South Korea play a central role in providing the two new reactors since South Korea is expected to pay most of their estimated $4 billion cost. But North Korea refused to accept reactors supplied by South Korea, its archenemy, contending that its models are unsafe.
North Korea had threatened to begin refueling its 5-megawatt nuclear reactor if an agreement with the United States had not been reached by Friday. The Clinton Administration, which believes the reactor is designed to produce plutonium for nuclear weapons, has said it would press for sanctions on North Korea if refueling starts.
The Administration on Friday proposed new talks between the two nations in Geneva, using higher-level diplomats than in Berlin.
North Korea's statement, issued today by the Government-controlled Korea Central News Agency, was open to conflicting interpretations.
After mentioning the proposal for the Geneva talks, the statement, issued in English, said "we will take a necessary decisive measure after getting a detailed report" of the Berlin negotiations and "sounding on the real intention of the U.S. side on the government level." That seemed to suggest that North Korea would consider Washington's proposal.
But the statement continued, "The measure which we will take in the future will be an entirely just and reasonable one for defending our sovereignty."
That wording and the Korean-language version convinced Naewoe Press, a South Korean Government news agency that monitors North Korea, that the North was moving toward confrontation. "The North seems to have decided on their next step," Naewoe Press said, according to the Associated Press in Seoul. "It sounded like it's going to be taking a pretty hard-line measure soon."
Yang Sung Chul, professor of political science at Kyunghee University in Seoul, said he did not think that North Korea would rush to begin refueling because it did not want to "burn its bridges." In a rare move, North Korea has invited thousands of foreigners to an international sports festival in Pyongyang starting next Friday. "I don't think they want to create tension and spoil the festival," Professor Yang said.
Renewed nuclear tensions would also be likely to stop the foreign investment that seems to be on the verge of starting in North Korea. It would also halt its progress toward normalizing relations with the United States and Japan.

HEADLINE: In India, U.S. Diplomacy Is Sounding a Lot Like Economics

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: BOMBAY, India, April 20

 BODY:
Just hours before Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and his entourage landed amid the chaos and crushing poverty of this historic trading center, the power grid for much of the area failed, plunging the homes that have electric power into darkness.
Such failures are fairly common here. But for Mr. Rubin, the fourth American Cabinet member to visit India since the start of the year, the timing was exquisite. Each official came to persuade India's leaders that it was not in their interest to allow a slowing in the broad movement to open their economy. 
 Each of the Americans has gone on to add that one early test would be to assure the completion of an American-built power plant near Bombay, one of the country's first privately constructed plants, which would help to relieve an overburdened, aging power system. But the contract, completed less than two months ago, has already run into trouble from politicians who charge that by letting American companies into a once-sealed market, India is submitting to a new form of imperialism.
In his first trip abroad, a round-the-world tour that took him from Indonesia to Dublin, Mr. Rubin constantly found himself walking a fine line between persuading countries like India to embrace deeper reforms beloved of international investors, and not appearing to be a visiting trade negotiator demanding instant change.
This is the kind of tough balancing act that marks the new era of American foreign policy. Now, the looming issues between the United States and India are not New Delhi's role in the nonaligned movement or its nuclear-weapons program, but the liberalization of its shallow and corrupt financial markets, its reluctance to allow private competition in the insurance business and its slowness in sweeping away choking regulations that date to the British Raj.
To travel with Mr. Rubin, the former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company and a man with an uncanny ability to cut through economic obfuscation, is to witness how much the age of economic diplomacy thrusts the United States into the heart of other nations' domestic economic policies.
In four days here, he dug into the guts of the country's changing economic structure at an extraordinary level of detail.
Meeting with American executives in New Delhi, he debated whether the United States should push India to create a Securities and Exchange Commission. He urged Prime Minister P. V. Narasimha Rao, who has slowed the economic reform movement after a series of political setbacks, to finally allow foreign insurance companies to enter the Indian market, which has been controlled by Government-run firms. He grappled with the question of what to do about ancient taxes levied against every truckful of products that passes a state border -- both slowing the process of moving goods and increasing their cost.
"This is a long-term effort," Mr. Rubin said midway through his trip. "We have to help build a successful society in order to build markets for American goods 10 or 15 years down the line. But we also have to be extremely respectful of what they have done, and make it clear we're certainly not meddling."
Mr. Rubin repeatedly edited his speeches to remove wording that seemed to lecture India about the need for change, and when answering questions often offered what he called "a perspective on what the markets will require."
If that was the message, then it often did not translate. News accounts in Indian newspapers of Mr. Rubin's visit frequently sounded the theme of American pressure, and suggested that the demands of "the market" were really the demands of the United States.
Just as Mr. Rubin arrived here, the opposition parties blocked approval of legislation in Parliament that would strengthen patent and copyright protection as required under a new world trade agreement; it was a provision Washington had pressed for vigorously. But the reality is that it would help put out of business companies here that copy American software or make knockoffs of Kellogg's corn flakes. Opponents of Mr. Rao have seized on it as evidence that he is bowing to the United States.
When Mr. Rubin announced midway through his trip that he would have postponed his visit if he had known that Iran's President, Hashemi Rafsanjani, would be there at the same time on a state visit, the Treasury Secretary was described in the Indian press as "displaying a petulance beyond his brief."
"Does the U.S. consider India as a banana republic?" an Indian paper, The Hindustan Times, asked. It suggested that even though the United States is by far India's largest trading partner and source of investment, New Delhi should keep its distance, rather than follow "America's shifting allergies and preferences, which make yesterday's friends today's foes, and vice-versa."
The incident underscored the mixed emotions that the new, economically driven foreign policy has evoked. On the one hand, Indian officials say they welcome the sudden high-level attention from Washington, including two visits by Energy Secretary Hazel R. O'Leary, focusing on the country's tremendous needs for electric power, and one by Commerce Secretary Ronald H. Brown, who traveled with a small army of chief executives and used the moment to seal about $6 billion in deals. But now the pressure has come to seem a bit overwhelming.
"If the impression develops, and it has, that America is delving deeply into the details of India's economic policy, it will have a backlash," said S. L. Rao, director general of the National Council for Applied Economic Research in New Delhi. "There has not been enough effort to show that these kinds of linkages solve the problem of health or education or poverty, and that makes them easy political targets."
Mr. Rubin made that effort repeatedly, even spending a day at a World Bank site in a remote mountain area where deeply impoverished villagers are being taught how to work the land so that it retains more monsoon rainfall, increasing the harvest. But in a country only beginning to learn about international capital markets, it is far harder to make the case that reforming the workings of the Bombay stock exchange will soon help the poor.
Even when the benefit seems obvious -- such as the power plant in Maharshita State near Bombay under construction by the Enron Corporation, Bechtel and General Electric -- political problems abound. Mr. Rao's Congress Party lost the state election last month, and in a battle that seems to have more to do with politics than electric power, the new state government has vowed to review the awarding of the contract to the American companies.
India is hardly the only country, of course, where the United States has thrust itself into the innermost plumbing of the domestic economy. It has done so for years in Japan, seeking to sweep away hidden trade barriers. In recent months it has mandated broad, highly specific rules for Mexico -- down to what its trade balances should look like and what its interest-rate policy should be -- as the price that country must pay for a $20 billion bailout.
But both those cases involve large trading partners, in which the United States holds a tremendous economic stake. India, in comparison, is tiny, attracting a scant $1.6 billion of American investment in 1992 and 1993, the last years for which there are reliable figures. Over the same period, American companies invested seven times more in China, and six times more in Thailand, a country of only 20 million, compared with 900 million in India.
Mr. Rubin and other American officials say they are being motivated by the experience in China, where the United States waited too long, let too many competitors enter the market first, and then engaged too late in long battles with the Chinese to end market practices that discriminated against foreign companies.

HEADLINE: Earth Day at 25: Promoting a Cleaner Environment and a More Effective Bureaucracy

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 22

 BODY:
Celebrating a quarter-century of modern environmentalism, hundreds of volunteers performed an Earth Day ritual along the Anacostia River today, hauling debris out of one of the nation's most poisoned waterways.
The crowd had gathered at the bowers of the National Arboretum to enjoy a sunny day on the tainted river that runs across the nation's capital, joining the much cleaner Potomac not far from the waterfront towers of the Environmental Protection Agency. 
 "I have always maintained that if E.P.A. and the Corps of Engineers cannot restore this river, where on the planet can they do it?" said Robert E. Boone, the head of the Anacostia Watershed Society, a local voluntary group.
On a day when environmentalists all over the country were torn between celebrating the undeniable achievements of the last 25 years and fretting over the demise of their political clout when they see much left to be done, they could at least find in organizations like the small Anacostia River group a continuing source of strength. Just as all politics is local, environmentalism is, too.
This drawing power at the grass roots could prove increasingly important as powerful business groups vie with large national conservation groups to influence public opinion and win lawmakers' loyalty at a time when the basic tenets of environmental laws are being reconsidered. The eventual winner may be the side that argues most persuasively at the local level.
For just this reason, Greenpeace, one of the more militant of the large groups, deliberately avoided the crowded gala on Washington's grassy downtown mall celebrating the 25th Earth Day. Instead, it sent canoes and speedboats to the smaller Anacostia River event, just as it joined small neighborhood activities across the country, said Rick Hind, a spokesman for the group. "Our theme around the country is to honor and promote small local efforts," he said.
The same attitude is showing up in the Government's environmental bureaucracy, which is trying to capture some of the energy that exists in the Anacostia Watershed Society and its cousins all over the country.
Increasingly, Federal officials say they believe that local actions like trying to restore the Anacostia may be more effective than new national programs.
At the Environmental Protection Agency, for example, senior managers have been trying to come up with a style of management that is rooted in places, not in programs or permits or even politics.
In this new way of thinking, the agency's work would be driven by the environmental needs of communities and ecosystems. Decisions would be based on detailed understanding of the economic and social as well as ecological concerns of specific places.
So far, the bureaucrats can't seem to decide whether to call it "place-driven" or "community-based" protection.
"I don't think it is just a new buzzword," said Dana Minerva, a water quality official at the agency. "It is an important way of changing how we do our thing. Of course, E.P.A.'s role as a national standards-setter is very important, and the people who do the work on how many parts per billion of a chemical cause cancer is very important. But the work that needs to be done in communities is the most satisfying."
In true bureaucratic style, the agency's first step was to publish a 357-page "Phase 1 Inventory of Current E.P.A. Efforts to Protect Ecosystems," a kind of guide to hundreds of local activities like those along the Anacostia.
In the case of the Anacostia, the agency's involvement has come slowly, in part because the river runs through poor urban neighborhoods without even a vote in Congress. Federal aid has only trickled in. But the Clinton Administration considers the river a model for how to manage the problems of polluted watersheds, and a place to redress environmental racism, the term used to describe what some say is the tendency to ignore serious pollution in poor areas with high minority populations.
All the good intentions of laws and bureaucracies have not yet made the Anacostia River safe for fish or swimmers.
The raw sewage of Washington still spills into the stream when heavy rains overwhelm the treatment plant, and pollutants from runoff from poor city neighborhoods and wealthier suburbs settle in the riverbed. In a survey last year, the Smithsonian Institution found that 15 of 20 catfish netted in the stream had cancerous livers. In clean water, no catfish is likely to have liver cancer.
But none of that discouraged the youthful crowd that took to the water today, arriving in school buses and in station wagons and on bicycles in a reaffirmation of that chestnut of environmental sloganeering, the commandment to think globally and act locally.
Their activities were typical of those going on in hundreds of towns and cities across the country -- planting trees, sprucing up parks, teaching about recycling -- as grass-roots organizations celebrated Earth Day.
Dozens of organizations sought to make the 25th Earth Day a time to increase political pressure on Washington not to roll back Federal environmental regulations. On campuses, students circulated petitions and urged one other to call and write their representatives in Congress.
In big cities, there were outdoor concerts and rallies likely to draw hundreds of thousands of people, and the speeches dripped with denunciations of the Republican Contract With America and what it would do to environmental laws.
But along the Anacostia River, the children, the students and even many of the adults who came to clean up did not seem terribly concerned about the changes being contemplated in Congress, including proposed changes to the Clean Water Act that many conservationists say would only slow down the cleanup of the Anacostia.
Even those who were well informed seemed to be saying they intended to achieve a cleaner environment regardless of what happened on Capitol Hill.
"Things we expected Government to do, Government can no longer do, so it falls on people to act as stewards of the areas that they themselves have dominion over," said Ulysses Garner, who brought a group of children to the scene.
One girl, 10-year-old Kathleen Crosby of Chelham, Md., said she believed the Government was doing its part and she was doing hers. "They have spent some money, so we thank them by helping to clean up the environment, to pay them back," she said.

HEADLINE: India Presses U.S. to Pass Biotic Treaty

BYLINE: By SANJOY HAZARIKA 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, April 22

 BODY:
India says it will seek to block American access to medicinal plants and other biological material from the third world unless the United States ratifies the international Biodiversity Convention by this summer.
The material -- herbs, medicinal plants, leaves, shrubs, roots, seeds and flowers -- is used in the drug, pharmaceutical and cosmetic industries, which are dominated by American and European companies. 
 "We cannot wait forever, and we do not want to be pushed into any corner," Environment Minister Kamal Nath said in making the announcement on Thursday. "But if the ratification does not take place in the next three months, then obviously we must prevent other countries from taking advantage of the benefits accruing from our genetic material."
The United States is the only major developed nation that has not ratified the treaty. It has been signed by 171 nations and ratified by 120. The figure includes the European Union as a unit, though, as well as each of its member countries.
Last year, the ratification process was killed in the Senate, largely because of Republican opposition, and the chances of passage are even slimmer now that Republicans control Congress.
In an interview, Mr. Nath said international drug and pharmaceutical corporations generated $30 billion in business every year on the basis of biological material imported from poor countries.
"The mega-biodiverse countries of Latin America, South and Southeast Asia are waiting for India to take the lead," Mr. Nath said. "If we do not have progress this summer then we will meet to map out a joint strategy on the transfer of genetic material."
The central purpose of the biodiversity treaty is to help prevent the extinction of flora and fauna around the world. But this has been overshadowed by contention over the use of developing countries' biotic resources by American companies and arrangements for transferring the fruits of the resulting research back to the third world.
The Indian position -- which has support from major countries with diverse biological resources like Brazil, Indonesia and Malaysia -- was first made public Tuesday after Mr. Nath and Timothy E. Wirth, the American Under Secretary of State for Global Affairs, signed an agreement for closer cooperation between the two countries on scientific and technological research.
Mr. Wirth pointed out at the time that although the Bush Administration had declined to sign the Biodiversity Convention at the 1992 Earth Summit in Rio de Janeiro, the Clinton Administration had done so soon after assuming office.
"The President proposes, but Congress disposes," Mr. Wirth said, adding that the Administration would resume the process and push strongly for swift ratification.
He later acknowledged the difficulties in moving ahead in a Republican-dominated Congress.
Western diplomats and Indian commentators have also said the problem of ratification in Washington was similar to the Indian Government's difficulties in getting Parliament to clear a crucial clause in the General Agreement on Trade and Tariffs that relates to intellectual property rights.
India had long resisted the clause, while American electronics, drug and pharmaceutical manufacturers have pressed for it, accusing Indian companies of patent piracy.
India finally agreed to fall into line with American policy on the issue after opening its economy to foreign investment. The change was denounced by opposition groups.
The Government is in a minority in the upper house of Parliament, and the opposition has declared that it will not allow the process to go through, thus stalling ratification.
"This is not a trade-off for the other side's ratifying the Biodiversity Convention, but clearly this is not a one-way street" said a senior Indian official.

HEADLINE: In School Bus Dispute, Focus Shifts From the Drivers to the Companies

BYLINE: By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

 BODY:
In pressuring for savings in the $316 million the city spends each year on school bus service, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and his aides had harsh words for bus company owners, most of whom have been able to renew their contracts with the Board of Education without fear of competition since 1979.
The Mayor described the bus companies as profiteers, combining brinkmanship with the threat of competition, as he did in showdowns last year with Legal Aid lawyers and school custodians. His chief labor official, Randy L. Levine, accused the operators of "sucking the blood out of the Board of Education." 
 But company owners protest that theirs is not a lucrative business. They contend that the same system that has guaranteed them continued work has also guaranteed shrinking profits. Yet they also warn that the more open competition proposed by the Mayor may force some companies out of business and leave workers unemployed, while paradoxically failing to save the city money.
The Mayor, who had earlier focused his attacks on the bus workers' unions, calling for an end to lifetime job security for drivers, toned down his attacks last week, after bus drivers agreed to call off a strike planned for tomorrow, when the spring recess ends.
Labor negotiations are continuing over the weekend, and while the Mayor appears to have softened his stance against the job security provision, he seems intent on bringing competitive bidding to the busing operation.
Several company owners say that their profit margins are thin, and that the city could lose more than it gains unless there are significant wage concessions by the union. Their arguments have largely been supported by Board of Education officials and by a report by KPMG Peat Marwick, consultants hired by the board to look for savings in the busing operation.
"I think the profits being earned are fairly slim," said Barry F. Sullivan, the board's chief operations officer and a former banker. "We can't be sure how much of a savings we'll get, but we've got to try everything to save money in this climate."
Several company owners, as well as Peat Marwick, point to the experience of Varsity Transit, which once held 80 percent of the city school bus contracts, to illustrate the problems with competitive bidding.
In 1979, to save money, city and school officials decided to divide Varsity's routes into more than 100 separate contracts and ask for competitive bids. Bus drivers, escorts and mechanics struck because they stood to lose jobs. After three months of disruption, the city settled by agreeing to require that companies taking over routes hire existing workers without pay cuts.
This effectively precluded cheaper competitors from emerging, so except for a few times since then, the Board of Education has given companies three-year extensions, rather than seek bids.
Though it lost much of its business in 1979, Varsity remained the largest bus company, with more than 600 routes. But in 1986, it refused to renew 453 contracts, which were put to competitive bidding.
"We gave them up because we were losing money," Burton Cooper, Varsity's president, said in an interview last week.
Annual increases in the amount the Board of Education paid the bus companies were limited to the consumer price index, the increase in the carrier's labor costs, or a fixed figure of 4 to 7 percent, whichever of the three was least.
With those controls, Mr. Cooper said, "It's better to take your chances with competition and maybe not get the business than to be guaranteed a slow but steady disaster."
Varsity bid on its former contracts, but lost most of them. The Board of Education ended up paying 12 percent more, or $17 million over five years, than it would have under a contract extension. "They paid a high price for competition," Mr. Cooper said.
The city's formula for payments to bus companies squeezes owners, said Dominic F. Gatto Jr., president of Atlantic Express, the city's largest school-bus franchise holder with about $60 million a year in city business.
"If the labor costs go up faster than the cost of living, we get the cost of living and our profits drop," he said. "If the cost of living goes up faster than our labor costs, we get our labor costs and again, our profits drop. It's a formula for falling farther behind every year."
Mr. Gatto said his company's yearly profits were 3 to 4 percent, or between $1.8 million and $2.4 million. "If we have to compete, we'll compete," he said. "But at the end of the day, I don't think they can save any money."
Peat Marwick concluded that even if contracts are put out to bid and job security provisions are eliminated, "there is the strong potential that prices will ultimately be as high or substantially higher than current prices."
Most of the bus companies are privately held and family owned, and most started small, when Varsity controlled all but the margins of the market. Mr. Gatto, a disabled Vietnam veteran, said he took a job as a driver for a small, 21-van fleet in 1972 because he needed work that would allow him to stay off his feet.
Two years later, he bought the company with borrowed money. Over two decades, through bidding on contracts as they became available and buying small competitors, he built a 750-route company, with two subsidiaries, Staten Island Bus Company and Amboy Bus Company.
Mr. Gatto's operation resembles others in New York in that it encompasses subsidiaries. While the Board of Education lists 78 separate companies with busing contracts, the market is still concentrated among a handful of firms. When companies with overlapping or identical ownership and shared garages and offices are considered as one, there are actually fewer than 40 separate concerns.
Eight companies or groups of related companies, including Atlantic, dominate the market, with 73.5 percent of the 3,805 routes and well over $200 million a year in city business.
In 1989 and 1990, law enforcement officials said that several of the bus companies had ties to organized crime. Board of Education officials say that as a result, 10 companies and several individuals were banned from the business, and law enforcement officials say that mob influence has declined.
The contracts at issue in the current negotiations, expiring June 30, are for 620 routes but are held by five of the eight major companies. Any concessions they make are expected to set the pattern for the future.
The companies have two large incentives to try to retain their city business. One is the capital they have invested, mostly in buses, maintenance equipment and garages. Some of the companies have borrowed heavily for this; Mr. Gatto said his debt totaled a relatively heavy $51 million, with annual revenues that total, for all operations, about $100 million.
Moreover, the owners face stiff immediate liabilities for pension plans if they lose their contracts. Under state law, bus companies are permitted to set aside only a fraction of the pension benefits earned by their employees, but a company that loses its contracts becomes immediately liable for the entire amount. For larger companies, that figure would be several million dollars.
Because of these factors, owners warn, many carriers would be bankrupted by a significant loss of business.

HEADLINE: A Lull in Battle Over the Pinelands, as All Wait for Whitman to Take Sides

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

DATELINE: CHATSWORTH, N.J. April 16

 BODY:
This is the New Jersey Pinelands, a million acres of scrub pine and sand roads in the heart of the most densely populated state in the nation, a place so sparsely inhabited that a fire earlier this month burned an area larger than Manhattan without touching a single house.
To conservationists, the fact that a fire of such magnitude caused no damage to people or property testifies to the success of development controls in the Pinelands, which are sometimes popularly called the Pine Barrens. And conservationists are asking, increasingly insistently, whether environmental regulations that took decades to put in place, here and across the state, will survive the administration of Gov. Christine Todd Whitman as easily as the piney woods have bounced back from the spring fire season. 
 Until now, Mrs. Whitman's environmental record has been more form than substance. Environmentalists complain about her promises to make it easier for industry to obtain permits from the Department of Environmental Protection, for example, but no one has yet cited a case of a polluter who got away with it. They criticize her cuts in the department's workweek, but favor her plan to wean the department from dependence on fees and fines from regulated industries.
Mrs. Whitman has been outspoken in her support of the State Plan, an anti-sprawl blueprint to encourage growth in already built-up areas. On the other hand, she has proposed uniform statewide rules for new construction -- rules that environmentalists fear would undermine more stringent local ones.
The equivocal reaction to the Governor in the green movement was neatly illustrated last month, when a coalition of environmental and conservation groups called a news conference promising to issue a report card on her first year in office. Reporters who came hoping for fireworks went away disappointed when all of the Governor's grades turned out to be incompletes.
Members of the groups that called the news conference explained that they were trying to alert the public to issues facing the Governor, not pass judgment on her policies. Indeed, some of them acknowledged that in certain ways Mrs. Whitman has made a good start.
"I think Governor Whitman has said a lot of things that are encouraging to environmentalists," said Sally Dudley, head of the Association of New Jersey Environmnental Commissions, one of the groups participating in the conference. But then she cited what she found discouraging: the Governor's budget cuts and proposed statewide construction rules.
Environmentalists are especially vigilant when it comes to the board that regulates the Pinelands, where large-scale development is restricted to the perimeter of the 1,700-square-mile preserve and where even the use of private property is tightly controlled.
The Pinelands Commission came into being in the late 1970's. Its 15-member board has seven gubernatorial appointees, seven from counties touched by the preservation district, and one appointed by the United States Secretary of the Interior. They serve three-year terms and can be reappointed indefinitely.
In the past, governors' appointees have tended to advocate controls, and have held sway over the more development-minded county appointees. As a result, thousands of privately held acres in the no-growth area have been rendered all but worthless because they cannot be significantly developed. Many owners have ended up giving their land to conservation groups in exchange for tax breaks.
Governor Whitman says she believes that there is room for diversity of opinion on the board. Her director of communications, Carl Golden, suggested as much when he said her approach would be to provide it with "balance."
But to Sally Price, head of the Pinelands Preservation Alliance, there is nothing to balance. "The charter says to preserve the values of the Pinelands," she said recently, "so I don't know where balance comes into that. I question if you can have votes that represent group interests and still carry out the charter to preserve, protect, and enhance. The word 'enhance' we never get to -- we barely protect."
Two of Mrs. Whitman's three appointees so far have tilted distinctly toward the development side, Ms. Price said. Daniel Galetta of Hammonton, an appraiser and engineer, was a candidate backed by farm interests, and Jay Edward Mounier of Franklinville is a farmer.
Farmers generally support the protection of open space afforded by the Pinelands rules, but they also in some cases favor development rights because development increases property values.
The third Whitman appointee, Daniel Kelleher of Medford, a water utility president, is regarded as a supporter of existing Pinelands rules.
Gov. Brendan T. Byrne's seven original appointees in the late 70's were "tree-hugging environmentalists," Ms. Price said, adding that today only one of them, Candace McKee Ashmun, a physicist, remains on the board.
Steven Lee, a board member who is a third-generation cranberry farmer in Chatsworth, argues for balance between property rights and preservation.
"I agree that conservation is important," Mr. Lee said, noting that his family farms only a fraction of its property, having kept more than a thousand acres in woodland. "But I don't agree that conservation is so important that it overrides the economic rights of inhabitants."
Mr. Lee, who was appointed by Gov. Thomas H. Kean in the mid-80's, approves of Governor Whitman's appointments to the board. He has upset preservationists by pushing the commission to respond more quickly to requests for development permits, and to delegate the granting of permits for driveways and other minor construction to local municipal authorities.
"The commission doesn't have to be involved in every single regulatory decision," he said.
While Ms. Price and others worry that speeding up the permit process may cut back on protection, Ida Anderson thinks things cannot change fast enough. Ms. Anderson, a Shamong Township businesswoman, heads an 800-member Pinelands property owners group, Aspire.
"If they want to have a Pinelands Commission," Ms. Anderson said, "it should be advisory only. The one we have is driving us off our land."
John Battistini, Mayor of Estell Manor in the heart of the no-growth area, agrees.
"When the Pinelands came in," he said, "we didn't think it would affect us." Instead, in the last five years, land with an assessed value of $11 million has been given to the town or to nonprofit, untaxed conservation groups, as owners discovered it was undevelopable and therefore unsellable.
"Our taxes are going up and people are leaving," Mayor Battistini said. "We're literally being preserved to death."

HEADLINE: Slaying Inquiry in Wales Tests DNA of 150 People

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: CARDIFF, Wales, April 18

 BODY:
Having had an occasional run-in with the law over his 30-odd years, John Jones, a resident of the St. Mellons housing project in northeast Cardiff, is not a big fan of the police.
But he went along when the police came knocking on his door recently, saying they would like a wee bit of his blood so as to analyze his DNA. Not that he was suspected of anything, mind you, but they wanted to rule him out in their investigation into the rape and murder of a 15-year-old girl. 
 "I wasn't arrested or anything," Mr. Jones said as he quaffed a midday pint of beer in the local pub. "I went in of my own accord. It was the right thing to do."
Saying they did not even consider the question of whether their strategy might raise concerns about coercion or civil liberties, the police have so far made the same request of 150 men and teen-agers in St. Mellons, some as young as 14. The police are using the blood samples to try to find a match to the DNA in the semen left behind in the body of the victim, a local girl named Claire Denise Hood. She was killed, apparently by strangulation, in the woods behind a shopping center as she played hookey from school.
The police have combed the woods for clues, and have gone door to door interviewing thousands of residents, but they have found no good clues to the identity of the girl's killer. Detective Superintendent Colin Jones of the South Wales Police, who is heading the St. Mellons investigation, said the fact that no one noticed any strangers entering or leaving the woods the day of the attack suggests that the killer was probably from the neighborhood.
If they do not turn up a genetic match from among those tested so far, the police said, they will eventually seek blood samples from every male over age 13 in the neighborhood -- more than 2,000 of them. It takes the police about two weeks to get the results back from the lab, and the first results are dribbling in now, showing no matches so far.
The use of DNA samples to try to establish guilt in criminal investigations in the United States and elsewhere is increasingly common, if still hotly debated on scientific and civil liberties grounds. But as the St. Mellons case suggests, no nation has been as aggressive in employing genetic "fingerprinting" as Britain.
Earlier this month, the British Government announced that it was starting the world's first DNA database of criminals, a computerized list that will eventually contain the genetic identification of 5 million Britons who have been convicted of serious crimes. Under new criminal justice laws that took effect this month, the police were also given the right to take hair roots, mouth swabs or other "non-intimate" samples for DNA testing from anyone they arrest on suspicion of a crime that carries a potential jail sentence, even if the suspect objects.
"This is a vital area in the fight against crime where Britain is leading the world," said Michael Howard, Britain's Home Secretary, who oversees law enforcement. "It's the biggest breakthrough since fingerprints."
Britain has tried semi-voluntary mass screenings like the one in St. Mellons before, with mixed results. Four years ago, the South Wales Police undertook the biggest effort to date when they screened 5,000 men in an unsuccessful attempt to find the killer of a 27-year-old woman.
Superintendent Jones said the police were not coercing anyone into giving a blood sample.
But he acknowledged that the screening, by forcing potential suspects to decide whether to cooperate, is an effective way of flushing out anyone who might have something to hide. And with more than three months having passed since the girl was killed, the police appear to have few other hopes for generating a break in the case.
The superintendent said "there is no disguising the fact that the individual would become of interest to us" if he failed to cooperate in the testing. Should a suspect be arrested, the DNA sample could be taken involuntarily under the new law.
So far, no one in St. Mellons has refused to be be "blooded," as the police say in referring to the procedure. A hematologist takes the samples at the local police station by drawing a vial of blood through a syringe.
"There are pockets of people who probably wouldn't give us the time of day in a less serious case who are happy to help us here," Superintendent Jones said. "I would like to think there is a genuine desire on their part to help us catch the killer of Claire Hood."
There have been few if any objections to the police tactics in the St. Mellons case, which is perhaps not surprising in a country where the political mood has swung distinctly toward tougher law enforcement. Britain has little tradition of civil liberties activism in the American mold.
Indeed, many people seem to favor the DNA sweep in St. Mellons, whose tidy townhouses and almost rural setting belie its relatively high rates of crime and unemployment. In an attempt to build support for the testing, the police held a news conference this month at which Steve Robinson -- the world featherweight boxing champion and the neighborhood's most famous resident -- urged local men "who have nothing to fear" to come forward to give a blood sample.
"The feeling around here is the sooner this guy is caught the better," said Malcolm Williams, a 45-year-old St. Mellons resident who has not yet been asked for a blood sample. "There are people who say we shouldn't have go through this testing. I think that's rather selfish myself. People should be suspect until proven innocent."
Leighton Smith, a 27-year-old resident who said he was scheduled for a test in a few days, said trying to match the DNA by urging local men to cooperate in the process would probably be the only way to solve the crime.
"Around here this kind of crime doesn't happen often," Mr. Smith said. "When it does, everyone helps out."
Among those being tested are the victim's male friends from school and other teen-agers in the area. So far, Superintendent Jones said, neither the youths nor their parents have objected to taking part in the screening.
While he declined to discuss his strategy in depth, local residents said it was clear that he was concentrating first on men with criminal records and on men and boys who either live close to the woods where the body was found or who were known to spend a good deal of time in the woods.
As a crime-fighting technique, mass DNA screenings do not come cheap. Superintendent Jones said it cost $72 to test each blood sample, or $144,000 if he eventually tests 2,000 men. He said that the South Wales police force had budget problems, but that he had received approval to spend about that amount if necessary.
"I'd still like to think we can solve this case through traditional police methods and good detective work," said the superintendent, who has a team of 50 officers working to find the killer. "But I'm quite prepared for the lab to call and say sample number whatever is the person responsible for the attack on Claire."

HEADLINE: April 16-22: A Great Divide;
The United States is the New Bastion of Inequality

BYLINE: By SARAH BOXER 

 BODY:
Of all the industrialized Western nations, not one has as great a gulf between rich and poor as the United States. While Congress argues about who must scrimp and who can save, new studies, based on figures from the 1980's, show that 40 percent of the nation's wealth is concentrated in only 1 percent of American households. Even Britain, a nation with a history of severe economic stratification, doesn't come close; the richest 1 percent of families there hold 18 percent of the country's wealth.
The United States is not only the most unequal nation in the West, but it is also "growing more unequal faster than the other industrialized countries," said Edward N. Wolff, an economics professor at New York University. One hundred percent of the increased wealth during the 1980's went to the top 20 percent of American families. Why? Possible explanations include: falling wages for unskilled labor, the decline of trade unions, low minimum wages and low tax rates on the wealthy. 
 Not everyone is alarmed by the trend. Murray L. Weidenbaum, a professor of economics at Washington University in St. Louis and the chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers under President Ronald Reagan, said the gap may look wider than it is because food stamps and Medicaid were not counted as part of the wealth of the poor. SARAH BOXER

HEADLINE: For the Weary, a Day for Feeling Good About a Battered Planet

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
The sun shone, the breeze was soft and it was an altogether swell day to feel good about this battered old planet. So thousands of New Yorkers put on smiles and T-shirts to celebrate the 25th Earth Day with a parade up the Avenue of the Americas.
In most places, the sidewalks were not much more crowded than they would be on a weekday lunch hour. But the onlookers cheered enthusiastically for a succession of marchers dressed as garbage cans, smokestacks spewing cotton and endangered tropical bird species. 
 Other New Yorkers observed ecological themes -- and enjoyed a stunningly beautiful spring morning -- closer to home, cleaning parks and doing other environmental chores.
At the parade, there were marchers carrying tombstones with the names of endangered species and a styrofoam polar bear skeleton. Chinese lion dancers were covered with recyclable cans. A group of 20 unidentifiable forms slunk along under a menacing black tarp, imitating an oil spill. Maniacs with chainsaws, dollar bills in their eyes, chased terrified trees.
The marchers were interspersed with bands playing music ranging from samba to steel drums to plumbers' plastic pipes.
Because police insisted that the parade start promptly at 11 A.M., there was no time for a series of planned opening speeches. But there was time to read parts of a proclamation from Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who declared that the air, the harbor and the city's drinking water have all greatly improved since the first Earth Day in 1970.
"Let us dedicate ourselves to make New York City by the year 2000 the best and cleanest city it can be," the proclamation said.
But others muttered to one another about the threat to environmental laws passed after the first Earth Day, as some politicians in Washington have questioned their economic cost. A man wearing a Newt Gingrich mask and wielding a pair of giant shears threatened to lop off the head of a fleeing daisy.
"If we don't take care of the earth, it won't take care of us," said Rick Carrier, a Manhattan writer wearing his World War II Army uniform for the occasion. "People do not have a focus."
Robert Marvin, an insurance salesman in Westchester County, was so bedraped with plastic bottles that he appeared to have no head. "I just decided it was time to get off my behind and do something," he said.
One group of demonstrators were dressed in black, carrying signs with the names of such major corporations as Sony and Exxon. "We're the world corporations," said Rob Youngblood, a 16-year-old from the Bronx. "We destroy the environment."
A group of women paraded about in garbage containers -- half of them metal and overflowing with discarded metal, plastic and paper, the other half blue plastic ones full of properly sorted recyclables. One in a metal can, Noelle Gracy, a graduate student in neuroscience at Cornell Medical Center, said, "We're the leftovers, the trash of the trash."
A colleague also clad in metal, Faith Schwartz, a community development worker, added lightly, "The leftovers of the left."
The mood was as light as the ubiquitous bottles of spring water. A group of demonstrators wore long coats made of growing grass. One of grass patches said that they were the ecologically responsible replacement for fur. Another, laughing, suggested that dogs could pose a bit of a problem.
The designer of the grass outfits is an artist who said he had adopted the name Gene Pool to make people think. "These coats are the only chance to be completely enclosed in a living thing beside the womb," he said.
Some of the more heartfelt celebrations were far removed from the parade. In Central Park, more than 70 volunteers showed up at Turtle Pond to clean the leaves and tidy up the surrounding area. "It brings an element of nature to a concrete world," said one volunteer, Jess Sogelman.
In Manhattan Valley, at La Perla Garden on 105th Street, the aroma of fresh flowers wiped away memories of the smells of urine and marijuana nearby. Sue Schmidt surveyed the garden she created three years ago between two brick buildings in a drug-plagued neighborhood.
"We celebrate Earth Day through work," she said, as she waited for friends to arrive to help repair a retaining wall.
"We celebrate by creating something beautiful and enjoying it," she said. "Knowing what this used to be -- a dumping ground -- and seeing a beautiful garden today makes me optimistic that this can be done everywhere. There's no reason New York City can't have these pockets of hope."

HEADLINE: Editorial Notebook;
Wine, Roses, Then and Now

BYLINE: By STEVEN R. WEISMAN 

 BODY:
When a couple hundred veterans of New York City's last fiscal crisis gathered last week to honor former Gov. Hugh Carey, they were eager to trade war stories about the heroic effort to keep the city out of bankruptcy. There were not many emissaries from Mayor Rudolph Giuliani and Gov. George Pataki, perhaps because they felt they had little to learn from such ancient history. But the lessons for today were clear.
First was the need for cooperation and shared sacrifice across ideological and even class lines. For example, there was Mr. Carey, the combative Democrat from Brooklyn, embracing Warren Anderson, a Republican from Binghamton, N.Y., who as the State Senate majority leader was his indispensable partner for saving the city. There were Victor Gotbaum, then the city's most powerful labor leader, and Walter Wriston, then chairman of Citicorp, the city's most powerful bank, another set of onetime enemies who found common purpose in avoiding municipal bankruptcy. 
 Another critical part of the bailout that many people forget was cited by Peter Goldmark, now president of the Rockefeller Foundation but then state budget director, who noted that a temporary tax increase helped serve as a bridge to solvency. Only after the state and city met their budget goals were taxes cut again. Today such a step would be unthinkable, with both Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Pataki compounding already grievous budget cuts by pushing for bigger tax cuts. Their approach is not simply fiscally unsound; it undermines the essential idea that everyone, even taxpayers, should be prepared to forgo something to get out of the current crisis.
The fiscal crisis of 1975 was more dire and dramatic than anything the Mayor and Governor face today. Each month, the city had to scramble to borrow huge sums to meet payments falling due and avoid Chapter 11. But those monthly crises at least focused the minds of New Yorkers in a way that the problems of today do not.
Once the financing needs of the city were met with help from Albany and Washington, and by declaring a moratorium on paying off debt that was later thrown out in court, the city bounced back because of underlying strengths that are also not available at present.
Back then, the city and state were heading into an economic recovery that swelled tax revenues and forestalled even deeper cuts. A Democratic governor and (after 1976) a Democratic President channeled aid to the city. Today, no such recovery is in sight, and neither is any help from Albany or Washington.
For next year, the city has a $3 billion budget deficit, and the state's deficit after Mr. Pataki's proposed tax cut is projected to be $5 billion. To the veterans of 1975 like Felix Rohatyn, architect and later chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation, cuts of that size cannot possibly be carried out in one year without wrecking the social fabric of the city and state.
He called for a broad bipartisan agreement, involving labor unions and the private sector, to reform health care, the welfare system and other parts of government, bringing the deficits down over a period of years, not months. That would take a credible plan and long-term financing because in the short term it would mean more debts. But he observed ruefully and correctly that no one around today is providing the leadership or vision for such a strategy.
Mr. Rohatyn was hardly alone in declaring that Mr. Carey's brand of leadership does not exist today. Without the former Governor's vision and even his sense of humor, the city might not have been rescued from the brink. Like Mr. Pataki, Mr. Carey took office seemingly unaware of the depth of the crisis he faced. He proclaimed immediately that "the days of wine and roses are over," but then went on to tap the strength of diverse forces to build a tradition of cooperation that towers over what exists today. He made the impossible seem inevitable. That is not a bad legacy for anyone to build on. STEVEN R. WEISMAN

HEADLINE: NEW YORKERS & CO.;
Why Is This Bowl of Noodles So Cheap?

BYLINE: By JANE H. LII 

 BODY:
To Vincent Mangano, 50, a supervisor at a cable company, Chinatown has always meant good food at cheap prices. So while he was on jury duty downtown one recent Tuesday, Mr. Mangano chose a Chinese noodle shop on Canal Street for lunch and ordered a heaping bowl of rice noodle soup with roast duck.
"It's a very balanced meal," Mr. Mangano said, pointing to the pieces of golden-colored duck crammed on top of the noodles and Chinese broccoli. "You've got carbohydrate, protein and vegetables in one bowl." 
 Nutrition aside, Mr. Mangano said what made his lunch enjoyable was the price: $3, which included a cup of tea.
But what Mr. Mangano did not see was that the waiter serving him was making around $15 a day, not including tips, averaging barely over $1 an hour for an 11-hour day, and no benefits. The minimum wage for waiters in New York State is $2.90 an hour. Nontipped kitchen staff should be paid the minimum wage, but few here are.
The mid-size restaurant where Mr. Mangano dined is just one of more than 500 restaurants in Chinatown that offer good foods at relatively inexpensive prices. Cheap labor, fierce competition between restaurants and the need to remain accessible to working-class Chinese, as well as tourists, keeps the prices low in all but a handful of banquet halls, despite high rents and increasing food and supply costs.
Oversupply of labor in Chinatown has kept wages at the low end of the industry pay scale. Workers are stuck here because they do not speak enough English to work in mainstream establishments. Adding to the glut are the hundreds of thousands of illegal immigrants from Fujian, China, who are causing wages to drop even more.
"When the supply exceeds the demand by this much, the wage will not go up," said Emanuel Tobier, professor of economics and planning at the Wagner Graduate School of Public Service at New York University. "It's the owners' market."
Even for $15 a day plus tips, jobs in Chinatown restaurants are hard to come by. Applicants flock to Chinatown employment agencies each morning. This puts pressure on those already employed. Although the mostly Cantonese-speaking Chinatown restaurant owners actually hire few of the Fujianese-speaking immigrants, employees still see these immigrants as threats.
"Of course, it's better to have health insurance, overtime pay and benefits," said Ai Young, a waiter who spoke on the condition that his last name not be used. "But if I leave today, there will be 10 people ready to take my job for less money."
Ai Young said, helped by tips, he averages $450 to $500 a week, although it takes him about 60 hours to make that much.
Like Ai Young, most workers often do not accept that long hours and low pay are forms of exploitation, believing instead that hard work is a necessary step to success. They look closely at those who came before them. Before becoming president of Chinatown's largest restaurant, Jing Fong, Chung Ko Cheng washed dishes for years in a Chinese takeout restaurant in Harlem.
Cultural constraints also make it difficult for workers to demand better treatment. Most Chinatown restaurants operate in a patriarchal way. Bosses are often viewed as father figures who watch out for workers and solve their problems.
Competition between businesses have also kept the prices low. When Chinatown was the only place to get authentic Chinese food and the only place where restaurants were open seven days a week, business bustled. But in recent years, many customers have stopped coming, as most mainstream restaurants began to stay open all week and added Chinese influence. At the same time, Chinese restaurants and noodle shops have cropped up all over, especially in Flushing, Queens, and Sunset Park, Brooklyn, where Chinese enclaves are growing.
"There is more pressure on owners to keep the price low to make their restaurants more attractive," said Clark Wolf, a food and restaurant consultant.
These days, although restaurants are still packed on weekends, Chinatown looks like a ghost town on weekdays. A walk through Chinatown on a Monday and a Tuesday evening, also traditionally busy nights for Chinatown restaurants, found most of the high- and middle-end restaurants with no more than seven tables in use per evening. In one, two waiters hovered over a table of four -- the only customer for the evening -- while the rest sat reading newspapers.
Although areas with many restaurants draw crowds and bring in profit, industry experts say Chinatown is so saturated that it has exceeded the maximum profit-making point and actually has diminishing profits.
Since February, a union, Local 318 Independent Restaurant Workers Union, which represents about 100 workers in two restaurants in Chinatown and Flushing, has been picketing Jing Fong and calling for better working conditions for all restaurant workers in Chinatown. But their efforts have been rebuffed by local business leaders, workers and community leaders, who showed their support for Jing Fong by raising $20,000 for it last month.
Owners say they are squeezed. While business is down, they must pay high rents, up to 12 percent of their total costs. (Mr. Wolf said the industry average is 4 to 8 percent).
"Chinatown rent is disproportionally high compared to the rest of the city," said Dean Lui, general manager of the New Golden Age Realty, a Chinatown real estate brokerage firm. "The real estate bust in the rest of the city a few years ago never affected prices here, because the demand to buy in Chinatown came from Asia."
Meanwhile, the cost of supplies has gone up. Gray sole, for example, has gone from $2.85 a pound three years ago to nearly $5 a pound.
"I would love to charge more than $3 for the noodles," said a manager, who insisted on anonymity. "But the fact is people just won't come here. There are so many other places they can go."
Prompted by the union's protest, restaurant owners are now working with the State Department of Labor to change their ways. The Chinese Restaurant Association has proposed raising prices to cover workers' benefits. Non-Chinese customers like Mr. Mangano say they would gladly pay more for the cause.
But some Chinatown residents say they are concerned that such an increase would crowd out the Chinese working class, for whom dining out has been a tradition. While Mr. Mangano is willing to pay more than $3 for noodles, Xing Guo, a street sock vendor, said he could not afford to.
"Three dollars is already too much for me," he said. "I only splurge like that once a week."

HEADLINE: Doctors Go Jobless, Patients Do Without;
Too Many Specialists

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Blaming health maintenance organizations for physician-specialist unemployment is like blaming the thermometer for the fever (front page, April 15). The United States has been producing an excess number of specialists for years. Medical schools and teaching hospitals have found training programs for specialists a source of low-cost labor, and the high-tech culture of most academic centers has provided students with specialists as role models. 
 By contracting only with physicians they need, health maintenance organizations have brought the oversupply issue to the surface by limiting the ability of specialists to "induce" demand by performing marginally useful procedures and tests.
The United States is headed toward a physician glut. Right-sizing of training programs and the flow of international medical graduates can match the supply of physicians to needs.
 
LEWIS G. SANDY, M.D.
V.P., Robert Wood Johnson Foundation
Princeton, N.J., April 17, 1995
