HEADLINE: BASEBALL '95;
For Richer, for Poorer: Leyland and Alou Are Keeping the Faith

BYLINE: By CLAIRE SMITH 

 BODY:
You cannot blame Jim Leyland and Felipe Alou these days if they feel like straight men in an Abbott and Costello routine gone wrong.
Not only do these two managers stand a good chance of having to ask who's on first and what's on second when their respective teams -- the Pirates and Expos -- open each new season. They also know there is one other question they always have to ask about their players: Can we afford to keep them? 
 In baseball's new economic reality, the answer to that final question is often "no," a cold, hard response that the have-not teams say is increasingly necessary for survival.
The 234-day work stoppage that began last August and gobbled up the post-season is estimated to have cost the 28 clubs $700 million. One team -- the Kansas City Royals -- responded by paring over $11 million from its payroll, jettisoning David Cone, the 1994 American League Cy Young winner, and Brian McRae, one of the game's up-and-coming center fielders.
The Pirates, more experienced at shedding salaries, saw the free-agent center fielder Andy Van Slyke become the latest player to join an exodus that had previously carried away Barry Bonds, Bobby Bonilla and Doug Drabek from a team that, in the early 90's, was one of the best in baseball.
"Supposing we had the revenue to keep guys like that," Leyland said wistfully. "We would have had a pretty good team for quite a while."
And then there are the Expos. Before Alou could have his long-awaited spring training reunion with the club that made him the winningest manager in baseball in 1994, the heart of his team was all but ripped out.
John Wetteland, a talented reliever, was traded to the Yankees for $2 million, a minor leaguer and a player to be named later. Ken Hill, the Expos' No. 1 starter, was traded to the Cardinals. Larry Walker, an All-Star right fielder and free agent, found riches with the Colorado Rockies after Montreal concluded it could not re-sign him.
And, in the unkindest cut of all, the Expos' high-octane center fielder, Marquis Grissom, was traded to the already talent-laden Atlanta Braves, a division rival the Expos were besting when the 1994 season ended early.
"First the strike, then replacement players, then to lose those guys," Alou said, shaking his head. "It's just been weird. But I knew we were going to lose them. We had been told that if we didn't have a new kind of basic agreement with the players, our market wasn't going to be able to stay in that pay stream."
Alou makes such statements rather matter of factly. After all, his club had already parted with Delino DeShields, Dennis Martinez and Tim Wallach the previous two years, moves that lowered the team's payroll to $18 million, the second lowest in baseball in 1994.
"This just seems so bad, now, because it happened to be that we lost four guys this year," said Alou, whose team's payroll is now expected to dip under $10 million. "But we've been losing a number of people every year. If we turned around and picked up the people we've lost the last three years we probably have the best team in baseball."
It's a lament similar to Pittsburgh's.
"There will be times it's going to be difficult for him, as it was for me, not to wear it on his sleeve," Leyland said of Alou. "Sometimes you're going to get down. But Felipe Alou is one of the proudest human beings I've met in baseball. He's going to handle this and do good."
Thus far, the 58-year-old Alou has shown no signs of getting down as he prepares for his fourth year as the Expos' manager.
"I know we lost Grissom and Walker, but I have Tony Tarasco, Moises Alou, Roberto Kelly and Rondell White -- and I wish I could play all four in the outfield," Alou said. "We have the same infield that we had last year, even better, because of better backups. The catching is the same. So really, we are short two arms, because the loss of a stopper and an ace is tough."
So, warns a confident Alou, "we're going to give some people some bad nights. We're going to have fun."
Still, to sit and watch top players depart, for monetary rather than baseball reasons, goes against everything managers were taught to believe about molding winners.
"If you feel like it's going to be worth it in the end, then you don't mind working overtime, day after day after day," said the 50-year-old Leyland. "But if you feel that your work is going to be fruitless, that it's going to be for nothing, then that bothers you."
Leyland, in his 10th season as the Pirate manager, has had to deal with the frustration of losing in the National League playoffs three consecutive seasons -- 1990, 1991 and 1992 -- and never making it to the World Series. In 1993, the Pirates fell to 75-87; last year they were 53-61. If the game remains structured along class lines, it seems doubtful Leyland will get another shot at the post-season with Pittsburgh.
"What bothers me most, when they talk about Pittsburgh, is a lot of people just see us as some poor sister that doesn't have any money, that can't compete, that it's a horrible place to play, where the fans aren't any good," said Leyland. "That's the farthest thing from the truth.
"Pittsburgh is a great baseball city. We just don't get up-front money that other organizations get from their cable deals that gives them the luxury of getting players and keeping them."
In the past decade and a half, the Montreals and Minnesotas, the Pittsburghs and Kansas Citys did manage to keep enough talent to compete; in fact, only five of the last 15 World Series were won by teams from Los Angeles, New York and Toronto.
Still, the financial gulf is widening. And the question is whether teams like the Expos and Pirates will ever be able again to use their baseball instincts to overcome the deep-pocketed clubs.
"More power to them; I don't begrudge anybody anything," Leyland said of the big-market teams. "There's a difference between spending and spending wisely. What the small markets have to hope is that they don't spend it wisely, giving you a better chance to compete."
Still, there are concerns -- about future raids, future heartbreaks if the salary-arbitration eligibles and free agents can't be kept. "If you can retain them, there's some hope," Leyland said. "If you can't, then it looks pretty grim."
The battler in Leyland hasn't allowed him or his team to quit. The first workout after the strike ended included a fiery speech that made its way to national television.
"I was not trying to give a pep rally," Leyland said. "This is not a Saturday football game. But I just don't want these guys feeling sorry for ourselves like everybody else is. I won't have that.
"We were a small market when we won three straight years. We're still a small market. That doesn't change. So you get good players, again, develop them, win and hope you can retain them. Before, we did everything but retain them. I hope we learned some lessons since then. We know we have less leeway for mistakes right now; when we make an acquisition, we have to make sure it makes sense. I don't have any problem with that. In fact, that's not a bad little challenge."
Baseball already knows what Jim Leyland and Felipe Alou can do with a challenge in a somewhat fair fight. Only time will tell what they can do now that baseball guile, instead of baseball billions, is the only weapon left to them.

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Expanding On-Line Services

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
MORE mutual funds are offering on-line investor services for everything from education to account information to interviews with fund managers.
Vanguard Online, available through America Online (keyword: Vanguard), offers a four-step course on creating a diversified portfolio. Investors can also retrieve prospectuses, get account information or share ideas with other investors on message boards. 
 The Montgomery funds joined the Internet's Networth investor service (http://www.xperts.montgomery.com/ 1) with a "Meet the Experts" program, a weekly commentary by fund managers based on investors' questions with the broadest appeal.
The Fidelity Investments on-line service can be found on the Internet's World Wide Web (http://www.fid-inv.com). Among other things, investors can use an asset allocation worksheet, review fund performance and other data, order prospectuses or retrieve a demonstration copy of Fidelity Online Xpress, which can be used to place orders for stocks, options and mutual funds, get price quotes and account balances.
 
Recovery Expected In Real Estate Funds
Real estate funds have fallen more than 3 percent so far this year, while domestic stock funds have risen nearly 9 percent. But coming off an incredible December, the moves do not necessarily indicate a long-term trend.
"We expected some retracing early in the year because of December," said Susan Belden, senior editor of the No-Load Fund Analyst, a San Francisco newsletter.
The outlook for the real estate funds is good, she said. The improvement in the real estate market merits higher valuations for the funds' investments, and cash flow and dividend yields are strong.
While only five funds specialized in real estate in 1990, with a total of $80 million in assets, there are now 22 funds with more than $1.5 billion under management, said A. Jason Windawi, an analyst with Morningstar, the mutual funds tracking service in Chicago.
Unlike health care, environmental and Latin American funds, which are fads based on industries or regions peripheral to the world economy, funds devoted to real estate allow investors to participate in one of the world's biggest classes of assets, commercial real estate, he said. For the most part, the funds buy real estate investment trusts, which trade like stocks and own a stake in properties.
Ms. Belden's favorites include Cohen & Steers Realty Shares in New York; CGM Realty and Fidelity Real Estate in Boston, and PRA Real Estate Securities in Chicago.
 
Emerging Markets
Despite the drubbing that the emerging markets have taken lately, many fund groups say the long-term outlook is strong for people willing to take the bumps along the way.
Warburg Pincus Emerging Markets, which carries no sales charge, will be co-managed by Richard H. King, manager of the top-performing Warburg Pincus International Equity, and Nicholas P. W. Horsley, the associate manager.
Calvert New Africa, with a sales charge of 2.5 percent and a redemption fee of 2 percent for shares held for less than two years, will be managed by New Africa Advisers and will seek opportunities on the Johannesburg stock exchange and other African markets.
Smith Barney Emerging Markets Portfolio, with a sales charge of 5 percent, can invest in equities in Eastern Europe, Africa, Asia and Latin America.
 
In Brief
Total returns on several John Hancock mutual funds have been listed as "not available" in recent weeks because of a computer transmission error by the company to Nasdaq. Correct returns are available in today's tables.

HEADLINE: Scientists and Engineers Need Broader Training, Report Says

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
The United States' system of doctoral education in science and engineering, while long a world model, should be reshaped to produce more "versatile scientists," rather than narrowly specialized researchers, according to a report by three of the nation's leading scientific advisory groups.
Many doctoral students are channeled into such specialization that they are not flexible enough for jobs involving new technologies and industries, a global marketplace, intensified economic competition, public health needs and environmental deterioration, the report said. 
 With openings for Ph.D.'s in decline at research universities, scientists and engineers "must be trained to broaden themselves," said Phillip A. Griffiths, director of the Institute for Advanced Research at Princeton University and head of the panel of academicians that issued the report.
The 19 panelists are members of the Committee on Science, Engineering and Public Policy, a standing committee drawn from members of the National Academy of Sciences, the National Academy of Engineering and the Institute of Medicine.
Titled "Reshaping the Graduate Education of Scientists and Engineers," the report said that from 1977 to 1991, the proportion of all scientists and engineers with doctorates employed in colleges and universities declined to 43 percent from 51 percent. Only 31 percent of those awarded Ph.D.'s from 1983 to 1986 were in tenure-track positions or had gained tenure by 1991. More than half of new Ph.D. graduates work in nonacademic businesses or industry.
"You tell a graduate student he has a 60 percent chance of not working in academe and that comes as a major surprise," Dr. Griffiths said.
The report cites the end of the cold war, with declining defense-research grants, and the rapid growth of international competition in high-tech industries as causes of the shifting demand.
Most students spend eight or nine years getting a Ph.D., Dr. Griffiths said, and should get better guidance about whether to pursue the degree. A mathematics major, he said, might "instead go for a master's degree in business administration or add engineering to his mathematics so he can learn how to design bridges."
"When they get their Ph.D.'s," Dr. Griffiths said, "many people decide they aren't interested in a teaching career and they wind up at Goldman, Sachs, the brokerage firm. We'd like to see them make that decision earlier."
Despite "worrisome indicators of weakness in the market" for new Ph.D.'s in science and engineering, and particularly in mathematics and physics, the panel did not recommend "across-the-board limits on enrollment."
Instead, it said "extensive, disciplined research experience" would prepare Ph.D. students for "a wide variety of nontraditional careers for which scientific and technical expertise is relevant."
The report was praised by Walter Massey, provost of the University of California system and a former director of the National Science Foundation.
"For a long time, I have been saying that we are preparing students to follow in the footsteps of their professors, yet that's not the way it's going to be," Mr. Massey said.
"Some people say we should control the supply of Ph.D.'s, but I think it would be a terrible mistake to deny that opportunity to the people who want it," he continued. "It's better to open up the demand for them by giving them a different kind of training so they could work in different areas."

CORRECTION-DATE: April 26, 1995, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article on Sunday about a report recommending more versatility in the doctoral training of scientists and engineers misidentified the research institute at which one author, Phillip A. Griffiths, is director. It is the Institute for Advanced Study based in Princeton, N.J.; it is not the Institute for Advanced Research at Princeton University. The two institutions are not affiliated.

HEADLINE: EARTH DAY '95;
Back to the Grass Roots

BYLINE: By Keith Schneider; Keith Schneider is a national environmental correspondent for The New York Times.

 BODY:

LOSING GROUND
American Environmentalism
at the Close of the Twentieth Century.
By Mark Dowie.
317 pp. Cambridge, Mass: The MIT Press. $25. 
AS far as Mark Dowie is concerned, the national environmental movement is "courting irrelevance." Why? Because the people leading its largest organizations are too white, too male, too elite, too polite and too involved with Washington.
Mr. Dowie first offered this analysis in a pathbreaking article three years ago in World Policy Journal. He predicted then that unless the movement changed its tactics and its leadership, its influence and its economic base would erode. In "Losing Ground," he reports that this is precisely what happened. What makes "Losing Ground" one of the truly important books on a genuinely American social movement is Mr. Dowie's ability both to ferret out the telling fact and to make a cohesive narrative out of a complex and fractious story. By turns curious, contemptuous, even irritable, this is a courageous critique of a movement that Mr. Dowie, a former editor and publisher of Mother Jones magazine, has long admired.
The tale told here is not pretty. As chronicled by Mr. Dowie, the environmental movement's senior leaders, while selling themselves to a willing public as above reproach, have quietly conducted their business, especially their business in Washington, just like any other special interest.
In the late 1980's, for instance, Dean Buntrock, chief executive officer of Waste Management Inc., the country's largest toxic waste disposal company, joined the board of the National Wildlife Federation, one of the country's biggest conservation groups, and became a reliable contributor. Shortly afterward, Jay Hair, head of the federation, attended a breakfast meeting with his friend William K. Reilly, then Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, and Mr. Buntrock. The subject under discussion: helping Mr. Buntrock overcome state and Federal regulations that were stopping his company from opening new hazardous waste dumps in South Carolina and New Jersey.
Mr. Dowie writes that mediation on behalf of industry has become more common in the 90's as the national groups' membership rolls and revenues have declined. The organizations attribute their woes to the election of Bill Clinton and Al Gore and a public perception that a team friendly to the environment was in charge. Mr. Dowie argues that the sources of the movement's problems are considerably deeper, and that it includes supporters' dismay at the extent to which the groups are mired in their own bureaucracies and unwilling to work on new issues.
By far the best display of Mr. Dowie's formidable ability as an investigator is seen in his discussion of fund raising, and especially of how some of the largest foundations -- notably the foundations of industrial families -- gained enormous influence over the agenda of the national environmental community.
Traditionally, environmental groups decided what issues were the most pressing and applied for grants to set up programs to address them. In the late 80's and early 90's, Mr. Dowie writes, the cycle was reversed. Dissatisfied with the effectiveness of national groups, the foundations began to decide among themselves what were the most important issues, proceeded to set aside millions of dollars and solicited grant applications from environmental groups.
What this turnabout represents, Mr. Dowie argues, is no more and no less than political subcontracting. It kept the large environmental groups in business, but ultimately it weakened the movement.
Not long ago environmentalists were led by "committed warriors" like David Brower, the former head of the Sierra Club. In the 60's and 70's, Mr. Brower and his contemporaries attracted attention and money -- and gained political influence -- by rousing the grass roots. Now, Mr. Dowie argues, the movement is led by bland lawyers and M.B.A.'s whose primary interest is "developing entrepreneurial skills and organizational enhancement skills" designed to collect money from big business and industrial foundations. Ostensibly working to defend the environment, they are actually shoring up their bottom lines.
It's a strategy that's failing, Mr. Dowie says. And indeed, the loose coalition of property owners, ranchers, small-business executives and municipal officials known as the wise use movement has gained substantial political ground of late by accusing environmentalists of being arrogant and out of touch.
In Mr. Dowie's view, there is merit to their arguments, and leaders of national environmental groups are not helping themselves by branding their critics stooges of big business. "Ordinary people in the countryside are being ignored and disrespected by the same Government agencies that the environmental movement has been fighting for decades," he writes. "Most of these people love the land around them as much as any Sierra Club hiker does."
Grass-roots environmentalists are as disgusted with the national groups as are those ordinary citizens. The grass-roots groups see the nationals as hogging all the financial support, wasting it on fancy urban offices and feckless lobbying campaigns, and making compromise a matter of routine.
But Mr. Dowie sees rescue ahead, at the hands of a new "fourth wave" of American environmentalism, as regional organizations with professional staff members join with the roughly 10,000 volunteer local groups across the country that usually organize around a single issue, such as battling a toxic waste site. He also champions the so-called environmental justice movement, which works on Indian reservations, in urban and rural communities, and among civil rights groups to get regulators to enforce environmental laws in poor communities the same way they do in wealthy ones. The "fourth wave" groups, he predicts -- perhaps too romantically -- will supplant the large national organizations because they have more quickly come to understand and act on American environmentalism's new operative motto: Think locally, act locally.
Mr. Dowie is to be commended for keeping his analysis on a subject as expansive as environmental politics to little more than 300 pages. But because of its discipline and welcome brevity, "Losing Ground" also suffers from a sense of haste. For instance, Mr. Dowie cites Lois Gibbs, head of the Virginia-based Citizens' Clearinghouse for Hazardous Wastes, as a model of the kind of leader who will reinvigorate the national environmental movement. But we learn less about this advocate, mother and former resident of Love Canal than we could have gleaned from a few newspaper clippings.
And there are noticeable small errors. Dixy Lee Ray, for instance, was the Governor of Washington State, not Oregon. The nation's newest commercial incinerator, in East Liverpool, Ohio, burns hazardous wastes, not garbage.
"Losing Ground" is an ambitious and brave book. Mr. Dowie has marshaled an exceptionally broad array of facts and produced a provocative explanation for why a once vibrant social movement is flagging. For the sake of what's left of America's natural heritage, and the tens of millions of citizens who are concerned about protecting it, let's hope the leaders of the big environmental organizations are among this book's most careful readers.

HEADLINE: Friendly Faces, Helping Hands

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
IN Bushnell Park in Hartford one recent sunny Saturday afternoon, a nervous-looking man approached Gladys N. Hoyle to ask if she could accompany his little girl to the restroom. He didn't feel comfortable taking the child to the men's room.
But he didn't seem bothered about approaching Mrs. Hoyle, even though she was a stranger. Her red windbreaker, golf cap and khaki slacks, made her recognizable as a Hartford Guide, someone always ready with a kind word and a helping hand. 
 In between her normal job of dispensing information and directions, Mrs. Hoyle is always on the lookout to provide more personal service. She regularly helps a blind girl pick out lipstick and other personal items in downtown shops. She holds open doors for women with strollers and men with their arms full of packages. She tells visitors about upcoming festivals or special events.
"I like being able to help people," Mrs. Hoyle said, her brisk stride carrying her through the park toward Jewell Street. "It makes you feel good about yourself." For almost four years, the guides have done their walking tours of downtown, doing what they can to help business owners and shoppers, tourists and office workers. They have logged more than 50,000 contacts on the streets of their city, circulating nonstop through the 26 square blocks they patrol, walking 11 miles or more in an eight-hour shift.
"Hartford really has a need for a friendly face, people who are knowledgeable about the city, and accommodating," said Phil Hopkins, a manager at Hartford Brewery Ltd., a downtown pub that has supported the guides with a yearly event called Brewfest. "Hartford has always been a city where people put on blinders and stick to themselves. The Guides can help change that image."
The executive director of the Guides, Austin Jordan, said the group was the cheapest economic development tool the downtown can employ. No matter how many different stores you bring in, if people have an unpleasant visit they won't come back to shop. "We've been known to change tires, we carry umbrellas for people who get caught in a sudden downpour, and we provide an escort service for people after dark," said Mr. Jordan.
One city council member has asked the Guides to consider expanding into Asylum Hill, if financial support can be found. There's also discussion about moving into a downtown Arts District, to the south of the area the Guides currently patrol. And Riverfront Recapture, the group developing a network of parks and walkways along the Connecticut River in Hartford and East Hartford, has opened talks about the Guides providing service in that area. "People have to feel comfortable and secure," said Joseph R. Marfuggi, director of Riverfront Recapture. "We want the kind of presence in the park that the Guides provide downtown, someone who clearly belongs, who answers questions and makes people feel welcome -- and who has a radio to call for help if people need it."
Tana M. Parseliti, director of Business for Downtown Hartford, one of the groups that helped found the Guides four years ago, said while the program was aimed at promoting tourism and other visits to the downtown, it's not just out-of-towners who use the Guides.
"You're probably, when you're talking to a guide, talking to one of the best sources for what's going on, where it's going on, and when it's going on," Ms. Parseliti said.
The Guides, patterned after a program in Portland, Ore., were started up in 1991 with the hiring of an executive director. There are now seven uniformed guides on the street, with plans to hire two more this summer, on a budget of $281,275. There could be an even dozen Guides if the budgetary goal of $325,000 -- largely from private and corporate contributions -- can be achieved, said M. Ronald Morneault, president of the Guides' board and owner of Tuesday's, a men's clothing store in the downtown. Working until 11 P.M. on weekends, the Guides make their rounds look easy. "But when it's cold out and the weather is inclement, there's not a lot of glory," Mr. Morneault said. What there is, is a strong tie to the merchant community.
"There are a lot of small retail operations in the downtown where there's only one or two people in the store, and when they have to go to the bank or grab a sandwich or even just go to the bathroom, it can be a problem," Mr. Morneault said. "If a Guide happens to be walking by they can ask them to step inside for a minute" to take over.
"It's not a Guardian Angel program or any other type of security," Mr. Morneault said. "It's more a comforting, reassuring presence in the downtown. It's the cordiality that's important." But security is a part of it as well. The Guides all carry two-way radios that can patch them into the emergency dispatch center, to summon police or rescue crews. Mr. Jordan proudly notes that crime in the downtown district has dropped more than 50 percent, according to police statistics, since the Guides began operating. That reflects police initiatives, and increased efforts on the part of merchants to provide a safe environment, but Mr. Jordan said some part of the credit belongs to the Guides, and the police agree.
"They're a significant addition to the eyes and ears we have out there," said Deputy Police Chief Thomas F. O'Connor, who shares his headquarters in the Police Museum at 101 Pearl Street with the Guides.
Deputy Chief O'Connor said just having someone with a radio nearby is often enough to defuse a domestic dispute, or calm a drunk. On one occasion a Guide helped apprehend a purse snatcher by following him and radioing directions to police.
But more important, Deputy Chief O'Connor said, is the routine: helping people who have locked themselves out of their car, or who are nervous about walking to a parking lot alone, calls the Hartford police might otherwise receive. With more than 350,000 calls logged each year, any relief is welcome, he said. The Guides perform other functions as well. Mrs. Hoyle often takes students to historic buildings. The Guides maintain a library of, for instance, the examples of Greek architecture downtown.
"I lived in Hartford for eight years, starting in 1983," said Mrs. Hoyle, who now lives in East Hartford. "I thought I knew the city. I got this job, and I realized how much I didn't know."
She also has memorized traffic patterns -- which streets are one way, which are busiest in the morning rush hour and so forth. And whenever a new shop opens, she stops in to acquaint herself with the owner and clerks. "I have a lot of people who want to know where they can buy beepers, or cameras, or whatever, and the more I know about the businesses the more I can help them out," Mrs. Hoyle said.
One continuing problem for the Guides has been finances. The organization is supported heavily by the Downtown Council, the state's Department of Economic Development and the city, as well as a variety of corporations and business groups. But fund raising is still a problem and Mr. Jordan said he hoped for more fee-based services: providing Guides at major events like Taste of Hartford or the Jazz Festival, for instance. The organization would also like to have more special events of its own, like the Brewfest organized by Hartford Brewery that raised almost $15,000 last fall.
And this year the Guides took over management of the information book at the Hartford Civic Center, where one Saturday afternoon recently James E. Hyland, a Guide, was answering two or three questions a minute for hours on end.
"When's the next time the Whalers will be playing in town?" "When's the next performance of 'Beauty and the Beast?' " Others want to know how to find restrooms and restaurants, shops and trade shows. On St. Patrick's Day, he recalled, one man wanted to know where he could find a shillelagh; after several calls, an imitation Irish walking stick was found at Luettgens Ltd.
A woman walked up to ask if Mr. Hyland could help her find her car; she had forgotten to note the name of the garage where she had parked, gotten turned around in the Civic Center and couldn't retrace her steps. He talked with her for a few minutes, finally eliciting enough information to make an educated guess, and sent her on her way. Mr. Hyland said that on another evening, a man from Vermont couldn't remember where he'd parked his car, either. It was snowing, and he couldn't even recall if the lot was paved or dirt. Mr. Hyland asked him to think hard: there are 12 parking lots within a reasonable walk of the Civic Center.
"On the coldest night of the year, we spent an hour and a half walking to every parking lot in the area," Mr. Hyland recalls. "We finally found it, shoveled it out, and waited while he warmed it up and got ready to go."
But the most frequent question Mr. Hyland had to deal with on a recent afternoon was, "Where do I find the fishing show?" And each time, Mr. Hyland patiently pointed to the white banner hanging next to the information booth, with 18-inch high blue letters proclaiming, "Fishing Show Downstairs."
Mr. Hyland said that's not unusual. On nights when there's a big game in the Civic Center, people will walk in, ignore the long lines of people waiting to buy a ticket, and ask, "Where can I get a ticket?"
"That really points out how important it is for visitors to have a human contact," said Ms. Parseliti of Business for Downtown Hartford. "They're overwhelmed by sights and sounds and can't always sort everything out. That's what the Guides have to do for them."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 16; Column 2; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1300 words

HEADLINE: EARTH DAY '95;
Live and Let Die

BYLINE: By David Quammen; David Quammen's forthcoming book, "The Song of the Dodo," concerns the biological significance of islands and islandlike places, from Komodo to Yellowstone.

 BODY:

NOAH'S CHOICE
The Future of Endangered Species.
By Charles C. Mann and Mark L. Plummer.
302 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24. 
NOAH'S big boat, 300 cubits long by 50 cubits wide by 30 cubits high and jammed to its gunwales with wildlife, has been a favorite metaphor among books about biological diversity. The very word "ark" has served as a signal of two things -- a rich miscellany of living creatures and an imperative for their rescue. Norman Myers's work "The Sinking Ark," published in 1979, was one of the first influential efforts to bring the whole problem of species extinctions caused by humans to public attention. Four years later, "The Secular Ark," Janet Browne's history of the science called biogeography (that is, the study of biological diversity as distributed in geographical patterns), was released. In 1986 came Lee Durrell's volume "State of the Ark," sort of a "Whole Earth Catalogue" of threatened species and ecosystems. And then, in 1989, Dale Peterson published "The Deluge and the Ark," an account of his travels to see some of the world's most spectacular and endangered primate species.
Charles C. Mann and Mark L. Plummer have turned to the same metaphor, which by now seems a little tired, but their variant carries some new energy. "Noah's Choice: The Future of Endangered Species" emphasizes the element of human decision making, not the condition of the boat. As construed by Mr. Mann and Mr. Plummer, Noah's choice determines which creatures get aboard and which don't. It's not one choice, of course, but a whole set of choices, with American society cast in the role of Noah.
American society? Yes, this is a domestic-policy discussion, as far as Mr. Mann and Mr. Plummer are concerned. Although the subtitle implies otherwise, their book mostly limits itself to one minor category of endangered species: those native to the United States. The truth is that our North Temperate ecosystems -- even the few portions not already badly fragmented and degraded -- don't harbor an extraordinary wealth of species, endangered or otherwise. The real superpowers of biological diversity are tropical countries like Brazil, Indonesia, Malaysia, Venezuela and Madagascar. But never mind. America being America, our struggle to cope with our own modest share does have resonance in the larger world, and the fights waged over spotted owls and desert tortoises and California gnatcatchers are certainly large enough and hot enough to keep us exercised.
The ark represents our willingness to restrain ourselves collectively and individually, to compromise with one another, to pay. How much will we pay to insure the survival of an obscure, localized subspecies of butterfly? How much will we restrain ourselves on behalf of a species of salamander or cave spider or fungus? Unfortunately, the ark of our willingness isn't so huge as the assemblage of needy creatures that would board it. Therefore, choices are inescapable, as Mr. Mann and Mr. Plummer argue persuasively.
"Over the next century or so," they write, "humanity will face a staggering number of small choices, few of them alike, between accomplishing some goal (building a highway to a hospital) and protecting some part of nature (one population of a beetle). Not many will involve anything so dramatic as a certain extinction." Yet the cumulative effects "will represent a fateful decision about how much of the natural world accompanies us on our journey to the future." Mr. Mann and Mr. Plummer's point is that if we don't address those choices more lucidly and more effectively than we have been doing, they will be made anyway -- haphazardly, by default and at great social and ecological cost. This logic brings the authors to the real subject of "Noah's Choice," which is the Endangered Species Act of 1973.
The historical origins of that law are intriguingly described in a chapter titled " 'The Awful Beast Is Back.' " The "awful beast" was the snail darter, and the nice over-the-top rhetoric came in 1979 from Senator Howard Baker of Tennessee, who also declared it "the bane of my existence, the nemesis of my golden years, the bold perverter of the Endangered Species Act," because the little fish and the big law had together been used to block (temporarily) the infamous Tellico Dam project in his state. Most of us know that tale in outline, but not its revealing details or its minatory significance, as the authors present them here. Had the act really been perverted in that instance, or was it functioning just as its designers had intended? If it was functioning as intended, had the intentions of the designers been sufficiently realistic and foresighted?
None of us should imagine that Senator Baker's reaction was purely theatrical, or that the snail darter case was an aberration. There are ranchers today in my neck of the Montana woods who are saying essentially the same thing about the gray wolf, now that it's being reintroduced to Yellowstone National Park under provisions of the Endangered Species Act: "The awful beast is back." Many of those ranchers are moderate, fair-minded people and one of them is a dear friend of mine, though I disagree with him diametrically about the return of the wolf.
The Endangered Species Act, as Mr. Mann and Mr. Plummer portray it, has for 22 years been our mechanism for pretending that we don't need to make Noachian choices about what can or can't be saved -- that the ark is big enough, that it must be big enough, to accommodate every jeopardized species and subspecies that turns up. Their view of the act will be controversial, and I don't share it completely myself. But they do a vital service by suggesting that we should rethink whether this law, as currently framed, contains all the best mechanisms for accomplishing its essential goals.
Can't we improve it or supplement it in some way, so that society at large bears the full costs of the biological diversity that society at large wants and needs, rather than assigning an incommensurate share of those costs to a few local people? Can't we mitigate the degree to which it fans the acrimony of our deliberations on the stewardship of the American landscape? What about positive incentives as well as sanctions? Maybe we should pay private landowners, in cold cash or tax credits, for harboring a pack of gray wolves or a female grizzly with cubs or a population of Karner Blue butterflies on the back 40. We have got to try something new. At present, all we're doing is shouting ourselves purple -- us against them -- while biological diversity drowns in a rising tide of consumptive land use.
"NOAH'S CHOICE" is no elegant piece of imaginative reportage, and you wouldn't read it for the grace of the writing. It also suffers just a bit, as most co-written books do, from having a "we" as the speaker instead of a less blurry and more accountable "I." But Mr. Mann and Mr. Plummer (who also collaborated on "The Aspirin Wars: Money, Medicine and 100 Years of Rampant Competition") have compensated for those limitations with the depth of their research, the clarity of their scientific explanations, the keenness and honesty of their thinking. As a study of the historical origins and the shortcomings of our precious but imperfect Endangered Species Act, "Noah's Choice" is a valuable work. It would be a good thing if we all read this book -- city people and ranchers, ecologists and economists, tree huggers and loggers, as well as those who cherish the sublimely sterile notion that our country's biological diversity doesn't concern them one way or the other -- and then sat down to a civil discourse about what we have, what we want, what we need and how we should proceed. Our boat is adrift, at the moment, with Ararat nowhere in sight.

HEADLINE: EARTH DAY '95;
Troubles Waters

BYLINE: By Jane O'Reilly; Jane O'Reilly has written about scuba diving and underwater archeology for many magazines.

 BODY:

SEA CHANGE
A Message of the Oceans.
By Sylvia Alice Earle.
Illustrated. 361 pp. New York:
G. P. Putnam's Sons. $25.95. 
WHEN Sylvia Earle was 3 years old, she stood on a New Jersey beach and fell in love. Fifty-six years later, glorious encounters like that are still in her dreams: "A monstrous wall of green water races my way, hissing, roaring, towering, inescapable, sweeping me into a cascading aquatic mayhem. I am lifted, tumbled, churned, pushed, and fall, gasping, clawing for air. My toes touch sand; a sweet breeze soothes my lungs. I stand, choking, face the next advancing wall, and leap into it, exhilarated!" The little girl who embraced the waves grew up to become one of the most distinguished of the 20th-century explorers who were drawn to what she calls the "indigo wilderness" of the deep seas.
A biologist specializing in the ecology of marine ecosystems, Sylvia Earle has been wreathed in honors. She is also an engineer, and a leader in the invention of technology for deep-sea research. From 1990 to 1992 she was chief scientist of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, the first woman to be appointed to the post; there she made the demoralizing discovery that the United States commitment to marine sanctuaries was $11 million a year, while the national parks were receiving $1.4 billion. Above all, Ms. Earle is a joyful master of the calculated risk.
Underwater groupies will not find "Sea Change" a treasure trove of personal revelation. It is a moving plea for the preservation of the oceans. Three children, devoted parents and several husbands flicker like damselfish through "Sea Change," glinting occasionally in the light of Ms. Earle's affection, but the domestic balances required by her career are merely acknowledged, not recounted. Nor does she gossip. I have never read a book that took less advantage of a chance to settle scores, or seen so impressive a resume presented with so little self-importance.
An oceanographic expedition, like an astronomical one, requires enormous amounts of money and extraordinary technological expertise. It involves years of preparation and later analysis. Ms. Earle has still managed to spend 6,000 hours actually diving, living in underwater research modules, cartwheeling with dolphins, descending to 13,000 feet. She has written about what she found for publications ranging from Redbook to the Occasional Papers of the Farlow Herbarium of Cryptogamic Botany.
Her role model in the supermacho world of scuba exploration was Eugenie Clark, the celebrated authority on sharks. Being a woman meant, Ms. Earle writes, that she had to be "prepared to do twice as much work for half as much credit." She lived with silly headlines like "Beacon Hill Housewife to Lead Team of Female Aquanauts" because, she thought, "If people could see what we see underwater . . . they will be motivated to take care of the place." And so she tells us about the luminous wonders on the floor of the Nankai Trough off Japan. She describes the black horrors of the Exxon Valdez spill and the ruin of the Persian Gulf shore. All "critters," as Ms. Earle calls subsurface life, delight her, from the Nassau grouper with its "Labrador retriever-like" personality to the society of humpback whales: "The large, curious female who had first come my way remained the most attentive. Several times she moved slowly by, turning her great eyes, registering awareness, perhaps locking away in her large brain impressions for future reference."
"Sea Change: A Message of the Oceans" is only incidentally an adventure story and a tribute to all creatures great and small. Tragically, it is a eulogy, a Rachel Carson-like warning of the silent tide inexorably approaching. The ecosystems Sylvia Earle explored have begun, within her lifetime, to crash. Garbage and toxic waste, drift nets and overfishing have transformed the exhilarating possibilities of her girlhood into the environmental catastrophe she passionately chronicles. Nearly 80 percent of the commercially valuable fish whose status is known are overfished, Ms. Earle reports (while noting that expecting to feed the world's population on wild fish is, in any case, as unreasonable as expecting to sustain humanity on a diet of wild buffalo, squirrels, roots and berries). But what of those creatures whose status is not known? What of the value of creatures for their own sake, which may be far greater than their value as dinner? The changes of the past few decades, Ms. Earle writes, should command "the sort of interest one might take in, say, the life-support system of a spacecraft housing all of the past, present and future of humankind."
There is no question that she is correct, as anyone knows who has walked along a beach or snorkeled over the weakening reefs, or just tried to catch a fish. Ms. Earle still takes hope, provides lists of sanctuaries and organizations working to reverse the damage, pleads against ignorance. And she has forced a sea change on me simply by describing the multitudes of the world's species displayed at Tsukiji, the Tokyo fish market -- one million tons of fish a year, dead fish.
No more for me. Ever since my first dive 20 years ago, I too have believed that, as Sylvia Earle says, "If there is heaven on earth, it's under the sea."
 
 
 
OCEAN WATERS
 Arriving in plenty of time for swimsuit season come two books for the environmentally concerned seashore visitor. Both are companion volumes to a traveling Smithsonian Institution exhibit, Ocean Planet, and one is a perfect accessory for a summer home's wicker chaise. OCEAN PLANET: Writings and Images of the Sea (Abrams/Times Mirror, $39.95) offers evocative photographs, disturbing statistics (the death rate for commercial fishing, 155 per 100,000 workers, is the highest of any industry or profession), fun facts (a Scottish sailor wore a golden earring so if his drowned corpse was found on the beach his funeral could be paid for) and passionate raptures on the deep from such disparate seafarers as Benjamin Franklin, Joseph Conrad, John McPhee and Rachel Carson. Edited by Peter Benchley, our modern master of the undersea bugaboo, and Judith Gradwohl, the director of the Smithsonian's environmental awareness program, "Ocean Planet" preaches a singular respect for the world's waters as it mixes scientific profundities, New Age mysticism and the occasional soggy metaphor. Mr. Benchley laments, perhaps with more accuracy than he intends, "Those of us who spend our lives in, on and around the sea are able barely to scratch its surface." Diving somewhat deeper, in THE WEALTH OF OCEANS (Norton, $25), Michael Weber, a freelance writer who has worked on the staff of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's National Marine Fisheries Service, and the Smithsonian's Ms. Gradwohl emerge with a jargon-laden but perilously persuasive account of humanity's ecological and economic relationship with the seas. They make a strong case for limiting coastal development, and blame the hearty commercial fisherman, romanticized in "Ocean Planet," for overfishing some species to the brink of extinction -- though they stop short of blaming American venture capital for every global ecological disaster (some of the ghastly red tides that have closed American beaches have had "natural" origins, for instance). Both books emphasize that by being blissfully ignorant about the ocean we are not merely fouling a few nests. As goes the ocean, these books say, so goes the human race. BILL KENT

HEADLINE: Harlem Empowerment Zone Embraces People and Business

 BODY:
To the Editor:
I was disappointed by the Op-Ed article by Mitchell L. Moss ("Empty Promises for Harlem," April 15) on the Upper Manhattan Empowerment Zone. It unfairly denounced the project as a failure even before a board was seated to determine a final course of action. It also reflected a misunderstanding of the goals of the creators, including myself. 
 Mr. Moss's most cynical allegation was that the zone was creating an enormous safety net for the poor by apportioning too much of its resources for community improvement at the expense of tax breaks to create jobs. I hope his fears will be allayed by the knowledge that Richard D. Parsons, president of Time Warner Inc., has agreed to be chairman of the board of directors, and that the New York City Partnership of 200 chief executive officers and business leaders endorses the project.
Even by Mr. Moss's standards, these executives ought to know what they are doing, even if he doesn't trust the coalition of community, academic, political and business leaders who designed the project.
I doubt that the Partnership would agree that its $1 billion commitment for residential and commercial construction in the empowerment zone represented a failure to attract private-sector resources, as Mr. Moss alleges. Nor would some of America's most respected companies that have endorsed the project or expressed their intention to participate call it a "political boondoggle."
Equitable Life, Travelers, New York Life, AT&T, Nynex, Republic Bank, Allen & Company, BDO Seidman and Salomon Brothers, to name a few, are excited and looking for ways to get involved. They understand that quibbling over the apportionment of the zone's resources is not the issue. The amount of investment tax credits (almost half the total) versus money for training, day care, education and other improvements will be worked out -- with the parties involved, in a way that gets the job done. What is important is the recognition that communities cannot be rebuilt -- or businesses attracted -- without an investment in the people who live there.
Mr. Moss took pains to belittle the location of an international trade center complex in Harlem. Proximity to financial centers is no prerequisite in the high-tech world of computers.
 
CHARLES B. RANGEL
Member of Congress, 15th Dist., N.Y.
Washington, April 17, 1995

HEADLINE: Autos Weave in and Out of U.S.-Japan Relations

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Thomas L. Friedman's impatience toward the Japanese intransigence in opening up auto and auto-parts markets is understandable (column, April 16). One need not be a "Japan basher" to be exasperated by the glacial speed of progress in solving what is a mutual problem in Japan-United States bilateral relations: the massive imbalance of trade between the two countries.
Whatever may be the cause of this problem, the lack of timely cooperation from Tokyo has not helped. Though the Japanese Government has made much progress in liberalizing and globalizing Japan's economy, not inconsequential vestiges of the "developmental state" abound in many sectors. However, in the automotive sector, the short-term perspective of American entrepreneurial capitalism is as much to blame as the Japanese Government's industrial policy. 
 Tokyo was not solely responsible for the reduction of United States share of the Japanese auto market from 60 percent in 1953 to 1 percent in 1960, as Mr. Friedman implies. The fault also lies with the failure of the United States automakers in the 1950's to see Japan as an important emerging (let alone, strategic) market, deserving continued investments and marketing efforts.
The American automakers were not simply driven out but, given the low rates of return on their investments, abandoned the Japanese market for greener pastures elsewhere. The reduction in the United States share of the Japanese automotive market was not only the result of political decisions made in Tokyo, but short-term, bottom-line corporate decisions made in Detroit.
Mr. Friedman must surely agree that the situation involving Chrysler is indicative of the self-defeating, short-term perspective that has contributed to America's massive trade deficit with Japan. If Kirk Kerkorian and Lee A. Iacocca succeed in their buyout bid, the shareholder value may be enhanced in the short run, but in the long run it would leave Chrysler in a weakened position to compete against its Japanese rivals, not only in Japan but here in the United States.
 
C. S. ELIOT KANG
Asst. Professor of Political Science
Northern Illinois University
DeKalb, Ill., April 16, 1995

HEADLINE: Essay;
The Hanging of Flor

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The dictatorial regime in Singapore, long critical of American weakness in upholding the law, hired a trio of American dry-bone experts to help gain moral absolution for too quickly executing a Filipino maid questionably convicted of murder.
Last month's hanging of Flor Contemplacion, who was one of the 60,000 Filipino household workers treated as little better than slaves by their Singaporean masters, has made a mockery of Strongman Lee Kuan Yew's pretense of upholding "Asian values" against the decadent West. 
 Remember how Singapore's prosecutors and local counsel extracted a "confession" out of an American teen-ager last year for the crime of graffiti?
The boy was sentenced to lashing by cane, and President Clinton's plea for mercy got exactly two lashes off his brutal beating. Dictator Lee exulted in humiliating the U.S., lecturing us on the efficacy of torture, while the local U.S. business community, sucking up to the dictator, cheered.
Now consider an Asian reaction to Singapore justice. When a Filipino maid and her ward were found dead, suspicion was directed away from a father-employer and toward Mrs. Contemplacion, another maid.
She was jailed, confessed -- perhaps under torture -- and her country's embassy did little in her behalf. Just another maid; who cared?
When Singapore's judges sentenced her to death, the Philippine public showed it cared. Protesters in that democracy burned Singaporean flags; Manila newspapers denounced the ruthless judicial system.
Lee Kuan Yew shrugged that off; his judges rejected appeals for a real investigation into the murders, the presentation of new evidence and independent interviews with the condemned woman. Promptly on schedule, Flor Contemplacion was hanged. Case closed. Message sent.
An unexpected message came back. Filipinos erupted in fury. President Ramos, under election pressure, fired his uncaring embassy officials and sent home Singapore's ambassador. The Philippine Foreign Minister who failed to stop the hanging quit.
When Filipino investigators dug up the body of the murdered maid, they found that she had been beaten, bones broken, and one later charged the Singapore pathologists had "tampered with the cadaver to simulate signs of strangulation."
The dictator's front man, Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong, realized this had caused a rift between two members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations. He agreed to a joint autopsy, at which the Philippine forensic experts saw their suspicions confirmed, but the Singaporeans -- apparently supported by their American experts -- professed to see the opposite.
I doubt if examination of a corpse after four years will determine if the hanged woman was guilty or if Singapore's judicial system protected a wealthy man and framed an innocent domestic servant, thereby maintaining its reputation as the world capital of punishment.
We do know this: The accused was given inadequate representation. As questions arose, the accusers were too quick with the noose -- suggesting cover-up of official wrongdoing.
The Contemplacion case teaches us also that democratic values -- individual rights -- are not culturally "Western," as the dictator scornfully insists, but universal. Even a poor Asian expatriate worker abandoned by her embassy has those rights.
Isn't it about time the world's free press broke the shackles imposed by Singapore's corrupt judiciary? Here's an idea I have not discussed with colleagues (if it's antitrust, come and get me): only a united front by all publishers with operations in Singapore will stop the judiciary from intimidating us one by one.
The Economist, Time, The Wall Street Journal, New York Times and Washington Post (owners of The International Herald Tribune) have all thundered at Singapore in home publications, but when publishing in the Far East write on eggs for fear of libel judgments or circulation harassment by the hanging judges.
Kowtowing to such coercion is not "respecting the laws of other societies." Filipinos are showing us that free speech knows no boundaries, and that silent submission to injustice need not be the price of doing business in Asia.
And if economic solidarity does not affect the dictator's judges -- why not cover the area from free Manila?

HEADLINE: American Center In Paris Is Stylish But Going Broke

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: PARIS, April 23

 BODY:
In an urban landscape transformed in recent years by monumental architectural projects paid for by the national Government, the new American Center in Paris stood out not only as an exciting example of New World panache but also as an expression of faith in nongovernmental financing of the arts.
Designed by Frank Gehry with contrasting classical and Cubist facades, the $41 million building opened in the Bercy section of eastern Paris in June last year, raising hopes that it would add fresh verve to an American cultural presence that predates the American Center's founding in 1931. But if financial troubles were already on the horizon last year, they now threaten the center's survival because the private donations needed to run it have not come through. Put bluntly, the center has a fancy new headquarters but no money in the till. 
 The new center's programming has included dance, plays, concerts, visual arts and photographic exhibitions, poetry readings, movie festivals and conferences, and the public's response has been good and occasionally exceptional. Following a decades-old tradition, the center has focused on avant-garde art on the ground that more conventional art is already well represented in Paris.
Some of the most successful recent programs have been a conference series called "War and Memory," a Bill Viola installation, Toni Morrison and Max Roach performances and a gay and lesbian film festival. "Some say we should be more mainstream to attract the crowds," said Frederick B. Henry, the center's new chairman, "but we don't think that's the answer."
The center has annual revenues of around $1 million, but it needs six times that much to function as planned. It has been able to maintain a cultural program only by dipping into a $6.5 million endowment provided largely by a matching grant from the Frederick Weisman Company of California.
"This gives us 12 to 18 months' breathing time to develop a solution," said Mr. Henry, who also heads the New York-based Bohen Foundation. And that solution, he went on, must inevitably involve "a radical restructuring" of the way the center is financed.
To underscore the dimension of the crisis, Mr. Henry and Marie-Claude Beaud, the center's first non-American executive director, have even gone so far as to suggest that Mr. Gehry's building might have to be sold, not to close the center but to turn its main asset into an income-producing endowment. "It's as if we'd bought a Ferrari that used very expensive fuel, and we didn't put enough money aside to buy the fuel," Mr. Henry said during a recent visit to Paris. "We are in the ironic but not at all uncommon situation where we cannot afford our greatest asset." In hindsight, he added, the center should perhaps have spent less on its new building and funneled more into its endowment.
Yet when the decision to build a new center was made in the mid-1980's, the outlook was rosier. Thanks to a real-estate boom, the center's old premises on Boulevard Raspail in Montparnasse were sold for $42 million. And the center's longtime leaders, Judith Pisar and Henry Pillsbury, were eager to do something dramatic.
"The institution was a cultural jewel on the French- American landscape," said Mrs. Pisar, who was the center's chairwoman from 1977 to 1994. "It had a tremendous draw. But the old building no longer served our needs. We wanted the new building to be a cultural statement."
One of the new center's proudest features is a 400-seat theater with a spacious high-tech stage. Performers love it and audiences love it, but even when all tickets are sold, the theater cannot cover its operating and production costs. "It will always have to be subsidized," Mr. Henry said.
Mr. Pillsbury, the center's executive director from 1969 until last year, said he remained convinced that "we did exactly the right thing" in building the new center and that "time will prove us right." But he conceded that fund-raising projections of the late 1980's were too optimistic.
Ms. Beaud, who has headed the Cartier Foundation for Contemporary Art, was quick to discover this when she took up her post in September last year. "I knew the center would be very expensive to run," she said, "but lots of promises of financial donations were never kept. Our first programs were meant to be already financed, but we had to pay for them." The reasons were obvious. Both the French and American economies had passed through difficult periods, many corporations had cut their support for the arts, the demands of American nonprofit foundations had increased, and as the United States looked inward, in Mrs. Pisar's words, "it was difficult for an American Center in Paris to compete."
Thus, what is now at stake is not only the center's role as a window for contemporary American creativity but also the very notion that nongovernmental subsidies can sustain a major cultural institution, at least in a country like France with a deeply entrenched tradition of state financing of the arts. Any thoughts that France might step in to save the day have been dispelled. Ms. Beaud said her efforts to persuade the Paris municipal government that it had an interest in supporting the American Center were quickly rebuffed. Her request for a $12.7 million short-term loan from one major bank was also turned down.
The only remaining avenue is to seek support in the United States. "Some people are scared of the slogan 'Save the American Center,' but that's where we stand," Ms. Beaud said. "We're in a great building; we have a tradition; we're a unique institution. We have to get our message across so that people in the United States understand."
Controversy continues over the new center's location in an area of Paris dominated by the Gare de Lyon, the Economy Ministry and the Omnisports Palace but far from many residential districts. Further, plans to build a footbridge across the Seine to link the center to the new National Library as well as to open a subway station beside the center have now been postponed until early 1998. But neither Mr. Henry nor Ms. Beaud calls location a problem. "The development of Bercy has been slower than we hoped, but it will come," Mr. Henry said. "More important is to create a frisson around what we are doing. We want people to think, 'What's happening at the American Center?' and 'Let's go to the American Center to see what's on.' "
For the moment, though, the institution's financial crisis blocks the path to the future. The center must not only raise operating capital and build up its endowment; it also needs well over $2 million to install a restaurant and complete its 26 artists' residences.
One plan is to lease the 26 apartments to American universities and cultural institutions for use by visiting artists and academics. But the most daring option remains that of selling the building to some foundation or corporation that, in exchange for name recognition, would allow the center to continue to operate on the premises. "We wouldn't move out," Mr. Henry insisted. "Our objective is to stay here and carry out our cultural mission."

HEADLINE: Treasury Sale Calendar Offers Bills and Notes

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financings this week is confined to the bills and notes markets, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills. On Tuesday, the Treasury will auction two-year notes, followed by five-year notes on Wednesday and one-year bills on Thursday.
Government agency issues being priced this week include a financing by the Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation. The three-part issue of consolidated systemwide bonds totals $2.475 billion. 
 By the close of the New York cash market on Thursday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was 5.60 percent and a six-month bill was 5.69 percent. In when-issued trading, the two-year note was being offered at a rate to yield 6.44 percent and a five-year note at a rate to yield 6.75 percent. The rate on a one-year bill was 5.77 percent.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. Sees Global Growth But Slower Pace for the U.S.

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
In its latest survey of global economic conditions, the International Monetary Fund predicted that the economic recovery would gather steam in most of the world, although it forecast a significant slowdown in the United States this year and next.
The I.M.F. predicted that the world economy would expand by 3.8 percent this year and 4.2 percent in 1996. These would be the hihgest rates since a 4.6 percent surge in 1988. Global economic output grew by 3.7 percent last year, up sharply from 2.5 percent in 1993. 
 The I.M.F. projected that gross domestic product in the United States would rise by 3.2 percent this year and drop to 1.9 percent in 1996.
The I.M.F. said significant risks to its forecast came from fears that Mexico's economic crisis could spill over to other countries and that the dollar would continue to plunge. The dollar has dropped to record lows against both the yen and the German mark.
The dollar was expected to be the chief topic when finance ministers and central bank presidents of the world's seven leading industrial economies -- the United States, Japan, Germany, Britain, France, Italy and Canada -- meet in Washington on Tuesday to prepare for spring meetings of the 179-nation I.M.F. and the World Bank.
The I.M.F.'s managing director, Michel Camdessus, took the unusual step last week of publicly urging the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates as a way of defending the dollar even though the Clinton Administration is worried that further Fed tightening could turn an economic slowdown into an outright recession.
The I.M.F. used today's release of its economic forecast to elaborate on Mr. Camdessus's arguments, noting that a rise in United States rates would be especially appropriate given that both Germany and Japan have reduced their rates in the last two weeks.
Higher American interest rates in relation to Japan and Germany would serve to bolster the United States currency because dollar-denominated investments would offer a greater rate of return.

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home;
Cupiditas Vincit Omnia

BYLINE: By ANTHONY LEWIS 

 BODY:
"We have an obligation tonight to talk about the legacy we're leaving our children and grandchildren." So Newt Gingrich said in his talk to the nation two weeks ago. "No truly moral civilization would burden its children with the economic excesses of the parents and grandparents."
Speaker Gingrich's concern for what we shall leave our grandchildren would be more convincing if he worried about leaving them not only a burdensome debt but a country of despoiled land, air and water. 
 Economic arrangements are temporary. This Congress may decide to victimize the poor, deny welfare to young women with babies, make it hard for people injured by defective products to sue. A later Congress can change those decisions.
But destruction of our surroundings is for keeps. An extinct bird or animal cannot be recreated. A wetland covered with concrete will not again nurture life.
A moral civilization, to use Mr. Gingrich's good phrase, must take the long view. It does not burden future generations with polluted water or denuded forests in order to let someone turn a quick profit now.
But that is exactly the tradeoff that legislation rushed through the Gingrich-dominated House would make: sacrificing the future diversity and richness of our natural resources for the short-term profit of a few. Plunder now and let tomorrow worry about itself: That is the common theme of several bills designed to strip away legal protections of the environment.
There are measures to gut the Clean Water Act and the endangered species law. Another would effectively prevent the Environmental Protection Agency from issuing or enforcing regulations to prevent pollution.
But the most menacing bill is one that would define as a constitutional "taking" of property any environmental regulation that substantially reduced an owner's ability to use property as he wished. That innocent-sounding idea would make it economically impossible to impose many, perhaps most, environmental restrictions for the benefit of future generations.
One example shows how devastating the "takings" legislation would be. It comes from a story by Charles McCoy in The Wall Street Journal of April 4.
The Central Valley of California, which would otherwise be a semi-desert, has been made highly productive by vast amounts of irrigation water supplied from far away by government projects. Farming corporations get the water at subsidized rates that are about one-tenth of the true cost.
So much water is being pumped out of California rivers that salmon runs are drying up. State and Federal authorities want to keep more of the water in the rivers to save the salmon. But under the bill passed by the House, Central Valley farmers would have to be compensated for what they say would be taking of their "property" -- the irrigation water -- at exorbitant cost.
The McCoy story quoted a California farm lobbyist, Jason Peltier, as saying, "We have a right to that water, and if the government wants it for fish, they have to pay us." And pay at the economic rate for water there, he said: 10 times what the water actually costs the farmers.
That theory is proof of the old adage, "No good deed goes unpunished." The Government makes Central Valley farmers prosperous by bringing water hundreds of miles and selling it to them at discount rates. Now, when some of the water is needed somewhere else, the farmers want to hijack the Government. That means us.
Even in straightforward economic terms, it is a foolish idea to gut environmental laws. Canada and Spain have lately been in conflict about fishing off Newfoundland, for the inescapable reason that the fish are running out. All kinds of things will run out, or be ruined, if we remove safeguards.
The safeguards imposed over the last 30 years have worked well. Our air is cleaner, our water more likely to be safe for swimming and drinking, more of our forests self-sustaining. Why would we want to turn back from that success?
The reason is greed: nothing more complicated than that. Lawyers and lobbyists for various industries sat in Congressional committee rooms and wrote this ripper legislation. They do not care about their grandchildren, or ours. They want their money up front.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Fortune Adds Service Sector To Its '500' List Of Corporations

BYLINE: By DEIRDRE CARMODY 

 BODY:
After 40 years of publishing its benchmark Fortune 500 list -- an annual compilation of the 500 largest industrial corporations in America -- Fortune magazine is making a dramatic change.
Having decided that its list no longer reflected the top level of American business, Fortune will announce Tuesday that for the first time since 1955 the 500 list will include service corporations -- banks, life insurance companies, utilities and so on -- as well as industrial ones. 
 This means that companies like J. P. Morgan, Metropolitan Life, Travelers, American Express, AT&T and Viacom are now on the list. The new Fortune 500 issue will be dated May 15 and arrive on newsstands on May 1.
The Fortune 500 rankings are a measure of standing in the business community; inclusion is considered an enormous marketing advantage and companies trumpet it in advertisements and company reports. Cities and states, in their efforts to attract industry, boast about the number of Fortune 500 companies they have.
It is hardly a secret that the industrial sector is no longer at the center of corporate America, as it was when the list was started in 1955. Indeed, few magazines have been as diligent as Fortune in tracking America's shift to a predominantly service economy.
"If you are writing about the new economy and your list isn't reflecting it, you begin to worry," said John Huey, managing editor of the magazine. "Is Microsoft a manufacturing or a service corporation? It doesn't really matter."
Not only have the lines between industrial and service companies become more blurred, but industrials have been deriving more and more of their revenue from service businesses. In 1994, for example, General Electric derived 40 percent of its revenue from service businesses.
In the first year of the new list, the number of service companies has already surpassed industrials, 291 to 209.
Fortune ranks companies by revenue, a system that has long drawn criticism from those who say a company's market value is a better measuring rod than its sales. That aside, the inclusion of service companies on the list has strikingly raised the level of revenue represented.
In the 1994 list, for example, the 500th company on the list, Texas Industries, reported revenue of $614 million. No. 500 this year, which Mr. Huey declined to name, has revenue of $2.2 billion. No. 250 last year, Quantum, had revenue of $1.7 billion. This year the 250th company has revenue of $4.65 billion.
In an interview, Mr. Huey and John Curran, assistant managing editor, who was in charge of compiling the list, disclosed little about the 1995 list and declined to give company rankings. They did say, however, that of the top 10 corporations, 7 were industrials. The highest-ranking service corporation on the list is at No. 4.
A quick comparison of last year's top industrials with the 500 service companies ranked by revenue would suggest that AT&T, Wal-Mart Stores and Sears, Roebuck are likely to be among the top 10 on the unified list.
The last 40 Fortune 500 lists provide a fascinating look at American business since World War II. One company, General Motors, held the No. 1 spot for 31 years. In the late 1970's and early 1980's the company ceded the dominant position nine times to Exxon. On last year's list, G.M. was No. 1 again, with revenue of $133.6 billion.
Americans love lists and magazines love to publish them, since issues with lists sell well on newsstands. Fortune's two leading competitors, Forbes and Business Week, also run annual lists, with each magazine contending that its own is the gold standard. The value of the lists lies not only in the rankings but also in the number crunching, analysis of data and huge amount of related information that the magazines provide. The Fortune 500 rankings issue, for instance, takes up about 300 pages.
Part of the news this year is that after losing its title to California last year, New York State finds itself once again as the state with the most Fortune 500 headquarters. New York is home to 65 companies on the list, compared with 51 for California. Last year, California had 48 and New York had 43.
New York City heads the 1995 list of cities, with 49 Fortune 500 companies, followed by Chicago, with 17. Last year New York had 29 and Chicago had 20.
The three business magazines' lists look very different. In the past, the Fortune 500 companies were those that derived the major portion of their revenue from manufacturing. That list was followed several months later with an issue featuring the top 500 service companies.
The 1995 list reflects a fiscal year ending on or before Jan. 31, 1995. Information for each company includes revenue, profits, assets, stockholders' equity and market value. Market value figures are based on the price per common share as of March 31, 1995.
Forbes has just published its top 500 list in its April 24 issue. It lists companies alphabetically and has separate rankings for sales, net profits, assets and market value. For example, Forbes ranked G.M. No. 1 in sales and net profits but No. 5 in assets and No. 10 in market value.
Asked to comment last week on reports that Fortune might change its list, Bruce Rogers, director of corporate communications for Forbes, replied, "If they do something different, it's because the Forbes list is better and they had to compete."
"If they don't change their list we'll still go after them," he added, pretty much summing up how the three magazines feel about each other.
The latest Business Week 1000 rankings -- "America's Most Valuable Companies, How They Rank in Market Value" -- appeared in the March 27 issue, with General Electric at No. 1. Business Week also includes information on sales, profits, assets, valuation, dividends, shares and earnings per share.
Since few people outside Time Inc., the unit of Time Warner that publishes Fortune, know about or have seen the new Fortune 500 list, it is too early to predict its reception in the business community. But some reaction is fairly easy to imagine.
"There are people who are going to wake up and not be on the list this year," Mr. Huey said, without feeling the need to elaborate.

HEADLINE: Mexico Seeks Funds For Gas Industry

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, April 23

 BODY:
The Mexican Government, breaking a long-standing practice, will open up the transportation, storage and distribution of natural gas to foreign investment and the private sector.
The country's energy minister, Ignacio Pichardo Pagaza, said on Friday that a bill to make the necessary changes to the Constitution had been sent to Congress. 
 The Mexican Government, battling a four-month-old economic crisis, foresees private and foreign investment in the sector of about $5 billion in the next three or four years, Mr. Pichardo said.
Both chambers of the Mexican Congress are dominated by the long-ruling Institutional Revolutionary Party of President Ernesto Zedillo, and approval of the bill is almost certain.
The move is likely to be welcomed by foreign companies, keen for a slice of Mexico's booming natural gas market, but it will anger nationalists.
The state's control of its oil and gas industry has been a powerful symbol of national sovereignty in Mexico since 1938, when it was nationalized and American and British companies were thrown out.
Mr. Pichardo said state control of the production and exploitation of gas and crude oil through the state-owned Petroleos Mexicanos would not be affected by the change.
