HEADLINE: TERROR IN OKLAHOMA: BUSINESS;
In Blast's Aftermath, Many Oklahoma City Companies Struggle to Survive

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON 

DATELINE: OKLAHOMA CITY, April 23

 BODY:
The worst terrorist attack on American soil has left many of the 25,000 people who work downtown here thankful that they escaped with their lives but struggling to save their livelihoods.
Last week, business in the heart of this neat city of almost half a million residents virtually ceased. Many companies far removed from the 50-square-block area that police cordoned off around the shattered hulk of the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building decided to abandon any pretense of business as usual. 
 The major corporations -- the state's largest banks, utilities and oil companies -- had enough alternate sites and contingency plans to survive the days after the explosion without major disruptions. But many smaller businesses, like restaurants and garages, that still have doors might be forced to close them, after years of serving a downtown neighborhood that has now been blown away.
Local officials say 75 buildings in the downtown area were seriously damaged, and repairing or replacing them will cost at least $100 million.
Among those shaken buildings is the Y.M.C.A., across an intersection from the Federal building. There, Blanche's Deli, a storefront restaurant on the bottom floor, was a favorite lunchtime spot of Government employees, especially for the bean soup and corn bread.
The explosion blew the restaurant's doors and windows onto the sidewalk, their glass and steel fragments smeared with blood. Blanche David, a 65-year-old widow who ran the restaurant, was far enough inside when the blast occurred to escape uninjured, although passers-by were hurt. She now scours the newspapers and studies the faces on television, looking for clues to the fate of her former customers.
"I knew them by their first names but never did think of getting their last names," Mrs. David said.
Those who can relocate their shattered businesses had only a few moments this weekend for reflection and gratitude that they were still alive. "If I had been at my desk, this would have gone right through me," Shawn Hogan said this morning, and recalled in a later interview, as she grasped a twisted spear of steel driven deep into the wall of her office.
Most mornings found her right there at Hogan Information Systems, sometimes glancing out her window at the facade of the Murrah building across the street. But Wednesday morning, she was in her car on an errand. In the explosion, she suffered only the shock of a shattered rear window.
Ms. Hogan and her husband manage a credit information business whose round-the-clock flow of data lubricates the nation's financial system. So they quickly turned to the tasks at hand, in rain-soaked offices that no longer have roofs. Wearing hard hats and watched over by a Federal agent, Ms. Hogan recounted, they scrambled to haul out the computers essential to reviving their business.
Over machines hooked up in an executive's kitchen, the company resumed transmitting financial records on Saturday at 4 A.M. The Journal Record, a daily business newspaper the family owns and printed in the same building, was back out on Friday, written and edited in the public relations office of the University of Central Oklahoma and printed by The Edmond Sun in the suburbs.
In the long run, economists and business leaders say, a disaster could be an economic advantage, after insurance and Federal emergency assistance pay off, new construction kicks in and businesses find new quarters, furniture and machines.
"If you want to be sterile and insensitive about it, the net economic impact could be positive," said Wayne Stone, president of the operations here of the Bank of Oklahoma, which closed its headquarters last week but routed most transactions through its branches. "When you look back four or five years from now after the shock and emotion, this is something that could be positive."
Even last week, as thousands of journalists, firefighters, rescue workers and Federal investigators converged, this city became a hot market for building materials, taxis, clothing, glass, hotel rooms and space of any sort within sight of the blast.
Three hours after the explosion, the Forest Lumber Company, the closest major source of plywood, had sold almost all of its 1,200-sheet inventory, which usually lasts a month.
Gary Gatewood, owner of Radio Supply Inc., two blocks from the Federal building, shut his electronics store down after many of his windows and doors were blown out and his dropped acoustic tile ceiling dropped a lot farther. He slapped up some plywood, swept up the ceiling tiles and rented his space to NBC so that Bryant Gumbel and the cast of the "Today" show could broadcast from his roof.
The city's quickest disaster recovery took place at the 400-room Medallion Hotel, the largest in the downtown area. An hour and a half after the bombing, the Future Business Leaders of America, a youth group, called to cancel its block of 285 rooms, reserved for that night. Within three hours, the hotel was again fully booked, mostly by newspaper and television crews.
Others wanting rooms had to go as far as 20 miles away. By Friday, hotel managers told the Secret Service and advance teams for President Clinton's visit that they could have lodging only if they doubled up.
Few of the smaller businesses in the blocks around the Federal building see many benefits, however. After several busy days, one taxi company was routed from its offices yesterday when its roof caved in under heavy rain and wind.
By yesterday afternoon, the Federal Bureau of Investigation let Cliff Judd Jr. back into his Auto Body and Computer Diagnosis Garage, where he found thousands of dollars in wrecked, uninsured equipment. He was separated from the Federal building by a parking lot that was used as a morgue.
Those business owners who have found new homes now have to rouse their staffs, often bandaged, to work at all hours. Early this morning, about 20 Hogan family employees huddled on a glass-strewn sidewalk in a stiff easterly breeze, Ms. Hogan said. They waited for Federal investigators to let them into their ruined offices in carefully guarded foursomes. Hard hats and flashlights were mandatory for snaking through upended furniture, up dark stairwells and around ducts and light fixtures hanging from the ceilings.
The Hogan employees had worked past 10 P.M. Saturday at their new offices on two floors of a building about six blocks away.
Jumbles of computers, monitors, telephones and cords sat on the floors there as crews with hand trucks wheeled in dusty, dented furniture borrowed from the warehouse of a local bank that has been cutting back. "I don't want it to face the window," hollered Larque Piatt, the Journal Record's personnel director, as a worker rolled past with her desk.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Reopening damaged businesses in Oklahoma City has been a struggle. At a Cadillac dealership near the site of the explosion, Joe Williams, left, and Shawn Sullivan cleared broken glass on Friday. (Monica Almeida/The New York Times)

 The Federal Government is finding overseas operations more expensive, including salaries for secretaries at the Embassy in Tokyo and living allowances for American troops in Germany. A7.
 
Congress to Take Up Budget
 Congress returns from its recess to find the central campaign promise of Republicans -- to erase the Federal deficit by 2002 -- due and payable on demand. In the winter legislators queued up behind the abstract concept of requiring a balanced Federal budget. Now, they will vote on the real thing: at least $1 trillion in spending reductions over seven years, crimping actual services popular with actual voters. A12.
 

Business Disruption From Bombing
 Many people who work in downtown Oklahoma City are grateful to have escaped with their lives but are wondering about their livelihoods. Large companies had enough alternate sites to shift to, but many restaurants, garages and other small businesses might be out of business, having served a neighborhood that has been blasted from the earth. B10.
 
Socialist Upset in France
 Lionel Jospin outdistanced his conservative opponents in the first round of voting for the French presidency. But the Socialist candidate will have a difficult time gathering the more than 50 percent of the vote that he will need to win the runoff on May 7. A1.
 
Optimism on Global Economy
 The International Monetary Fund predicted that the economic recovery would gather steam in most of the world, though it forecast a significant slowdown in the United States this year and next. The fund predicted that the world economy would expand by 3.8 percent this year and 4.2 percent in 1996, while the American economy would rise by 3.2 percent this year and 1.9 percent in 1996. D2.

Machine Tool Orders Up Sharply
 Orders for industrial tools rose 47.3 percent last month, capping the best quarter in almost 15 years and demonstrating that capital spending is still strong. D2.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY: The Meaning of Digital Life;
Publishers Sell Remedies for Computer-Age Angst

BYLINE: By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
It was Al Gore who came up with the notion of an "information superhighway" -- a phrase that's already a cliche, a reality that's somewhere in the future.
But nobody seems to know quite what it is, this highway of digital technologies that is somehow supposed to change the face of work, schools, home life and society itself. Which is why America's leading book publishers see an opportunity to cash in with the definitive what-it-all-means best seller. 
 And it's why the angst-tinged confusion surrounding the future of information technology has created a brisk market for answers, or what can pass for answers, and for the people bearing them: the aspiring gurus of the digital age.
The early lead is held by Nicholas Negroponte, director of the Media Lab at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, whose "Being Digital," published by Knopf, a division of Random House, made it as high as No. 11 on The New York Times best-seller list of nonfiction hardcover titles earlier this month.
Behind the Negroponte book, but selling strongly since it was published two weeks ago is "Silicon Snake Oil: Second Thoughts on the Information Highway," by Clifford Stoll, a computer-security expert. The publisher is Doubleday, which is owned by Bertelsmann A.G.,
Several other would-be gurus have joined the chase. And the person sure to create the biggest splash -- or flop -- in this part of the publishing world is Bill Gates, the billionaire chairman of the Microsoft Corporation, whose "The Road Ahead" will be published by Viking, a unit of Pearson P.L.C.
Delayed for months, and most recently overhauled during a marathon week of work last month by Mr. Gates and his collaborators at the entrepreneur's vacation home outside Seattle, the manuscript is finally finished. The book will be published in late summer or early fall, with the exact date to be set in the next week or two.
When the Gates book is published, Viking is expecting a blockbuster. Already, said Marvin Brown, president of Viking, a division of Penguin USA, also part of Pearson, there are advance orders from booksellers for more than 500,000 copies. "I have no doubt that this book will be a No. 1 best seller," Mr. Brown said. "The only question is how long it will last there."
In a sense, this is a race to emerge as the Marshall McLuhan of the 90's, a popular interpreter of digital technology, the way Professor McLuhan served as the sage of the mass media in the 1960's and 70's.
And just as Mr. McLuhan used a Gutenberg-era medium -- the book -- to describe how the printing press was quickly being overtaken by electronic media, the current crop of techno-pundits, though steeped in computer-age skills, have turned to the printed page. They have concluded that the printed word remains the richest, most interactive medium for conveying ideas -- viewed through the eye, brought to life by the intelligence and imagination of the human brain.
So the aspiring digital gurus are conventional authors all, with new books and soon-to-be-published books, running the gamut from Utopian celebrations of the new technology to dire warnings of looming disaster. The publishing industry is rushing to get their titles out, desperately trying to seize the cultural and commercial moment created by the rapid spread of personal computers and the public fascination with the idea of going on line.
In the last year, especially, as personal computers have gone into homes in record numbers and people have plugged into computer networks from America Online to the Internet, ordinary citizens have been forced to grapple with digital technology -- named for the electronic language of ones and zeros used by computers. Not just the machines, but the terms and acronyms of the new technology -- cyberspace, CD-ROM, Internet, World Wide Web, multimedia -- have become part of the vernacular of American culture, commonly used if only vaguely understood.
"People have a real craving for knowledge in this field," said Marty Asher, who edited the Negroponte book for Knopf. "Many people, especially in business, are terrified to admit that they don't know what this digital technology is about."
"Being Digital" is the first big commercial success in the field, though for The New York Times best-seller list that will be published on Sunday, April 30, it has slipped to No. 16 in its sixth week as a best seller. The Negroponte book, Knopf executives say, has sold more than 100,000 copies in America since its publication in February. In a hit-or-miss industry where most serious nonfiction hardcover titles sell between 8,000 and 12,000 copies, "Being Digital" is a standout.
Of the current entries, the book by Mr. Negroponte, a columnist for Wired, a monthly magazine of computer culture, is the most optimistic about what the new technology portends. His starting point is that once all forms of media -- text, voice and video -- are in the digital lingua franca, the structure and economics of the information and entertainment industries are totally transformed. And in the future, the real gap in society will not be between rich and poor, but between the old and the young, who are fluent with digital tools like personal computers and on-line communication.
There will be adjustments, he concedes, but Mr. Negroponte is confident that the technology will not only make people better off materially but also "be a natural force drawing people into greater world harmony."
The Gates book, although not yet out, also presents the vision of an unabashed enthusiast for new technology. The central premise of "The Road Ahead," said Jonathan Lazarus, a Microsoft vice president who served as agent and chief organizer for the Gates book, is "Bill's belief that the model of the personal computer industry is the model for the digital future." That means, Mr. Lazarus explained, a PC-style rapid pace of technological innovation with software playing a key role.
"The Road Ahead" runs more than 100,000 words, Mr. Lazarus said, but less than 10 percent of it deals with Mr. Gates and the explosive growth of Microsoft, the biggest maker of software for personal computers. Most of the book, Mr. Lazarus added, focuses on how the new technology will affect business, education and home life, and on issues related to the development of an information highway, like privacy, government involvement and financing. An accompanying CD-ROM, including interviews with Mr. Gates, is also planned.
Microsoft, of course, has a big stake in how the new digital technologies take shape. So the credibility of Mr. Gates's views are already being questioned. "Gates on this subject is like an arms manufacturer telling us why it's good to have an aggressive foreign policy," Richard Kot, an executive editor at Hyperion, said.
Several experienced computer journalists are weighing in with books cast as measured explanations of the new technology. An example is Danny Goodman's "Living at Light Speed: Your Survival Guide to the Information Superhighway," published by Random House, which is owned by Advance Publications. Having grappled with all manner of high-tech gadgetry for years, Mr. Goodman concluded, "The information highway is a mishmash of technologies that is going to dribble out over years, if not decades."
Mr. Stoll's "Silicon Snake Oil" is a digital backlash book from an engaging iconoclast. He is best known for his 1990 best seller "The Cuckoo's Egg," an account of tracking a computer hacker from California to Germany. The message of his new book, he said, is that "you lead a much shallower life on-line than you do in the real world."
This, Mr. Stoll admits, scarcely would qualify as a revelation to most people. But he has received a barrage of angry electronic-mail messages from cyberspace regulars, accusing him, Mr. Stoll says, of being "the Benedict Arnold of the computer world."
In "The End of Work," Jeremy Rifkin, an economist, warns that the new information technology poses the threat of mass unemployment and social unrest. "Guys like Negroponte predict the end of mass production, but they never say what happens to the masses," Mr. Rifkin said. Since the Industrial Revolution, technological change has destroyed jobs, but also created many more new ones. This time, Mr. Rifkin argues, that will not happen. Nations should cope by adopting a 30-hour workweek, tax credits for volunteer work and other measures.
Despite the varied field of entrants in the guru race, some readers are not satisfied. "We don't have a Marshall McLuhan yet for the digital age," said Mark Stahlman, who heads a media research firm. But Mr. Stahlman hasn't given up hope. He has his own book in the works, tentatively called "The Battle for Cyberspace."

HEADLINE: Long-Running Unabom Case Continues to Perplex the F.B.I.

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 23

 BODY:
No one in the United States has apparently ever set off as many bombs, 15, over as long a period, 17 years, as the central figure in the Unabom case.
"We don't know what his motivation is," said Rick Smith, of the F.B.I. office here. "We don't know what his demands are. It's so difficult." 
 More than 20 agents from the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Treasury Department and the Postal Service have worked on travel records, tips, interviews, laboratory reports and other records in the case code-named Unabom by the F.B.I. because universities were early targets.
"We're trying things in this case that we've never tried before," said Robert C. Barnett, head of the office of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms here.
The authorities say the criminal is white, 40, quiet, antisocial and extremely meticulous. Instead of buying the electrical switches that he has used to kill 2 people and injure 23, the authorities added, he builds them himself. "He likes to show us his expertise," Mr. Barnett said.
The explosives are not exotic. From the heads of matches the bomber has moved to powders and now uses materials that can be extracted from firecrackers. "The bombs have increased in sophistication," Mr. Smith said. "Today he's more able to do certain things than 17 years ago."
Sometimes, the officials said, the bomber carves bomb parts from wood, and he often packages the bombs in wood, sometimes using four varieties.
The bomber used to autograph the bombs, placing a metal tab with "FC" where it would survive the explosion, but Mr. Barnett said the bomber no longer did that. "He doesn't need the FC anymore," Mr. Barnett said. "We can look at the bomb and know that he did it."
When a bomb is ready, the officials said, the bomber takes it apart and builds it again and again. Before mailing, the authorities added, the bomber polishes the exterior of the bomb.
The victims have changed, from universities and professors, particularly involving engineering, to aviation. One bomb almost blew up an American Airlines flight in 1979. Later the case involved computer stores, and in 1993 the case turned back to professors, including a geneticist.
In the latest attack linked to the case, an advertising executive, Thomas J. Mosser, was killed at his home in North Caldwell, N.J., in December. Mr. Mosser lived on Aspen Drive. Another victim, the president of United Airlines, Percy A. Wood of Lake Forest, Ill., was injured in June 1980 when he opened a package.
The bombs have also had fake return addresses like Ravenswood and Forest Glen Road. One bomb was in a book with a leaf design on it. Another had tree twigs attached.
For return addresses the bomber sometimes uses universities. In the New Jersey incident, the return address was for a nonexistent economist at San Francisco State University.
In the beginning the bomber apparently mailed some devices, as well as placing a few in parking lots, classrooms and stores. The first death linked to the case was in 1987, when a bomb in the parking lot of a computer store in Sacramento, Calif., killed the owner, Hugh Scrutton. The authorities said that when the bomber tried the same method in Salt Lake City four months later he was seen, and a composite drawing was released.
"He was seen, and he knows he was seen," said a postal inspector in San Francisco, Donald Davis.
The next incident tied to the bomber was a mailed bomb in 1993. "We've found people who remember handling the packages, but not anybody who mailed it," Mr. Davis said. "Some were found on the counter when the post office opened in the morning."
In a letter to The New York Times in June 1993, the bomber said he belonged to an anarchist group called FC and promised additional communiques, but none have been reported. "We'd like to hear from this guy if he's got some sort of an agenda," Mr. Davis said. "But I doubt he's that focused, other than to strike out at whatever demons he's striking out at."
One reason for the lack of communiques may be that the bomber made a rare mistake. On his letter to The Times, F.B.I. technicians found the impression of a note that the bomber had apparently written on another paper, "Call Nathan R Wed 7 pm." Mr. Smith estimated that investigators contacted 10,000 Nathan R's but said there had been no results.
Advances in DNA technology may make it possible to analyze saliva traces on an envelope or a stamp, and metal and chemical laboratories are working with the investigators. But none of the 8,000 calls to the F.B.I. about the case have proved fruitful, the authorities said.
"This case," Mr. Barnett said, "is probably going to be solved by an agent doing something ingenious."

HEADLINE: Machine Tool Orders Rose 47% in March

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
Orders for industrial tools rose 47.3 percent last month, capping the best quarter in almost 15 years.
Orders for machine tools have increased in four of the last five months, figures compiled by the Association of Manufacturing Technology, a trade group, showed. Economists monitor machine tool orders and shipments to gauge industrial output, consumer demand and business investment. 
 The association said orders rose 30.7 percent in the first three months of this year compared with the corresponding period in 1994.
"The quarter we just completed was the best since the second quarter of 1980," Albert W. Moore, the association's president, said.
Though consumer spending has slowed this year, capital spending is still strong, suggesting orders could maintain their gains, analysts said.
"Car producers still plan to expand factories, the overseas market is improving and companies are reaching capacity levels," said Astrid Adolfson, an economist at MCM Moneywatch in New York.
To be sure, other reports show the economy is weakening. For example, the Commerce Department reported last week that housing starts fell 7.9 percent in March, to the lowest level in two years.
In March, machine tool orders increased to $558.90 million after rising a revised six-tenths of 1 percent, to $379.55 million in February. Previously, February orders were reported to have declined 1.1 percent. Compared with a year earlier, machine tool orders advanced 50.9 percent last month.
Machine tool shipments increased 24.7 percent in March to $400.05 million. The backlog of orders, which tracks pent-up demand for tools, rose 7.1 percent, to $2.39 billion.

HEADLINE: METRO MATTERS;
Plans for Supermarket Caught Up in Politics

BYLINE: By Joyce Purnick 

 BODY:
IN some places, a supermarket is a supermarket. In New York, it's a supermess.
That is about the mildest way to describe the status of a proposed $12 million Pathmark store for East Harlem. The long-pending project has turned into a racial, ethnic and political quagmire involving scores of politicians, three levels of government, community groups, nonprofit groups and declaiming lobbyists. It has pitted blacks against Hispanic New Yorkers, devolved into name-calling and sent the normally bold Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani into the hiding place of neutrality. 
 In the middle are the residents of all races living in East Harlem, who registered overwhelming support in a recent poll for building the supermarket on 125th Street and Third Avenue, no doubt because residents of poor city neighborhoods customarily have to pay higher food prices for less choice than other New Yorkers do.
"This is ridiculous," says the Rev. Calvin O. Butts 3d, pastor of the Abyssinian Baptist Church in Harlem, an arm of which would be the store's chief developer. "This is economic development. This is how we can do things with public and private resources. And people are playing the racial card."
Councilman Antonio Pagan bluntly admits that he resents the intrusion of black Harlem into East Harlem. "It's the wrong neighborhood," said Mr. Pagan, who represents a different district but says he's worried enough about small food markets, mostly owned by Dominicans, to speak out. "They didn't propose this for black Harlem. They proposed this for Spanish Harlem. It's amazing. Shame on them. I'm embarrassed for them. I'm sure you have never heard me pull a race card before, but this is very different."
AS if the controversy in East Harlem isn't enough, the Pathmark dispute has drawn in nearly every other elected official in Manhattan because it involves a land transfer. That requires a vote of the Manhattan Borough Board, which includes all Manhattan Council members, the head of the affected community board, who is supportive, and the Borough President, who votes if there is a tie.
Right now the tally is very close, which is why the Mayor could be a critical player. He can control the two Republican Councilmen from Manhattan, Andrew Eristoff and Charles Millard. Mr. Millard is inclined against the project. Mr. Eristoff is still neutral; both would presumably respect Mr. Giuliani's wishes. But the Mayor -- so enthusiastic about retail development and assumed supportive of the Pathmark project until recently -- has suddenly gotten very democratic.
Many of the project's supporters point to recent polls, which, in addition to reflecting the Mayor's traditional weakness among blacks, showed Mr. Giuliani in new trouble with Hispanic residents. "Maybe the Mayor said to himself, 'I can't afford to take a stand on Pathmark because they'll yell and scream,' " said former Mayor David N. Dinkins, who initiated the supermarket project. "Maybe. I don't know. But it fits."
Unfair, says Mr. Giuliani's communications director, Cristyne F. Lategano. "He doesn't look at polls to determine his opinion," she said. "The Mayor is going to take his direction from the Borough Board." That is odd, because if the board votes no, the project dies. Ms. Lategano said: "The Mayor doesn't have to get involved in this at all. It's not his project."
THE Mayor is no doubt feeling the heat from opponents, who object to the high level of subsidy for Pathmark and its football-field size. Their main fear is that it would push out other food stores, hurting not only them but their distributors. They are, through their lobbyist, Howard Tisch, making their objections known, as is Richard Lipsky, who represents the 16 small-store owners in the area.
Studies in other city communities found that the arrival of a large supermarket holds customers in the neighborhood and does not crowd out the smaller ones. "This is an effort to get food-buying money we know is leaving the community to be spent in the community," said Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President. "I have tremendous respect for owners of small supermarkets, but I believe while Pathmark may increase competition, it will not put them out of business." Opponents disagree.
Joseph B. Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission, says critics are ignoring substance and instead churning up racial antagonisms. "This guy Lipsky is whipping up the local businessmen," said Mr. Rose, a Giuliani appointee in the curious position of arguing for Pathmark despite his boss's silence.
Mr. Lipsky says the issue is not race but "an unfair level of subsidy." Economists say that without sizable grants and loans, large developments in poor neighborhoods would be unlikely.
Stan Sorkin, a spokesman for Pathmark Stores, says Pathmark is committed to investing in New York and hopes the Mayor isn't changing his business-friendly message. Councilman Pagan says he hopes City Hall is not taking him and other opponents lightly, "because we're Latinos representing our community." Mr. Butts says he hopes the Mayor "will stick by his economic develoment plans." And the debate goes on. Without the usual referee in City Hall.

HEADLINE: Sinking Dollar Raises the Costs of U.S. Operations Overseas

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 23

 BODY:
The weak dollar is badly squeezing the Federal Government's operations overseas, raising the cost of everything from salaries for Embassy secretaries in Tokyo to living allowances for American soldiers in Germany.
The Pentagon estimates that the dollar's recent plunge to post-World-War-II lows against the Japanese yen and the German mark will increase the costs for the American military by $700 million this year. The Pentagon's total budget is $253 billion. 
 The State Department, with a $2.1 billion operating budget, predicts that the dollar's fall will push up its costs by $20 million this year, not just in Japan and Germany, but also in France, Britain and other European countries.
"The decline of the dollar has certainly caused us serious budgetary problems," Secretary of State Warren Christopher said in an interview.
Officials at both the State Department and the Pentagon complain that after several years of essentially flat budgets, the financial squeeze caused by the plunging dollar is forcing them to scramble to compensate.
For instance, the American Embassy in France sent its diplomats on fewer trips around France for reports to the State Department about the French presidential campaign. The Pentagon has asked all the armed services to recommend cuts to help offset the unexpected costs caused by the sinking dollar.
The weak dollar increases the cost to American Government offices abroad of both goods and services, like gasoline and phone calls, and salaries for foreign employees, like cooks or interpreters.
The American Embassy in Tokyo, which pays its Japanese employees in yen, now pays a Japanese administrative assistant the equivalent of $54,000 a year, up from $40,000 last fall, the State Department says. The Embassy in Bonn has had to raise the cost-of-living allowance for a typical Foreign Service officer, which comes on top of salary to account for higher living costs than in the United States, to about $500 a month, double what it was last fall.
For an Air Force staff sergeant in Ramstein, Germany, with a family of four, the cost-of-living allowance has jumped to $580 a month, up from $427 in January. For an Army sergeant based in Yokota, Japan, the allowance has soared to $1,068 a month, from $793 in January.
Pentagon officials estimate that if the dollar remains at current levels, the cost of such overseas allowances will be $250 million more this year than the $1 billion budgeted.
The dollar's ups and downs do not affect the basic salaries paid to soldiers or Foreign Service officers, however, because they are in dollars.
The Pentagon's budget predicted that on the average for fiscal year 1995, the dollar would be worth 108.33 yen. In Friday's trading in New York, the dollar closed at 82.70 yen.
For years, the Pentagon and State Department have maintained a contingency fund to handle such currency fluctuations. But Administration officials say that both the Pentagon's $200 million currency fund and the State Department's $5 million fund will soon be depleted because of the dollar's 19 percent plunge against the yen so far this year and its 12 percent drop against the mark.
"We are burning up money needed for contingency operations," said John J. Hamre, the Pentagon's comptroller.
The dollar's fall would have a much worse effect on the Pentagon if the Japanese Government were not financing much of the cost of stationing 45,000 American troops in Japan. This year, Japan is expected to contribute more than $5 billion toward the troops, covering their utility and construction costs as well as the salaries for Japanese working for the American military.
The Pentagon estimates that Germany will contribute $1.2 billion this year toward maintaining the 88,000 American troops there.
Pentagon officials say they plan to offset the $700 million in increased costs with $250 million from supplemental funds approved by Congress, $200 million from what remains in their currency fluctuation fund and $250 million from cuts still to be decided.
Some Pentagon officials suggest that the weak dollar could aggravate the readiness problems that President Clinton's critics in Congress have sought to highlight.
To cover the State Department's $20 million in increased expenses, officials say they will first drain the $5 million that remains in their currency fluctuation fund. With little enthusiasm, they say they then plan to use $15 million designated for modernizing the department's obsolete computer system.
Richard Greene, the State Department's chief financial officer, said: "You could say that 20 million bucks out of $2.1 billion doesn't amount to very much, but you have to look at our overall budget situation. Our operating budget has been flat since 1993, and at the same time we have 29 new embassies to support."
With many Republicans in Congress already threatening to reduce the department's budget, State Department officials say they have no plans to ask Congress for extra money because of the weak dollar.
Donald S. Hays, administrative director of the Embassy in Bonn, expects the payroll for 900 German employees to increase to $31 million this year, $4 million more than budgeted. The utility costs will increase to $12 million, $1 million more.
The Embassy is cutting back in dozens of ways. It has reduced magazine subscriptions, eliminated overtime, delayed hiring and trimmed its travel budget.
"If you're in a budget crunch, you're not going to send people on a routine basis to cover meetings of Germany political parties or to see the latest developments in the economic field," Mr. Hays said. "You start missing a lot of the color, flavor and texture of what's going on."
As a result of the dollar squeeze, some embassies have delayed promotions, stopped giving cash awards to outstanding employees and even delayed plans to paint fading walls. All this, embassy officials say, is taking its toll on morale.
"It's a real tragedy," Mr. Hays said. "We're being forced to eat our own tail to survive. That's no way to prepare for the future."

HEADLINE: TERROR IN OKLAHOMA: THE ENEMY;
New Images of Terror: Extremists in Heartland

BYLINE: By SERGE SCHMEMANN 

 BODY:
When news of the Oklahoma City explosion first spread, it was invariably depicted as an alien stab directly at America's heretofore invulnerable and innocent heartland. But when the suspect turned out to be a white extremist from a small town near Buffalo, the finger of guilt turned precipitously inward.
Suddenly there was a new image of the heartland, of alienated white men nurturing racism and hatred in grimy trailer parks, of shady, gun-loving right-wing groups that held the Federal government as the source of all evil. 
 The quip uttered 25 years earlier by Pogo, Walt Kelly's wise cartoon 'possum, came to mind: "Yep, son, we have met the enemy and he is us."
The first reaction after the massive explosion sheared the face off the Alfred P. Murrah Federal Building in Oklahoma City, crushing scores in the rubble, was that the foreign blight of terrorism had breached America's sacred core, and no place could any longer be considered safe.
"Heartland" figured in every headline, in every commentary. "If any statement was made," declared Douglas Simon, a political scientist at Drew University, in the refrain of the day, "it's that any place can be targeted. After all, this wasn't New York or Los Angeles. It was the heartland of America."
The inherent notion was that terrorism was an alien evil, indigenous to places like Beirut, London, Tel Aviv or Tokyo, and if it did invade America, as it had two years before when the World Trade Center was bombed, then it was restricted to what many Americans consider the Sodoms and Gomorrahs on the coasts -- New York, Washington, San Francisco, Los Angeles.
But to strike at the heartland was to strike at an America whose uncorrupted values and innocence were beyond the reach of such violence.
"If terrorists can strike in the safe and place heart of America," declared Gov. Frank Keating of Oklahoma, "then it is an awful statement about the evil that lurks in the world." To President Clinton, the bombing was nothing less than "an attack on the United States and our way of life."
Editorials across the Midwest joined in with litanies of cities that had suddenly become exposed to evil. "If it can happen on a street in Oklahoma City, it can happen in Minneapolis or Fargo, Madison or Duluth," warned The Minneapolis Star-Tribune. "If it can happen here, it can happen anywhere," said The Daily Oklahoman, "in Peoria, Dubuque, Boise, Montpelier, in Rapid City, Little Rock, Reno."
Conservative legislators rushed to harvest an anticipated wave of support for the Omnibus Counterrorism Act, which is designed to bolster the Government's authority in blocking or deporting suspected foreign terrorists but includes measures that have been criticized as violations of due-process rights.
Radio talk shows buzzed with speculation about Mideastern connections and foreign suspects, and the threat of anti-Arab actions hung in the air. At the St. Elijan Antiochian Orthodox Church in Oklahoma City, less than two miles from the bombing site, the pastor, Father Constantine Nasr, spoke of the anxiety that spread among his parishioners, many of whom are Arab-Americans.
Father Nasr said his parish plunged into the relief effort, but some parishioners urged against holding the traditional outdoor procession on Easter night, which the Orthodox celebrated yesterday, for fear of attacks. "I said we will go outside. Why not? What have we done?," he said. "In my sermon, I said this is a melting-pot society, there is evil here as everywhere, and people have to be very cautious, because emotions can take over from reason."
But when a suspect was announced, he turned out to be something entirely home-grown -- an unexceptional white drifter who had served in the Army, lived in a trailer, carried a 9-millimeter Glock handgun loaded with "cop-killer" bullets, and shared the pathological hatred of the Federal Government that motivates most extreme-right organizations.
Timothy James McVeigh has yet to be brought to court for even his preliminary hearing; that is scheduled for Thursday. But his arrest was enough for a dramatic swing of the pendulum in public perception.
The heartland abruptly lost its innocence. Newspapers and television shows plunged into the murky world of the extreme right, of paramilitary groups with names like The Order, Aryan Nation Group, White Aryan Resistance, Posse Comitatus, Bruder Schweigen or Duck Club, whose members rail against Jews, blacks, Communists, Muslims and bankers, train with weapons, and above all, despite the Federal Government.
"The one common thread is Big Government," said James P. Corcoran, a professor of journalism at Simmons College in Boston who wrote "Bitter Harvest," the story of one of the extreme-right's heroes, Gordon Kahl, a militant tax protester who killed three law-enforcement officers and was himself gunned down. "There are shadings in how they blame it -- some believe Jews control the Government, others that moneyed interests do, others that it's too big, too intrusive, that it's planning to take away their guns, their money. But government is always evil."
The shift in attention caught conservative legislators off-guard, and many found themselves having "a devil of a time" -- as the television host Robert Novak said after watching one squirm on his news show -- trying to reconcile their positions on foreign-based terrorism, internal law enforcement and gun controls."
Mr. Novak's co-host, Rowland Evans, pushed one Republican senator, Hank Brown of Colorado, on whether he expected new pressure for gun control. "I think people are going to be smart enough to understand that this was explosives," the Senator replied noncommittally.
The House Speaker, Newt Gingrich, angrily rejected a suggestion that Republican attacks on the size and intrusiveness of government may have inspired the Oklahoma City attack. But many of the senators pressing hardest for tougher measures against foreign terrorists were the same ones objecting to any toughening of gun controls -- even though, as The Economist noted, the carnage in Oklahoma City took as many lives as are taken each day in murders and accidents caused by firearms.
In the end, public opinion was bound to cease the violent lurches common in the wake of a disaster, and to recognize that the "heartland" was neither all that innocent nor all that depraved and prone to violence. Of the six major previous bombings in the United States, one was in Lansing, Mich., one in Chicago, one in Los Angeles, and three in New York, and all but one were committed by Americans.
In an age of constant electronic communication and incessant analysis, it would be difficult and painful to acknowledge that in the end there was no sure defense against either international or domestic extremists.
The Government was certain to beef up security at Federal buildings, and the F.B.I. was likely to acquire new powers against extremists, just as American embassies abroad are ringed by massive concrete barriers since the Beirut bombing, and airline travelers must submit to electronic checks since hijacking became common.
Whatever security measures were devised, the American Government could never be sealed off from the public. And anybody could rent a van and turn it into a fertilizer bomb, and sick minds were certain to think of new outrages.
But even as the disputes raged, there were other images of the calamity in Oklahoma, images that did not wane or change with the passing days. They were of President Clinton and his wife planting a tree, of exhausted rescuers working through rain and thunder, of people rallying as best they could to help, whether bringing food, talking, hugging a victim or just weeping and praying as the reports came in. That, as The Economist said, was "democracy's natural answer to terror."

SECTION: Section A; Page 16; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 360 words

HEADLINE: Diluting Day Care

 BODY:
In 1990 Congress enacted child care legislation that was both a boon to the working poor and a long-overdue response to the new realities of American life. Less than five years later, a new Congress is busily ripping it apart -- at a time when, more than ever, Americans are in desperate need of decent, affordable day care for their children.
Consider women who are receiving Aid to Families With Dependent Children. Americans want to see them off the dole and into independence. But the version of welfare reform passed by the House of Representatives recently, which requires states to push recipients into jobs more quickly and cut off their cash benefits after five years, does not provide one extra cent for child care. Instead it cuts funding for all child care by 13 percent over the next five years. Furthermore, it eliminates the guarantee, set during the Reagan Administration, that mothers who leave welfare or participate in work or training programs will be assured of child care assistance for at least one year. 
 The legislation also allows states to transfer up to 20 percent of their already shrunken child care money to other services. They will surely be tempted, given their need to make up cuts in foster-care and child-protection services. The requirement that they match Federal funds to help with child care provisions for certain welfare recipients has been dropped, as has the requirement that most child care providers who receive public funds meet minimal health and safety standards.
Only a few months ago a study of hundreds of day care centers in four states showed that the care given by most was so poor it threatened youngsters' emotional and intellectual development. The House bill flouts those findings by knocking out money intended to improve the quality of day care
If the legislation is myopic, its consequences are a slap to every parent who, pushed to get off welfare, is going to find countless stumbling blocks. The bill is an affront to parents who already have a hard time finding and paying for child care. Above all, it slights hundreds of thousands of children who deserve better of their country.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: Autos Weave in and Out of U.S.-Japan Relations;
Made in America

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Thomas L. Friedman (column, April 16) refers to statistics that indicate roughly 25 percent of cars sold in the United States today carry the nameplate of a Japanese manufacturer, whereas only 1.5 percent of the cars sold in Japan carry the nameplate of an American manufacturer. Many "Japanese cars" sold in America are often actually made in America, by American workers, and with largely American parts. 
 More than half the Japanese car models sold in the United States are made in America, and this percentage is rising. In 1993, 52 percent of these cars were made in the United States, and in 1994, 57 percent. They were not just assembled in America from Japanese-made parts.
Japanese car manufacturers provide about 320,000 American jobs in manufacturing, research and development, and distribution. Furthermore, roughly 200,000 American-made Japanese models are exported from America, compared with only 86,000 American-made American models in 1994 (excluding exports to Canada). Thus, Japanese-affiliated automakers in the United States are contributing to the American economy as a whole.
The share of American cars sold in Japanese markets is still low. But this is not proof that Japanese auto markets are closed to foreign cars. The share of German cars in the Japanese market is 3.6 percent. German cars only have 3 percent share in the American market. German cars then have a larger market share in Japan than in the United States.
Moreover, the share of the market held by foreign cars in Japan is growing rapidly, from 4.5 percent in 1989 to 8.1 percent in 1994.
Sales of American models are rapidly increasing in Japan.
January through March of this year, the sale of Ford cars in Japan increased by 180 percent over the same period last year. General Motors and Chrysler cars also recorded big increases. More than 34,000 American-made American models were sold during 1994 in Japan.
Purchases of American-made parts by Japanese car makers are also rapidly increasing, for both American-made and Japanese-made cars.
 
YUTAKA YOSHIZAWA
Director, Japan Information Center
New York, April 19, 1995

HEADLINE: A DAY IN THE DECLINE OF THE DOLLAR: TOKYO;
The Traders

BYLINE: By SHERYL WUDUNN 

 BODY:
Hiroyuki Mizoguchi jumped up and reached across a row of colorful flashing screens to grab a blue order slip from a colleague.
As traders in New York arrived home and dealers in London were fast asleep, Mr. Mizoguchi was starting his trading day. He had just sold $3.6 million to a customer at 83.37 yen to the dollar and made a slim profit for the First National Bank of Chicago, where he buys and sells currencies. 
 At 30, Mr. Mizoguchi is one of this city's agile traders -- and he needs to be. It has been a frenzied month as he and traders around the world maneuver to profit as the dollar plunges, hitting a postwar intraday low of 79.75 yen on Wednesday.
But when Mr. Mizoguchi sat down at his desk Friday morning at 7:30 to chart his trading strategy, no clear picture of the yen's future came to mind. He had read the financial news during his 40-minute train ride to work. He had checked the news wires. He had analyzed the busy trading patterns of his night-shift colleagues.
It was four days until the meeting in Washington of the Group of Seven industrial nations and traders know that what they say about the dollar can move markets. But no one expected any major announcements this Friday. So, how should he bet today?
At first, Mr. Mizoguchi thought the dollar might go up, so he bought dollars by selling yen. He now held $5 million at a cost of 83.32 yen to a dollar. But the quiet market dipped slightly, so Mr. Mizoguchi sold his $5 million position, incurring a small loss, and then sold an additional $10 million. He now owned, net, $10 million of yen.
Then a news item flashed across his Reuters screen: Japan's Finance Minister says the G-7 meeting will make progress in ways to support the dollar.
The comment could be interpreted as an encouraging remark for the dollar. Unfortunately, it would not be helpful to his bet that the dollar would fall. So he switched again and sold yen to buy $13 million. Now he had a net position of $3 million. But later he decided to get out and sold his $3 million. "This market is boring," he said.
The dollar was up, after seesawing, but the unlucky timing of Mr. Mizoguchi's bets cost him about $20,000. Still, he took it in stride -- some days he makes that in a few minutes. SHERYL WuDUNN

HEADLINE: A DAY IN THE DECLINE OF THE DOLLAR: OSAKA;
The Exporters

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK 

 BODY:
When Mitsuo Sugiyama left for work on Friday morning, the dollar was trading at about 83 yen, its highest level in days. "It's getting better, but only slightly," he said.
Probably few people worry about the dollar-yen exchange rate as much as Mr. Sugiyama, general manager of the overseas planning office of the Matsushita Electric Industrial Company. Matsushita helped make Japan an economic powerhouse and its Panasonic brand familiar worldwide. But the drastic fall of the dollar and the rise of the yen are making Japan's exports less competitive and less profitable, forcing painful changes throughout the nation. 
 A quick look at the numbers: Matsushita, with total revenues of more than $80 billion at today's exchange rate, exports about 1.6 trillion yen of products, or about $19 billion. The company estimates that every one-yen decline in the value of the dollar cuts annual revenues, when measured in yen, by 8 billion yen, or about $96 million.
Despite his company's sensitivity to the yen, Mr. Sugiyama does not have a monitor in his office to watch the currency movements. Nor has Matsushita set up any committees to deal with the yen's surge.
"We know what we have to do," the soft-spoken 54-year-old manager said. "We have been suffering this kind of thing for more than 15 years."
The first countermeasure is to insulate it a bit from currency fluctuations. By hedging, Matsushita has already locked in until September the rates at which it will convert most of the dollars it earns abroad into yen.
A longer-term response is to move production out of Japan. Matsushita now produces only 20 percent of its goods abroad with 25 percent a target for next year.
But that is not the ultimate solution. Many of those overseas factories rely heavily on imported parts from Japan. Those imports have become more expensive with the yen's rise, making the factories less profitable.
There are other worries as well. Can quality be maintained at new overseas factories? Would raising overseas prices lead to lower market shares? Mr. Sugiyama said he thought that Matsushita would be able eventually to adjust to the new yen level as long as it can continue to innovate technologically.
Some economists think the dollar will rise, providing some relief to exporters. But Matsushita cannot count on the vagaries of the currency market. "We are not allowed to be optimistic," Mr. Sugiyama said. ANDREW POLLACK

SECTION: Section D; Page 6; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 406 words

HEADLINE: A DAY IN THE DECLINE OF THE DOLLAR: HONG KONG;
The Shoppers

BYLINE: By EDWARD A. GARGAN 

 BODY:
Richard Chen, looking crisp in his blue suit, white shirt and subdued tie, glanced at a computer screen in a corner of his jewelry shop inside the exclusive Mandarin Oriental Hotel in Hong Kong.
"Well, the dollar's at 83.5," he said. "Of course Japanese customers can buy more now, but I don't see many Japanese these days." 
 Before lunch, he said, he had sold a diamond bracelet, but it was to an American.
"Our prices are still cheaper than in the United States," Mr. Chen said. "Diamonds are always quoted in dollars, so the yen doesn't affect that."
Only pearls, which he buys from Japan, have soared in price, by 20 percent. But it has not affected sales.
"Surprisingly, the demand is still there," he said.
Mr. Chen's experience is like that of many business people here in Hong Kong, where the local currency is linked to the value of the dollar. Indeed, many economists here see little negative impact from the soaring yen on Hong Kong's economy and suggest instead that the colony will benefit.
"Look at our trade account," said Ajay Kapur, the regional strategist for the Union Bank of Switzerland in Hong Kong. "As a percentage of total exports, Japan represents 5.5 percent, and about 16 percent of our imports are from Japan. So there is a trade deficit. But Hong Kong is such a durable economy that we will immediately shift to other sources."
Among the many things that are suddenly cheaper here for Japanese is the Hong Kong stock market. Mr. Kapur said that in the first two months of this year the equivalent of 31 billion yen was withdrawn from the Hong Kong market, but last month, there was an injection of 11 billion yen.
"The stock market is like any U.S.-dollar-based asset," he said. "It's suddenly 20 percent cheaper."
On Oct. 17, 1983, as the Hong Kong dollar continued to slip in response to worries about Britain's capitulations to China over the future of Hong Kong, the colony decided to peg the Hong Kong dollar to the American dollar.
There is virtual unanimity here that the move was correct and the concern now is not that the fixed link exists but that it will be abandoned after China takes over in 1997.
At the Hongkong and Shanghai Bank, Jim H. Y. Wong, the bank's economic adviser, cautioned that his inflation forecasts for Hong Kong this year, at 8.5 percent, might have to be revised upward because of the weaker dollar.
"But not much," he added. EDWARD A. GARGAN

SECTION: Section D; Page 6; Column 6; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 226 words

HEADLINE: A DAY IN THE DECLINE OF THE DOLLAR: ROME;
The Tourists

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

 BODY:
"The mark is like the dollar was in the 70's," said Maria Massa, a friendly dark-haired woman whose family has run the restaurant Dei Musei, across from the bustling Vatican museums, for three generations.
"In those days, the Americans left five-dollar tips, and now it's the Germans," she said. "Its a return to the good old days." 
 Exchange rates have in recent years turned into the rudder of tourism. And if the German mark and the Japanese yen have been surging against the dollar, one consolation for Americans traveling abroad has been that the lira, the wobbly tender of Italy, a perennially favorite destination of American travelers, has been wilting even against the dollar.
So, Italian tourism experts are reporting that the number of foreign visitors during Easter was up 15 percent from last year, led by the Germans but with a strong American presence.
"We had planned this trip 10 months ago, so our decision wasn't tied to the lira, but it was nice to arrive and find the dollar so strong," said John Kennedy, one of a group of teachers chaperoning a high school class from Medway, Mass., on a package tour (hotel rooms and two meals a day already paid for).
As his students lazed about like lizards at the warm and sunny Colosseum, Mr. Kennedy added: "The students aren't complaining about the prices." JOHN TAGLIABUE

SECTION: Section D; Page 6; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 410 words

HEADLINE: A DAY IN THE DECLINE OF THE DOLLAR: SHANGHAI;
The Investors

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

 BODY:
Jimmy Sher, an executive with Hewlett-Packard, is starting to look over his shoulder at the growing investment by Japanese competitors.
With China's currency, the renminbi, virtually unchanged against the dollar in recent months, Mr. Sher says his sales of laser and dot matrix printers are growing steadily, unaffected by the currency turmoil. But the future concerns him. 
 With deeper pockets and a stronger currency, Japanese companies are expanding their role in manufacturing and assembly plants in China, an area in which until recently they ceded leadership to American companies, preferring to concentrate on trade.
"More and more Japanese companies are coming to set up manufacturing facilities here," said Akira Ito, general manager of the Bank of Tokyo's Shanghai branch. "Electronics, clothing, machine tools -- all are becoming more affordable to make here."
According to Japanese Government figures, Japanese investment in Shanghai alone doubled in 1994 to $730 million from $360 million in 1993, leapfrogging over United States investment in Shanghai, which reached $560 million.
United States officials are keenly aware of the shift.
"You are going to see a very rapid increase in Japanese investment," said Jeffrey E. Garten, Under Secretary of Commerce for International Trade, in a recent interview. "The last several years are no indication of the kind of competitive race we are going to face. The yen is one reason. We are seeing a real shift in Japanese strategy toward making Asia a platform for their commercial policy around the world."
If international currency prices shift by the minute, investment flows change over the months and years that follow. American representatives said the full effect of a stronger yen and weaker dollar might not be clear for some time.
"Normally, people are sitting down for a beer and grumbling about their currency problems," said Drew Thompson of MSL Express, a company whose business includes shipping textiles out of China and heavy machinery in. "But that's not happening now."
Yet currency problems in China, even for importers of Japanese electronics, are only one of several obstacles to doing business there. Imports of Japanese television sets and music components, for example, are hit by heavy import duties -- currently 117 percent.
"A 15 percent drop in currency is small change when you're facing duties of 117 percent," Mr. Thompson said. SETH FAISON

HEADLINE: A DAY IN THE DECLINE OF THE DOLLAR: FRANKFURT;
The Prospectors

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

 BODY:
Trudi Schifter's office overlooks one of Europe's richest streets, Bockenheimer Landstrasse in Frankfurt, and with the weak dollar it should be a street paved with opportunity for Americans.
Ms. Schifter is head of the California Office of Trade and Investment, one of more than 30 representative offices run by American states in Europe as shop windows offering business openings back home to German investors. 
 "We do see an increase in activity," Ms. Schifter said. "We certainly see an increase in the number of Californian companies who are reassessing their ability to export."
The low dollar makes American exports to Germany much cheaper, while the American currency's weakness means lower labor costs that encourage German investment in the United States. Equally, though, the dollar's decline means that the cost of running an office in Germany has shot up, raising a question about the cost-effectiveness of offices like Ms. Schifter's. The answer from several directors of state offices in Germany is that their efforts are worth it.
"This is the time when you need to be here because the Europeans are interested," said Forrest Rogers, head of the North Carolina office in Dusseldorf.
 "We have never been busier and we have never had more inquiries," said Gagriele Brennan of the New York state office," We don't have to go after them." ALAN COWELL

HEADLINE: A DAY IN THE DECLINE OF THE DOLLAR: LONDON;
The Acquirers

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

 BODY:
As head of European mergers and acquisitions for Merrill Lynch, Ed Annunziato has seen a big surge recently in European purchases of American companies.
But while the fall of the dollar enabled the European companies in some cases to bid more aggressively, it was long-term strategic planning and economic recovery -- not currency fluctuation -- that drove the deal-making, he said. 
 "If anything, the dollar is a secondary or tertiary factor," Mr. Annunziato said. "The way most buyers look at acquisitions is strategically, long term, through cycles over 5- to 10-year time horizons, not over short-term currency swings."
Since Saint-Gobain, a French glass maker, started negotiating in February to buy Carborundum, which is based in Niagara Falls, N.Y., and makes heat-resistant materials, the dollar has declined 7.5 percent against the franc. The decline makes Saint-Gobain's purchase cheaper in franc terms, but did not affect the decision to bid.
"It is a sensible investment, a good opportunity, but who knows where the dollar will be in three months when the deal is signed," said Jacques Valentin, a spokesman for Saint-Gobain.
Acquisitions Monthly, a British trade magazine, reported that the dollar value of European acquisition bids this year reached $18.4 billion by April 19, just below the $19.8 billion figure for all of 1993. RICHARD W. STEVENSON

HEADLINE: A DAY IN THE DECLINE OF THE DOLLAR: NEW YORK;
The Oil Broker

BYLINE: By AGIS SALPUKAS 

 BODY:
Those who buy and sell oil have watched the fall of the dollar from the corner of their eye.
"When you're trading in oil you're not watching the dollar, you're watching the oil fundamentals," said James T. Colburn, vice president of energy options at ED & F Man International Inc., which acts as a broker for big oil companies, Wall Street firms and large commodity funds that trade oil contracts. 
 Some of the questions traders were asking on Friday were: What are the prospects of Iraqi oil coming back onto the world oil market and how will that affect prices? Are some of the major economies slowing, which could reduce demand? Questions about supply and demand weigh more heavily on oil traders than the decline of the dollar does, Mr. Colburn said.
Certainly a big drop in the dollar could cause a decline in the United States economy and a resultant drop in the demand for oil. And that is always a concern to Richard Redoglina, who is a director of the energy group at Merrill Lynch. In Mr. Redoglina's daily work, however, the focus remains on the fundamentals.
"We watch the strategies of other oil companies," he said. "We watch the position of other traders. We don't watch the dollar much." AGIS SALPUKAS

HEADLINE: A DAY IN THE DECLINE OF THE DOLLAR: RIO DE JANIERO;
The Central Banker

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

 BODY:
Persio Arida is the rare central banker who is quietly pleased about the dollar's recent fall.
"From the point of view of Brazil's trade balance, the fall of the dollar is beneficial," Mr. Arida, Brazil's central bank president, said in an interview from his Sao Paulo home on Friday. 
 Hitching a ride on the dollar's fall, Latin American countries are getting free devaluations, without the tears. Sometimes called the dollar zone, virtually all Latin American nations tie their local currency exchange rates to the dollar. In the region, the United States is the largest foreign investor, creditor and trader.
In Argentina and Venezuela, the dollar exchange rate is frozen by law. In other countries, like Brazil, central bank presidents carefully manage the exchange rate, usually through auctions or purchases of dollars. They know that a 10 percent local currency devaluation today can translate tomorrow into a 10 percent jump in the local inflation rate.
Mr. Arida would not say whether continued weakness in the dollar concerned him nor would he discuss whether Brazil is comfortable keeping its central bank currency reserves in dollars. He said the bank kept reserves in a diverse number of currencies and banks.
For the most part, he said, the weak dollar is a boon for trade.
"The dollar's fall has the effect of a devaluation, without the internal effects," Mr. Arida said. "And what is true for Brazil is true for any other country in the dollar zone. Today, half of Brazil's exports are outside the dollar zone -- Europe, Japan and Asia. To these countries, our exports are now more competitive."
With imports running at double last year's levels, Brazil needs all the help it can get to increase its exports. But economists say that a realistic exchange rate is only one factor needed to turn around a trade deficit.
"The Brazilian currency has depreciated 10 percent in real terms since October, largely as a result of the U.S. dollar's weakness vis-a-vis most European currencies and the Japanese yen," a report published this week by the NatWest Securities Corporation said.
Low inflation -- only 3.5 percent for the first three months of this year -- has put enormous purchasing power in the hands of Brazilians. With the economy growing by 9.5 percent since an anti-inflation plan started last July, consumer demand sucks in imports and diverts goods to the domestic market that might otherwise be exported. JAMES BROOKE

LENGTH: 430 words

HEADLINE: A DAY IN THE DECLINE OF THE DOLLAR: LOS ANGELES;
The Consumers

BYLINE: By JAMES STERNGOLD 

 BODY:
It was a cool afternoon and a soft breeze pulled at Chris Pawlowski's cap as he scanned a lot full of gleaming new cars at Marina Del Rey Toyota and faced some harsh facts.
A steady drumbeat of price increases in the last few years caused by the relentless plunge of the dollar against the yen, and another $200 price jump just two weeks ago, meant that he had had to abandon the idea of buying a new car. He was looking at a used car, and wrestling with finances. 
 "I'm only 23, and right now that $200 means a lot," Mr. Pawlowski, a health club manager. said. "I'm trying to save some money, and I can't spend that kind of money."
Ross Allen, a salesman at the dealership, said the recent rise was already a key factor in sales, and, worse, bigger jumps were expected.
"That $200 may not sound like much, but it can make or break a deal," Mr. Allen said. "And you know more is coming. You can't do anything about it. But the ones hurt are the little people, the consumer and the people who deal with the consumers. Why is the yen rising so much? Do you know?"
He added, "Used-car sales are where the money is at."
For the most part, car dealers, food stores and other shops that carry Japanese products have yet to pass on much of the increased cost of goods from the steep plunge in the value of the dollar. But it is clear that big increases are coming, if the dollar remains so weak.
The price increases have already brought about significant shifts as the strong yen, while not putting Japan out of business, is reshaping the way it does business.
Toyota and other car makers are raising production in the United States. Toyota recently doubled the capacity at a Kentucky plant, to 400,000 Camrys a year.
Other examples are evident at the Yaohan supermarket in west Los Angeles, part of a Japanese chain where about half the products are imported. Curtis Kasuyama, the store's assistant manager, said that while there had not been any quick leaps in price, the differences between Japanese-made and other products was growing.
Mr. Kasuyama pointed, for instance, to two almost identical packets of instant noodles, called Sapporo Ichiban; the Japanese-made packet cost $1.29, while the American-produced packet cost 33 cents.
"I don't worry as much as I used to whether things come from Japan," said Hiruma Akira, the sushi chef at a Japanese restaurant, who was shopping at Yaohan. "There were some things I liked and I thought they were better if they were Japanese, but it is so much cheaper to buy things from other places." JAMES STERNGOLD

HEADLINE: Kerkorian Bid For Chrysler Is Rejected

BYLINE: By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: DETROIT, April 24

 BODY:
Accusing Kirk Kerkorian of threatening to cripple the company, the directors of the Chrysler Corporation rejected his takeover offer for the auto maker today, while dangling the prospect that they would buy back more stock or increase the dividend to mollify other investors.
In a peppery letter to Mr. Kerkorian, scorning his financial strategy for the buyout, Chrysler's chairman and chief executive, Robert J. Eaton, wrote that "our directors do not have any interest in gambling with Chrysler's future." 
 Mr. Kerkorian is Chrysler's largest shareholder, with 10 percent of the company's stock. He did not indicate today how he would respond to what amounted to not just a formal rejection, but a public scolding.
"We are very disappointed in Chrysler's response, and we will make a further comment about our intentions at the appropriate time," said Michael Claes, a spokesman for Mr. Kerkorian's Las Vegas-based holding company, the Tracinda Corporation. He would not say if Mr. Kerkorian would continue to seek financing for his proposal.
Mr. Eaton's letter was addressed only to Mr. Kerkorian, and made no mention of Lee A. Iacocca, Mr. Kerkorian's partner in the proposed purchase and Chrysler's former chairman and chief executive.
After Mr. Kerkorian announced his $22.8 billion buyout offer on April 12, the board said that Chrysler was not for sale, but that it would review his proposal. Mr. Kerkorian has not publicly filled in the details of his financial plan, but the board evidently decided that it had enough information to act. Chrysler said its board had made a "thorough and careful review" of the offer.
The directors reached their decision after meeting at least two hours at the company's new headquarters in Auburn Hills, north of Detroit. The meeting was convened specifically to discuss Mr. Kerkorian's offer.
The board endorsed Mr. Eaton's goal of setting aside $7.5 billion in cash to pay Chrysler's bills and sustain its development of new cars and trucks during the next economic downturn.
Mr. Kerkorian and some other large Chrysler investors, who have been restive as Chrysler's stock price languished, call that too conservative, implying that the board is holding back money that should flow to shareholders.
Mr. Kerkorian has said he would use $5.5 billion of Chrysler's cash cushion, which was $7.3 billion at the end of the first quarter, to help finance his takeover. That idea may prove to have been a great miscalculation, since the United Automobile Workers union, Chrysler dealers and several of Chrysler's institutional investors seized on it to criticize the proposed buyout.
Mr. Eaton's letter seemed to have little effect on Chrysler's stock in trading today. It closed at $44.50 on the New York Stock Exchange, down 62.5 cents. "I'm surprised the stock didn't crater," said Joseph S. Phillippi, auto-industry analyst at Lehman Brothers. He said the letter was likely to kill Mr. Kerkorian's remaining chances of buying the company.
In a statement, Mr. Eaton said that once the company's reserves exceeded $7.5 billion, "Chrysler plans to use the excess to create additional shareholder value, through share repurchases or increased dividends." He added the proviso that the company would first consider "opportunities for investment in our core businesses and changes in business conditions."
Mr. Phillippi said Chrysler was likely to increase the dividend, but only modestly, so that the company would not feel required to cut back a sharply increased dividend during the next downturn. Instead, he said, Chrysler might be considering an "open-ended buyback program," in which it would continually buy shares, driving up their price by increasing the earnings per share. Currently, Chrysler pays an annual dividend of $1.60 a share
A stock buyback approach seems unlikely to please Mr. Kerkorian, since it would do little to raise the stock price in the short term.
Chrysler has already spent $403 million in a previously announced $1 billion stock-repurchase program.
In the letter, Mr. Eaton said that Mr. Kerkorian's buyout would actually cost $30 billion because it would force Chrysler and its finance subsidiary to refinance $10 billion of bank debt.
"Not a single non-Chrysler dollar of that financing -- according to Tracinda's announcements -- has been lined up," Mr. Eaton wrote. "Even if this immense financing could be accomplished, the result would be a crippled company."
On the day Mr. Kerkorian proposed to pay $55 a share to buy the company, Chrysler's stock, trading near its 52-week low, jumped $9.50 to close at $48.75. No additional investors or banks have stepped in at Mr. Kerkorian's side, and the price has since drifted down.

HEADLINE: Low-Wage Fathers and the Welfare Debate

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
When his son was born out of wedlock nine years ago, Moses Woodruff Jr. was 19 years old, a high school dropout and working at a fast-food restaurant, earning the minimum wage. Given the situation, Mr. Woodruff said, the child's mother had little choice but to go on welfare.
"I was not able to take care of a family," Mr. Woodruff said by telephone from his home in Cleveland. "The minimum wage was $3.25 an hour, and inflation was steady on the rise. My situation didn't allow me to be the provider I needed to be." 
 Mr. Woodruff's experiences highlight what many researchers say is a phenomenon that is being overlooked in the debate on overhauling welfare and reducing out-of-wedlock births: the economic pressures on young men to abandon their responsibilities as fathers.
A study released today by the Annie E. Casey Foundation reported that from 1969 to 1993, the number of households headed by women increased at virtually the same rate that the economic fortunes of young men declined.
Drawing upon census data, the foundation determined that the percentage of men 25 to 34 years old earning less than the amount needed to lift a family of four above the poverty line had more than doubled, to 32.2 percent in 1993 from 13.6 percent in 1969. Likewise, the percentage of children living in households headed by women increased twofold, to 23.3 percent from 11 percent, during that period.
"One of the things that's widely overlooked is the economic dimension in the rise in mother-only families," said William O'Hare, the chief demographer for the foundation, a philanthropy that promotes policies benefiting poor children. "Men with low incomes are much less likely to become married and, if they are in a married couple, they are much more likely to be divorced."
The Casey researchers found the trends to be the same for blacks, Hispanic people and non-Hispanic whites. Mr. O'Hare said global economic competition and automation had pushed down wages, especially among those with high school diplomas or less. That, along with drug and alcohol abuse, makes these men poor marriage prospects for women who want children.
"I think many women may have reconciled themselves to the fact that they can't find a husband who can support them," Mr. O'Hare said. "So they have children and try to support them as best they can."
If there is a link between the deteriorating economic status of young men and the rise in the number of households headed by women, researchers say, the debate over reducing the welfare rolls contains little discussion of the role of fathers, beyond proposals to better establish the paternity of children born out of wedlock and to enforce child-support orders more strictly.
"When you look about and compare the enormous amount of argument about what we need to do to equip, train, cajole or compel mothers to make this transition to work, and look at how much debate or attention is given to fathers, they are virtually invisible," said Douglas W. Nelson, executive director of the Casey Foundation.
But Mr. Nelson emphasized that he was not seeking to excuse the behavior of men who abandon their children.
Mr. Woodruff made the point that it was not just his low income that led him to turn his back on his son, and later on a daughter born out of wedlock to another woman. He candidly acknowledged a history of alcohol and drug abuse and an outlook that led him to evade responsibility.
Such an attitude, he said, also lowered the expectations and level of trust that women had in him, so that he received little pressure from the women to marry them. "We as African-American men have been given a bad reputation, so therefore women don't look at us as being providers," said Mr. Woodruff, who is black. "They look at us as worthless, and sometimes we confirm that."
But four years ago, Mr. Woodruff started to turn his life around. He entered a drug treatment program, got his high school equivalency diploma and began group therapy. He found steady employment paying more than the minimum wage.
Two months ago, wearing a crisp white shirt and clutching a bouquet of flowers, a greeting card and a new dress, he nervously visited his 8-year-old daughter, a child he had not seen since her birth, and whose paternity he had long denied.
"When we first met, she gave me a big hug and a kiss and said, 'Daddy, I love you,' " recalled Mr. Woodruff, who said he eventually would like to have custody of both his children.
