HEADLINE: COMPANY REPORTS;
First-Quarter Profit at Nynex Does Not Reach Expectations

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

 BODY:
The Nynex Corporation reported weaker-than-expected first-quarter earnings yesterday and said that the mild winter and higher interest rates had contributed to the results.
Excluding a charge for employee buyouts, net income at Nynex rose a modest 4.6 percent, to $304 million, or 72 cents a share, in the quarter. Analysts had expected earnings closer to $316 million, or 75 cents a share. Revenue increased 2.5 percent, to $3.35 billion. 
 Nynex said its rate of use -- the number of minutes its customers spent on the telephone -- grew just 5.9 percent in the first quarter. That compares with a gain of 8.3 percent during the first quarter of 1994, when a spate of winter storms kept many people at home and made them more dependent on their telephones.
"They're installing plenty of lines," said William Deatherage, a telecommunications analyst at S. G. Warburg & Company. "But the volume of calls on those lines is below our projections."
Nynex also paid $32 million more in interest expenses, mostly on its commercial paper, than it did in the comparable period a year earlier. It said several analysts had not factored that additional expense into their first-quarter projections. Nynex had total interest payments of $191.6 million in the quarter.
Nynex executives sought to put a good face on the results. "There were a couple of things that went the way we wanted them to," said Alan Senter, the chief financial officer. He said Nynex had reduced costs in its core telecommunications group by 2 percent, after a cost increase during the first quarter last year. The reduction reflects the company's sweeping plan, begun last year, to reduce its labor force. Since the first quarter of 1994, Nynex has slashed 6,200 jobs, mostly through buyouts.
Nynex took a charge of $53.8 million in the first quarter to pay for the buyouts. Including the charge, the company had net income of $250.2 million, down almost 14 percent from $290.6 million in the 1994 quarter.
"They're controlling costs, which is a good sign," said Tim Horan, a telecommunications analyst at Smith Barney. "Nynex's costs have tended to be higher than their competitors."
Mr. Senter said Nynex would have generated higher earnings if New York State had approved a proposal to free the company from rate-of-return regulation. Specifically, he estimated that Nynex would have earned an additional $13 million in the quarter if it had been able to keep all the savings from its cost-cutting efforts.
Officials at the New York State Public Service Commission said recently that they would probably vote on the so-called incentive regulation plan in early June. But it is not clear whether the new rules, if approved, would apply retroactively to the first-quarter results of the company.
Separately, Nynex declined to comment on a report in The Observer, a British Sunday newspaper, that it was reconsidering a plan to sell shares in Nynex Cablecomms, its combined cable-telephone unit in Britain. The Cablecomms unit reported robust growth in both cable television and telephone subscribers in the first quarter. But some industry executives said Nynex was chary because other recent stock offerings in Britain had attracted a tepid response from investors.

HEADLINE: Borrowing and Taxing to Protect Water

BYLINE: By ALAN FINDER 

 BODY:
The State Legislature created two new municipal agencies in the spring of 1984 to make it easier for New York City to borrow money to complete a new water tunnel and repair old water and sewer lines.
One, the New York City Municipal Water Finance Authority, was set up to borrow money by selling bonds to pay for the multibillion-dollar effort to finish the new water tunnel and renovate the water and sewer systems. The other, the New York City Water Board, was created to set water and sewer rates. Revenues from the fees are used to pay off the bonds. 
 The goal, city and state officials said at the time, was twofold: to guarantee that fees raised for the use of city water and sewers went to repair and improve the system, and to reduce the cost of borrowing for modernization. Interest rates on bonds that are backed by designated revenues, like water and sewer fees, are generally lower than those on general obligation bonds, which are backed by general tax revenues.
The two agencies first attracted public attention in 1986, when Mayor Edward I. Koch announced that the city was beginning a 10-year effort to install water meters in all houses and apartment buildings. The water board approved a rate increase to pay for the installations.
The city, which had experienced several droughts in the previous years, hoped to encourage New Yorkers to conserve water through metering. Instead of paying a flat rate for water and sewers, consumers would pay directly for the water they used. To save money, officials hoped, they would save water.
The water board approved a series of significant rate increases in subsequent years, occasionally drawing the ire of homeowners. Industry groups that represent landlords frequently criticized the rate increases, complaining that the higher fees could not be passed on to renters. They said that landlords had to absorb the higher costs, while their tenants had no financial incentive to reduce their water use.
In all, water and sewer rates increased by nearly 150 percent between 1986 and 1993. City officials said there were several reasons for the increases, including a Federal ban on dumping treated sewage in the Atlantic Ocean, which forced the city to spend much more money to dispose of sludge on land, and a decrease in Federal aid for water projects, which caused the city to spend more of its own money, especially on water pollution control projects.

HEADLINE: From D'Amato, a Lecture on Bad Jokes

BYLINE: By JOHN T. McQUISTON 

DATELINE: BROOKVILLE, L.I., April 24

 BODY:
Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, in his first public appearance since he was hospitalized overnight for chest pains two weeks ago, said today that it felt great to be back.
"This has been a rather tumultuous period in my rather serene political career," Mr. D'Amato said, joking with students on the C. W. Post campus of Long Island University about his health and recent verbal gaffes involving Judge Lance Ito, who is presiding in the O. J. Simpson trial. 
 "Think before you try to be funny," he advised the students and a group of Long Island banking and business executives. Three weeks ago, Senator D'Amato apologized on the floor of the Senate for mocking Judge Ito's Japanese heritage.
Mr. D'Amato also said that he took a stress test two weeks ago because he was suffering chest pains, and that his doctors said the initial results indicated he was "a ticking time bomb and could literally explode." But he said tests at St. Francis Hospital, in Flower Hill, L.I., found him to be in good health and without any problems with his heart or arteries.
Mr. D'Amato, who teaches a graduate course, Critical Issues in the Public and Private Sectors, at Post, lectured on a wide variety of topics today, including the economic health of Long Island.
The Island, he said, along with New York State, had "outpriced itself at every level," particularly in energy costs. "And there's enough blame to go around, so we should not attempt to make it a partisan or personal battle."
Among those in the audience was William J. Catacosinos, chairman and chief executive of the Long Island Lighting Company, who recently gave up a $60,000-a-year raise after criticism from business and political leaders.
Speaking of the high electricity rates, Mr. D'Amato said, "That was a situation long in the making before Bill Catacosinos came on the watch." The comment elicited a broad smile from Mr. Catacosinos.
The Senator said he was concerned about proposals for a nationwide flat tax to replace the income tax. "It's a very popular proposal," he said. "But such a change would be very difficult for high-tax states, like New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
"While a flat tax of 19 or 20 percent might sound terrific, you lose the ability to deduct certain expenditures for home ownership, like mortgage costs and the high property taxes we pay here on Long Island."

HEADLINE: Dow Advances 33.89 Points, Topping 4,300

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
Barreling through its third century mark in a month, the Dow Jones industrial average yesterday surged 33.89 points, to 4,303.98, its third consecutive session to record a closing high.
Broader market measures also gained, paced by a strong rally in semiconductor stocks and continued euphoria over robust corporate earnings reports. The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks jumped 4.40 points, or 0.87 percent, to 512.89, also a record and the day's biggest percentage gain among the major market yardsticks. The Nasdaq composite index, heavy with technology shares, rose 5.47 points, to 828.91. 
 "The market is sprinting here," said Robert Stovall, president of Stovall/21st Advisers. "It's running at a pace of being up more than 30 percent by the end of the year. I think that's unlikely, but it's converting a lot of bears into reluctant bulls."
Indeed, advancing issues yesterday outpaced decliners on the New York Stock Exchange by a healthy margin, 1,366 to 863.
Because no single reason exists -- or because the celebrants do not want to tempt fate by leaving out any one explanation -- analysts cited numerous causes for the market's continued strength. For one, corporate acquisitions continued apace yesterday: the Hillhaven Corporation, the nation's second-largest operator of nursing homes, agreed to be acquired by Vencor Inc., a provider of long-term hospital care, in a $1.4 billion stock swap, and Chiron Corporation, the biotechnology company that owns 17 percent of the Viagene Corporation, agreed to buy the rest for about $95 million.
Corporate profits also continued to surprise traders. Premark International Inc., the maker of Tupperware plastic products, ended the first quarter with earnings of 71 cents a share, up from 56 cents a year ago and well above the consensus analyst estimate of 64 cents. Premark closed up 2 3/8 a share, at 48.
Then there was the dollar: Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin, speaking at a news conference yesterday in advance of today's meeting of the leading industrial countries in Washington, did not suggest any proposals about how the United States might build a floor under the dollar. Traders considered that a deliberate omission and interpreted it as a signal that interest rates might stay where they are, adding to the enthusiasm for stocks.
In addition, one of the most forlorn sectors of the market awakened yesterday -- Mexican stocks, which have performed dismally since the Mexican Government devalued the peso in December, gained sharply. American depositary receipts for shares in Telefonos de Mexico rose 1 3/4 to 31 3/8 yesterday, while those of Grupo Televisa S.A. jumped 1 3/4 to 20 3/4.
After taking a weekend to ponder last week's healthy earnings reports from I.B.M., analysts had kind words for the company and, to a greater extent, the semiconductor companies that thrive on growth in computer sales. I.B.M. gained 1 7/8 a share to 93 1/2, but the day's most impressive action came among the chip makers. Shares of Texas Instruments Inc. gained 7 1/4 to 101; those of the Intel Corporation jumped 3 5/8 to 96 1/2; Micron Technology Inc. rose 3 7/8 to 80; and Motorola Inc., a laggard in recent sessions, moved ahead 2 to 54 1/4.
"All of the semiconductor makers reported earnings well in excess of what the most bullish of us thought," said Rick Whittington, an analyst for Soundview Financial of Stamford, Conn. "In addition, we got highly favorable reports from I.B.M., Compaq and Silicon Graphics. That sets the stage for continued high consumption of semiconductors."
Mr. Whittington said that after last week's earnings announcements from the computer-chip makers, he raised his estimates of 1995 earnings by an average of 20 percent for each of those companies.
"For a number of these companies, people thought the semiconductor makers were like Ford and Chrysler, that earnings were about to roll over and die," Mr. Whittington added. "This is an upward trend that will last several more years, not just through the end of 1995."
There's no lack of illustrations of just how impressive a run stocks have had. Yesterday's close for the Dow industrials, in which the index broke through the 4,300-point level in the last hour of trading,, makes this the eighth consecutive week in which the industrials have hit a new record. And the index's 10 highest all-time closes have all occurred this month.
The bellwether Dow industrials' first close over 4,300 points came less than three weeks after breaking through 4,200 and one month after breaking through 4,100. The index first closed at more than 4,000 points on Feb. 23.

HEADLINE: 7 Rich Nations Meet for Talks In Bitter Mood

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
For years, the world's three most powerful economies -- the United States, Germany and Japan -- have maintained at least the pretense of cooperation and civility when it comes to managing the world's most vital currencies. Even when vitriolic in private, they always issued soothing statements in public, vaguely promising "coordination" in hopes that a magic word would soothe the markets.
But as the finance ministers of the world's seven wealthiest nations began to gather here today for an annual meeting, they have rarely sounded more divided or bitter. 
 Coordination? Not a chance, said Germany's Chancellor, Helmut Kohl, in a speech last week in which he called Washington's unwillingness to trim further the huge United States budget deficits as "not acceptable." The Japanese, who only a week ago were offering Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin vague promises of action, are back to arguing that the weak dollar is made in America and should be fixed there.
And to the chagrin of the Clinton Administration, the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Michel Camdessus, will not relent in his criticism of American policy. Today he took another swipe at the Federal Reserve for failing to raise interest rates, a step that would attract more international investors to buy dollars, and asserted that the world's biggest economies, by bickering among themselves, "probably missed a good opportunity to prevent" the recent chaos in the currency markets.
There is reason for all this fingerpointing. For all the international angst touched off by the volatility in foreign exchange markets, there is little political incentive for any of the three countries to seek a radical change in the status quo. "The hard fact," one Administration official noted today, "is that we're all acting out of self-interest."
What worries many economists is that open dissension can set off forest fires. Debate still rages over the question of whether James A. Baker 3d, then the Treasury Secretary, helped touch off the 1987 stock market crash after he publicly criticized Germany's monetary policy. In the 1970's, there was a nasty public argument among major powers over their failure to cooperate in creating a "locomotive" effect to pull all of the economies into prosperity at the same time. In that case, everyone was embarrassed into joint action.
"In recent years, there has been something of a nonaggression pact in operation," C. Fred Bergsten, the director of the Institute for International Economics, said today. "No one wanted to bash, because no one wanted to be bashed. But now there is just too much frustration pent up."
It is pent up because all the major players seem convinced that the others are not paying attention to the fundamental underlying problem -- and naturally they cannot agree on what the problem is.
The Germans and the Japanese say the basic problem is America's Federal budget deficits. It is hardly a new argument, of course, and Mr. Rubin took time out today to argue that it is wrong. As a percentage of gross domestic product, he said at a news conference today, the United States has the lowest or next to lowest deficit of any of the Group of Seven countries, about 2.7 percent.
The Germans are unconvinced by Mr. Rubin's argument and contend that coordination is next to useless until the United States undertakes serious steps to cut its deficit.
"Central banks are certainly not helpless," Hans Tietmeyer, the president of the Bundesbank of Germany, said last week. "But they must follow stability-oriented domestic policies."
Rather than get into an argument, Mr. Rubin did everything he could today to play down the differences among the finance ministers, instead focusing attention on longer-term issues, including how to design international institutions to deal with future Mexico-style financial crises. Is the group as division-ridden as it appears? "There is a temptation to focus on exchange rates because that's sort of pizazzy and it's here and now," Mr. Rubin said. "I think what is critical for the future of the world and the future of this country is that we get beyond the thing of the moment."
Washington argues, of course, that the dollar is not declining on most world markets, but the Japanese yen is rising. And that means the problem is in Tokyo and can be solved only when the weak Government of Prime Minister Tomiichi Murayama decides to get serious about opening its markets and stimulating its economy.
For a while last week, Mr. Rubin professed that he was beginning to win this test of wills. Japan's Finance Minister, Masayoshi Takemura, spent the better part of an hourlong meeting with Mr. Rubin in Bali, Indonesia, 10 days ago describing Japan's grand plans to speed up the deregulation of its economy and to stimulate demand with deficit spending.
Mr. Takemura offered no lectures to the new Treasury Secretary and engaged in no arguments, perhaps because, as he told the Japanese press later, he was a bit "intimidated" during the meeting. (That would be no surprise: Mr. Rubin spent 26 years on Wall Street at Goldman, Sachs & Company, while Mr. Takemura, the leader of a small party in Japan, had never dealt with economic matters of any kind before becoming Finance Minister.)
Mr. Takemura's conversion did not last long. Back home from the meeting in Bali, he and other finance officials began talking once again about the fundamental changes the United States needs to make.
Then there is Mr. Camdessus, who faults Japan, Germany and the United States for squandering their chances to work together and says Washington will have to wake up and raise interest rates if it wants to lure investors back to the dollar.
Such advice is hardly welcome at the Federal Reserve, which has a long history of raising and lowering rates according to the needs of the domestic economy, not those of America's trading partners. And as Mr. Rubin made clear by implication today, the domestic economy does not need it -- inflation is low, the economy is headed toward a "soft landing" and the stock market is at an all time high. "This is not the kind of situation you mess up unless you have to," one White House official said recently.
That is also the message the markets have figured out, too. And so far, Mr. Rubin has been unable to persuade them that his daily incantation -- "a strong dollar is in the United States' national interest" -- translates into a solid commitment to find a way to strengthen the currency.
To the Treasury Secretary's obvious frustration, analyst after analyst has gone on television to declare that the United States doesn't mind a weak dollar, in part because it makes American exports less expensive, and in part because it creates so much pain for Japanese industry. In time, the theory goes, that pain will become so intense that Japan will raise the white flag and agree to far greater market openings, particularly in the current trade crisis of the month, automobiles and auto parts.
Mr. Rubin has argued repeatedly and emphatically that the United States "has not and will not use the dollar as an instrument of trade policy." During a trip to Indonesia and India last week, he told reporters traveling with him that "I don't think there's been a meeting that I've had in the two and a half years that I've been here where anybody has suggested using the dollar as an instrument of trade policy."
That does not change the perception in Tokyo that Mr. Rubin keeps a little dial under his desk and inflicts another shock whenever he feels the need to get Japan's attention.
 But getting attention and getting action are two different things, and most analysts seem pessimistic that much will come of Tuesday's meeting. Of course, if there is division, it may take a while to learn about it. Finance ministers are practiced at turning out statements specifically intended to calm the markets and create the appearance of consensus even if little exists. The question is whether the G-7 still has the power to convince.

HEADLINE: Plan to Aid New Business District Rejected

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK 

 BODY:
Facing criticism that it might help lure business away from New York City, the Grand Central Partnership will not help to create a new business improvement district in Jersey City, the partnership's top official said yesterday.
The chairman, Peter L. Malkin, said that his staff would not accept a one-year, $210,000 contract to act as consultants to the proposed district, which would encompass Journal Square and the surrounding blocks of Jersey City. 
 Negotiations for the contract had taken place in recent months between Daniel F. Biederman, the partnership's president, and Jersey City executives.
"Even though I believe helping start a business improvement district in Jersey City would have had social benefits," Mr. Malkin said, "I now know that you simply can't do anything that leads to the perception that you might be competing with New York City."
Mr. Biederman, who is also president of the Bryant Park Restoration Corporation and 34th Street Partnership, said he and his staff had made four presentations last year to the Jersey City group that wants to create the Journal Square District. He said they had done so without being paid.
Mr. Biederman announced the partnership's involvement in late March after an accountant's report of 1994 operations was made public and revealed that he and other partnership executives had already devoted time to the Jersey City project.
Mr. Malkin said the report had prompted criticism from several officials, including Ruth W. Messinger, the Manhattan Borough President. Ms. Messinger, who has a seat on the partnership board, has asked for an emergency board meeting to discuss the district's involvement in Jersey City and other operations included in the accountant's report.
The report, prepared by KPMG Peat Marwick, found that the Grand Central Partnership and 34th Street Partnership, in addition to volunteering staff time of their executives, had made "certain expenditures" last year on behalf of the Jersey City project.
The Jersey City project has contributed to a current controversy over the practices and public accountability of business improvement districts, which are authorized by New York City to assess fees from property owners to provide security, sanitation and other neighborhood services.
Much of the debate has focused on the districts managed by Mr. Biederman. Several former employees of a homeless outreach program operated by the Grand Central Partnership have said that they were part of a squad used by the district to roust homeless people from automated teller machine vestibules, sometimes beating them up.
Both Mr. Malkin and Mr. Biederman have denied that any such squad existed or that any maltreatment of homeless people was condoned by the partnership.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
No Progress on Umpires

 BODY:
Telephone conversations between negotiators for locked-out umpires and their employers, the National and American leagues, produced no progress yesterday, making it virtually certain that the baseball season will open tonight in Florida with replacement umpires.
The league presidents, Leonard Coleman of the National and Gene Budig of the American, said in a statement that the umpires' economic demands "in a normal year would be insupportable" and in "this year of heavy industry losses" were unrealistic. 
 They said their latest offer would give the umpires a salary scale of $70,000 to $215,000. They didn't say it, but the top figure would be for umpires with 30 years in the major leagues. Harry Wendelstedt of the National League is the only umpire who would qualify.
The scale in the expired agreement was $60,000 to $175,000 for 25-year umpires.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Up vs. Yen and Mark As Group of 7 Meets Today

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
The dollar moved higher against the Japanese yen and German mark yesterday ahead of today's opening of a meeting of the leading industrial nations in Washington.
Some currency dealers speculated that the finance ministers of the Group of Seven nations might make a concerted effort to bolster the dollar. 
 "The market doesn't really expect much to happen at the G-7 meeting," said David Glowacki, a senior trader at NBD Bank in Detroit. "But market players want to square their positions in case something does happen."
Indeed, many dealers who had bet the dollar might fall bought dollars yesterday to hedge their positions. But others avoided making any risky moves until more information was known.
"There's a level of risk involved with this meeting," said David Solin, a partner at Foreign Exchange Analytics, an investment advisory firm in New York. "A lot of players are holding off until the meeting is over."
The dollar was also helped after the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Michel Camdessus, said he expected Mexico to recover by the end of the year. Mr. Camdessus was in Washington yesterday to present proposals for preventing another crisis like Mexico's. The peso was stronger, rising 5.8650 pesos to the dollar from 6.0550 pesos on Friday.
An improvement in the peso can help the dollar because the two economies are closely linked.
In New York trading late yesterday, the dollar edged up to 83.10 yen from 82.71 yen on Friday. The dollar also rose to 1.3762 German marks from 1.3680.
Some dealers speculated yesterday that the Group of Seven meeting might set a trading range for the dollar. Central bankers and finance ministers from the United States, Germany, Japan, France, Canada, Italy and Britain were to attend the meeting.
The United States has come under pressure from European and Japanese officials to take action to help the dollar, which has lost 16.45 percent of its value against the yen and 9 percent against the mark in the last three months.
But Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin indicated yesterday that long-term global currency issues would be the focus of the meeting.
Mr. Glowacki of NBD Bank said: "There are going to be a lot of things discussed at the meeting. One solution to the world's currency crisis just won't work."

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
U.S. Bond Prices Mixed As Group of Seven Gathers

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Prices of Treasury securities ended mixed yesterday with many investors on the sidelines, apprehensive over today's meeting of leading industrialized nations about the plight of the dollar.
In addition, with a lack of economic news yesterday, few investors had reason to place any large bets. 
 The price of the 30-year bond rose 10/32 , to 10327/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 7.31 percent, from 7.33 percent on Friday.
Rates for Treasury bills at yesterday's auctions were moderately higher than last week's results. The average discount rate for a three-month bill gained 10 basis points to 5.66 percent, while a six-month bill rose 6 basis points to 5.75 percent. A basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point.
Today, the Treasury is auctioning $17.75 billion of two-year notes. It is selling $11.5 billion of five-year notes tomorrow. In late when-issued trading yesterday, the two-year note was offered at a price to yield 6.48 percent and the five-year note at a price to yield 6.78 percent.
Analysts do not expect today's meeting of finance ministers of the leading industrialized nations, or the Group of Seven, to have a direct impact on the Treasury market.
But they do anticipate that the United States will be pressed to take steps to bolster the dollar. Previous coordinated efforts by central banks to prop up the dollar have had limited success. As a result, analysts say, the only move that could effectively strengthen the dollar would be an increase in short-term interest rates by the Federal Reserve.
Matthew F. Alexy, chief market strategist at the CS First Boston Corporation, said there was room for surprises coming out of the Group of Seven meeting in Washington.
"I'm getting more and more of a feeling that this is a battle of will between those who believe that a strong yen will impact the Japanese economy more negatively than those who feel a strong dollar will hurt the U.S. economy," he said. "So it's down to who blinks first."
This week, the market will turn its attention to a supply of new Treasury securities and to a fresh series of economic data. The Treasury will announce the size of its quarterly borrowing needs tomorrow.
The Government reports on consumer confidence today and on durable goods tomorrow. The most important report comes on Friday, when the Commerce Department releases its early estimate of first-quarter economic growth.
The preliminary report on the first-quarter gross domestic product is expected to be supportive for bonds. Economists expect the growth rate will be 3.1 percent, a much slower pace than the 5.1 percent of the last quarter of 1994.
But the overall economic growth rate is not as likely to draw the market's attention as is the report's data on final sales and inventory accumulation.
Some analysts are forecasting growth in final sales at 2.3 percent, a significant slowdown from 5.7 percent in the fourth quarter.
Chris Moore, senior fixed-income analyst with Technical Data in Boston, said most traders were hoping that the market would quickly absorb the supply from the two note auctions this week so that it could focus attention on the growth report.
"The market seems more susceptible to a move lower in yield," Mr. Moore said, "but sellers have consistently emerged when yields have challenged lower levels."
Municipal bonds were little changed yesterday as investors searched for higher-income bonds, but the run-up in bonds to higher prices has tempered demand somewhat, traders said.
Following are the results of yesterday's three- and six-month Treasury bill auctions:

HEADLINE: Let the Public, Not the Planners, Decide Future of Superstores

 BODY:
To the Editor:
"Megastores Mean Lost New York Jobs" (Op-Ed, April 18) is the typical planner's accumulation of misconceptions. 
 While the elaborate planning ordinance restrictions of 1961 have resulted in a decline in New York City manufacturing jobs, from 985,000 to 282,000, according to governmental agencies, the article refers to "800,000 industrial jobs" through vacuous reasoning. There are actually fewer than 300,000 manufacturing jobs and if limited to "industrial" manufacturing, employment would be reduced by half because excluded would be most of publishing and other similar employment and thousands of executive office personnel working for manufacturers.
The article allude to the havoc that will be created by superstores. If and when the public objects to the superstores, they will disappear rapidly.
The thirty-five year failure of zoning ordinance restrictions should finally establish that the economy, in all its details, is guided by the public's interest and needs and is not desirably influenced by planners and planning.
 
SEYMOUR B. DURST
New York, April 19, 1995
 
The writer is president of the Durst Organization, a real estate company.

HEADLINE: FUTURES MARKETS;
Copper and Oil Prices Decline, While Cotton Rises to a Record

BYLINE: By Bloomberg Business News 

 BODY:
Copper prices continued their slide yesterday on signs that demand might be weakening.
On other commodity markets, crude oil prices declined, while cotton rose to a record high. The Commodity Research Bureau index of 21 commodities fell 0.34 point, to 236.70. 
 On the Commodity Exchange of New York, copper for May delivery fell 3.4 cents, to $1.2825 a pound, its lowest price since Nov. 15. Copper prices have fallen 5.65 percent in the last week.
The decline came ahead of the report set for tomorrow on factory orders for durable goods like automobiles and kitchen appliances, which typically use large amounts of copper. The report is expected to show a decline of five-tenths of 1 percent in March, which would be the first monthly decline in nearly two years.
"Copper should be going down," said David Threlkeld, general partner of Resolve Trading in Randolph, Vt. "The slowdown in the U.S.A. is taking hold in both housing and automobiles."
Crude oil prices fell as repairs to a broken pipeline in the North Sea proceeded faster than expected.
Shell U.K. Exploration and Production Ltd. said the emergency repairs on the Brent crude pipeline from the Cormorant Alpha platform to the Sullom Voe terminal in the Shetland Islands off Scotland were completed ahead of schedule and pumping returned to normal on Sunday. None of the complex's production of 540,000 barrels a day was lost, Shell said.
"The fact that the Brent pipeline was resolved took a little bit of steam out of the market," said Morris Greenberg, an analyst at Lehman Brothers Inc.
In addition, analysts say they expect to see higher imports when the American Petroleum Institute reports on petroleum stockpiles after the market closes today.
On the New York Mercantile Exchange, crude oil for June delivery fell 29 cents, to $20.12 a barrel, ending a five-day rally. May unleaded gasoline fell 0.99 cent, to 61.21 cents a gallon, and May heating oil slipped 0.62 cent, to 50.02 cents a gallon.
Cotton for May delivery rose to a record high amid concern about low warehouse inventories.
There are only 6,291 bales of cotton in New York Cotton Exchange warehouses certified for delivery, unchanged from Friday, and the May contracts outstanding are for more than 300,000 bales. Yesterday was the first day that traders could post their intention to deliver cotton in fulfillment of May contracts. None did.
Cotton for delivery in May rose 1.38 cent, to settle at $1.1688 a pound, a record high.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;
The world-class sign-scape of Times Square attracts its first Chinese marketer.

BYLINE: By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
TIMES SQUARE will soon add another language to the many tongues used to pitch products from the colorful cacophony of its oversized outdoor posters: Chinese.
The San Jiu Enterprise Group, a powerful Chinese company with Western investors and ties to the Chinese military, has signed a yearlong contract to sponsor a billboard atop two buildings at the southeast corner of Seventh Avenue and 48th Street. The sign will promote a drug company owned by San Jiu (pronounced San JOE), the 999 Pharmaceutical Company, which describes itself as China's largest. 
 The painted vinyl sign, being leased to San Jiu by Van Wagner Communications in New York, is believed to be the first notable presence of a Chinese advertiser in the neighborhood. It is scheduled to appear Monday, but may be posted as soon as Friday, in a space now occupied by Union Bay Sportswear to promote denim overalls. The cost of the sign's lease is estimated at $20,000 to $25,000 a month, or $240,000 to $300,000 a year.
San Jiu "is looking for an international platform to make a statement," said Wei-Tai Kwok, managing director of Dae Advertising, the San Francisco agency hired to handle the development and introduction of the billboard.
"And if you're looking for an international advertising platform," Mr. Kwok added yesterday in an interview during a visit to New York, "there's nothing like Times Square."
Executives at Van Wagner hope the sign is a harbinger of more Chinese advertisers in Times Square. They liken it to the billboards that a handful of Japanese and South Korean marketers began sponsoring in the 1970's and that have subsequently come to rival the spectaculars of American advertisers in number and prominence.
"We view this as the beginning of a long and mutually prosperous relationship," said Tom Turner, vice president of Van Wagner.
"We're defensive about overselling the value of Times Square," he added, "but here's a classic example of a company that wants to do something for the first time to raise awareness of its name." The Japanese and South Korean marketers that now write their names across Times Square in vinyl and neon include Canon, Fuji, Goldstar, JVC, Konica, Olympus, Samsung, Sony and Suntory.
The San Jiu sign will be in two parts, the larger of which will be 30 feet high by 40 feet wide. It will bear the 999 Pharmaceutical name in Arabic numbers and English letters and the Chinese characters for "San Jiu yao ye" or, as Mr. Kwok translated, "Three Nine Drug Company."
Through 999 Pharmaceutical, San Jiu, which is based in the Shenzhen special economic zone that borders Hong Kong, sells traditional Chinese medicines like herbal remedies that are marketed in Southeast Asia as well as China and Hong Kong.
The company sponsors what The South China Morning Post calls the world's largest neon advertisement, on the Sheung Wan waterfront of Hong Kong harbor, as well as ads in China on venues like blimps and even airport control towers.
Its medicines are made in Western-style dosage forms like capsules, pills and tablets and packaged in Western-style bottles and boxes. Last year, 999 Pharmaceutical, its San Francisco-based American subsidiary and its American distributor suspended United States distribution of its flagship product, a stomach-remedy capsule known as Wei Tai 999, after the Food and Drug Administration said the package made unproven health claims.
Rather than sell products to American consumers, Mr. Kwok said, the Times Square billboard will be aimed at North American drug makers to alert them that San Jiu "wants to partner with them and distribute their pharmaceutical products in China." When San Jiu executives hired Dae last year, he added, they already "had their minds made up when they came to us: 'We want Times Square.' "
The largest shareholder in San Jiu is the People's Liberation Army of China, which owns more than 20,000 businesses as part of extensive commercial and entrepreneurial efforts being undertaken by the nation's military-industrial complex. Among the Western investors in San Jiu are an Asian unit of Citicorp and two investment funds, the Tudor Investments Group, owned by the financier Paul Tudor Jones, and Paloma Partners L. P.
San Jiu is already thinking about when its contract on the sign atop 717-719 Seventh Avenue expires.
"We really think they're looking to be in Times Square on a long-term basis," Mr. Turner said. Indeed, Mr. Kwok said, the company's contract with Van Wagner includes a clause to upgrade the lease "if we want to move" -- perhaps to a site offering the potential to advertise in neon.
They say the neon lights are bright on Broadway. But in 999 ways?

SECTION: Section C; Page 4; Column 1; Science Desk; The Environment Page

LENGTH: 1465 words

HEADLINE: Congress Asks, Is Nature Worth More Than a Shopping Mall?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

 BODY:
INCREASINGLY over the last few years, Federal regulators have been criticized on the ground that they spent billions of dollars to attack environmental and health threats without adequately considering whether the benefits justified the costs.
In cleaning up toxic waste, for example, is it really worth the expense to make the site as spotless as a kitchen? Might some of the money be better spent on another problem? 
 In February the House of Representatives passed a bill requiring analysis of the costs and benefits, and comparison of the relative seriousness of environmental and health risks, before any regulation expected to result in an annual cost of $25 million or more can be issued. Similar legislation is soon to be considered by the Senate.
Who could argue with such a rational proposition?
Lots of people.
The main problem, say many experts in cost-benefit analysis and the assessment of risk, is that these analytical tools are too inexact, too prone to large margins of error, too dependent on assumptions and too riddled with value judgments -- necessarily so -- to be employed in the way in which the House bill stipulates.
How much, for instance, is an endangered ecosystem worth compared with the commercial or industrial development that could replace it? Many experts say that scientists and economists do not yet know nearly enough to answer the question quantitatively; that in the end, the attempt would often boil down to a subjective reckoning. Yet the emerging new legislation could require in some cases that the question of costs and benefits be addressed when land use is regulated under the Endangered Species Act. This would be especially true if, as has been discussed in the Senate, the requirement is broadened to include any case in which there might be a "significant impact" on the economy.
Risks to health as a result of environmental contamination -- and therefore the benefits of reducing them -- are considered somewhat easier to assess, but even there the ignorance quotient and the margin of error remain large, experts say. "At their best, risk assessments contain data gaps and rely on assumptions that can affect the outcome by 100 or 1,000 fold or more," seven prominent authorities on the subject said in a letter to the Senate earlier this month. They wrote that while cost-benefit analysis has a place in public policy, it is "no magic wand," and "public policy is not well served by pretending science can do what it cannot."
One of the seven, Dr. Nicholas A. Ashford of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, an expert in cost-benefit analysis, says that the technique "is not ready for prime time, and I doubt that it will ever be."
The House bill appears to recognize the limitations of the method: it does not require regulatory agencies to base their decisions on a finding that benefits exceed costs, or even that costs and benefits be expressed in dollar amounts where that is not possible. It merely requires the agencies to show that the benefits are "likely to justify, and be reasonably related to" the costs.
If the bill stopped there, some critics say, all might be well. But it goes on to give the courts the authority to review the risk assessments and cost-benefit analyses in the case of a challenge. Since the imprecision of such analyses makes their results highly arguable, the critics fear, judicial review would open the door to interminable challenges by regulated parties like chemical manufacturers and owners of endangered habitats, paralyzing the regulatory process. That result, some charge, is precisely what the Republican sponsors of the bill intend.
Some prominent economists who support cost-benefit analysis, while recognizing its limitations, agree on the pitfalls of judicial review. "I shudder at the thought of turning these things over to the courts to decide," said Dr. Paul R. Portney of Resources for the Future, a nonprofit research organization in Washington.
The courts, Dr. Ashford says, "are just not equipped intellectually to pass on cost-benefit analysis or risk assessment; they just don't have the expertise."
Even some of the strongest proponents of the general thrust of the emerging new legislation think it goes too far on the question of judicial review. Carried out properly, judicial review "will favor those that have the strongest case in science and economic rationality," said Dr. John D. Graham, the director of the Harvard Center for Risk Analysis at Harvard University. But, he said, the House bill "is a little too aggressive." This could be cured, he said, if the challenger is saddled with the burden of proof while the regulating agency is "given deference."
The provision for judicial review goes beyond existing arrangements for risk assessment and cost-benefit analysis, concepts not unknown to the Federal bureaucracy. The Environmental Protection Agency, for example, has performed several cost-benefit analyses over the years. Some have supported proposed regulations while others have not, says Dr. Richard Morgenstern, a senior policy analyst who recently left the agency after 12 years. He is now employed at Resources for the Future, where he is working on a book on cost-benefit analysis.
Another proposed new feature, he said, is a requirement in the House bill that when the annual cost of a regulation is likely to be $100 million or more, cost-benefit analyses and risk assessments must be reviewed by outside panels of experts. This, he said, is designed as a quality-control measure. Critics have attacked the measure because some of the experts sitting on the panels would be designated by regulated parties. But Dr. Morgenstern points out that all panelists would have to declare their interests, as is commonly done in such situations, and that any overweening interest would tend to weaken a panelist's influence. Besides, he said, it is usually impossible to find qualified panelists who do not have some interest in one side of an issue or another, as has been amply demonstrated by efforts to assess the environmental effects of asbestos.
In the past, agencies have sometimes based their assessments of health risks on the worst cases -- for instance, the effect of air pollution on the very old, the very young and those with respiratory or heart problems. The House bill would require that the impact on average people be assessed, as well. A regulation might then be based on the worst case or the average case, but this value judgment would be made explicit.
Similarly, in cases where benefits or costs cannot be well quantified -- as in determining the relative value of an endangered ecosystem and the mall that might replace it -- nonmonetary criteria would be allowed, but they would have to be explained.
Generally speaking, environmental benefits are harder to measure than costs, but even cost estimates are "ballpark at best," the seven experts said in their letter to the Senate. History has shown, said Dr. Ashford, that costs usually have been overestimated and benefits underestimated.
It is especially difficult to measure the value of natural ecosystems. While scientists know in a broad sense that nature has enormous value -- not least, it supports human life -- economists and scientists have often been frustrated in trying to attach dollars to specific slices of nature or natural functions.
These experts have tried to calculate how much people would pay for the use and enjoyment of nature. And it may, for instance, be possible to gauge in narrow terms the relative economic value of clear-cut logging versus recreational use of a forest. But how much are undiscovered medicinal plants worth? Or an individual species or ecosystem with no obvious special utility that is on the brink of extinction? The answers are elusive, perhaps unobtainable.
To some scientists, the exercise is pointless, or worse, because it devalues nature. They point out that while insurance companies may be able to put a dollar value on a human life, moral arguments place human life beyond economics. What is true of an individual human, some say, is or should be true of a wild species.
In the view of Dr. David Ehrenfeld, a conservation biologist at Rutgers University in New Brunswick, nature "is not a subject for cost-benefit analysis." Not only is it impossible to quantify nature's benefits, he says, moral and ethical arguments for preserving species are more compelling than economic ones.
He notes that this is a minority view, but argues: "The reason cost-benefit analysis has emerged is because, in fact, the moral arguments against killing species are very powerful, even though economists like to pretend they are not. Cost-benefit is a kind of smoke screen that hides those arguments."

Portney, Resources for the Future -- "I shudder at the thought of turning these things over to the courts to decide." (Resources for the Future); John D. Graham, Harvard Center for Risk Analysis -- Judicial review "will favor those that have the strongest case in science and economic rationality." (Liza Green)

HEADLINE: THEATER REVIEW: ECSTASY;
Cheer and Economy In Baring the Soul

BYLINE: By STEPHEN HOLDEN 

 BODY:
"If you can't have a laugh and a drink on a Saturday night, when can you?" announces a character in "Ecstasy," Mike Leigh's devastating portrait of four working-class English friends carousing in a shabby furnished room in northwest London.
Over the course of the party, which consumes the play's second act, nothing much happens except that the characters drink a lot of beer, smoke a lot of cigarettes, become sloppily sentimental and sing songs. But through a wealth of casually dispensed personal detail and naturalistic ensemble acting of astonishing intensity and nuance, "Ecstasy" cheerily bares the soul of a society on a precipice. 
 It is 1979. As these London bricklayers, house painters and store clerks chatter and reminisce, it becomes clear that the center is not holding. Booze and rowdy camaraderie provide the only insulation from their terror of being trapped in dead-end lives that are as economically precarious as they are spiritually stultifying. Threaded through their boisterous remarks are currents of racism and xenophobia, with special worry about the new wave of Pakistani immigrants.
Mr. Leigh is best-known in America as the film maker responsible for "Life Is Sweet," "High Hopes" and "Naked." "Ecstasy," which is being presented by the New Group at the John Houseman Studio Theater (450 West 42d Street, Clinton) through May 14, is his first play to be produced in the United States. Like his films, the play is a comic slice of life that gets painfully and sometimes hilariously under the skin of its characters.
Where Mr. Leigh's films have an edge of satire, "Ecstasy" is utterly naturalistic. In the play's opening scene, its taciturn central character, Jean (Caroline Seymour), waits in bed naked for Roy (John Wojda), her loutish married boyfriend, to get dressed and leave. No sooner has he gone than she breaks out the gin and begins silently drinking herself into oblivion. When Roy returns the next evening, she gives him the cold shoulder and is nearly raped. Things get out of hand when his wife, Val (Zaniz Jakubowski), shows up in a rage.
The second act fleshes out Jean's bleak world, as she returns from a pub with her married best friends, Mick (Patrick Fitzgerald) and Dawn (Marian Quinn), and Len (Jared Harris), an old friend who has unexpectedly shown up after a long absence. The party that follows is choreographed by the director, Scott Elliott, with such microscopic perfection that the actors no longer seem to be playing roles. You are looking through a keyhole into an impromptu bash that could erupt in any number of ways.
Mick, the life of the party, is an endearing bloke who suggests a cross between Rod Stewart and Rob Reiner as Meathead. He likes to spike his beer with vodka and when fully tanked does a crude Elvis imitation. Nothing, not even two scary asthmatic attacks, will deter him from having fun. He and his garrulous wife, Dawn, indulge in noisy bickering that threatens to turn nasty but doesn't. As the booze mellows them, they become sentimental and slow-dance to Elvis singing "Love Me Tender."
The couple are so intent on having fun that they are oblivious to the unhappiness of their two companions. Urging Jean to sing a song, they prod her into delivering a slightly embarrassed (and terrible) performance of "Danny Boy." It is Jean's only moment of exuberance.
And that's it, but it's not. "Ecstasy" is as much about a party as "The Cherry Orchard" is about real estate. Its compassion for its characters goes to the bone.
 
ECSTASY
By Mike Leigh; directed by Scott Elliott; set by Kevin Price and Zaniz; costumes by Eric Becker; lighting by Benjamin Pearcy; sound by Raymond D. Schilke; music by Tom Kochan; hair by Jeff Francis; production stage manager, John J. Harmon; assistant director, Marie Masters; dialect coach, Stephen Gabis; fight choreographer, Nicole Callender. Presented by the New Group, Mr. Elliott, artistic director; Claudia Catania, producing director. At the John Houseman Theater Center, 450 West 42d Street, Clinton.

WITH: John Wojda (Roy), Caroline Seymour (Jean), Marian Quinn (Dawn), Zaniz Jakubowski (Val), Jared Harris (Len) and Patrick Fitzgerald (Mick).

GRAPHIC: Photo: Caroline Seymour plays Jean, the central character, in "Ecstasy." (Ron Reeves/"Ecstasy")

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

As Finance Ministers Meet, Harmony Stays at Home
Public harmony was notably absent as finance ministers of seven of the world's leading industrial nations met in Washington. A coordinated response to the world's currency roller coaster is "not acceptable," Chancellor Helmut Kohl of Germany has said; the Japanese see a weak dollar as an American problem that America should deal with, and Michel Camdessus, the I.M.F.'s managing director, blamed the Federal Reserve for failing to raise interest rates even more. The discord has economists worried. A1.
 
Stronger international financial institutions were proposed by Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and Mr. Camdessus to avert Mexican-style crises. D7.
 
Boeing: Profit Off, Stock Up
Boeing earnings dropped 38 percent, to $181 million, or 53 cents a share, mainly because of fewer deliveries -- 59 commercial jets, down from 82 in 1994's first quarter. But Wall Street was expecting an even worse performance, and the company's stock touched a 52-week high. D8.
 
Hillhaven Takes Vencor Bid
Hillhaven accepted a $1.4 billion buyout offer from Vencor, a much smaller hospital chain. Hillhaven, the big nursing home chain, had just turned away another bidder. D2.
 
Lloyd's: Down, Not Out
Lloyd's of London will survive, it said, responding to news reports of its possible demise. This year looks bleak, but it has "utter confidence" for the long haul. D10.
 
Phar-Mor, With or Without Haft
Phar-Mor offered two blueprints for emerging from bankruptcy. One would involve Robert Haft, former Dart Group president, but the company filed a separate reorganization plan in case talks with Mr. Haft fall through. D2.
 
Microsoft Defends Antitrust Deal
Microsoft and the Justice Department defended their antitrust settlement in a Federal court, while opponents of the deal said a judge was right to strike it down. D4.
 
Chiron Bets on Gene Therapy
Chiron will acquire Viagene in a $95 million deal, placing a big bet on a gene therapy company the market had abandoned. D4.
 
Weather Lets Nynex Down
Nynex's earnings rose less than expected, and it said one culprit was the weather. A year ago, pinned inside by an exceptionally cold winter, people talked and talked. This year's mild winter meant mild earnings. D7.
 
Urging 'Brand' Appeal
For Newspapers
Newspapers should build brand identities and imitate the way American auto makers rebuilt their good names, the president of the Newspaper Association of America said at its New Orleans convention. The problem: even though newspapers' revenue is high, their share of ad dollars keeps shrinking and just 62 percent of American adults are daily readers, down from 78 percent in 1970. D4.
 
The Risks of Playing It Safe
For a natural gas company, it's an odd way to operate. Louis Dreyfus Natural Gas protects itself from volatile prices by hedging heavily -- which is fine if prices fall, but it'll lose out if prices rise. Investors are not impressed. Market Place. D12.
 
Times Square Learns Chinese
Times Square has many unusual features, but one thing it lacks is a billboard from a Chinese marketer. That's about to change, with a huge sign for China's largest drug company. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. D11.

HEADLINE: Prevention of Mexican-Style Crisis Sought

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, April 24

 BODY:
Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin and the managing director of the International Monetary Fund, Michel Camdessus, proposed today the strengthening of international financial institutions to help prevent another Mexican-style financial crisis.
The proposals, which will be discussed at this week's annual spring round of meetings among world finance ministers here, underscored the financial leaders' continuing preoccupation with the fallout from Mexico's botched devaluation last December and the destabilizing shockwaves it sent through financial markets around the world. 
 "We need to create a financial architecture that is as modern as the financial markets and the challenges of today's economy," Secretary Rubin told a press conference, stressing the greatly increased speed with which huge sums of money can shift around the world, disrupting economic growth and undermining exchange rates.
"There have been tremendous changes in the international financial system in the last few years" as capital flows have increased in size and speed, Mr. Rubin said, adding that the time was ripe for finance ministers to review the world's existing financial institutions.
The proposals that both men offered were fundamentally similar, stressing the need for a new early warning system to spot countries in potential financial trouble; an emergency financing system to help those with a sudden outflow of capital, and special steps to aid the poorest and most heavily indebted countries, including the possible sale of some of the I.M.F.'s 103 million ounces of gold bullion.
The main difference between the two proposals appeared to be a public appeal by Mr. Camdessus for a doubling of the I.M.F.'s capital, now about $217 billion, giving it more funds to lend to countries with financial difficulties so that they gain time to adjust their economic policies in a relatively controlled way.
Mr. Camdessus said the world needs "a strong I.M.F. able to respond decisively to future crises." He termed "conservative" his proposal for a doubling of the subscriptions, known as quotas, that the I.M.F.'s 179 member countries pay.
Secretary Rubin did not discuss increasing the I.M.F.'s quotas. But officals said the Administration has agreed to consider some increase. But increasing America's $40 billion I.M.F. quota has tended to create political difficulties for the Administration since 1983, when Congress mandated that all new contributions go through the normal Congressional appropriation process even though such payments do not affect the budget deficit.
Although the proposals put forward by Secretary Rubin and Mr. Camdessus are directly inspired by the Mexican crisis, both emphasized that Mexico's economy is on the mend as a result of the tough austerity measures taken by the government of President Ernesto Zedillo.
Mr. Camdessus called the "first results" of this austerity package "very encouraging," noting that the huge trade deficit that undermined the peso is being wiped out, while the exchange rate is now at a more reasonable level and investor confidence is returning.
The comments from the two helped send the Mexican stock market to a three-month high as the main stock index jumped almost 98 points, or 5 percent. The peso also rallied, rising 2.5 percent to just over 167 cents to the dollar.
Mr. Rubin said that a more effective early warning system to identify countries facing potential difficulties would require "comprehensive and timely public disclosure of monetary and financial data."
But he also called for more effective international surveillance of all nations' economies with the I.M.F. developing "a greater capacity for ongoing and more intensive monitoring of countries and of capital market developments that present potential risks to the system."
In a paper prepared for this week's ministerial discussions, Mr. Camdessus said he was making very similar recommendations, including more frequent I.M.F. reviews of some countries' economic policy than the single annual review required under Article 4 of its rules and more pointed and critical judgments by the I.M.F. instead of the opaque verdicts it usually issues.

HEADLINE: Let the Public, Not the Planners, Decide Future of Superstores;
Can't Ignore the Car

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In "Megastores Mean Lost New York Jobs" (Op-Ed, April 18), Tom Angotti and Ron Shiffman call for these proposed shopping giants to be situated "near mass transit while eliminating parking." 
 The secret to the success of giant shopping facilities in the suburbs is that they offer acres of convenient parking for shoppers who load up with the bulky items these stores and warehouses sell at discount prices. Shoppers cannot lug huge purchases into the subway, and taxi fares would wipe out the savings.
New York City planners repeatedly fail to recognize that the automobile is part of the 20th, and soon to be 21st, century. The Jacob K. Javits Convention Center suffers because of a total lack of parking. Too many New Yorkers cannot take advantage of Battery Park City's recreational and cultural activities because of insufficient parking. And just look at the brouhaha in the Bronx over parking for Yankee Stadium.
Unfortunately, until New York City planners and politicians recognize the automobile, and make acommodation for its use, large-scale developments like megastores and discount warehouses should be put in park.
 
AVRUM HYMAN
Bronx, April 19, 1995
 
The writer was deputy commissioner of the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal.

HEADLINE: The U.S. Is Still No. 1

BYLINE: By Josef Joffe 

DATELINE: MUNICH

 BODY:
Thirty years ago, the dollar was worth four marks; today, it is one-third as much. Then, Americans could travel across Europe on $5 a day; now, $50 won't pay for bed and bratwurst. Have the mighty fallen? Have Japan and Germany, with their swollen currencies, muscled aside Uncle Sam? Hardly.
It is Washington that orchestrates the Middle East peace process. America, not Germany or Japan, leads the drive against the spread of the Bomb, coaxes North Korea and confronts Iraq. When the U.S. went into Somalia, the others followed; when it bolted, the others did, too. And who defines the relationship with Russia? 
 There are more power centers now than during the cold war. But the U.S. still sits on top of the heap, no matter what the traders say about the dollar. Indeed, power is when a country can devalue its currency as brutally as the U.S. has without unleashing retaliation. In the 1920's and 1930's, the watchword was "competitive devaluation." If country A devalued, countries B and C followed suit immediately so as to deny A the advantage of cheaper export prices. Or they would raise tariffs in order to get even.
Today, Germany and Japan just watch the dollar plummet; they manipulate neither tariffs nor parities, even as the skyrocketing yen and mark tear at their competitiveness.
Since the middle Reagan days, the external value of the dollar has been halved, which is the equivalent of a 100 percent surcharge on exports to the United States. The rest of the world submitted, another way of dramatizing America's exalted position in the global trading system. Nobody wants to wants to rile Mr. Big, let alone lose the largest market there is.
Historically, nations that play the devaluation game never win. After a short-term improvement in the trade balance, the bill comes due. Higher import prices fuel inflation by driving up the domestic price level. As a result, exports decline and the trade deficit rises again. Miraculously, though, the U.S. has been spared that fate. As the dollar declines, inflation holds steady. Indeed, the U.S. is once more the world's largest exporter.
This explains why Bill Clinton and Alan Greenspan, apart from ritual murmurings of "this can't go on," have been so laid back. In spite of the incredibly shrinking greenback, the U.S. is doing quite well. Nor, one must add, could the Fed do very much to arrest the slide. When trillions of dollars zoom instantly around the world, a few billions in intervention money amount to little.
So much for the short run. In the longer run, though, the U.S. has a big problem. America has lived like a person who writes checks at will. For almost a generation, it has bought more abroad than it sold -- hence, the zillions of dollars in global circulation. What happens when there is too much money? It buys less. Hence, no more four marks to the dollar.
Again, the external value of one's currency does not really matter as long as the fundamentals are sound. But the unstoppable fall of the dollar says that the fundamentals at home are askew. It virtually screams that America is consuming too much while saving and investing too little. The Government is living on borrowed money; so is the consumer.
When households are profligate, they go bankrupt. Great powers can postpone the reckoning for a long time. But even the greatest powers of their days -- Spain, France -- fell from grace because they ignored the ledgers for too long. It is not the dollar that will deflate American power. It is profligacy -- being hooked on the sweet poison of consumption -- that might yet lay low the American economy and thus American might.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Op-Ed

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (98%); JAPAN (94%); EUROPE (92%); GERMANY (92%); MIDDLE EAST (91%); SOMALIA (79%); IRAQ (79%); KOREA, DEMOCRATIC PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF (72%); 

GEOGRAPHIC: UNITED STATES (98%); JAPAN (94%); EUROPE (92%); GERMANY (92%); MIDDLE EAST (91%); SOMALIA (79%); IRAQ (79%); KOREA, DEMOCRATIC PEOPLE'S REPUBLIC OF (72%);

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Promises on the Dollar, But No Clear Course Is Set
 The U.S. and other economic powers promised to work together to reverse the dollar's fall. But some traders had their doubts even before the meeting ended that the seven big industrial nations would act decisively to revive the slumping dollar. 
 The dollar slipped further in New York, as the meeting took place, but in early Tuesday trading in Tokyo, it reversed course, climbing more than a half-yen. A1.
 Poor countries appealed to the economic powers to keep financing a World Bank agency that gives low-cost development loans. D4.
 
Low Point for RJR Nabisco
 RJR Nabisco's shares hit a 52-week low of $26.625 after the company reported disappointing earnings, which was only its latest bit of bad news. U.S. tobacco sales are falling, sales are weak abroad, legal liabilities loom, and Kohlberg, Kravis recently got rid of its 8 percent stake. D2.
 
Met Life in Merger Talks
 Metropolitan Life and New England Mutual are discussing a merger. Met Life, its insurance sales to the middle class sagging, is eager to expand among richer households, while for New England Mutual, the lure is Met Life's financial might. D6.
 
A New Microsoft Alliance
 Computer Associates and Microsoft teamed up to market a software package for corporate computer systems. D2.
 
After 6 Years, Profits at UAL
 UAL turned its first quarterly profit since 1989, a sure sign that the 1994 employee buyout put a big dent in United's costs. D8.
 
Newsprint on Their Minds
 Soaring newsprint prices -- up 40 percent recently -- will force more newspapers to close or scale back, publishers said at their New Orleans convention. D8.
 
The Power of Lobbyists
 Georgia-Pacific wanted the E.P.A. off its back, so lobbyists got custom-made language into a bill, due for a Senate panel vote today, on limiting Government regulators. A18.
 
Kmart Halves Its Dividend
 Kmart halved its dividend and said it expected a loss. Joseph Antonini, long the chief executive, defended the dividend, so the cut has been expected since he resigned. D2.
 
Rising Yen Takes Toll on Mazda
 Mazda will slash production twice as deeply as it had planned, a sign that the company -- which is more dependent than other Japanese car makers on exports to the United States -- is being battered by the yen's surge. D4.
 
Sitting Ducks Like Chrysler?
 Chrysler bondholders will have a weaker company owing them money if Kirk Kerkorian has his way. The obvious next question: What other companies, with loads of cash backing up outstanding debt, offer similar targets? Floyd Norris: Market Place. D10.

How to Succeed? Advertise!
 Chutzpah propels the hero from window-washer to board room in "How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying." So it should be no surprise that the musical's advertising strategy is similarly aggressive, with a prepaid phone card and ads aimed at Brooks Brothers customers. Advertising. D9.
 
Two Try Ticketless Shuttles
 In five seconds, some Delta passengers have paid for tickets on the Northeast corridor shuttle with the flick of an AT&T Smart Card. And US Air has started a new ticketless program on its shuttle. Business Travel. D8.
